('89', 0, 5, 11, 342) 2. LETTER TO JIVANJI D. DESAI SODEPUR, December 7, 1945
('89', 0, 6, 12, 398) JIVANJI, I got your proof copy of the pamphlet on constructive work yesterday.
('89', 0, 6, 13, 477) I wanted to use that copy here and did so.
('89', 0, 6, 14, 520) But I had already gone through the proof earlier.
('89', 0, 6, 15, 570) As there is no letter accom panying it, I don’t quite understand why you have sent it.
('89', 0, 6, 16, 657) You have given a heading to my preface but there is no heading on the page on which the pamphlet itself begins.
('89', 0, 6, 17, 769) I infer from this that final touches still remain to be given to the printing.
('89', 0, 6, 18, 848) I have of course asked Pyare lalji to write to you about this, but I think it is better to dictate this just now in the morning.
('89', 0, 6, 19, 977) I have the impression that I have already written to you about the cover.
('89', 0, 6, 20, 1051) My suggestion is that the eighteen headings which you have given in the pamphlet should be reproduced on the cover in their proper order, with the page number given against each.
('89', 0, 6, 21, 1230) This will help the reader and we shall be able to show what topics have been covered.
('89', 0, 6, 22, 1316) The topics can also be shown on the cover in the form of a circle.
('89', 0, 6, 23, 1383) We can have a drawing of the spinning wheel in the centre and the head ings can be printed round it like the planets round the sun.
('89', 0, 6, 24, 1515) There is one difficulty in this, of course.
('89', 0, 6, 25, 1559) How can communal unity be repre 
('89', 1, 0, 1, 1592) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 1, 1, 2, 1632) sented as a planet?
('89', 1, 1, 3, 1652) If it is so represented, my original conception would be vitiated, for the basic conception is that khadi is the chief handicraft and that the other industries take their place and revolve round khadi like planets round the sun.
('89', 1, 1, 4, 1881) If now we can find a place in this scheme for Adivasis, kisans, students and communal unity, then the conception will have been worked out.
('89', 1, 1, 5, 2021) It might be better, there fore, to give up the idea of the circle, or to form the circle only with khadi and cottage industries.
('89', 1, 1, 6, 2150) But we need not waste any time over this, for it is essential that the pamphlet should be published as soon as possible.
('89', 1, 1, 7, 2271) It is also necessary that the translations should be published simultaneously.
('89', 1, 1, 8, 2350) It would, also, be good if at the end a supplementary list of other books to be read with the pamphlet are given.
('89', 1, 1, 9, 2464) For example, Rajendra Babu’s book, Gulzarilal’s essay, etc.
('89', 1, 1, 10, 2524) You may drop this also, if you cannot recollect the names of the books imme diately.
('89', 1, 1, 11, 2609) Pyarelal will most probably send you a wire today saying, “Send another copy proof.” The idea behind this is that if I have to correct the proof, the time which would be taken by an ordinary letter may be saved, for the copy which I have passed on is not likely to come back to me now.
('89', 1, 2, 12, 2895) Blessings from BAPU
('89', 1, 3, 13, 2915) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 9960. Also C.W. 6934. Courtesy: Jivanji D. Desai

('89', 1, 5, 18, 3178) You can render great service if you calm down.

('89', 1, 5, 22, 3356) Greatness lies in becoming small and smallness in assuming greatness.
('89', 1, 5, 23, 3426) We should therfore only serve by becoming as small as dust particles.

('89', 2, 8, 13, 4141) 5. LETTER TO SHYAMAPRASAD MOOKHERJEE
('89', 2, 9, 14, 4178) SODEPUR, December 7, 1945
('89', 2, 10, 15, 4204) BHAI SHYAMAPRASADJI, Why did you fall ill?
('89', 2, 10, 16, 4247) Dr. Bidhan tells me that you do not take care of your health and that once you take up some work you never let go.
('89', 2, 10, 17, 4362) This is a virtue as well as a vice.
('89', 2, 10, 18, 4398) It is good when you persevere in it within a certain limit.
('89', 2, 10, 19, 4458) It is bad when you go beyond the limit.
('89', 2, 10, 20, 4498) I hope that, as reported in the newspapers, you will resume work after taking complete rest.
('89', 2, 11, 21, 4591) Yours, M. K. GANDHI SHYAMAPRASAD MOOKERJEE CALCUTTA

('89', 4, 4, 6, 6141) 9. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS December 7, 1945
('89', 4, 5, 7, 6184) Asked whether he would like to say anything about the Congress Working Committee meeting 1, Gandhiji replied.
('89', 4, 5, 8, 6294) No, I am tired.
('89', 4, 6, 9, 6310) In reply to another query Gandhiji remarked : What can I give you?
('89', 4, 6, 10, 6377) The Maulana is here.
('89', 4, 6, 11, 6398) You can take what ever you like from him.
('89', 4, 6, 12, 6440) They have called me here, but they have not given me any food to eat, or water to drink.
('89', 4, 6, 13, 6529) And after my work has been finished they are sending me back to my place.Your food is being cooked at Maulana’s hands and he will give it to you when it is ready.
('89', 4, 7, 14, 6692) While waiting for the car Gandhiji turned to Maulana Azad and remarked : Maulana Saheb, these press reporters and photographers are having a good time and detaining our car.
('89', 4, 8, 15, 6866) A hearty laughter followed.
('89', 4, 8, 16, 6894) A Press correspondent drew Gandhiji’s attention to the announcement from New Delhi that the Viceroy had agreed to see Mahatma Gandhi.
('89', 4, 8, 17, 7028) The correspondent inquired whether it suggested that Gandhiji had sought the interview.
('89', 4, 9, 18, 7116) Gandhiji replied the news had appeared in the newspapers and he declined to make any further comment.
('89', 4, 9, 19, 7218) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 8 12 1945
('89', 4, 10, 20, 7250) 1 Held at the residence of Abul Kalam Azad, the Congress President.
('89', 4, 10, 21, 7318) According to the source “Gandhiji spoke for over an hour and touched upon the political situation, the Indian National Army, changes in the Congress constitution, Congress prospects in the Central and Provincial elections and other matters.
('89', 4, 10, 22, 7559) He also reported on his talks with R. G. Casey.”
('89', 5, 0, 1, 7608) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 5, 1, 2, 7648) 10. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SODEPUR, December 7, 1945
('89', 5, 2, 3, 7703) Gandhiji said that he noticed that the people became quiet only after he arrived at the place.
('89', 5, 2, 4, 7798) That was not ideal.
('89', 5, 2, 5, 7818) The place where a prayer was conducted, he said, should be considered as a temple and only in prayerful mind should they present themselves there.
('89', 5, 2, 6, 7965) They should come silently and maintain calm and should leave the place in the same mood.
('89', 5, 3, 7, 8054) If, however, those who joined in the prayer would remain quiet and peaceful he would be only too glad to see the whole of Calcutta assembled there.
('89', 5, 4, 8, 8202) Proceeding, Gandhiji said that there were incorporated in the service Bengali songs as the majority of those present were Bengalees; but for the benefit of others he wished to get a booklet including all songs and other prayers printed in both Devanagari and Urdu scripts.
('89', 5, 4, 9, 8475) This proposed booklet which might be priced two pice would be of permanent benefit to the readers who could then be acquainted with the texts whenever they so wished.
('89', 5, 4, 10, 8642) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 9 12 1945

('89', 6, 6, 8, 9776) 13. LETTER TO R. G. CASEY
('89', 6, 7, 9, 9802) Immediate KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR, December 8, 1945
('89', 6, 8, 10, 9857) DEAR FRIEND, I write this with the greatest hesitation.
('89', 6, 8, 11, 9913) The more I see and hear, the greater is the grief over the happenings in Bengal.
('89', 6, 8, 12, 9994) Here is a sam ple demanding immediate attention.
('89', 6, 8, 13, 10043) Satish Babu brings me the story that potato growers cannot get seed potatoes and the planting season will be over in a week’s time.
('89', 6, 8, 14, 10175) Seed potatoes are there in the market under Government control.
('89', 6, 8, 15, 10239) But the grower cannot get them.
('89', 6, 8, 16, 10271) There is evidently something radically wrong if the news brought by Satish Babu is true.
('89', 6, 8, 17, 10360) I wonder if you can do anything.
('89', 6, 8, 18, 10393) You were telling me about the clever Mr. Dey whose services you have enlisted for such matters.
('89', 6, 8, 19, 10489) Can you make him over to me or some other officer who can attend to this immediate affair?
('89', 6, 8, 20, 10580) I am having this letter delivered at once.
('89', 6, 8, 21, 10623) The question is small
('89', 6, 9, 22, 10645) 1 The addressee had asked Gandhiji to send directly to the Home Member the details about Vidyarthi and Lohia.
('89', 6, 9, 23, 10755) 2 A telegram was however sent on December 9.Vide also “Letter to Sir Even M. Jenkins”, 25 11 1945
('89', 7, 0, 1, 10853) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 7, 1, 2, 10893) enough on the large Bengal canvas but is all in all to the poor growers whose livelihood is at stake.
('89', 7, 2, 3, 10995) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('89', 7, 3, 4, 11025) From a photostat: G.N. 813; also Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, p.
('89', 7, 4, 5, 11117) 14. LETTER TO R. G. CASEY
('89', 7, 5, 6, 11143) KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR, December 8, 1945
('89', 7, 6, 7, 11188) DEAR FRIEND, I have just finished reading your broadcast to be delivered today.
('89', 7, 6, 8, 11268) It makes interesting and informative reading.
('89', 7, 6, 9, 11314) If the waters of the rivers can be captured and utilized by the people of Bengal, instead of being wasted in the Bay, it would be a great gain.
('89', 7, 6, 10, 11458) But it is a long term proposition.
('89', 7, 6, 11, 11493) The millions, meanwhile, must be taught to utilize every minute of the working hours for their own benefit.
('89', 7, 6, 12, 11601) If they learn this art they will make good use of the captured waters.
('89', 7, 6, 13, 11672) You have well said :
('89', 7, 7, 14, 11693) The tens of millions of farmers of Bengal are idle more than half the time.
('89', 7, 7, 15, 11769) They constitute the biggest problem of unemployment in the world and the biggest waste of potential human effort.
('89', 7, 7, 16, 11883) I have provided you with a complete answer which can be worked out today with a very little outlay on the part of the Govern ment.
('89', 7, 7, 17, 12014) Regard human labour more even than money and you have an untapped and inexhaustible source of income which ever increases with use.
('89', 7, 7, 18, 12146) If I had been your adviser, before the speech was printed I would have suggested the insertion immediately after, “Let us exa mine the problem”, of a paragraph or two, showing the way of imme diate utilization of human effort.
('89', 7, 7, 19, 12373) You could then have followed it up with your entrancing scheme as a long range proposition.
('89', 7, 7, 20, 12465) Is your peroration right?
('89', 7, 7, 21, 12491) You say :
('89', 7, 8, 22, 12501) The answer to my mind lies not in our politics, our religion or our individual ambition, but in the abiding factors of our environment, i.e., the land and water of Bengal.
('89', 7, 9, 23, 12673) 1 In Gandhi’s Emissary.
('89', 7, 9, 24, 12697) Sudhir Ghosh writes that the Government, using emergency powers, seized whatever stocks there were with the profiteers and 250 mounds were distributed among the growers that same day.
('89', 8, 0, 1, 12881) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 9
('89', 8, 1, 2, 12927) This is a gross error or thought and consequent action, handed down from generation to generation by the British official element.
('89', 8, 1, 3, 13058) Your gigantic project will come to nothing until the whole mass of the people of Bengal is interested in the Government of the province.
('89', 8, 1, 4, 13195) Therefore, religion and even individual ambition are intermixed.
('89', 8, 1, 5, 13260) They are as much abiding factors of our environment as the land and water of Bengal, and they are equally shifting.
('89', 8, 1, 6, 13376) You asked me for my reaction to your thoughtful speech and I have given it as it has come to me.
('89', 8, 1, 7, 13473) Very many thanks for your prompt action 1 on my letter of this morning on seed potatoes.
('89', 8, 2, 8, 13562) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('89', 8, 3, 9, 13592) From a photostat: G.N. 812; also Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, pp.
('89', 8, 4, 10, 13685) 15. LETTER TO THE AGA KHAN CAMP: KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR (NR.
('89', 8, 4, 11, 13750) CALCUTTA) December 8, 1945
('89', 8, 5, 12, 13777) DEAR FRIEND, I had your long wire to which I have replied 2 as follows : Of course, I shall be glad to receive your suggestions.
('89', 8, 5, 13, 13906) It does not matter to me in the least that in this matter you will be representing nobody but yourself.
('89', 8, 5, 14, 14010) The only question is how we shall meet, when and where.
('89', 8, 5, 15, 14066) I have a fixed programme for Bengal, Assam and Madras, which is calculated to take me up to almost the middle of February before I return to Sevagram.
('89', 8, 5, 16, 14217) If, therefore, I know your movements about February, I shall try to see what I can do.
('89', 8, 5, 17, 14304) Maulana Saheb has interrupted his rest for the sake of the Working Committee.
('89', 8, 5, 18, 14382) He is none too well, but I have no doubt he will be in communication with you himself.
('89', 8, 6, 19, 14469) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI H. H. THE AGA KHAN BOMBAY From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('89', 10, 6, 12, 16102) I am certainly going to … 1 Tara.

('89', 10, 6, 14, 16171) The work which she is doing now will not clash with the work of K. G. N. M. Trust.

('89', 10, 6, 16, 16300) 2 If she would rather not stay at the Mahila Ashram, she can live in Akola and there can be no hitch even if she has to be paid a salary.

('89', 10, 6, 19, 16482) I strongly feel that you two should go and stay at Bombay for a time.

('89', 10, 6, 21, 16627) Still it made a story.
('89', 10, 6, 22, 16650) People might be escaping hun dreds of such accidents daily.
('89', 10, 6, 23, 16710) It the papers were to take note of them we would have to stop travelling by cars, etc.

('89', 11, 1, 2, 17108) 20. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH SODEPUR, December 8, 1945
('89', 11, 2, 3, 17167) NARAHARI, I have your letter.
('89', 11, 2, 4, 17197) I think the kind of questions asked by Vishnudatta’s friend ought not to be encouraged.
('89', 11, 2, 5, 17285) Had I been conducting Harijan I might occasionally answer such questions.

('89', 14, 1, 2, 20868) 28. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SODEPUR, December 8, 1945
('89', 14, 2, 3, 20923) Congratulating the congregation on its maintaining an ideal condition for proceeding with the prayer straight away as soon as he reached the place, Gandhiji explained the significance and gradual development of the system of mass prayer at Sodepur Ashram.
('89', 14, 3, 4, 21179) In 1936 about a dozen Japanese monks paid him a visit when he was staying at Maganwadi, Wardha.
('89', 14, 3, 5, 21275) The leading monk suggested to him that he intended to send one or two of his disciples to the Ashram, a proposal which he approved.
('89', 14, 3, 6, 21407) First came one and later on another.
('89', 14, 3, 7, 21444) Of the two, one was staying with him till the war with Japan broke out and as a result he was taken into custody.
('89', 14, 3, 8, 21558) This Buddhist monk used to do all the tasks he was given very punctually and methodically.
('89', 14, 3, 9, 21649) In between his work he used to spend the time at his disposal in singing religious songs in the Japanese language all the time beating a little drum.
('89', 14, 3, 10, 21799) This he did while taking his rounds.
('89', 14, 3, 11, 21836) This was a Buddhist religious song in praise of the Infinite.
('89', 14, 3, 12, 21898) Gandhiji said that he incor porated the song in his prayer.
('89', 14, 3, 13, 21958) This was the first item of the prayer.
('89', 14, 4, 14, 21997) The second item of the prayer was a Sanskrit sloka and was, according to him, universal in its appeal.
('89', 14, 4, 15, 22100) This was an invocation to Mother Earth, sustainer of man.
('89', 14, 4, 16, 22158) If there was any objection to it on any score he would plead that he was helpless.
('89', 14, 4, 17, 22241) To him all faiths were welcome.
('89', 14, 4, 18, 22273) He believed in all faiths but he saw no reason to give up his own faith.
('89', 14, 4, 19, 22346) Possibly, said Gandhiji, this Sanskrit sloka was symbolic, but, according to him, many noble thoughts and ideas were couched in symbolic language.
('89', 14, 5, 20, 22493) Thirdly, there was the prayer quoted from the Koran.
('89', 14, 5, 21, 22546) It was incorporated at the instance of daughter 1 of Abbas Tyabji, the well known Congress leader.
('89', 14, 5, 22, 22645) She possessed a gifted voice.
('89', 14, 5, 23, 22675) When on a visit to the Ashram she expressed the desire to propagate the teachings of the Koran to the Ashramites, he readily agreed.
('89', 14, 5, 24, 22808) She suggested a verse from the Koran for inclusion in the prayer and it was done.
('89', 14, 6, 25, 22890) The fourth item of the prayer was taken from the Zend Avesta written in the Pahlavi language.
('89', 14, 6, 26, 22984) When he was fasting in the Aga Khan’s Palace, Dr. Gilder was there as were also Dr. Bidhan Roy and some other medical men.
('89', 14, 6, 27, 23107) Dr. Gilder was a Parsi and from him the verse from the Zend Avesta was taken and included.
('89', 14, 7, 28, 23198) So far as bhajan songs were concerned, said Gandhiji, there was no hard and fast rule.
('89', 14, 7, 29, 23285) It all depended upon the time and place of the prayer.
('89', 14, 7, 30, 23340) As the prayer was for the moment being held in Bengal and Bengalees in larger numbers were present, Bengali songs had to be included in the prayer daily.
('89', 14, 8, 31, 23494) It was Gandhiji’s desire to get all the prayers included in a booklet with their meanings given in Hindustani.
('89', 14, 8, 32, 23605) He wished it to be printed both in Devanagari and
('89', 14, 9, 33, 23655) 1 Raihana Tyabji
('89', 15, 0, 1, 23672) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 15, 1, 2, 23713) Urdu scripts and, if possible, in Bengali too.
('89', 15, 2, 3, 23760) He asked the assembled people to follow the prayer in a proper spirit and to live up to the lofty ideals it inculcated.
('89', 15, 2, 4, 23880) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 9 12 1945

('89', 22, 5, 9, 33399) 44. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SODEPUR, December 10, 1945 When we are making a supreme effort for the realization of our goal let nobody have any opportunity of pointing it against us that we are not disciplined and therefore not fit for swaraj.
('89', 22, 5, 10, 33643) Either today or tomorrow the power must come to our hands.
('89', 22, 5, 11, 33702) But how are we going to exercise that power unless we are disciplined ?
('89', 22, 6, 12, 33774) The British Government, he reminded the people, was not the last hurdle to be got over.
('89', 22, 6, 13, 33862) If the people were not disciplined then even if power came to their hands they would not be able to retain it and someone else would be there to snatch it away from their hands.
('89', 22, 7, 14, 34040) It was only wild animals which were not disciplined and took recourse to unreasonable and meaningless climbing.
('89', 22, 7, 15, 34152) But if men also took recourse to such tactics how could drivers and guards of trains manage their affairs.
('89', 22, 7, 16, 34259) 1 It was also often found that small boats which had only limited capacity often gave way and sank because of overcrowding.
('89', 22, 7, 17, 34383) They were crores and perhaps for that reason they did not notice the loss they sustained in such catastrophes.
('89', 22, 7, 18, 34494) If they could not board a train they should just wait for the next to travel instead of overcrowding the first and thus make it impossible for the driver and the guard to run it.
('89', 22, 8, 19, 34673) 1 The reference is to the conduct of passengers who boarded engines and guards’ compartments on the previous day to travel to and from Sodepur.
('89', 23, 0, 1, 34817) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 23, 1, 2, 34858) Proceeding, Gandhiji said that they must learn discipline.
('89', 23, 1, 3, 34917) There were two ways of learning it.
('89', 23, 1, 4, 34953) The soldiers learnt it by having drill exercises.
('89', 23, 1, 5, 35003) But there was the prayer to teach them the other way.
('89', 23, 1, 6, 35057) Prayer not only secures for them their salvation for the next world but also in this world.
('89', 23, 1, 7, 35149) If they failed to secure their salvation in this world, could there be any possibility of securing the salvation for the next?
('89', 23, 1, 8, 35276) In the circumstances, concluded Gandhiji, they should conduct themselves as thinking men.
('89', 23, 1, 9, 35366) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 11 12 1945
('89', 23, 2, 10, 35399) 45. SPEECH AT CALCUTTA 1
('89', 23, 3, 11, 35424) December 10, 1945
('89', 23, 4, 12, 35442) Addressing the gathering outside Government House, Gandhiji said that when he entered Government House in the evening he found a crowd of people around his car.
('89', 23, 4, 13, 35603) Hence he had come this time walking to them.
('89', 23, 5, 14, 35648) He asked them to be calm and peaceful.
('89', 23, 5, 15, 35687) He was an old man and could not bear the strain of demonstrations.
('89', 23, 5, 16, 35754) If they did not allow him to go by car, he would have to walk on foot to Sodepur.
('89', 23, 6, 17, 35836) Gandhiji added that he had come there to serve them and the country.
('89', 23, 6, 18, 35905) He urged on them the need for discipline.
('89', 23, 6, 19, 35947) India had attained a great position in the past because of her great message of shanti.
('89', 23, 6, 20, 36035) They could attain freedom only by peace and discipline.
('89', 23, 7, 21, 36091) Referring to the prayer meeting at Sodepur Ashram, Gandhiji said that thousands and thousands of people came there to join the prayer, but perfect silence was maintained.
('89', 23, 8, 22, 36262) Gandhiji then asked the gathering whether they would allow him to go by car.
('89', 23, 8, 23, 36339) The crowd respectfully replied in the affirmative and Gandhiji got into his car while a corridor was made for him to pass through.
('89', 23, 8, 24, 36470) Sitting with his hands folded in salutation, Gandhiji then moved out in the car to his Ashram at Sodepur.
('89', 23, 8, 25, 36576) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 11 12 1945

('89', 24, 1, 2, 36797) 46. CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION 1
('89', 24, 2, 3, 36841) [On or before December 11, 1945] 2
('89', 24, 3, 4, 36876) After the arrest of the principal Congressmen in the August of 1942, the unguided masses took the reins in their own hands and acted almost spontaneously.
('89', 24, 3, 5, 37031) If many acts of herosim and sacrifice are to their credit, there were acts done which could not be included in non violence.
('89', 24, 3, 6, 37156) It is, therefore, necessary for the Wor king Committee to affirm, for the guidance of all concerned, that the policy of non violence adopted in 1920 by the Congress continues unabated, and that such non violence does not include burning of public property, cutting of telegraph wires, derailing of trains and intimidation.
('89', 24, 3, 7, 37479) The Working Committee is of opinion that the policy of non violence as detailed in the Congress resolution of 1920, since expan ded and explained from time to time, and action in accordance with it, has raised India to a height never attained before.
('89', 24, 3, 8, 37730) The Working Committee is further of opinion that the construc tive activities of the Congress, beginning with the spinning wheel and khadi as the centre, are emblematic of the policy of non violence and that every other Congress activity including what is known as the parliamentary programme, is subservient to and desi gned to promote the constructive activities as explained by Mahatma Gandhi.
('89', 24, 3, 9, 38127) The Working Committee is of opinion that civil disobedience, mass or any other, meant for the attainment of freedom, is inconcei vable without the adoption of the constructive programme on the widest scale possible by the masses of India.
('89', 24, 3, 10, 38366) The Hindu, 12 12 1945
('89', 24, 4, 11, 38388) 1 The resolution, drafted by Gandhiji, was passed by the Congress Working Committee on December 11, the concluding day of its five day session held in Calcutta.

('89', 25, 1, 2, 38590) 47. LETTER TO R. G. CASEY
('89', 25, 2, 3, 38616) KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR, December 12, 1945
('89', 25, 3, 4, 38662) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter of 10th instant, for which I thank you.
('89', 25, 3, 5, 38734) I have not discounted 1 your irrigation scheme.
('89', 25, 3, 6, 38782) I have only suggested an addition to it so as to bring almost immediate individual relief to the crores of villagers by occupying their admitted leisure hours.
('89', 25, 3, 7, 38942) In your written note you seem to be in entire accord with my proposition.
('89', 25, 3, 8, 39016) Where then is the difficulty in the Government of Bengal sponsoring the scheme and at once creating a hopeful situation so far as the shortage of cloth is concerned?
('89', 25, 3, 9, 39182) I have never suggested that attainment of happiness is possible without the control of physical surroundings.
('89', 25, 3, 10, 39292) But I have no desire to enter into any argument.
('89', 25, 3, 11, 39341) If you have immediate regard for home spinning and weaving and other village crafts, I have suggested a way out.
('89', 25, 3, 12, 39454) That each cultivator should grow his own cotton is not a sine qua non of my scheme and certainly no cultivator should be compelled or even advised to grow cotton to the detriment of any staple crop.
('89', 25, 3, 13, 39653) The question is one of utilizing waste labour, as under your scheme it is one of utilizing waste water.
('89', 25, 3, 14, 39757) If you favour the idea as practical and capable of immediate application, I could furnish you with a detailed scheme which, as I have told you, can be worked with the help of the various khadi organizations controlled by the All India Spinners’ Association.
('89', 25, 4, 15, 40015) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('89', 25, 5, 16, 40045) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, p.
('89', 25, 6, 17, 40104) 1Vide “Letter to R. G. Casey”, 8 12 1945

('89', 27, 9, 16, 42526) 52. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SODEPUR, December 12, 1945
('89', 27, 10, 17, 42582) Gandhiji said that an individual, even if a snake might be lying on his way, would pass by it, assuming that it was not a snake but a piece of rope.
('89', 27, 10, 18, 42731) He would not be frightened then.
('89', 27, 10, 19, 42764) But if his companion then drew his attention to the fact that it was not a piece of rope but a living snake that he passed by, he would at once be frightened.
('89', 27, 10, 20, 42923) Was it not curious, asked Gandhiji, that although the same conditions prevailed, at one time the individual had no trace of fright in him and at another he would be awfully frightened and would thank God for his miraculous escape.
('89', 27, 11, 21, 43154) Drawing the moral from the illustration, Gandhiji concluded that the source of

('89', 28, 1, 2, 43513) happiness and woe, therefore, did not lie elsewhere but in one’s own mind.

('89', 28, 1, 4, 43811) 1 This was possible only on the part of that individual who was self controlled.
('89', 28, 1, 5, 43892) To a self controlled man life becomes simple and salvation easy.

('89', 28, 4, 9, 44047) No knowledge conducive to the real good of the world could be attained without purification of heart, said Mahatma Gandhi.
('89', 28, 4, 10, 44170) Those who attended these meetings should derive some benefits from them; otherwise, it would be useless for them to attend prayer meetings.
('89', 28, 4, 11, 44310) They must concentrate their minds and only then would they realize the existence of God in their hearts.
('89', 28, 4, 12, 44415) But if they kept quiet because he (Gandhiji) had asked them to do so, they would derive no benefit from the prayer.
('89', 28, 4, 13, 44531) By concentration, their hearts would be purified and their inner knowledge would grow.
('89', 28, 4, 14, 44618) Everybody should think that they were going to the prayer metting for self purification.
('89', 28, 4, 15, 44707) Only then would their intellectual progress be uninterrupted and they would get real peace by controlling their passions.

('89', 33, 6, 8, 50917) 61. LETTER TO G. E. B. ABELL
('89', 33, 7, 9, 50946) CAMP: KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR (NEAR CALCUTTA), December 15, 1945
('89', 33, 8, 10, 51014) DEAR FRIEND, A correspondent writes from the United Provinces to the effect that manufacture of gur 1 is prohibited there.
('89', 33, 8, 11, 51137) Gur making is a village industry.
('89', 33, 8, 12, 51171) It is manufactured on their fields by cane growers from juice extracted by means of village kolhus 2 and boiled in village pans.
('89', 33, 8, 13, 51300) I, therefore, thought that my correspondent must be mistaken and asked him to send me a copy of the order on which his obser vations were made.
('89', 33, 8, 14, 51444) He has sent me a copy of the enclosed startling order.
('89', 33, 8, 15, 51499) 3 Cane growers have since passed resolutions protesting against the order and threatened to disobey it if it was not withdrawn.
('89', 33, 8, 16, 51627) As a result the authorities relaxed the order.
('89', 33, 8, 17, 51674) A copy of the relaxation order is also herewith enclosed.
('89', 33, 8, 18, 51732) I doubt not that you realize what this means to the poor people.
('89', 33, 8, 19, 51797) The original order could not have been issued for the protection of sugar mills but must have been meant to secure judicious use and distribution of sugar as gur or refined.
('89', 33, 8, 20, 51971) If so, it defeats the purpose.
('89', 33, 8, 21, 52002) The modified order, though less bad than the first, does not really serve the purpose, considered in the light of the villagers.
('89', 33, 8, 22, 52131) There should be no licence for gur made in village.
('89', 33, 8, 23, 52183) As this is not a mere provincial matter but applies to all India

('89', 34, 6, 8, 52931) DEAR NARAYANASWAMI, I am afraid that, owing to my movements after leaving Poona, I have not been able to be up to date with my correspondence.

('89', 36, 1, 2, 55654) 65. LETTER TO HARJIVAN KOTAK
('89', 36, 2, 3, 55683) KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR, December 15, 1945
('89', 36, 3, 4, 55729) HARJIVAN, I got your letter of the 10th yesterday.
('89', 36, 3, 5, 55780) You seem to be very impatient.
('89', 36, 3, 6, 55811) You ask my blessings by wire.
('89', 36, 3, 7, 55841) We are after all poor people and trustees of those much poorer than we.
('89', 36, 3, 8, 55913) And how can we so much as wish for blessings?
('89', 36, 3, 9, 55959) Even if we have such a desire, how can we have it met telegraphically?
('89', 36, 3, 10, 56030) So thinking I refrained from sending a wire.
('89', 36, 3, 11, 56075) Why should you need any blessings?
('89', 36, 3, 12, 56110) Here is the secret of blessings.
('89', 36, 3, 13, 56143) When we are engaged in a work which is worthy of blessings, then the work itself is a blessing; it does not wait for blessings from others.
('89', 36, 3, 14, 56283) Seeking blessings from other people is, there fore, meaningless; it is nothing but self deception.
('89', 36, 3, 15, 56382) It no doubt has a meaning in that bless ings act as a stimulant from which a weak person derives momentary encouragement.
('89', 36, 3, 16, 56504) But this kind of encouragement is not of much help.
('89', 36, 3, 17, 56556) If you understand this and still really need my blessings, you certainly have them for your work of producing the tools necessary for making khadi provided it is done intelligently.
('89', 36, 3, 18, 56738) When I say intelligently I mean that we should not manufacture spinning wheels, winding frames, taklis, etc., just to sell; we should make only as many as are needed and see that they are so perfect that no one may find fault with them.
('89', 36, 3, 19, 56975) Our aim should be—and is—that all the things are produced locally.
('89', 36, 3, 20, 57042) Only then will the villages prosper.
('89', 36, 3, 21, 57079) What I am now saying is covered by the new line of thought on khadi that I am propounding.
('89', 36, 3, 22, 57170) Whatever I have not elaborated may be deduced from the aforesaid.
('89', 36, 3, 23, 57236) Yesterday Sardar was here.
('89', 36, 3, 24, 57263) He wanted to know why he was not informed about your leaving the khadi shop.
('89', 36, 3, 25, 57340) I could not give him a satisfactory answer.
('89', 36, 3, 26, 57384) I take it that you must have gone through all the formalities since you are so alert.
('89', 36, 3, 27, 57470) However, if you have anything to say in this regard, write to Sharda.
('89', 36, 3, 28, 57540) I see from your letter that Sharda is with you.
('89', 36, 3, 29, 57588) Is she doing anything ?
('89', 36, 4, 30, 57612) Blessings from BAPU HARJIVAN KOTAK

('89', 43, 6, 10, 66569) 77. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 43, 7, 11, 66598) SODEPUR, December 16, 1945
('89', 43, 8, 12, 66625) The tendency of learning English rather than one’s own language was deprecated by Mahatma Gandhi.
('89', 43, 8, 13, 66723) “If we could stop this tendency we would be free from one of our slaveries,” said Mahatma Gandhi, adding that he could not express how this tendency of some people talking and writing in English damaged them and the country.
('89', 43, 8, 14, 66948) But in England, whenever a good book was published anywhere in the world, within a few days it would be translated and would reach the hands of the English speaking public.
('89', 43, 8, 15, 67121) Mahatma Gandhi asked : Should we not do the same thing in India?
('89', 43, 8, 16, 67186) Although it would take time for all people to understand the rashtrabhasha, there were languages of the locality and any good book could be translated and presented to the public in their mother tongue.
('89', 43, 9, 17, 67389) The Hindu, 18 12 1945
('89', 43, 10, 18, 67411) 78. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('89', 43, 11, 19, 67438) December 17, 1945 I see that I have overstayed my time in Calcutta.
('89', 43, 11, 20, 67506) I found I had more work in Calcutta than I had expected.
('89', 43, 11, 21, 67563) And then events com pelled me to work more strenuously than I had counted upon.
('89', 43, 11, 22, 67643) The result is that, much to my and my fellow workers’ disappoint ment, I have been compelled to cut off the places I had originally conceived and tentatively discussed with friends who were arranging
('89', 44, 0, 1, 67843) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 45
('89', 44, 1, 2, 67890) the tour.
('89', 44, 1, 3, 67900) But let no one think that the curtailment will affect my study of the Bengal situation.

('89', 50, 8, 13, 75962) CAMP: KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR (NEAR CALCUTTA), December 18, 1945
('89', 50, 9, 14, 76030) DEAR MR. CROSS, I have very carefully read your letter of the 15th and the note you left with me when we last met.
('89', 50, 9, 15, 76145) Dr. Sushila Nayyar added that after best thought you had come to the conclusion that it would not be proper to worry me in the matter, at least for the time being.
('89', 50, 9, 16, 76309) If this last news is accurate, I need not say anything more.
('89', 50, 9, 17, 76370) However, I want to say that in popular estimation anything which the Government either directly or indirectly supports is considered to be anti Independence and there is, at some stage or other, a clash between the people and the power that keeps the former from their cherished goal.
('89', 50, 9, 18, 76655) This has happened often enough within my own experience.
('89', 50, 9, 19, 76712) Therefore, ‘non 
('89', 50, 10, 20, 76729) 1Vide “Letter to Sir Evan M. Jenkins”, 25 12 1945 2Acknowledging this in his letter dated December 20, the addressee said that the statement had been forwarded to the Home Member.
('89', 51, 0, 1, 76909) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 51, 1, 2, 76950) political’ has come to mean non Indian, i.e., anti Independence.
('89', 51, 1, 3, 77015) Hence the unpopularity of movements connected with the Govern ment.
('89', 51, 1, 4, 77083) This is the crux.
('89', 51, 1, 5, 77101) Association with war has a meaning with me but not with the average man.
('89', 51, 1, 6, 77174) Everything British is certainly not bad if it is not synonymous with the Government; as C.F. Andrews, from top to toe British, was not bad.
('89', 51, 1, 7, 77314) There are many organizations under Democracy which are not themselves run democratically but are not anti democratic.
('89', 51, 1, 8, 77432) Thus, a bank or a hospital would require experts to run it even though they may be run by democrats in the interest of democracy.
('89', 51, 2, 9, 77562) Yours sincerely, M. K. G. G. L. CROSS, ESQ.

('89', 57, 5, 7, 84454) SODEPUR, ON THE TRAIN TO SANTINIKETAN, December 18, 1945
('89', 57, 6, 8, 84511) KRISHNACHANDRA, I have received all your letters.
('89', 57, 6, 9, 84561) The letter written on rough paper is also lying with me.
('89', 57, 6, 10, 84618) Today I shall answer whatever I possible can.
('89', 57, 6, 11, 84664) I am doing quite a bit of work here.
('89', 57, 6, 12, 84701) As for hand carding I believe that this makes the cotton very clean.
('89', 57, 6, 13, 84770) It is not so well cleaned either by machine or by any other means.
('89', 57, 6, 14, 84837) By all these other means the fibre does become somewhat weak.
('89', 57, 6, 15, 84899) In my view land carding is a grand process.
('89', 57, 6, 16, 84943) Combing should be given a place in it.
('89', 57, 6, 17, 84982) Hand carding teaches us cleanliness and patience.
('89', 57, 6, 18, 85032) Adding the time spent in hand carding [to that of the whole process] the speed of spinning the yarn seems slow.
('89', 57, 6, 19, 85144) But that does not matter.
('89', 57, 6, 20, 85170) Hand carding of course cannot provide a livelihood.
('89', 57, 6, 21, 85222) But it has a very significant part in self reliance.
('89', 57, 6, 22, 85275) As the process of hand carding has not been very much in vogue, we have not had a real estimate of its power.
('89', 57, 6, 23, 85385) We shall have an idea of its power if large numbers of people take to hand carding.
('89', 57, 6, 24, 85469) Show this letter to Vinoba also Hand carding is his discovery.
('89', 57, 6, 25, 85532) He has also had a wide experience.
('89', 57, 6, 26, 85567) I would like to know if I am mistaken in this.
('89', 57, 6, 27, 85614) Because the sadhu had gone away, it was quite proper that he was asked to leave the Ashram.
('89', 57, 6, 28, 85706) In my view this does not mean that it was quite wrong to have kept him in the Ashram.
('89', 57, 6, 29, 85792) This will enable you to understand my argument.
('89', 57, 6, 30, 85840) I have no doubt that there should be separate classes for women.
('89', 57, 6, 31, 85905) As for Om Prakash I shall be content with whatever you think right.
('89', 57, 6, 32, 85973) It would not be proper for me to write anything about this.

('89', 58, 1, 6, 86418) The same applies to me.

('89', 59, 2, 3, 88363) SANTINIKETAN, December 18, 1945 Gurudev (Rabindranath Tagore) was like a great bird, wide and swift of wings, under which he gave protection to many.
('89', 59, 3, 4, 88513) Under the warmth of his wings Santiniketan has been nurtured to its present size.
('89', 59, 3, 5, 88595) Bengal is full of his songs.
('89', 59, 3, 6, 88624) He has glorified the name of India throughout the world not by his songs only but also by his pen and brush.
('89', 59, 3, 7, 88733) We all miss the warmth of his protecting wings.
('89', 59, 3, 8, 88781) But we must not grieve.
('89', 59, 3, 9, 88805) The remedy lies in our own hands.
('89', 59, 3, 10, 88839) True monuments to the great are not statues of marble, bronze or gold.
('89', 59, 3, 11, 88910) The best monument is to adorn and enlarge their legacy.
('89', 59, 3, 12, 88966) A son who buries underground his father’s legacy or wastes it will be adjudged unworthy of his inheritance.
('89', 59, 3, 13, 89074) Whilst on Rathi Babu 2 and his colleagues must primarily rest the sacred duty of making Santiniketan truely worthy of Gurudev’s great tradition, that duty rests no less upon all those who, though they may not be directly connected with Santiniketan, received the warmth of Gurudev’s wings.
('89', 59, 3, 14, 89364) All mortals must quit this world one day.
('89', 59, 3, 15, 89406) Gurudev has gone, having achieved all that a human being can expect to in life.
('89', 59, 3, 16, 89486) His soul now rests in peace.
('89', 59, 3, 17, 89515) It is for you now, the workers and inmates of Santiniketan—as indeed all those who are imbued with Gurudev’s spirit—collectively to represent his ideal.
('89', 59, 3, 18, 89668) Santiniketan has been the abode of peace to me and since my family was given shelter on arrival from South Africa it is a pilgrimage to me and whenever I got the opportunity I came here to seek peace and tranquility.
('89', 59, 3, 19, 89885) It is indeed sad that we no longer have his protective wings on us.
('89', 59, 3, 20, 89953) But I find solace in the fact taht he has left own memorial in the form of many gifts that he has bequeathed to the nation.
('89', 59, 3, 21, 90077) It is our duty to receive those gifts with humility and gratitude and to see that they go on increasing.
('89', 59, 3, 22, 90182) If we can continue his work and prove ourselves true to the task he has left us, I do not see why we should mourn his passing away.
('89', 59, 3, 23, 90314) I feel in my heart that his soul is

('89', 61, 6, 19, 92969) That is why we close our eyes during prayers.

('89', 61, 7, 22, 93304) I would like to see the students of this Ashram invested with that hallmark of peace and fellowship.
('89', 61, 7, 23, 93405) I would like to see, moreover, how alert they are to receive the world and how unperturbed and calm they are in the face of difficulties.

('89', 64, 1, 2, 97238) 110. DISCUSSION WITH HEADS OF DEPARTMENT, SANTINIKETAN 1
('89', 64, 2, 3, 97295) December 19, 1945
('89', 64, 3, 4, 97313) Regard me as a blank slate.
('89', 64, 3, 5, 97341) So far I have had only hearsay and hearsay has very little place in my life.
('89', 64, 3, 6, 97418) Solid facts are what I want.
('89', 64, 3, 7, 97447) Without a full knowledge of facts I shall be able to do little to help you.
('89', 64, 3, 8, 97523) It is not that you have nothing to say.
('89', 64, 3, 9, 97563) That would mean that the institution is perfect.
('89', 64, 3, 10, 97612) But nothing in this world is perfect.
('89', 64, 3, 11, 97650) Speak to me freely about the shortcomings.
('89', 64, 3, 12, 97693) Good things speak for themselves, not the bad things, at any rate, not to me.
('89', 64, 3, 13, 97771) I have followed every word of what you have said with the keenest interest and I have learned a lot from it.
('89', 64, 3, 14, 97880) I do not propose to make detailed observations on what has been said or to give expression to all that is welling up in me just now but shall confine myself to one or two remarks of a general character.
('89', 64, 3, 15, 98083) As I listened while Nanda Babu 2 and Kshiti mohan Babu were speaking, I said to myself: ‘Here is a real difficulty; but it is a diffi culty of our own making.’ If a person conducts a big department he is expected to transmit what he stands for to someone who can be termed as his successor.
('89', 64, 3, 16, 98374) Yet it is the dominant cry of the two stalwarts that they are unable to find a suitable successor for their respective departments.
('89', 64, 3, 17, 98506) True, these are departments of a special character.
('89', 64, 3, 18, 98558) I know these departments and I know too Gurudev’s views about them.
('89', 64, 3, 19, 98626) Speaking generally, may I venture to suggest that there is no difficulty but can be overcome by tapascharya?
('89', 64, 3, 20, 98735) It is almost an untranslatable word, the nearest approach to its true meaning being perhaps ‘single minded devotion’.
('89', 64, 3, 21, 98853) But it means much more than that.
('89', 64, 3, 22, 98887) When ever, in the course of my multifarious activities, I have been con fronted with a difficulty of this character, this single minded devotion has solved my difficulty in a manner which I had never expected.

('89', 67, 3, 9, 104966) A. By material resources I suppose you mean finance.

('89', 68, 2, 9, 107713) Q. We are trying to serve villagers.
('89', 68, 2, 10, 107750) We find that at every step our activity is blocked by the social environment in the villages.
('89', 68, 2, 11, 107844) The joyless routine of life there, the stagnation and the incubus of evil social customs obstruct our efforts.
('89', 68, 2, 12, 107955) Should we not work for the eradication of these before we can hope for success in our other activities, and if so how can it be done ?
('89', 68, 2, 13, 108090) A. Ever since I came to India I have felt that social revolution is a much more difficult thing to achieve than the political revolution, by which I mean ending our present slavery under the British rule.
('89', 68, 2, 14, 108295) There are some critics who say that India cannot attain her political and economic emancipation till we get social emancipation.
('89', 68, 2, 15, 108424) I regard it as a snag and a conundrum set to puzzle us, because I have found that the absence of political emancipation retards even our efforts for bringing about social and economic emancipation.
('89', 68, 2, 16, 108622) At the same time it is also true that without a social revolution we will not be able to leave India happier than when we were born.
('89', 68, 2, 17, 108755) I can however indicate no royal road for bringing about a social revolution except that we should represent it in every detail of our own lives.
('89', 68, 2, 18, 108900) Force has been used to alter the structure of society in some countries.
('89', 68, 2, 19, 108973) But I have purposely eliminated it from our consideration.

('89', 68, 2, 22, 109300) It is thankless and laborious work.

('89', 69, 2, 3, 109587) A. I have no difficulty in saying that it makes no difference whether you pay a fixed salary or your expenses are paid for you.

('89', 84, 3, 7, 136838) How surprising and sad that, though you claim to be a public worker, you feel embarrassed to have to ask for money from time to time?
('89', 84, 3, 8, 136972) Why need one feel embarrassed to ask for money for public work?
('89', 84, 3, 9, 137036) You have, I am sure, seen me putting out my head through windows of railway carriages and begging a pice each from the people.
('89', 84, 3, 10, 137163) You have even helped me in this.
('89', 84, 3, 11, 137196) And still the letter to which I am reply ing seems to have been written by a millionaire.
('89', 84, 3, 12, 137286) I can understand your feeling embarrassed if you were asking for money for yourself.
('89', 84, 3, 13, 137371) But how can it be too much to ask for money even a hundred times for a public cause?
('89', 84, 3, 14, 137456) You have asked for an additional sum, but have not sent me a copy of the letter.
('89', 84, 3, 15, 137537) If you have addressed the letter to me in my capacity as Chairman, you should have addressed a formal letter to the Secretary too.
('89', 84, 3, 16, 137668) I can immediately reply to a letter received through the Secretary.
('89', 84, 3, 17, 137736) If you have written to me as to an elder, you should give me enough details to enable me to send the money to you without delay.
('89', 84, 3, 18, 137865) I sought your advice as from a daughter, co worker and one who was more than a sister to Sushila.
('89', 84, 3, 19, 137963) Instead of giving the advice I asked for, you have written as if we were utter strangers.
('89', 84, 3, 20, 138053) I do not undertand what all this is.
('89', 84, 3, 21, 138090) Address your reply to Sodepur.
('89', 84, 3, 22, 138121) I shall be touring in Bengal, and they will redirect the letter from here.
('89', 84, 4, 23, 138196) Blessings from BAPU

('89', 88, 0, 1, 142072) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 89
('89', 88, 1, 2, 142119) 137. DISCUSSION WITH POLITICAL WORKERS1
('89', 88, 2, 3, 142159) SODEPUR, December 23, 1945
('89', 88, 3, 4, 142186) The first [question] was from a lady who wanted to know when the remaining prisoners would be released.
('89', 88, 3, 5, 142290) Gandhiji was reported to have talked with H. E. the Governor about them.
('89', 88, 3, 6, 142363) Some of the prisoners were important workers without whom the great organization could not be said to be in full working order.
('89', 88, 4, 7, 142491) Gandhiji said he had naturally discussed with His excellency many questions, but he could not allow himself to be cross examined.
('89', 88, 4, 8, 142621) He could only hope with those present that if they were on the eve of liberty these prisoners must be set free sooner rather than later.
('89', 88, 4, 9, 142758) But he warned the lady questioner not to worry about them if she believed with him that prisons for patriots were gateways to liberty.
('89', 88, 4, 10, 142893) Was not India in bondage one vast prison ?
('89', 88, 5, 11, 142936) To a student who wanted to know what part students were to play Gandhiji said that he could not understand student organizations antagonistic to one another.
('89', 88, 5, 12, 143094) Students should all be lovers of freedom and therefore all Congressmen in thought.
('89', 88, 5, 13, 143177) But their first work was study.
('89', 88, 5, 14, 143209) They were all servants of the nation.
('89', 88, 5, 15, 143247) They should have no communal taint nor could they harbour untouchability.
('89', 88, 5, 16, 143321) They were bound to follow the constructive programme and, through the charkha and all it meant, ally themselves with the millions of poor villagers of India.
('89', 88, 5, 17, 143479) For the rest they should hear everything and everyone respectfully, weigh everything and follow what they thought was right.
('89', 88, 5, 18, 143604) But they must keep out of party politics.
('89', 88, 6, 19, 143646) To the question whether “Vandemataram” should be replaced by the new song “Qadam, Qadam”, Gandhiji said that a song that carried such glorious asso ciations of sacrifice as “Vandemataram” could never be given up.
('89', 88, 6, 20, 143859) It would be like discarding one’s mother.
('89', 88, 6, 21, 143901) But they could certainly add a new song or songs like the one mentioned to their repertoire of national songs after due thought and discrimi nation.
('89', 88, 7, 22, 144050) Q. Was there violence by the people in 1942 ?
('89', 88, 8, 23, 144096) Gandhiji referred the questioner to his reply 2 to the Tottenham pamphlet and added that had the people as a whole not remained non violent, India would have gone back.
('89', 88, 8, 24, 144265) He also thought the Government had senselessly put the principal Congress 
('89', 88, 9, 25, 144340) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s Weekly Letter issued to the Press.
('89', 88, 9, 26, 144403) Those present included members of the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee, students and trade union workers.
('89', 88, 9, 27, 144513) The meeting took place in the afternoon between 3 and 5 p.
('89', 88, 9, 28, 144572) before Gandhiji left for Santiniketan.
('89', 88, 9, 29, 144611) 2Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 15 7 1943
('89', 89, 0, 1, 144699) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 89, 1, 2, 144740) men in prison and thus provoked the people who were not yet restrained enough for complete non violence.
('89', 89, 1, 3, 144845) He had seen nothing to alter his conviction that the Government excesses far outweighed what the people had done in the way of violence.
('89', 89, 2, 4, 144982) Q. What could Congressmen do to draw Muslims to the Congress?
('89', 89, 3, 5, 145044) Gandhiji said that in the presence of the prevailing distrust there should be no attempt to enlist Muslims or any other group or individuals.
('89', 89, 3, 6, 145186) What however every Hindu could do was mutely to serve his Muslim or for that matter every non Hindu neighbour as his blood brother.
('89', 89, 3, 7, 145318) Such selfless service was bound to tell in the end.
('89', 89, 3, 8, 145370) That was the way of non violence, otherwise called love.
('89', 89, 4, 9, 145427) Asked as to what the position of the Congress in relation of class struggle between the capitalists and the labouring class was, Gandhiji replied that he could speak only in his individual capacity as he was not even a four anna member of the Congress.
('89', 89, 4, 10, 145680) His own relations with his capitalist friends, he remarked, typified the attitude of the Congress towards the capitalist class.
('89', 89, 4, 11, 145808) He freely accepted the hospitality of capitalists like the Birlas and made use of their money to serve the cause of the poor, but the latter did not expect anything in return from him.
('89', 89, 4, 12, 145993) On the contrary, they were glad to be exploited by him in the interests of the poor.
('89', 89, 4, 13, 146078) His relationship with them was ethical.
('89', 89, 4, 14, 146118) He could never give up his associations with the capitalists because of fear of anybody.
('89', 89, 4, 15, 146207) To do so would, in his opinion, amount to a betrayal of the cause of the poor.
('89', 89, 5, 16, 146286) Similarly, whilst the Congress accepted the financial help and cooperation of the capitalists in its fight for independence, it never was and never could be a capitalist organization.
('89', 89, 5, 17, 146470) The Congress was pledged to defend the rights of labour against anyone who might attempt to encroach upon them.
('89', 89, 5, 18, 146582) From its very inception it had stood for the poor, and consciously or unconsciously striven to become an organization of the masses.
('89', 89, 5, 19, 146715) In this connection he referred to Dadabhai Naoroji’s monumental work Poverty and Un British Rule in India, which showed the deep concern of the Grand Old Man of the Congress for Indian masses.
('89', 89, 6, 20, 146908) They could now understand why he asked them to rally round the Congress.
('89', 89, 6, 21, 146981) They should all identify themselves and serve the Congress, irrespective of whether they were on its membership register or not.
('89', 89, 6, 22, 147110) The Congress tricolour symbolized truth and non violence.
('89', 89, 6, 23, 147168) It was the only flag worthy of being adopted by them.
('89', 89, 6, 24, 147222) There was no power in the universe greater than truth.
('89', 89, 6, 25, 147277) Bereft of truth man was no better than the four footed beast.
('89', 89, 6, 26, 147339) If they made truth their staff and ahimsa their shield they would be irresistible.
('89', 89, 7, 27, 147422) Continuing, he told them that he considered himself to be a labourer just like themselves.
('89', 89, 7, 28, 147513) He did not think that there was any essential antagonism between capital and labour.
('89', 89, 7, 29, 147598) In fact he held that labour alone was true capital.
('89', 89, 7, 30, 147650) All the gold of
('89', 90, 0, 1, 147666) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 91
('89', 90, 1, 2, 147713) the capitalists could not provide them with one morsel of bread.
('89', 90, 1, 3, 147778) Collaboration of labour was necessary before capital could bear fruit.
('89', 90, 1, 4, 147849) Again the gold and silver of the capitalists had only a limited currency but labour was universal currency.
('89', 90, 1, 5, 147957) The capitalists could be robbed of their wealth but no one could rob the labourer of his wealth, namely, industry.
('89', 90, 2, 6, 148072) Moreover, capitalists were after all few in number.
('89', 90, 2, 7, 148124) The workers were many.
('89', 90, 3, 8, 148147) But capital was well organized and had learnt to combine.
('89', 90, 3, 9, 148205) If labour realized its
('89', 90, 4, 10, 148228) inherent strength and the secret of combination it would rule capital instead of being
('89', 90, 5, 11, 148315) ruled by it.
('89', 90, 6, 12, 148328) He commended to them the Ahmedabad Labour Union as a model organization to copy.
('89', 90, 6, 13, 148409) It was perhaps the best organized labour union in the world.
('89', 90, 6, 14, 148470) It ran its own free hospital, schools for children and cheap grain shops out of the union funds.
('89', 90, 6, 15, 148567) It had conducted several successful strikes.
('89', 90, 6, 16, 148612) The essential condition of a successful strike was that the strikers should not be dependent on public charity for their sustenance during the strike.
('89', 90, 6, 17, 148763) They must have an alternative occupation to fall back upon in a crisis.
('89', 90, 6, 18, 148835) He recalled how during the 23 days’ strike 1 of Ahmedabad labour workers, he had offered them work but had refused to give them doles.
('89', 90, 6, 19, 148970) The latter would have demoralized them.
('89', 90, 6, 20, 149010) Spinning was an occupation par excellence for their purpose.
('89', 90, 6, 21, 149071) He therefore asked them to learn and practise it in their homes.
('89', 90, 6, 22, 149136) Concluding, he observed that a strike should be organized not out of hostility towards the employers but for the restitution of the just rights of labour.
('89', 90, 6, 23, 149291) Rights and duties were reciprocal in their nature, the former accrued only from a due performance of the latter.
('89', 90, 7, 24, 149404) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 25 12 1945

('89', 93, 6, 10, 153219) 144. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('89', 93, 7, 11, 153251) SODEPUR, December 24, 1945
('89', 93, 8, 12, 153278) Monday the 24th December was a great day for the Christians.
('89', 93, 8, 13, 153339) The day following would be Christmas Day and that was the reason why they had heard in the bhajan a translation of one of the best English songs from the “Book of Psalms”.
('89', 93, 8, 14, 153511) They should understand the meaning of the song.
('89', 93, 8, 15, 153559) It depicted one who had lost his way and was penitent for going on a wrong track.
('89', 93, 8, 16, 153641) Now after a period he had been able to realize his mistake and he implored God to guide and show him the right way.
('89', 93, 8, 17, 153757) He appealed to God to illumine his way in order that he might not fall into numerous pits which covered all his way.
('89', 93, 8, 18, 153874) Wistful as he was to realize God, he fervently appealed to Him to take to the other world.
('89', 93, 8, 19, 153965) He knew that it was God alone who was able to take him from darkness to the kingdom of light.
('89', 93, 9, 20, 154059) This was the essence of the song, said Gandhiji.
('89', 93, 9, 21, 154108) What they said in their daily prayer was not different from this.
('89', 93, 9, 22, 154174) Gandhiji asked all to remember this and respect all religions of the world like their own.
('89', 93, 10, 23, 154265) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 25 12 1945
('89', 93, 11, 24, 154298) 1As it was Gandhiji’s silence day, the speech was read out by Kanu Gandhi.

('89', 94, 1, 2, 154420) 145. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('89', 94, 2, 3, 154455) December 25, 1945

('89', 94, 3, 8, 154867) 2 I dis cussed the same point with Jawaharlal also.

('89', 95, 5, 15, 156938) Hence, for the time being you had better give up the desire to receive letters written in my own hand.
('89', 95, 5, 16, 157041) That occasionally I may write myself is a different matter.

('89', 95, 5, 22, 157463) Don’t act in haste.

('89', 95, 5, 24, 157552) After all you are doing work there and I also believe it will bear fruit.

('89', 96, 1, 2, 158201) 147. LETTER TO SAUDAMINI G. MEHTA
('89', 96, 2, 3, 158235) December 25, 1945
('89', 96, 3, 4, 158253) DEAR SISTER, I have your letter.
('89', 96, 3, 5, 158286) Did you have the purse you had brought specially for the Bengal Harijan Sevak Sangh?
('89', 96, 3, 6, 158371) Anyway it does not matter whether or not you have it.
('89', 96, 3, 7, 158425) For my part, I have collected a fairly large amount.
('89', 96, 3, 8, 158478) How much would you require?
('89', 96, 3, 9, 158506) Please let me know.
('89', 96, 3, 10, 158526) If you say that no sum will be too much I am going to look upon you as a lazy person.
('89', 96, 3, 11, 158612) Workers who only know how to spend and cannot produce what they spend cannot do any work.
('89', 96, 3, 12, 158702) This has been my experience over the past sixty years.
('89', 96, 3, 13, 158757) It began with myself.
('89', 96, 3, 14, 158779) In England we formed the Vegetarian Society in the Way’s Hotel, but did not collect funds from amongst the members, with the result that we achieved nothing.
('89', 96, 3, 15, 158937) I occasionally exposed myself to laughter but I don’t remember anyone having been converted to vegetarianism because of my activity.
('89', 96, 3, 16, 159070) My later experience gradually proved sweeter because I then decided that funds would be collected from those amongst whom we proposed to work.
('89', 96, 3, 17, 159213) That balanced the two sides.
('89', 96, 3, 18, 159242) The result was I became a “Mahatma”.
('89', 96, 3, 19, 159279) I am pointing out the golden way in case you want to become one.
('89', 96, 3, 20, 159344) This by way of jest.
('89', 96, 3, 21, 159365) I am dicta ting this on board the steamer taking me to Midnapore.
('89', 96, 3, 22, 159431) That is how I could get some time.
('89', 96, 3, 23, 159466) About meeting Harijan workers you may decide after I return.
('89', 96, 4, 24, 159527) SAUDAMINI MEHTA CALCUTTA

('89', 99, 5, 11, 162243) 153. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING 1
('89', 99, 6, 12, 162275) DIAMOND HARBOUR, December 25, 1945
('89', 99, 7, 13, 162310) Gandhiji had already had one blessing from them.
('89', 99, 7, 14, 162359) They had gathered there in thousands but there was no noise and they were sitting there quietly and peacefully under the scorching sum.
('89', 99, 7, 15, 162495) If he left them after two hours, he would be going to serve them elsewhere.
('89', 99, 7, 16, 162571) If they realized that in their heart he would be really happy.
('89', 99, 8, 17, 162634) So many of them, men and women, were spinning there.
('89', 99, 8, 18, 162687) That was a sight very pleasing to him.
('89', 99, 8, 19, 162726) He also desired to thank them for the purse of Rs. 25,250 which they had given him for work in this sub division.
('89', 99, 8, 20, 162840) It was still more pleasing to him that this money had been collected from 3,900 persons.
('89', 99, 8, 21, 162929) He was giving it to Charu Babu 2
('89', 99, 9, 22, 162962) and was sure that it would be spent wise with maximum benefit.
('89', 99, 9, 23, 163025) He hoped that the work would be taken up with this sum as capital.
('89', 99, 10, 24, 163092) He had read and heard of the calamities suffered by the people of this sub division due to flood, famine and pesstilence.
('89', 99, 10, 25, 163214) He also knew that unless they bore such calamities with fortitude, they would not be able to survive in this would.
('89', 99, 10, 26, 163330) Calamities occurred at every moment in some place or other and humanity all over the world had to pass through such sufferings.
('89', 99, 10, 27, 163458) Today humanity was suffering in one form or other all over the world.
('89', 99, 10, 28, 163528) But if people thought of them as misfortunes falling on them and broke under them, they would not be able to reap good out of evil.
('89', 99, 11, 29, 163660) The songs sung at Khadi Pratishthan at prayer time every day had one central message and that was that even those who suffer get the blessings of God hidden in those sufferings.
('89', 99, 12, 30, 163838) 1 Gandhiji’s Hindi speech was simultaneouly rendered into Bengali by Satis Chandra Das Gupta.
('89', 99, 12, 31, 163932) 2 Charuchandra Bhandari
('89', 100, 0, 1, 163956) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUAR, 1946 101
('89', 100, 1, 2, 164003) It pained him to find that thousands of villagers were still coming there from distant places.
('89', 100, 1, 3, 164098) It had been decided that he should come there at half past three and remain with them for two hours.
('89', 100, 1, 4, 164199) If he had done so his progamme of work would have been disturbed and he would not have been able to serve them as he desired.
('89', 100, 2, 5, 164325) He had a faith and it was still with him after he had come there.
('89', 100, 2, 6, 164391) That was about the charkha.
('89', 100, 2, 7, 164419) He had been saying from the very beginning that if we did not have faith in the charkha and realized its inner meaning, we would not be able to live peacefully in Hindustan.
('89', 100, 2, 8, 164593) He had been saying this for 60 years, and this was true not noly for Hindustan but for the whole world, wherever humanity lived, whether it was a small or big community or country.
('89', 100, 2, 9, 164774) Humanity could not live peacefully unless it accepted the creed of truth and non violence.
('89', 100, 2, 10, 164865) It needed to be said that hooliganism or rowdyism would not enable us to bring swaraj or do anythiny good for humanity.
('89', 100, 2, 11, 164985) He was convinced that if the 40 crores of people in India were truly imbued with this spirit of truth and non violence then sawraj would be in our hands.
('89', 100, 3, 12, 165139) He would also tell them briefly the significance of the charkha.
('89', 100, 3, 13, 165204) They would see that the poorest of the poor could have a charkha and spin.
('89', 100, 3, 14, 165279) He had not seen any other machine which could be as useful as the charkha.
('89', 100, 3, 15, 165354) Spinning was a form of labour.
('89', 100, 3, 16, 165385) If a person did not work for his bread, he would be like a thief stealing the property of others.
('89', 100, 3, 17, 165483) The charkha gave them scope for honest labour.
('89', 100, 4, 18, 165530) In our country persons who knew English and who were said to be educated told us that our people, who had no work to do for six months, could have nothing in store for them but begging.
('89', 100, 4, 19, 165716) He would tell them that they would have to use intelligence in spinning too.
('89', 100, 4, 20, 165793) A few minutes earlier he was spinning.
('89', 100, 4, 21, 165832) The charkha was good but there was something wrong in it.
('89', 100, 4, 22, 165890) He had to mend it before he could spin.
('89', 100, 4, 23, 165930) In this way, if there was anything wrong in the machinery used by the people of India, then we would not be able to reap the maximum benefit out of it.
('89', 100, 4, 24, 166082) Here one charkha went wrong.
('89', 100, 4, 25, 166111) What would be the fate of Hindustan if 40 crores of charkhas went wrong?
('89', 100, 4, 26, 166184) Those who believed that swaraj could be won by the charkha, would necessarily have the blessings of God.
('89', 100, 4, 27, 166289) So long as we did not believe in God we would not be able to banish fear from our mind.
('89', 100, 4, 28, 166377) A person or people who was not fearless could not be free.
('89', 100, 4, 29, 166436) That was a simple truth.
('89', 100, 5, 30, 166461) He desired to thank them again for they had listened to him quietly.
('89', 100, 5, 31, 166530) He hoped they had listened and realized what he had said.
('89', 100, 5, 32, 166588) If, however, they had not been able to follow him, he hoped what he had said would be translated into Bengali and circulated among them.
('89', 100, 5, 33, 166725) When he heard that they would be glad if he held his prayer there he was greatly delighted.
('89', 100, 5, 34, 166817) He would hold his prayer for a few minutes and then would take leave of them.
('89', 100, 5, 35, 166895) That did not mean that his work there was finished.
('89', 100, 5, 36, 166947) He would go to the launch and hold discussions with their representatives.
('89', 100, 5, 37, 167022) If he could work according to his plan, he would know his duties towards them.
('89', 100, 5, 38, 167101) Concluding Mahatma Gandhi said :

('89', 101, 1, 2, 167176) I would request you to be quiet at the time of prayer.
('89', 101, 1, 3, 167231) You should be wholly given to meditation of God while praying.
('89', 101, 1, 4, 167294) Prayer is not parrot like repetition of words.
('89', 101, 1, 5, 167341) It is meaningless without single ness of heart.

('89', 101, 2, 7, 167422) 154. DISCUSSION WITH CONGRESS WORKERS 1
('89', 101, 3, 8, 167462) MAHISHADAL, [On or after December 25, 1945] 2
('89', 101, 4, 9, 167508) I cannot say that all that has been done has been well done or ought to have been done.
('89', 101, 4, 10, 167596) On the contrary, much of it ought not to have been done.
('89', 101, 4, 11, 167653) That the people did not remain inert is a matter of satisfaction, but the fact that after all these years they should not have known what the Congress stood for is a matter for sorrow.
('89', 101, 4, 12, 167838) What they did was thoughtless.
('89', 101, 4, 13, 167869) By its very nature it could not be sus tained.
('89', 101, 4, 14, 167916) You have graphically put in your reports how you blew up a railway track, put roads out of use, burnt a kutchery, seized a thana, set up a parallel government and so on.
('89', 101, 4, 15, 168086) This is not the technique of non violent action.
('89', 101, 4, 16, 168135) People committed the mistake of thinking that all that did not involve killing was non violence.
('89', 101, 4, 17, 168232) Sometimes killing is the cleanest part of violence.
('89', 101, 4, 18, 168284) If you kill the mischief maker out right, there is an end to it as far as he is concerned, but harassment is worse.
('89', 101, 4, 19, 168400) It did not put out mischief.
('89', 101, 4, 20, 168429) On the contrary, it brought the mischief on our own heads.
('89', 101, 4, 21, 168488) The authorities became vindictive.
('89', 101, 4, 22, 168523) Per haps, you will say that they would have been vindictive anyhow, but that is not what we should desire or aim at.
('89', 101, 4, 23, 168640) It does not pay us to let them go into panic.
('89', 101, 4, 24, 168686) In August 1942, the authorities became panicky.
('89', 101, 4, 25, 168734) We gave them that excuse.
('89', 101, 4, 26, 168760) But they are a people who do not know what defeat is; their cowardice is not fundamental.
('89', 101, 4, 27, 168850) So, they let such things as thanas, kutcheries, panchayat courts, etc., remain in your hands for a short while as toys but as soon as they had completed their dis positions they turned the full blast of their machinery of retaliation against us.
('89', 101, 4, 28, 169096) It is not in this way that India will attain her independence.
('89', 101, 4, 29, 169159) We cannot afford to repeat it.
('89', 101, 5, 30, 169190) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Non violent Technique and Parallel Govern ment” 2 Gandhiji was in Mahishadal from December 25 to 30.
('89', 102, 0, 1, 169320) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUAR, 1946 103
('89', 102, 1, 2, 169367) Today you have to reckon not with Britain alone but the Big Three.
('89', 102, 1, 3, 169434) You cannot successfully fight them with their own weapons.
('89', 102, 1, 4, 169493) After all, you cannot go beyond the atom bomb.
('89', 102, 1, 5, 169540) Unless we can have a new way of figting imperialism of all brands in the place of the out worn one of a violent rising, there is no hope for the oppressed races of the earth.
('89', 102, 1, 6, 169715) Let nobody be misled by the Russian parallel.
('89', 102, 1, 7, 169761) Our tradition is wholly different from Russia’s.
('89', 102, 1, 8, 169810) The historical setting too is defferent.
('89', 102, 1, 9, 169851) In Russia the whole population was under arms; Indian masses will not take to arms even if they could be given the necessary training.
('89', 102, 1, 10, 169986) But it is useless to think that our rulers will let us give them that training when they have at a stroke disarmed a first rate military State like Japan.
('89', 102, 1, 11, 170141) Today Japan lies prostrate at the conqueror’s feet.
('89', 102, 1, 12, 170193) But non violence knows no defeat.
('89', 102, 1, 13, 170227) It must however be true non violence, not a make believe.
('89', 102, 1, 14, 170285) I would not shed a single tear if I alone were left to represent such non violence.
('89', 102, 2, 15, 170369) Q. After all that we have done and suffered, we have begun to doubt whether our energies have flowed in the right channel, whether the mass awakening was not misdirected.
('89', 102, 2, 16, 170540) But is not non violent rebellion a programme of seizure of power ?
('89', 102, 2, 17, 170607) A. Therein lies the fallacy.
('89', 102, 2, 18, 170636) A non violent revolution is not a programme of ‘seizure of power’.
('89', 102, 2, 19, 170703) It is a programme of transforma tion of relationships ending in a peaceful transfer of power.
('89', 102, 2, 20, 170797) If the people had fully carried out the five steps outlined by me in my 8th of August speech 1 in the A.I.C.C. in Bombay, and had there been a perfect atmosphere of non violence, the Government’s power and repression would have been sterilized and it would have been compelled to yield to the national demand.
('89', 102, 2, 21, 171107) If under the impact of foreign invasion or some such.
('89', 102, 2, 22, 171161) cause the ruling power abdicates and a vacuum is created, the people’s orga nization will naturally take over its functions but such jatiya sarkar would have no other sanction except that of non violence and service of the people to enforce its fiats.
('89', 102, 2, 23, 171413) It will never use coercion.
('89', 102, 2, 24, 171441) Even those who might hold contrary views will receive a full measure of security under it.
('89', 102, 3, 25, 171532) As an instance of the infinitely greater efficacy of the non violent technique as compared to the technique of coercion, he mentioned the case of Bardoli.
('89', 102, 3, 26, 171687) In Midnapore whilst they succeeded in capturing a few symbols of power in the initial
('89', 102, 4, 27, 171773) 1Vide “Speech at A.I.C.C Meeting”, 8 8 1942 and “Speech at A.I.C.C. Meeting”, 8 8 1942
('89', 103, 0, 1, 171860) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 103, 1, 2, 171902) stages, they could not retain the fruits of their success.
('89', 103, 1, 3, 171961) But in Bardoli the satyagrahis were able fully to retain the gains of their struggle.
('89', 103, 1, 4, 172047) Moreover, you have seen that all your bravery could not prevent the violation of women.
('89', 103, 1, 5, 172135) Now that is intolerable.
('89', 103, 1, 6, 172160) No one should be able to cast an evil eye upon them.
('89', 103, 1, 7, 172213) This requires inculcation of a higher form of bravery, i.
('89', 103, 1, 8, 172271) e., that of non violence which can hurl defiance at death and against which the power of the aggressor cannot prevail.
('89', 103, 1, 9, 172390) This is what I am trying to do.
('89', 103, 1, 10, 172422) It may take time.
('89', 103, 1, 11, 172440) It takes a long time to infuse this kind of higher courage among the millions.
('89', 103, 1, 12, 172519) Whether this kind of non violene will ever come into play or not I do not know.
('89', 103, 1, 13, 172599) But you who have had training in non violence for all these years ought to realize that in your hands non violence should show all the brilliance that is inherent in it.
('89', 103, 2, 14, 172769) They next wanted to know as to how they could start on the right lines.
('89', 103, 2, 15, 172841) Gandhiji in reply prescribed to them the spinning wheel as “the symbol and central sun of the 8 fold constructive programme”.
('89', 103, 2, 16, 172967) It was the best way of achieving social solidarity and non violent organization.
('89', 103, 2, 17, 173048) The technique of non violent action consisted in isolating and sterilizing the instruments of evil.
('89', 103, 2, 18, 173148) Jatiya sarkar based on non violence would not put Government servants under duress but would effectively isolate them so that they would either have to align themselves with the people or be reduced to the necessity of carrying out the foreign Government’s writ through undiluted barbarism of which they would soon sicken and tire.
('89', 103, 2, 19, 173480) Even their relations and dear ones would desert them.
('89', 103, 2, 20, 173534) This presupposes that no section among the people is labouring under a sense of injustice and wrong at the hands of the others.
('89', 103, 2, 21, 173662) Untouchability, exploitation and communal rancour can have no place under a jatiya sarkar, or it will be like a house divided against itself which must fall.
('89', 103, 2, 22, 173820) Harijan, 17 2 1946

('89', 107, 8, 17, 178390) I have not come here to deliver speeches.

('89', 107, 9, 20, 178612) Referring to the sufferings of the people of Midnapore during the past years Gandhiji said that he was anxious to visit the district for some time, and he was glad that he got the opportunity today.
('89', 107, 9, 21, 178811) During his stay in their midst, he would study their conditions–political and economic.
