('89', 108, 1, 2, 179364) 164. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('89', 108, 2, 3, 179396) MAHISHADAL, December 27, 1945 If we can conduct ourselves unitedly as we have done in maintaining the rhythm of the bhajan sung, then whatever injury is inflicted on us and however wronged we may be as the result of the visitation of Nature or policy of the State, we will be the master of the situation and keep our head unbent.
('89', 108, 2, 4, 179726) History provides many such instances.
('89', 108, 3, 5, 179764) Proceeding, Gandhiji referred to the bhajan sung at the meeting and stated that it would not distort the meaning of the song if in the place of ”temple” the word “liberation” was used.
('89', 108, 4, 6, 179949) But, asked Gandhiji, what was exactly that liberation which the Poet in the song and they as well wanted to attain?
('89', 108, 4, 7, 180065) Was it the liberation or salvation that came to man after his death or was it the liberation from all vestiges of bondage that a human being suffered under in this world ?
('89', 108, 4, 8, 180237) The congregation, Gandhiji hoped, would agree with him that they all wanted the liberation from bondage in this world.
('89', 108, 4, 9, 180356) If that was the hankering then they must appreciate the significance of a unitedly given rhythm.
('89', 108, 5, 10, 180453) They were suffering under a bondage of foreign yoke and consequently they were anxious to be liberated therefrom.
('89', 108, 5, 11, 180567) There might be, if not equally, strong powers or influences in their country which also were anxious to keep them down in bondage.
('89', 108, 5, 12, 180698) They were anxious to get rid of all these bondages but, added Gandhiji, the worst type of bondage was that which enabled one to submit himself to any form of slavery.
('89', 108, 6, 13, 180865) Man was a slave to may things— his property, his desires, They should seek deliverance from all these things.
('89', 108, 6, 14, 180975) If they could press forward their claim for liberation from all these bondages in the same way as they did in maintaining the rhythm of the chorus of the bhajan, they would, he hoped, realize his message.
('89', 108, 7, 15, 181180) When they kept rhythm by a movement of the hands, the feeling of such a movement came from within.
('89', 108, 7, 16, 181279) In other words their hearts were attuned to the outside movements.
('89', 108, 7, 17, 181346) That was exactly the thing prerequisite to the attainment of salvation.
('89', 108, 8, 18, 181418) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 28 12 1945
('89', 108, 9, 19, 181451) 1 The meeting was attended by over one lakh people.
('89', 109, 0, 1, 181503) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('89', 116, 8, 10, 192672) BHAI JAJUJI, It is my firm view that we should demand yarn for the khadi required by the Congress.
('89', 116, 8, 11, 192771) It calls for tact and efficiency.
('89', 116, 8, 12, 192805) Those who wear a uniform must learn to spin.

('89', 116, 8, 17, 193100) By efficiency I mean we may provide yarn in cases where spinning cannot be started right now.
('89', 116, 8, 18, 193194) I always have quite a large stock of yarn and I am willing to spare some.The only provision is that I will give yarn only to those who are willing to give it but are not able to do so immediately as they do not know spinning.

('89', 116, 8, 20, 193497) And they should collect yarn for the khadi required in future.

('89', 118, 6, 14, 196105) Gandhiji smilingly asked the boys whether they would like to play with him.
('89', 118, 6, 15, 196181) On being asked by a boy to give him his blessings Gandhiji said that he could not do that because the boy had dirty dress.
('89', 118, 6, 16, 196304) He thereupon turned to the teacher of the boys and said that he would have a quarrel with him.
('89', 118, 6, 17, 196399) He explained to the teacher that the aims of Wardha scheme of education was not merely to teach the boys arithmetic and a few other things.
('89', 118, 6, 18, 196539) The Wardha scheme of education, Gandhiji emphasized, moulded the life of man to a new form.
('89', 118, 6, 19, 196631) Why should they sit with their face bent down?
('89', 118, 6, 20, 196678) They should be taught to sit erect.
('89', 118, 6, 21, 196714) Remember if they are properly reared up they will be the best soldiers of Hindustan.
('89', 118, 6, 22, 196799) Why should the boys put on dirty dress after having undergone Wardha training for six months ?
('89', 118, 7, 23, 196894) He urged that in imparting Wardha training they should be more concerned with its essence rather than the routine courses of study.
('89', 118, 7, 24, 197026) Gandhiji also enquired about their progress in spinning.

('89', 119, 4, 6, 197603) 182. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 119, 5, 7, 197633) MAHISHADAL, December 28, 1945
('89', 119, 6, 8, 197663) Gandhiji stated that he had noticed that ordinary rules of business of an assembly were not observed.
('89', 119, 6, 9, 197765) If one was to attend a meeting it was expected of him, whether he liked the proceedings or not, that he should remain till the end.
('89', 119, 6, 10, 197897) If this procedure was not followed and if he left abruptly while the meeting was going on he would only disturb others.
('89', 119, 6, 11, 198017) He had been told by many women attending such meetings that they had only a limited time at their disposal for attending such functions because they had to attend to other household duties.
('89', 119, 6, 12, 198207) Undoubtedly it was a strong argument in their favour but his reply to them would be that in such cases they should consider beforehand whether they had the time or not at their disposal to sit till the end of the meeting.
('89', 119, 7, 13, 198429) If they at all decided to attend the meeting they should be there till the meeting was dissolved.
('89', 119, 7, 14, 198527) There are many who arrived at the meeting after it had commenced.
('89', 119, 7, 15, 198593) In such a case the attendant should stay outside the assembly.
('89', 119, 8, 16, 198656) All these rules of conduct were applicable in respect of an ordinary assembly.
('89', 119, 8, 17, 198735) But they are obligatory in case of prayer meetings.
('89', 119, 8, 18, 198787) Because at the prayer they wanted to be in meditation.
('89', 119, 8, 19, 198842) During such a time anything disturbing from outside was un welcome.
('89', 119, 8, 20, 198910) He would particularly draw the attention of the organizers of such meetings to the observance of these general rules of conduct.
('89', 119, 8, 21, 199039) They should circulate amongst the people before hand these rules for their observance.
('89', 119, 8, 22, 199126) If they could train up people in this respect they would be rendering a public service and will be able to organize themselves better, advance the cause of public decorum and give new inspiration.
('89', 119, 9, 23, 199323) 1 Dr. Maitreyi Bose, Secretary of the Hindustan Mazdoor Sevak Sangh, Bengal Branch, had asked Gandhiji about the advisability of Congressmen engaged in the labour movement using the Red Flag.
('89', 120, 0, 1, 199515) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 121
('89', 120, 1, 2, 199563) Referring to the charkha demonstration participated in by about 500 spinners, men and women, Gandhiji said that he noticed that there were two types of charkhas in use.
('89', 120, 1, 3, 199732) The older one was the wheeled one and the latter was called the box charkha.
('89', 120, 1, 4, 199809) The latter was introduced by him and the reason for its introduction was that for the convenience of men like him who were regular spinners and had to travel, this type of box charkha was suitable.
('89', 120, 1, 5, 200007) But let them not forget, he said, the golden rule for charkha that its price should be cheap and be made from materials available in the particular locality.
('89', 120, 1, 6, 200165) Crores of persons could not be expected to use one uniform type of charkha.
('89', 120, 1, 7, 200241) Nor should its manufacture be limited to one central place.
('89', 120, 1, 8, 200301) If they developed a central supply store of charkha how would it be possible for them to supply it to the 40 crores of people ?
('89', 120, 2, 9, 200429) So far as the strength of the charkha was concerned he could assert that there was no other machine which was more powerful than it.
('89', 120, 2, 10, 200562) To him the charkha was the symbol of swaraj, ahimsa and annapurna.
('89', 120, 3, 11, 200629) Referring to the bhajan sung Gandhiji said that its composer maintained that it was through sufferings that a man could realize God.
('89', 120, 3, 12, 200762) What was the method prescribed for the realization of God was also true for the attainment of swaraj.
('89', 120, 4, 13, 200864) There was no instance in the world to show that swaraj could be had without undergoing sufferings.
('89', 120, 4, 14, 200963) Not only swaraj, they could not acquire even knowledge with out undergoing hardships.
('89', 120, 4, 15, 201049) If there was anything which was available to a man with out undergoing hardships he could not fully prize or appreciate the same.
('89', 120, 4, 16, 201179) Therefore, if they had followed the bhajan of the day they should remember that for the sake of God they had to put up with all sufferings.
('89', 120, 4, 17, 201319) As it was true that without suffering they could not realize God so was it equally true that without suffering they could not attain freedom.
('89', 120, 4, 18, 201461) They should also remember that for the sake of swaraj whatever they had suffered had not been in vain.
('89', 120, 4, 19, 201564) They had all paved the path towards their attaining swaraj.
('89', 120, 4, 20, 201624) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 30 12 1945

('89', 121, 1, 2, 202073) I would like your doing whatever work relating to spinning comes to you unsought at home.
('89', 121, 1, 3, 202163) If you have skill, proficiency, firm ness of mind, purity of character, devotion to God and humility, then the work you do at home will be like the Ganga flowing by your door step.
('89', 121, 1, 4, 202344) I will regard such work done during student life as more than enough.
('89', 121, 1, 5, 202414) If by fulfilling your family obligations and doing service to others while studying you have to take two years instead of one to complete your studies you need not feel unhappy at all.
('89', 121, 1, 6, 202599) It would certainly be a matter of shame if studies were neglected from lethargy or love of pleasures.
('89', 121, 1, 7, 202701) Those who believe that it is impossible to do public service during student life are mistaken.
('89', 121, 1, 8, 202796) The student’s stage of life is also meant for increasing one’s capacity for service.
('89', 121, 1, 9, 202881) If, there fore, the immediate opportunity for service is neglected, the student’s life becomes as it generally is today, a selfish one instead of one dedicated to service.
('89', 121, 1, 10, 203053) Moreover, present day education by and large is antagonistic to the spirit of service or patriotism.
('89', 121, 1, 11, 203154) Add to this the burden of learning through English.
('89', 121, 1, 12, 203206) And the subjects of study also include some which are unnece ssary and exclude some which are essential, such as spinning.
('89', 121, 1, 13, 203329) According to me, spinning, which means both its science and craft, should be introduced as the principal subject right from the earliest stage.
('89', 121, 1, 14, 203473) But that is not done anywhere.
('89', 121, 1, 15, 203504) Our boys, therefore, who study in Government institutions must determinedly make good this deficiency, as you have been doing.
('89', 121, 1, 16, 203631) If that is not done, one would be guilty of the vanity of claiming perfection.
('89', 121, 1, 17, 203710) You should not, therefore, in any circumstances abandon spinning and its science.

('89', 121, 1, 19, 203848) It will help her to understand and realize how much service, and nothing but service, is contained in spinning.

('89', 121, 1, 24, 204189) You should remain detached and go on doing what you can.
('89', 121, 1, 25, 204246) I could perhaps have revised the English of your report and sent it to you, but the news you had given in it was so good that I felt I must convey it to Jajuji and so sent on the report to him.
('89', 121, 1, 26, 204440) I do not very much care if your English is not of the highest class.

('89', 124, 6, 15, 208202) 188. TALK WITH PEOPLE 1
('89', 124, 7, 16, 208226) MAHISHADAI, December 29, 1945
('89', 124, 8, 17, 208256) Gandhiji replied that he had been asked the same question 2 in 1920 and 1921 and he could only repeat the reply which he gave then.
('89', 124, 8, 18, 208388) The question betrayed ignorance of non violence and also of swaraj of his conception.
('89', 124, 8, 19, 208474) He did not want swaraj at the cost of women’s honour.
('89', 124, 8, 20, 208528) If what passed as non violence did not enable them to protect the honour of women or if it did not enable the women to protect their own honour, it was not non violence.
('89', 124, 8, 21, 208698) Believe me, it is something quite different.
('89', 124, 9, 22, 208743) And he described what he had written in Hind Swarajin 1909. Gandhiji obser ved that experience had added force to the argument.
('89', 124, 9, 23, 208871) After all who protected Sita from Ravana?
('89', 124, 9, 24, 208913) The poet tells us that her purity was such that Ravana dared not compass his end without her consent.
('89', 124, 10, 25, 209015) 1 Extracted from Sushila Nayyar’s “Non violence and Molestation of Women”.
('89', 124, 10, 26, 209090) On the night of the 29th Gandhiji met about 200 men and women of Mahishadal and neighbouring villages including local workers and victims of police and military atrocities during the 1942 movement.
('89', 124, 10, 27, 209288) 2 The question was whether they were expected to remain non violent even when their womenfolk were molested.
('89', 125, 0, 1, 209397) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 125, 1, 2, 209439) He warned them in the end that if anybody came to him with the plea that they could not protect the honor of their womenfolk because they had taken the vow of non violence, he would give them no quarter.
('89', 125, 1, 3, 209643) Non violence should never be used as a shield for cowardice.
('89', 125, 1, 4, 209704) It was a weapon of the brave.
('89', 125, 1, 5, 209734) He would rather they died fighting violently than became helpless witnesses to such atrocities.
('89', 125, 1, 6, 209830) A truly non violent man would never live to tell the tale of such atrocities.
('89', 125, 1, 7, 209908) He would have laid down his life on the spot in non violent resistance.
('89', 125, 2, 8, 209980) Harijan, 10 2 1946
('89', 125, 3, 9, 209999) 189. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 125, 4, 10, 210029) MAHISHADAL, December 29, 1945
('89', 125, 5, 11, 210059) Gandhiji paid a glowing tribute to the affection and painstaking care that the men and women volunteers who were in charge of the camp, had shown is looking after him and his party.
('89', 125, 5, 12, 210241) Gandhiji congratulated the gathering on the exemplary silence and order which prevailed during the public prayers at Mahishadal.
('89', 125, 5, 13, 210370) It had given him the deepest satisfaction.
('89', 125, 5, 14, 210413) The peace of mind which he experienced there exceeded even what he had experienced in Sevagram or Sodepur.
('89', 125, 6, 15, 210520) Referring to the events in connection with the 1942 struggle, he said that as a result of all that he had heard and learnt during the last few days, he had come to the conclusion that whilst people had shown singular courage and endurance, they had also committed some mistakes, especially in their understanding of the principle of ahimsa.
('89', 125, 6, 16, 210861) He added : Besides, there were some acts of high handedness amongst our selves.
('89', 125, 6, 17, 210941) There must be some difference between a national organi zation and alien rule.
('89', 125, 6, 18, 211020) In our national organization there should not be any differences amongst ourselves.
('89', 125, 6, 19, 211104) I should go further today and say that those outsiders who lived near us should be made to realize that our organization was superior to the alien organization because we did not want violence.
('89', 125, 6, 20, 211298) We wanted to carry on our work through non vilence.
('89', 125, 7, 21, 211350) Under a national government, even the opponents or those who held contrary views ought not to experience a feeling that the ideal had not been attained in Midnapore or, for that matter, in any part of India.
('89', 125, 7, 22, 211558) It might even be said that it was a tall order.
('89', 125, 7, 23, 211606) But if he did not point out their faults or place the undiluted ideal before them, they could never hope to reach their ideal.
('89', 125, 7, 24, 211733) Gandhiji continued :
('89', 125, 8, 25, 211754) 1 These two paragraphs are reproduced from The Hindu of 30 12 1945.
('89', 126, 0, 1, 211822) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 127
('89', 126, 1, 2, 211870) If you do not do it, I won’t be able to do anything, even if I carry our claim throughout the world.
('89', 126, 1, 3, 211971) I won’t succeed if I do not make these things clear to you.
('89', 126, 1, 4, 212031) During my work for the last 60 years it has been the practice with me that I do not praise those who work with me.
('89', 126, 1, 5, 212146) I make their mistakes known to others and I think, by doing so, our mistakes would be rectified.2
('89', 126, 2, 6, 212244) Gandhiji reiterated his conviction that India had lost nothing, but on the con trary had gained in every way as a result of the adoption and practice of truth and non violence during all these years.
('89', 126, 2, 7, 212444) If they had not attained the goal which they had set before themselves, the fault lay not in truth and ahimsa, but in themselves.
('89', 126, 3, 8, 212574) For instance, if they had fully imbibed the principle of ahimsa, they would be completely free from the feeling of discrimination against the votaries of religions other than their own and regard them and serve them all with equal love.
('89', 126, 3, 9, 212811) It had pained him to learn that, in the Mahishadal area, Harijans were still not being admitted in the temples.
('89', 126, 3, 10, 212923) He hoped they would completely rid themselves of the taint of untouchability.
('89', 126, 3, 11, 213001) It would be a big advance in ahimsa.
('89', 126, 4, 12, 213038) Referring to the song that had been sung, he pointed out that, in it, the devotee prays to God to purge him of the cowardice which springs from doubt, as well as the cowardice that results from fear of misfortunes.
('89', 126, 4, 13, 213253) To harbour doubt is to insult God.
('89', 126, 4, 14, 213288) To shrink from misfortune, is to run away from Him.
('89', 126, 4, 15, 213340) He, therefore, prays for spiritual as well as physical courage, so that he might be completely rid of all fear.
('89', 126, 4, 16, 213452) The Hindu, 30 12 1945 and 31 12 1945

('89', 135, 0, 1, 227639) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 135, 1, 2, 227681) 201. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 135, 2, 3, 227711) CONTAI, December 31, 1945
('89', 135, 3, 4, 227737) Gandhiji congratulated the people of Contai on successfully rivalling other places in Bengal, where he had been of late, in maintaining exemplary discipline.
('89', 135, 3, 5, 227895) He hoped that they would show the same spirit of discipline in the event of any other leader coming in their midst.
('89', 135, 4, 6, 228011) Gandhiji recalled how in 1934, when he was touring in Orissa in connection with the Harijan programme, a German Nazi, Herr Buto, had requested to be allowed to accompany him on his tour.
('89', 135, 4, 7, 228198) He professed himself to be an ardent admirer of Hitler.
('89', 135, 4, 8, 228254) Having heard how Gandhiji’s method was exactly contrary to Hitler’s and how in South Africa he had led a successful struggle against General Smuts with only a handful of Indians and no other weapons than that of non violence, he was curious to meet the author of that movement and study his method at close quarters.
('89', 135, 4, 9, 228571) Gandhiji had granted him his request in the hope of converting him to non violence, but when Herr Buto saw the undisciplined behaviour of Orissa crowds, he told Gandhiji that he could now understand how a handful of Britishers in India could keep a nation of 400 millions in bondage.
('89', 135, 4, 10, 228855) As a result of his experience, he had become sceptical of India ever winning freedom through non violence.
('89', 135, 4, 11, 228962) What India needed, he thought, was a Hitler.
('89', 135, 4, 12, 229007) Gandhiji, however, had drawn a different moral from the same events.
('89', 135, 4, 13, 229076) What India needed was discipline, no doubt, but not of the Hitlerite variety.
('89', 135, 4, 14, 229154) It had to be of the non violent type and, therefore, voluntary.
('89', 135, 4, 15, 229218) His experience in Bengal during his present tour had confirmed him in his faith that the latter was infinitely superior to the former.
('89', 135, 4, 16, 229353) If six and a quarter crores of Bengalis could show the same discipline which the present gathering had shown that evening, not even a thousand Hitlers would be able to deprive them of their freedom.
('89', 135, 5, 17, 229552) Commenting next on Gurudev’s song that had been sung, he observed that, in that song, a devotee pledges his soul to Truth and prays that Truth may always triumph.
('89', 135, 5, 18, 229715) He prays further that Truth may give him strength so that neither misfortune nor fear of direct punishment may force him into untruth in thought, speech or action.
('89', 135, 5, 19, 229879) For fulfilment of that pledge, he longs to lay down his life and all.
('89', 135, 5, 20, 229949) If the song that had been sung came really from their heart and not merely from their lips, it ought to transmute their entire life and they should see the sovereignty of Truth in their lifetime.
('89', 135, 6, 21, 230145) Referring next to repression, followed by the havoc caused by cyclone and floods through which the people of Midnapore had recently passed, he told them that all that had filled his soul with anguish.
('89', 135, 6, 22, 230346) The song which they had just sung was surely a message for them in their present misfortunes too.
('89', 136, 0, 1, 230444) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 137
('89', 136, 1, 2, 230492) As regards the triple problem facing them, namely, shortage of food, shortage of clothing and lack of drinking water, he told them that it would be easily solved if they could throw off their inertia.
('89', 136, 1, 3, 230693) It was no use waiting idly for Government help.
('89', 136, 1, 4, 230741) They must show capacity to help themselves.
('89', 136, 1, 5, 230785) He was afraid that, so far, they had not done all that they might have.
('89', 136, 1, 6, 230857) If all the people of Contai and the neighbouring areas took to spinning in right earnest, they could solve the problem of cloth shortage.
('89', 136, 1, 7, 230995) He observed that their success in that would be followed by amelioration in other respects too.
('89', 136, 2, 8, 231091) Concluding, Gandhiji remarked that if the Government had recognized in their behaviour in 1942 the legitimate longing to be free and co operated with them instead of trying to thwart them, the history of India would have been written differently.
('89', 136, 2, 9, 231338) That was not to be.
('89', 136, 2, 10, 231358) He, however, refused to shed a single tear over the past and wanted them to do likewise.
('89', 136, 2, 11, 231447) The present was enough to claim their energy and attention, and that evening’s song indicated the spirit in which to approach the problem.
('89', 136, 2, 12, 231586) The Hindu, 3 1 1946
('89', 136, 3, 13, 231606) 202. NOTE TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL

('89', 140, 2, 3, 236672) SODEPUR, January 1, 1946 I did send you a longish letter.
('89', 140, 2, 4, 236730) I have asked S. to send you a copy.
('89', 140, 2, 5, 236766) I have before me two letters from you.

('89', 148, 6, 15, 250498) 220. DISCUSSION WITH CONGRESS WORKERS
('89', 148, 7, 16, 250536) January 1, 1946
('89', 148, 8, 17, 250552) Gandhiji’s advice to ladies was that they could serve the country even by doing household duties.
('89', 148, 8, 18, 250650) Generally, they hankered after making their daughters fit for marriage and sons for earning.
('89', 148, 8, 19, 250743) Such families could not be said to be serving the country.
('89', 148, 8, 20, 250802) Married men and women could give much time for the service of the country even after looking after their children and doing household duties.
('89', 148, 8, 21, 250944) Instead, they passed their days in enjoyment of life and thus ended the span of life.
('89', 148, 8, 22, 251030) There were some who were so addicted to pleasure that they used contraceptives.
('89', 148, 9, 23, 251110) Asked how women whose husbands were imprisoned could serve the country, Gandhiji said that they should no doubt spin.
('89', 148, 9, 24, 251228) But this might not be sufficient for their living.
('89', 148, 9, 25, 251279) They should take to some means of earning money.
('89', 148, 9, 26, 251328) They could still work for the country.
('89', 148, 9, 27, 251367) Under no circumstances, Gandhiji emphasized, should women earn their livelihood by sacrificing their honesty and purity.
('89', 148, 9, 28, 251488) Mahatmaji was faced with the problem of spending annually one crore and 25 lakhs of rupees of the Kasturba Fund.
('89', 148, 9, 29, 251601) Althouh he was trying hard to utilize the money in the best possible way still enough women workers could not be found.
('89', 148, 10, 30, 251721) Gandhiji advised women living in towns to serve the villages.
('89', 148, 10, 31, 251783) He appealed to
('89', 148, 11, 32, 251798) them to search their hearts whether they were really ready and then begin work when
('89', 148, 12, 33, 251882) they found response in their hearts.
('89', 148, 13, 34, 251919) Addressing the students, he said that the question which was put to him was not new.
('89', 148, 13, 35, 252004) How the students could serve Harijans should not have been asked so late.
('89', 149, 0, 1, 252078) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 149, 1, 2, 252120) they were ready to serve the Harijan they could easily do it.
('89', 149, 1, 3, 252182) They could go to villages, mix with the Harijan and educate them.
('89', 149, 2, 4, 252248) As regards inter dining and intercaste marriage, Gandhiji said that so far as he understood the mind of the Congress he knew there was no difference of opinion about inter dining but he thought that so long as one could not think himself one of the Harijans the poison of untouchability could not be removed.
('89', 149, 2, 5, 252557) If anybody was not prepared to marry a Harijan he found no occasion of giving his blessings to that marriage.
('89', 149, 2, 6, 252667) The question of marrying a Harijan was not so difficult but the difficulty was only mental.
('89', 149, 3, 7, 252759) Replying to the question whether girl students should have a separate organization, Gandhiji said although the life of men and women was not quite different so long a woman remained a woman there might be necessity for a separate organization for their work.
('89', 149, 3, 8, 253018) In his Ashram men and women lived together and worked together, still there might be such necessity.
('89', 149, 4, 9, 253119) Discussing the constructive programme, Gandhiji said that besides the charkha there were several other items in his fifteenfold programme and women could take to any of them as they liked.
('89', 149, 4, 10, 253308) Women could take a large share in the freedom movement of the country as they always had done specially in Midnapore and other places of India during the Salt Satyagraha.
('89', 149, 4, 11, 253479) So he thought that it was needless to question what share the women could take in national movement.
('89', 149, 5, 12, 253580) As regards reorganization and rehabilitation scheme 1 Mahatmaji said that the people and workers should depend more on their own strength an endeavour than on the Government.
('89', 149, 5, 13, 253755) Regarding the drainage problem he had talks with the Governor Mr. R. G. Casey and was trying to do whatever was possible in that respect.
('89', 149, 5, 14, 253893) 2 If they could take up any item of work themselves and could fulfil it other things would follow.

('89', 152, 2, 3, 258753) MAIN CAMP: SODEPUR, CONTAI, January 2, 1946
('89', 152, 3, 4, 258797) SHIVABHAI, Your letter is good.
('89', 152, 3, 5, 258829) Instead of replying ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ to your questions, I think I shall be able to explain my point of view more clearly if I state my own ideas.
('89', 152, 3, 6, 258972) If any institution has not become self supporting on the lines suggested by me, the fact can be interpreted in two ways; either that the workers were not efficient enough, or that my calculations were erroneous.
('89', 152, 3, 7, 259184) If any institution has not succeeded so far, I will begin to doubt only my calculations.
('89', 152, 3, 8, 259273) But Probably you will be able to see that both these inferences are irrelevant.
('89', 152, 3, 9, 259353) I have advocated self reliance in three matters: (1) for the workers in villages, (2) for basic education and (3) for institutions.
('89', 152, 3, 10, 259485) In regard to the first, my view is that any individual or family who settles in a village must earn their subsistence by working in the village itself.
('89', 152, 3, 11, 259637) For instance, the person may start some industry—that is, without entering into competition with anybody else engaged in a similar industry—or may join an existing industry.
('89', 152, 3, 12, 259811) If the person becomes popular with the local population, the people themselves will meet his needs.
('89', 152, 3, 13, 259911) In either case I will describe the worker as self supporting.
('89', 152, 3, 14, 259973) (2) As regards basic education, I am of the view that the rent of the school building, the teacher’s salary and the running expenses of the school should be met from the pupils’ labour during the seven years of their stay in school.
('89', 152, 3, 15, 260206) I am doubtful about including the expense incurred on the pupils’ food in the scheme of self reliance.
('89', 152, 3, 16, 260309) Third, any institution will be considered to be self supporting if the people for whose benefit it is run provide its expenses.
('89', 152, 3, 17, 260437) For instance, if the money for Indian Christian institutions comes from America, then the Indian Christians will have proved their incapacity.
('89', 152, 3, 18, 260580) Those institutions must be supported by the local Christians.
('89', 152, 3, 19, 260642) I think this should answer all your doubts.
('89', 152, 3, 20, 260686) But the three rules.
('89', 152, 3, 21, 260707) I have suggested should not be interpreted to mean that any activities which do not conform to them should be treated as useless and be wound up.
('89', 152, 3, 22, 260853) I have thought deeply and long about our institutions and formulated a code on the basis of experience.
('89', 152, 3, 23, 260957) We shall be able to render better service to the extent we are able to live up to it, and will not become a burden on others.
('89', 152, 3, 24, 261083) I think it would be danger ous to take the prevailing prices as the basis for any calculations.
('89', 153, 0, 1, 261179) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('89', 155, 1, 2, 264170) 228. SPEECH AT VOLUNTEERS RALLY
('89', 155, 2, 3, 264202) January 2, 1946
('89', 155, 3, 4, 264218) Gandhiji, while taking the salute of the volunteers, asked whether they belon ged to any permanent corps or were recruited temporarily.
('89', 155, 3, 5, 264354) On being told that they were recruited on the occasion of his visit there, Gandhiji said that they should have a permanent volunteer corps for their own good and for the service of the people.
('89', 155, 3, 6, 264547) The volunteers, he said, should be wedded to the cult of non violence and should serve the people and not harass them.
('89', 155, 4, 7, 264666) They should spin charkha regularly and know the rules of cleanliness.
('89', 155, 4, 8, 264736) That means, Gandhiji emphasized, that if they found dirt anywhere they should try themselves to clean it.
('89', 155, 4, 9, 264842) They should look at every human being with an eye of love and should do their best to alleviate the sufferings of the people.
('89', 155, 4, 10, 264968) Their whole life should be dedicated to prayer and they should realize that prayer would instill a power in them which would enable them to face anything.
('89', 155, 5, 11, 265123) Gandhiji put a number of questions to Sj.
('89', 155, 5, 12, 265165) Sudhir Chandra Das, G.O.C. of volunteers and asked them why they did not have uniform dress.
('89', 155, 5, 13, 265258) Knowing that their volunteer group was temporary and due to shortage of time they could not have uniform dress, Gandhiji told them that volunteers must get such instructions so that wherever and whenever they were required they all must be in the same uniform.
('89', 155, 5, 14, 265519) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 3 1 1946

('89', 155, 7, 16, 265601) CONTAI, January 2, 1946
('89', 155, 8, 17, 265625) GANDHI: How long would you take to learn it then ?

('89', 155, 10, 19, 265696) G. Since Hindustani is one out of the 18 items included in the constructive programme and since the carrying out of all these items in their fulness is swaraj, how long at this rate would you take to attain swaraj?
('89', 155, 11, 20, 265911) In independent India, continued Gandhiji, they would need to have a lingua franca which could be understood by everybody.
('89', 155, 11, 21, 266033) He was an admirer of the English

('89', 156, 1, 2, 266303) language, but it could never take the place of the national language.
('89', 156, 1, 3, 266373) There was a saying in English to the effect that matter out of place was dirt.
('89', 156, 1, 4, 266452) English had its place in international affairs.
('89', 156, 1, 5, 266500) But he could not tolerate the introduction of English in our day to day business, in our domestic life.

('89', 156, 2, 9, 266851) After that Gandhiji took up the questions which had been submitted to him before the meeting.
('89', 156, 3, 10, 266945) The first question invited suggestion as to how they could make a success of the constructive programme and how they could overcome the obstacle in their way.
('89', 156, 4, 11, 267104) Replying, Gandhiji enumerated the various items of the constructive pro gramme.
('89', 156, 4, 12, 267184) The spinning wheel, though he gave it the central place, must not be on the brain.
('89', 156, 4, 13, 267267) There were 17 other items.
('89', 156, 4, 14, 267294) Communal unity was one of them.
('89', 156, 4, 15, 267326) Did they regard all communities as one?
('89', 156, 4, 16, 267366) Then they had to get rid of untouchability root and branch.
('89', 156, 4, 17, 267426) Similarly, they must realize the importance and place of the mother tongue.
('89', 156, 4, 18, 267502) Their mother tongue alone could be the language for the domestic affairs and day to day business.
('89', 156, 4, 19, 267600) He was in his 77th year and yet he had set his heart on learning Bengali.
('89', 156, 4, 20, 267674) He hoped to learn to read Bengali before he left Midnapore.
('89', 156, 4, 21, 267734) Nothing would give him greater pleasure than to be able to talk to them in Bengali.
('89', 156, 4, 22, 267818) He could hope to touch their hearts through Bengali, never through English.
('89', 156, 5, 23, 267894) Then there were the Adivasis (called Aboriginals).
('89', 156, 5, 24, 267945) The 1935 Act had separated them from the rest of the inhabitants of India and had placed the “excluded areas” under the Governor’s direct administration.
('89', 156, 5, 25, 268099) It was a shame that they had allowed them to be treated like that.
('89', 156, 5, 26, 268166) It was up to them to make the Adivasis feel one with them.
('89', 156, 5, 27, 268225) The other items were prohibition, village industries, basic education, adult education, women’s education in health and hygiene, economic equality, kisans, labour, students, and village sanitation.
('89', 156, 5, 28, 268423) The last was most important and at the same time most difficult.
('89', 156, 5, 29, 268488) He almost despaired of our people ever observing the rules of sanitation voluntarily when he saw the riverside fouled without hesitation even by those who should know better.
('89', 156, 5, 30, 268663) He continued : The execution of the constructive programme in its entirety means more than swaraj.
('89', 156, 5, 31, 268762) It means Ramarajya, Khudai Sultanat or the divine kingdom.
('89', 156, 5, 32, 268821) I am thirsting after such Ramarajya.
('89', 156, 5, 33, 268858) My God does not reside up above.
('89', 156, 5, 34, 268891) He has to be realized on earth.
('89', 156, 5, 35, 268923) He is here, within you, within me.
('89', 156, 5, 36, 268958) He is omnipotent and omnipresent.
('89', 156, 5, 37, 268992) You need not think of the world beyond.
('89', 156, 5, 38, 269032) If we can do our duty here, the ‘beyond’ will take care of itself.
('89', 156, 5, 39, 269099) This necessarily includes political indepen dence.
('89', 156, 6, 40, 269150) Such independence could only be achieved through non violence and truth exemplified in constructive work.
('89', 156, 6, 41, 269256) The Working Committee had realized the

('89', 157, 1, 2, 269337) importance of constructive work.

('89', 157, 1, 4, 269427) He did not believe that Subhas Babu was dead 1. His feeling was that he was hiding somewhere and would appear at the right moment.
('89', 157, 1, 5, 269558) He admired his courage and patriotism.
('89', 157, 1, 6, 269597) But he differed from him with regard to the means.
('89', 157, 1, 7, 269648) He was convinced that real freedom, freedom for the man in the street, could never be achieved through armed revolt.
('89', 157, 2, 8, 269765) For him, the parliamentary programme was only a means of promoting constructive work.

('89', 157, 4, 18, 270668) God would take them to task for having been helpless witnesses to those atrocities.

('89', 157, 5, 20, 270846) Another friend asked him what he thought of the class struggle which was ineitable in labour work.
('89', 157, 6, 21, 270945) Gandhiji’s reply was that class struggle there had been always.
('89', 157, 6, 22, 271009) It could be ended if the capitalists voluntarily renounced their role and became all labourers.

('89', 157, 6, 24, 271194) What the two hands of the labourer could achieve the capitalist would never get with all his gold and silver.

('89', 157, 6, 27, 271384) It had to have in one hand truth and in the other non violence, and it would be invincible.
('89', 157, 6, 28, 271476) Labour and capital, classes and masses, are as old as the hills.
('89', 157, 6, 29, 271541) The whole trouble arises from the fact that neither labour nor those who are guiding the labour movement realize the dignity and strength of labour.
('89', 157, 6, 30, 271690) It is like the lame leading the blind.

('89', 158, 3, 6, 272591) 230. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 158, 4, 7, 272621) CONTAI, January 2, 1946
('89', 158, 5, 8, 272645) Summing up his experience of prayer gathering in Contai and elsewhere in Bengal, Gandhiji said that he had been noticing phenomenal changes in behaviour of crowds taking place before his very eyes.
('89', 158, 5, 9, 272843) He was not surprised at it.
('89', 158, 5, 10, 272871) Bengal had given birth to that prince of devotees, Chaitanya, and a host of other God intoxicated saints.
('89', 158, 5, 11, 272977) He longed for the day when the example of the crowds would be taken up by the whole of India.
('89', 158, 6, 12, 273071) He had felt overwhelmed by the consideration that had been shown to him, by ensuring him as much peace and quiet as was humanly possible, and the way in which he had resolved to repay his debt of gratitude was by devoting every moment of leisure accruing therefrom to learning Bengali.
('89', 158, 6, 13, 273357) He had been doing that ever since he came to Bengal most systematically.
('89', 158, 6, 14, 273430) In Contai he hoped that the love for all Indian languages which that resolve symbolized, would fill them too.
('89', 158, 7, 15, 273540) Before coming to the meeting he had been told that carcasses of about 700 cattle and 300 human beings, out of many more which had perished in a cyclone, lay buried indiscriminately together where the prayer gathering was held.
('89', 158, 7, 16, 273767) Dust had returned to dust, and there was no mark to tell the tale, as Gurudev had observed in one of his songs.
('89', 158, 7, 17, 273879) God mercifully hides man’s tragedy on earth under a mantle of greenery.
('89', 158, 7, 18, 273951) Nevertheless, it betrayed lack of human feeling on the part of those who were responsible for it.
('89', 158, 7, 19, 274049) The common practice was to give to each dead body a separate burial and the ground in which the burial took place became consecrated ground.
('89', 158, 7, 20, 274190) This was where cremation was not in vogue.
('89', 158, 7, 21, 274233) While, therefore, he respected sentiment, he did not make a fetish of it and he even derived satisfaction from the fact that common calamity had united men and cattle in death, thereby symbolizing the essential unity of all life.
('89', 158, 7, 22, 274463) Thought of it ought to humble man’s pride and bring home to him the insignificance of human existence with its illusions, which 1 held him a prisoner in
('89', 158, 8, 23, 274616) 1 In Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, “Petition to Lord Ripon”, 14 7 1894, the rest of the paragraph reads: “.
('89', 158, 8, 24, 274725) hold him prisoner.
('89', 158, 8, 25, 274744) If man learned to break through this net of illusions and made the fulfilment of his dharma the Pole Star of his life’s pilgrimage, it would considerably lessen the burden under which the world is groaning.”
('89', 159, 0, 1, 274952) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 159, 1, 2, 274994) their net till man had learned to break through this net of illusions and make the fulfilment of one’s dharma the pole star in life’s pilgrimage.
('89', 159, 2, 3, 275140) Explaining the significance of prayer Gandhiji told them that it ought to result in self purification and it ought to transmute their entire conduct.
('89', 159, 2, 4, 275290) If anybody thought that it gave him licence to do as he liked during the rest of the day, he deceived himself and others.
('89', 159, 2, 5, 275412) That was a travesty of the true meaning of prayer.
('89', 159, 3, 6, 275463) Commenting on the song that had been sung at prayer, Gandhiji said that in it the devotee prayed to God that he might be able to see Him face to face.
('89', 159, 3, 7, 275614) Through single obeisance it betokened an indefinable strength of faith in man.
('89', 159, 3, 8, 275693) With such faith nothing in the world would be impossible of attainment.
('89', 159, 3, 9, 275765) Faith in God to be real, however, had to find expression in work.
('89', 159, 3, 10, 275831) In his opinion the eighteenfold constructive programme which he had placed before the country was prayer through work since it was based on the principles of truth and ahimsa.
('89', 159, 3, 11, 276007) If they fulfilled that programme in its fulness not only would they be free, but their example would serve as a beacon light to all the oppressed and exploited people of the earth.

('89', 167, 7, 14, 287746) 245. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 167, 8, 15, 287776) SODEPUR, January 4, 1946
('89', 167, 9, 16, 287801) Gandhiji said that he had come back in their midst after some time.
('89', 167, 9, 17, 287869) He would again go out to Assam on the 8th.
('89', 167, 9, 18, 287912) The prayer would be held here till January 7. He did not know if he would be able to hold prayer here again on his return from Assam.
('89', 167, 10, 19, 288046) He had been on a pilgrimage to Midnapore.
('89', 167, 10, 20, 288088) The tour was so peaceful, the orderliness was so impressive, that they were unique.
('89', 167, 10, 21, 288172) He had been to three or four places: Diamond Harbour, Mahishadal, Kakra and Contai.
('89', 167, 10, 22, 288256) In each of these places the orderliness of the people was praiseworthy.
('89', 167, 10, 23, 288328) At prayer time the gathering went up to about a lakh of people.
('89', 167, 10, 24, 288392) Many people came from long distances.
('89', 167, 10, 25, 288430) Every one of them was quite peaceful and none disturbed the orderliness.
('89', 167, 10, 26, 288503) From Diamond Harbour he witnessed this orderliness.
('89', 167, 11, 27, 288555) Gandhiji said that Ramanama was so attractive that it could absorb man’s whole thought and self into it.
('89', 167, 11, 28, 288660) That was why he had asked them to clap their hands
('89', 167, 12, 29, 288711) 1 Lord Melbourne (1779 1848) was the first Prime Minister of Queen Victoria.
('89', 167, 12, 30, 288788) He was responsible for many important liberal measures of her reign.
('89', 168, 0, 1, 288857) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 169
('89', 168, 1, 2, 288905) rhythmically when taking Ramanama.
('89', 168, 1, 3, 288940) As they went on clapping their hands they got absorbed in the prayer.
('89', 168, 1, 4, 289010) They knew soldiers were so trained that they were disciplined and learnt to work together.
('89', 168, 1, 5, 289101) Discipline being the most essential thing, there was an English saying—‘disciplined soldier’.
('89', 168, 2, 6, 289195) They were also soldiers of freedom.
('89', 168, 2, 7, 289231) Soldiers of a State received salary and they maintained discipline.
('89', 168, 2, 8, 289299) Soldiers of freedom did not get such payment; but they acquired strength by maintaining discipline.
('89', 168, 2, 9, 289399) In the words of Badshah Khan 1, they were all Khudai Khidmatgars or servants of God.
('89', 168, 2, 10, 289484) They were to maintain discipline and that was why he had introduced the practice of clapping hands while praying.
('89', 168, 3, 11, 289598) Explaining the bhajan sung at the prayer Gandhiji said it was very sweet.
('89', 168, 3, 12, 289672) The Poet—Rabindranath—said that if nobody responded to their call they must not despair but continue to work for their ideal.
('89', 168, 3, 13, 289798) Even if failures met them they must not be broken.
('89', 168, 3, 14, 289849) They should go on working irrespective of whether their hopes and aspirations were realized or not.
('89', 168, 3, 15, 289949) One who was devoted to God did not feel despair; he went on knocking at heaven’s door for entrance to the kingdom of God.
('89', 168, 4, 16, 290071) Swaraj had not yet come, but he had not given up hope.
('89', 168, 4, 17, 290126) They must keep on knocking and one day swaraj was bound to come.

('89', 176, 6, 10, 301887) 259. SPEECH AT CONGRESS WORKERS’ CONFERENCE—I 1
('89', 176, 7, 11, 301935) January 5, 1946
('89', 176, 8, 12, 301951) After enumerating the various items of the 18 fold constructive programme as mentioned in the revised and enlarged edition of his brochure 2 Constructive Programme, Its Meaning and Place, a copy of which had come into his hands only on the day before, he asked them to take note of the fact that the charkha and khaddar was only one—though by no means the least important—out of the 18 items in that programme.
('89', 176, 9, 13, 302362) Civil disobedience had been mentioned at the end of the 18 items.
('89', 176, 9, 14, 302428) It had a place there since the theme of the brochure was the constructive programme not merely as an economic activity but as a means of the attainment of swaraj.
('89', 176, 10, 15, 302591) Civil disobedience was of two types, individual and mass.
('89', 176, 10, 16, 302649) Individual civil disobedience was everybody’s inherent right like the right of self defence in normal life.
('89', 176, 10, 17, 302757) No special sanction was needed for the practice of this kind of civil disobendience.
('89', 176, 10, 18, 302842) Just as a man in normal life would use his dagger, revolver or even
('89', 176, 11, 19, 302910) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('89', 176, 11, 20, 302955) About 750 to 800 workers from all the districts of Bengal, including several women, met Gandhiji on January 5 and 6 to seek his guidance regarding the Congress reorganization work in Bengal, particularly the constructive activity.
('89', 176, 11, 21, 303186) A long list of questions were handed to Gandhiji just before he came to the meeting.
('89', 176, 11, 22, 303271) Before answering the questions, Gandhiji addressed them briefly in Hindustani.
('89', 176, 12, 23, 303350) 2 Amrita Bazar Patrika, 7 1 1946, had reported that, “incidentally in the course of his remarks, Gandhiji congratulated two Calcutta papers—Amrita Bazar Patrika and The Hindustan Standard for publishing the brochure in their columns and hoped that people would take up the programme and give effect to it in right earnest.”
('89', 177, 0, 1, 303674) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 177, 1, 2, 303716) fisticuffs to foil a sudden attack, even so civil disobedience would be resorted to by the constructive worker as a non violent equivalent to the use of fisticuffs or arms.
('89', 177, 1, 3, 303889) It did not need sanction or permission from anybody.
('89', 177, 1, 4, 303942) As an illustration of how civil disobedience could be used to overcome Government’s opposition to constructive work he took up the hypothetical case of a worker engaged in the service of the Adivasis.
('89', 177, 1, 5, 304143) If the Government prevented him from going among them he would simply disobey the order.
('89', 177, 1, 6, 304232) The Government might put him in prison, he would wel come it.
('89', 177, 1, 7, 304294) It would be a most auspicious beginning for his work.
('89', 177, 1, 8, 304348) The very fact that he had gone to prison in order to serve the Adivasis would enshrine him in their hearts.
('89', 177, 2, 9, 304456) Mass civil disobedience was for the attainment of independence.
('89', 177, 2, 10, 304520) For if the fulfilment of the constructive programme almost in its entirety was an indispensable preliminary condition.
('89', 177, 2, 11, 304639) The ‘Quit India’ resolution of August 1942 might be cited as an exception to this dictum, he remarked.
('89', 177, 2, 12, 304742) His reply was that it was justified by exceptional circumstances into which, however, he did not propose to take them at present.
('89', 177, 2, 13, 304872) Moreover, the movement had never been started.
('89', 177, 3, 14, 304919) Gandhiji then took up the first two items from the constructive programme and showed how they helped the struggle for independence.
('89', 177, 3, 15, 305051) The first was communal unity.
('89', 177, 3, 16, 305081) If they could achieve true heart unity among all the communities, not as a political expedient to be cast aside when its purpose was served or as a token of their common dislike of the third party, no power on earth would be able to sow division amongst them as at present.
('89', 177, 3, 17, 305355) And even a child would understand that an India united would be an India free.
('89', 177, 3, 18, 305434) The same held true in regard to the removal of untouchability.
('89', 177, 4, 19, 305497) In the course of his remarks Gandhiji referred to the report of Sarat Babu’s recent speech 2 which was to the effect that since with Gandhiji he believed in non violence of the strong—not of the weak, he felt that military training was necessary to inculcate the spirit of discipline, without which true non violence could not be practised.
('89', 177, 4, 20, 305838) Commenting upon it, Gandhiji said that he did not know whether Sarat Baba had been correctly reported or not.
('89', 177, 4, 21, 305948) He himself had often suffered from bad reporting.
('89', 177, 4, 22, 305998) But the statement as it appeared lent itself to an ambiguous interpretation.
('89', 177, 5, 23, 306075) It was only a half truth to say that military training was an aid to the practice of non violence.
('89', 177, 5, 24, 306174) The statement was true if by military training was meant inculcation of perfect discipline, but if by military training was meant training also in the use of arms and the art of killing it could have no place in his (Gandhiji’s) programme of non violence.
('89', 177, 6, 25, 306430) 1 The following four paragraphs have been taken from Amrita Bazar Patrika, 6 1 1946 2 In the Bengal Legislative Assembly
('89', 178, 0, 1, 306551) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 179
('89', 178, 1, 2, 306599) He Himself had been advocating the necessity of non violent discipline in his prayer meetings and had even been trying to impart it to the people wherever he went.
('89', 178, 1, 3, 306763) He considered this kind of discipline to be superior to what was known as military discipline inasmuch as the latter was enforced by penalties while the disci pline of non violence was absolutely voluntary and called for the strength to face death without killing.
('89', 178, 2, 4, 307028) If he found that his views were opposed to Sarat Babu’s views and he people of Bengal asked him as to which of the two sets of views they should follow, he would unhesitatingly tell them to follow Sarat Babu’s views and discard his, since Sarat Babu was the leader of Bengal and not he.
('89', 178, 2, 5, 307315) But in the present case he felt sure that there was no difference between their views as Sarat Babu had himself told him in the course of his recent talks with him that in the matter of non violence he wantd to go the whole hog with him.
('89', 178, 2, 6, 307553) Therefore, he was of opinion that Sarat Babu’s advocacy of military training held good only in the context of non violence.
('89', 178, 2, 7, 307677) In no other sense was it compatible with the Congress faith much less with non violence as he (Gandhiji) understood it.
('89', 178, 3, 8, 307797) Gandhiji then proceeded to answer questions :
('89', 178, 4, 9, 307843) Q. You have asked the charkha workers to keep themselves detached from the political work of the Congress.
('89', 178, 4, 10, 307950) From experience the questioner finds that such centres fail to make the people conscious fighters for swaraj.
('89', 178, 4, 11, 308060) On the other hand, other centres, where workers have been working in double functions—both as charkha as well as Congress workers—give a better account of themselves during civil disobedience.
('89', 178, 4, 12, 308253) So please make your directions in this respect clear.
('89', 178, 5, 13, 308307) GANDHIJI: It is a good question but it betrays want of clear thinking.
('89', 178, 5, 14, 308378) All I have said is that a khadi worker will not be able to do full justice to his work if he has too many irons in the fire.
('89', 178, 5, 15, 308503) Khadi work demands one’s undivided attention.
('89', 178, 5, 16, 308549) But that does not mean that it should be done mechanically.
('89', 178, 5, 17, 308609) No khadi worker can afford to be indifferent to other things with which khadi is interrelated or lose sight of its correlation to the struggle for independence.
('89', 178, 5, 18, 308770) Experience has shown that wherever intensive charkha work had been done the people had shown greater grit, unity and capacity for organization in the struggle for independence.
('89', 178, 6, 19, 308947) Q. You have often repeated that charkha without its full implications means nothing.
('89', 178, 6, 20, 309032) Supposing we do not associate the charkha with political work, then, how will people understand its full implications ?
('89', 178, 7, 21, 309152) G. ‘Full implications’does include political work, but it includes many more things.
('89', 178, 7, 22, 309237) The charkha has an undoubted value as a means for providing economic relief to the masses but as I have so
('89', 179, 0, 1, 309344) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 179, 1, 2, 309386) often reiterated, khadi activity, stripped of its significance in terms of India’s independence means nothing to me today.
('89', 179, 1, 3, 309509) At the same time if you take up charkha work merely for gaining political ends, it will defeat its purpose and you will make a mess of it in the political as in the economic sense.
('89', 179, 1, 4, 309690) To say that unless we associate charkha work with Political work it will have no political value, betrays a thorough ignorance of the non violent technique.
('89', 179, 1, 5, 309847) Let me take ‘service of the lepers’ which is another item in the 18 fold constructive programme.
('89', 179, 1, 6, 309944) Surely, it cannot be associated with any kind of political work in the accepted sense.
('89', 179, 1, 7, 310031) Yet it would be absurd to say that it has no value in terms of swaraj.
('89', 179, 1, 8, 310102) Under the non violent technique every real service renderd, every right act performed does bring the country nearer to the goal of political indepedence though in itself it may not have any direct political significance.
('89', 179, 1, 9, 310323) If you were to tell me that you have lost faith in non violence as a means for the attainment of swaraj, I would agree that the charkha or constructive work have no use for you.
('89', 179, 1, 10, 310501) Nor would you have any use for me in that event.
('89', 179, 1, 11, 310550) But since you have discarded faith neither in ahimsa nor in me, your indifference to charkha and constructive work is a sign only of your laziness and inertia.
('89', 179, 1, 12, 310710) It is my conviction that the phennome nal awakening that has taken place in India during the last 25 years is entirely due to the adoption of non violence and the charkha as its symbol.
('89', 179, 1, 13, 310896) To the extent to which we have neglected the charkha and cons tructive work we have failed in the attainment of our goal.
('89', 179, 2, 14, 311018) Q. On December 23, you have advised 1 Hindu workers to offer selfless service to the Muslim masses, for it will tell in the end.
('89', 179, 2, 15, 311147) That might be termed a long term policy.
('89', 179, 2, 16, 311188) Should we then do nothing political among the Muslim masses?
('89', 179, 2, 17, 311249) Apart from its effect on the Muslims, is not the policy of non interference and political aloofness likely to engender in the non Muslims a new attitude of exclusiveness towards the Muslims and thus serve the ver purpose of those who are trying to divide the nation ?
('89', 179, 3, 18, 311517) G. With due deference to the framer of the question let me say that I fail to understand it.
('89', 179, 3, 19, 311610) If millions of Hindus regarded non Hindus as their blood brothers and sisters and treated them as such without the slightest tinge of a political motive, it must result in the complete political unity of India.
('89', 179, 3, 20, 311821) Is it a ‘long term’ effect?
('89', 179, 4, 21, 311849) 1 Vide “Discussion with Political Workers”, 23 12 1945
('89', 180, 0, 1, 311904) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 181
('89', 180, 1, 2, 311952) framer of the question does not seem to know how ahimsa works.
('89', 180, 1, 3, 312015) What I have deprecated in the present poisoned state of our communal relations is the attempt on the part of Congressmen to draw non Hindus into the Congress fold, as it would only accentuate the existing mistrust.
('89', 180, 1, 4, 312230) But supposing I make friends with Badshah Khan how does it widen the gulf between the communities?
('89', 180, 1, 5, 312329) On the contrary, it imme diately eases communal tension to that extent.
('89', 180, 1, 6, 312401) Multiply this picture a millionfold and it will be seen that the difficulty posed in the question is altogether chimerical.
