('89', 182, 6, 13, 314932) 265. SPEECH AT CONGRESS WORKERS’ CONFERENCE—II
('89', 182, 7, 14, 314979) January 6, 1946
('89', 182, 8, 15, 314995) Meeting Gandhiji on the second day of the conference 1 the Bengal workers found in him a hard customer.
('89', 182, 8, 16, 315099) Instead of waiting fot them to put question he anticipated them by asking them whether they knew Hindustani.
('89', 182, 8, 17, 315208) As only about half the number raised their hands in reply, he inquired as to how long they would require to learn Hindustani.
('89', 182, 8, 18, 315334) Some replied: “One Year.” Gandhiji commented : No good, Contai people did not require more than six months 2.
('89', 182, 9, 19, 315444) “All right then, six months,” shouted a few voices.
('89', 182, 9, 20, 315496) But Gandhiji twitted them for doing no better than the countryfolk of Contai in the matter of learning the national language.
('89', 182, 9, 21, 315622) Calcutta should do better.
('89', 182, 9, 22, 315649) Someone from the gathering objected that they were not all Calcutta folk.
('89', 182, 9, 23, 315723) But the objector’s voice was drowned in a chorus from the rest who shouted “three months”.
('89', 182, 9, 24, 315814) [Gandhiji said :] That is good, but say “six months” all in chorus and endorse the same by raising your right hand in affirmation.
('89', 182, 10, 25, 315945) 1 For the previous day’s report, vide “Speech at Congress Workers Confe rence I, 5 1 1946 2Vide “Discussion with Midnapore Political Workers”, 2 1 1946
('89', 183, 0, 1, 316097) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 183, 1, 2, 316139) A forest of hands rose in reply.
('89', 183, 1, 3, 316172) But Gandhiji’s keen eye detected a lacuna.
('89', 183, 1, 4, 316215) I notice that the women workers are hesitating.
('89', 183, 1, 5, 316263) Is Azad 1
('89', 183, 2, 6, 316273) Hindustan then going to be for men only and are women for ever to be in Zenanistan?
('89', 183, 2, 7, 316357) If not, you should all shout out, “sub” (“all”) in one voice.
('89', 183, 3, 8, 316419) There was a deafening chorus of “sub, sub” in reply.
('89', 183, 3, 9, 316472) Gandhiji was pleased .
('89', 183, 3, 10, 316495) he told them it was up to them to see that they kept it.
('89', 183, 3, 11, 316552) There were ample facilities in Calcutta for learning Hindustani and they should avail themselves of it.
('89', 183, 4, 12, 316656) Another friend asked whether by learning Hindustani was meant ability to understand Hindustani or whether it included the ability to read and write Hindustani as well.
('89', 183, 4, 13, 316824) This gave Gandhiji the opportunity to emphssize the importance of learning to read and write both the Nagari and the Urdu scripts, if they wanted to maintain direct touch with all the sections of the people in the country.
('89', 183, 4, 14, 317047) Even Hindus in north, let along Muslims, did not know the Nagari script.
('89', 183, 4, 15, 317120) In support of his argument he mentioned the instances of the late Lala Lajpat Rai, the Lion of the Punjab, Pandit Ajodhyanath, who was one of the founders of the Congress and Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, none of whom knew the Nagari script.
('89', 183, 4, 16, 317355) The Urdu script was not difficult to learn.
('89', 183, 4, 17, 317399) Anyway he was not prepared to hear objections on the score of difficulty from intellectual Bengal.
('89', 183, 5, 18, 317498) Gandhiji’s attention was next drawn to a Press cutting purporting to give a restatement of his views on the utility of the parliamentary programme in relation to constructive work.
('89', 183, 5, 19, 317679) The reference was to a recent writing of his in Hindustani in Khadi Jagat.
('89', 183, 5, 20, 317754) “What attitude should a wholetime constructive worker maintain towards the parliamentary programme?
('89', 183, 5, 21, 317854) Can the will of the people be really represented by a legislature under present conditions in India?
('89', 183, 5, 22, 317955) If the conditions are adverse, i.
('89', 183, 5, 23, 317989) e., if the Government is hostile, should Congressmen continue to function in the legislatures and what help can they advance under the circumstances to the cause of constructive work ?”
('89', 183, 6, 24, 318175) Gandhiji, replying, said that he had advocated the boycott of the legislatures as a part of the fourfold non co operation programme.
('89', 183, 6, 25, 318308) He still held the view that if that programme had been given effect to in full, India would have got swaraj.
('89', 183, 6, 26, 318417) But the country as a whole was not prepared fot it.
('89', 183, 6, 27, 318469) There was a considerable section in the country that wanted to use parliamentary talent in the service of the country.
('89', 183, 6, 28, 318588) No one should prevent them from serving the country in their own way.
('89', 183, 6, 29, 318658) As a practial idealist he had therefore reconciled himself to Congressmen capturing the legislatures and other elective bodies, if only to prevent self seekers and enemies of India’s freedom from getting there.
('89', 183, 7, 30, 318869) 1 Independent
('89', 184, 0, 1, 318883) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 185
('89', 184, 1, 2, 318931) He repeated what he had said at Contai, that nothing would please him better than that ideal scavengers should be returned to legislatures to represent the Congress there.
('89', 184, 1, 3, 319103) He himself claimed to be scavenger No.
('89', 184, 1, 4, 319142) 1 of India.
('89', 184, 1, 5, 319154) His ideal scavenger would not be an ignorant puppet but a man with sturdy common sense and capacity to think and decide upon the problems of the day.
('89', 184, 1, 6, 319304) He would be an educated person though he might not know English.
('89', 184, 1, 7, 319369) He could not see why such a one should not be President of the Congress.
('89', 184, 1, 8, 319442) The positive function of those who went to the legislatures would be to promote constructive work.
('89', 184, 1, 9, 319541) He, however, warned them that mere parliamentary work would not bring them swaraj.
('89', 184, 1, 10, 319624) That would come only as a result of their work outside among the masses.
('89', 184, 1, 11, 319697) A wholetime constructive worker would not be able to take up parliamentary activity without detriment to his own work.
('89', 184, 1, 12, 319816) But those who were not giving all their time to constructive work might enter the legislature if people wanted it, provided however that it did not lead to rivalries among workers and they had not to enter into any expenditure in order to be elected.
('89', 184, 2, 13, 320067) Q. In many portions of Bengal, the cultivators are Muslims and the proprie tors Hindus.
('89', 184, 2, 14, 320155) Recently in some places the Muslim tillers have refused to till the land under Hindu owners.
('89', 184, 2, 15, 320248) What should the Hindu owners do under the circumstances ?
('89', 184, 3, 16, 320306) Gandhiji, replying, said that the views he was going to express were strictly his own.
('89', 184, 3, 17, 320393) As they all knew, he was not even a four anna Congress member and therefore he could not speak as a Congressman.
('89', 184, 3, 18, 320506) He spoke only in his personal capacity as a satyagrahi.
('89', 184, 4, 19, 320562) Although the question had been posed in a communal setting the real cleavage
('89', 184, 5, 20, 320639) as he saw it was not communal but economic.
('89', 184, 5, 21, 320683) In Bengal the cultivators might be
('89', 184, 6, 22, 320718) Muslim and the properietors Hindu.
('89', 184, 6, 23, 320753) But in Andhra both the cultivators and
('89', 184, 7, 24, 320792) proprietors were Hindus and yet the same conflict was in evidence in some parts.
('89', 184, 8, 25, 320873) His views, continued Gandhiji, on the ownership of land were well known.
('89', 184, 8, 26, 320946) The only rightful owner of the land was he who tilled it.
('89', 184, 8, 27, 321004) The present properietors were morally entitled to hold land only if they became trustees for it.
('89', 184, 8, 28, 321101) If the cultivators of the fields of a proprietor, who had become a trustee, refused to till the land for him, he would not sue them or seek otherwise to coerce them.
('89', 184, 8, 29, 321267) He would leave them alone and try to earn his livelihood independently by his honest industry.
('89', 184, 8, 30, 321362) If he has been discharging his function as a trustee honestly, they would come to him before long in contrition and seek his guidance and help.
('89', 184, 8, 31, 321506) For, he would use his privilege not to fill his pockets by the exploitation of the labourers but teach the letter co operation and organization so as to increase their produce and generally ameliorate their conditons.
('89', 184, 8, 32, 321724) This would mean that the proprietor must himself become a cultivator par excellence.
('89', 184, 8, 33, 321809) A propeietor who regarded his property merely as a means of satisfying his lusts was not its owner but its slave.
('89', 184, 8, 34, 321923) The proprietors of land in
('89', 185, 0, 1, 321950) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 185, 1, 2, 321992) Bengal had therefore only to adopt his ideal of trusteeship and their troubles would end.
('89', 185, 2, 3, 322082) Q. Would the trustee’s property be passed on to his children by in heritance ?
('89', 185, 3, 4, 322161) G. A proprietor who holds his property as a trust will not pass it on to his children in inheritance unless the letter in their turn become trustees and make good their claim as such.
('89', 185, 3, 5, 322345) If they are not prepared for it, he should create a trust of his property.
('89', 185, 3, 6, 322420) It is demoralizing for an able bodies young man to live like a parasite on unearned income.
('89', 185, 3, 7, 322512) A father should inculcate in his children the appreciation of the dignity of labour and teach them to earn their bread by their honest industry.
('89', 185, 3, 8, 322657) As regards the monied people all I can say from my close personal association with a large number of them, is that if a general atmosphere in favour of trusteeship, devoid of ill will and class hatred, is created in the country they will fall in line with it.
('89', 185, 4, 9, 322917) Q. Many Congress workers who have recently come out of jail have to earn a living for themselves or their families.
('89', 185, 4, 10, 323033) Under present economic conditions they have been forced to crowd into towns for this purpose with the result that the villages have begun to lose their services.
('89', 185, 4, 11, 323195) Could not a paid service be established for them by the provincial or the district Congress organizations?
('89', 185, 4, 12, 323302) If so, how would you advise them to find the money for this prupose ?
('89', 185, 5, 13, 323372) G. The question reflects the present deplorable condition of the country.
('89', 185, 5, 14, 323446) The cities are not only draining the villages of their wealth but talent also.
('89', 185, 5, 15, 323525) The only way to check the process is for Con gress workers to refuse to make their lives their God but to dedicate themselves to the service of their ideal only.
('89', 185, 5, 16, 323687) God will then take care of them.
('89', 185, 5, 17, 323720) A labourer is always worthy of his hire but I know that I have no magic wand to revolutionize people’s outlook up to the ideal of voluntary poverty.
('89', 185, 5, 18, 323869) There fore I consider it desirable that a fund should be created either by the Provincial Congress Committee or by local agencies to provide maintenance for such workers as may want to dedicate themselves to the service of the villages.
('89', 185, 5, 19, 324106) Do not expect me however to provide you with funds.
('89', 185, 5, 20, 324158) My begging days are over.
('89', 185, 5, 21, 324184) It is my firm belief that no worthy cause has ever suffered for want of finances if there are sincere workers to work fot it.
('89', 185, 5, 22, 324310) Calcutta has got enough ‘money bags’, and if a practical scheme of work in the villages is produced and there are sincere and earnest workers forthcoming to take it up, I am sure the money will come forth.
('89', 186, 0, 1, 324516) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 187
('89', 186, 1, 2, 324564) Q. You have advised spinning for swaraj.
('89', 186, 1, 3, 324605) If, in trying to execute that programme in its full implications, spinning for wages has to be restricted, should we do so?
('89', 186, 1, 4, 324729) That will mean hardship for the very poor who find some relief through their spinning wages.
('89', 186, 1, 5, 324822) Then, again, if we keep up spinning for wages, the new rules of purchasing khadi against yarn will make it more difficult for us to dispose of the khadi produced for offering relief to the poor.
('89', 186, 2, 6, 325017) Gandhiji said that what he had recommended was that all people should spin not for self but for swaraj.
('89', 186, 2, 7, 325121) Such conscious and altruistic spinning on the part of forty millions would constitute a veritable yajna or sacrifice out of which swaraj would emerge.
('89', 186, 2, 8, 325272) It would knit the classes and masses, the brain workers and the manual labourers, in a living bond of unity.
('89', 186, 2, 9, 325381) What had however happened was that although their efforts had resulted in providing thousands of men and women with a supplementary source of income, the spinners themselves did not wear khaddar.
('89', 186, 2, 10, 325577) They did not realize the implications of khadi in terms of swaraj.
('89', 186, 2, 11, 325644) He had therefore come to the concluclon tha if khadi was truly to become the “livery of freedom” 1, to use Pandit Jawaharlal’s expression, all those who spin should consciously adopt khadi and all those who wanted to wear khadi should spin.
('89', 186, 2, 12, 325885) There was thus no conflict between spinning for wages and spinning for sacrifice.
('89', 186, 2, 13, 325967) The two were supplementary, one of the other.
('89', 186, 3, 14, 326013) Q. Violence is bad .
('89', 186, 3, 15, 326034) The only substitute for it is constructive activity as symbolized by the charkha.
('89', 186, 3, 16, 326116) But the dynamic quality seems to have gone out of it.
('89', 186, 3, 17, 326170) What should be done to bring out its revolutionary significance ?
('89', 186, 4, 18, 326236) G. Dr. Radha Kumud Mukherji in one of his books has quoted Colebrooke as saying that in India, the home of chronic poverty, the spining wheel is the provider of butter and bread for the poor.
('89', 186, 4, 19, 326428) The late R. C. Dutt has shown how the prosperity of the East India Company was founded on their trade in Indian textiles.
('89', 186, 4, 20, 326550) No part of the world, neither China nor Japan could produce fabrics to equal them.
('89', 186, 4, 21, 326633) In the early phase the East India Company battened on the exploitation of its monopoly in Indian textiles.
('89', 186, 4, 22, 326740) Not only did it bring them immense trade profits, it also gave an impetus to British shipping.
('89', 186, 4, 23, 326835) Later, Lancashire developed its own textile industry follow ing upon a series of mechanical inventions.
('89', 186, 4, 24, 326939) This brought it into com petition with the Indian textile manutactures.
('89', 186, 4, 25, 327011) The policy of exploi tation of the Indian artisans then gave way to that of destruction of their craft.
('89', 186, 5, 26, 327115) 1Vide “Livery of Freedom” 2 What follows is extracted from Harijan, 31 3 1946. It appeared under the title “How to Make It Dyamamic ?” by Pyarelal, who had explained that the question was “put to Gandhiji at Calcutta by the khadi workers of Borkamata”.
('89', 187, 0, 1, 327368) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 187, 1, 2, 327410) An English writer has observed that the history of cotton is the history of civilization.
('89', 187, 1, 3, 327500) Politics is the handmaid of commerce.
('89', 187, 1, 4, 327538) Indian history provides an apt illustration of it.
('89', 187, 1, 5, 327589) In the heyday of our cotton manufactures we used to grow all the cotton for our needs.
('89', 187, 1, 6, 327676) The cotton seed was fed to the cattle which provided health giving milk to the people.
('89', 187, 1, 7, 327763) Agriculture flourished.
('89', 187, 1, 8, 327787) The lint was turned into beautiful fabrics of which the jamdanis of Dacca were a specimen.
('89', 187, 1, 9, 327878) As an offshoot we had the worldfamed dyeing and printing art of Masulipatam.
('89', 187, 1, 10, 327955) Connoisseurs say that our old indigenous dyes could not be matched by any in the world for their permanence as well as brightness and beauty.
('89', 187, 1, 11, 328097) All that is gone now.
('89', 187, 1, 12, 328119) India is today naked.
('89', 187, 1, 13, 328141) We have to cover her nakedness.
('89', 187, 1, 14, 328173) If anybody could suggest a better substitute than the spinning wheel for the prupose I would discard the spinningwheel today.
('89', 187, 1, 15, 328299) But none has been found so far and I dare say none is likely to be found.
('89', 187, 1, 16, 328373) The question may however be asked: ‘How can the charkha bring India freedom when it could not prevent its loss ?’ The reply is that in the past charkha was not linked with the idea of freedom.
('89', 187, 1, 17, 328566) Nor did it then symbolize the power of non violence.
('89', 187, 1, 18, 328619) In olden days it symbolized our slavery.
('89', 187, 1, 19, 328660) We had not realized that our progress, prosperity and even freedom depended on the charkha or else we should have put up a fight and resorted to satyagraha to save it from destruction.
('89', 187, 1, 20, 328845) What was lost through our ignorance and apathy has now to be won back through intelligence and knowledge.
('89', 187, 1, 21, 328951) We have today ceased to think for ourselves.
('89', 187, 1, 22, 328996) The Government says that Bengal is a pauper province and we mechanically accept the statement.
('89', 187, 1, 23, 329091) To call a province which boasts 61 2 crores of population as pauper is only to proclaim our own intellectual bankruptcy.
('89', 187, 1, 24, 329212) Did not the Governor of Bengal observe in a broadcast talk 1 the other day that the cultivator in Bengal remains unemployed for six months in the year?
('89', 187, 1, 25, 329364) Can any population in the world subsist while remaining idle for half the year?
('89', 187, 1, 26, 329444) Even if all the water that the rains bring were captured and harnessed to irrigaion it would not keep the masses alive if their enforced unemployment for the better part of the year were not removed.
('89', 187, 1, 27, 329644) Our real malady is not destitution but laziness, apathy and inertia.
('89', 187, 1, 28, 329713) You may achieve marvels of irrigational engineering.
('89', 187, 1, 29, 329766) But wellfilled grana ries alone cannot and will not end our slavery.
('89', 187, 1, 30, 329835) To end slavery you must over come the mental and physical inertia of the masses and
('89', 187, 2, 31, 329919) 1 On December 8, 1945; vide also “Letter to R. G. Casey”, 8 12 1945
('89', 188, 0, 1, 329987) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 189
('89', 188, 1, 2, 330035) quicken their intelligence and creative faculty.
('89', 188, 1, 3, 330084) It is my claim that the universa lization of hand spinning with a full knowledge of all that it stands for alone can bring that about in a sub continent so vast and varied as India.
('89', 188, 1, 4, 330266) I have compared spinning to the central sun and the other village crafts to the various planets in the solar system.
('89', 188, 1, 5, 330383) The former gives light and warmth to the latter and sustains them.
('89', 188, 1, 6, 330450) With out it they would not be able to exist.
('89', 188, 2, 7, 330495) Q. If swaraj hangs on the thread of hand spun yarn, as you say, why have we failed to attain it up till now after a quarter of a century of khadi work ?
('89', 188, 3, 8, 330648) G. Because our labour was not quickened by knowledge.
('89', 188, 3, 9, 330702) The peace of the grave makes the latter the house of death.
('89', 188, 3, 10, 330762) But the peace in the soul makes it the seat of divine intelligence.
('89', 188, 3, 11, 330830) Similarly, soulless labour symbolizes serfdom Labour illumined with knowledge smy bolizes the will to freedom.
('89', 188, 3, 12, 330941) There is a world of difference between the two.
('89', 188, 3, 13, 330989) Khadi workers should understand that khadi work without the mastery of the science of khadi will be love’s labour lost in terms of swaraj.
('89', 188, 4, 14, 331128) Q. What do you mean by the science of spinning?
('89', 188, 4, 15, 331176) What things are included in it ?
('89', 188, 5, 16, 331209) G. I have often said that I can do without food but not without sacrificial spinning.
('89', 188, 5, 17, 331295) I have also claimed that no one in India has perhaps done his spinning with such unfailing regularity and conscientious diligence as I. And yet I will say that all that by itself cannot take the place of scientific knowledge.
('89', 188, 5, 18, 331521) Scientific knowledge requires constant probing into the why and wherefore of every little process that you perform.
('89', 188, 5, 19, 331637) Mere affirmation that in charkha there is swaraj and peace is not enough.
('89', 188, 5, 20, 331711) A scientific mind will not be satisfied with having things scientific just on faith.
('89', 188, 5, 21, 331796) He will insist on finding a basis in reason.
('89', 188, 5, 22, 331841) Faith becomes lame when it ventures into matters pertaining to reason Its field begins where reason’s ends.
('89', 188, 5, 23, 331949) Conclusions based on faith are unshakable whereas those based on reason are liable to be unstable and vulnerable to superior logic.
('89', 188, 5, 24, 332081) To state the limitation of science is not to belittle it.
('89', 188, 5, 25, 332139) We cannot do without either—each in its own place.
('89', 188, 5, 26, 332190) When I first discovered the spinning wheel it was purely through intuition.
('89', 188, 5, 27, 332266) It was not backed by knowledge so much so that I confused charkha with kargha, i.
('89', 188, 5, 28, 332348) e., handloom.
('89', 188, 5, 29, 332362) Later on, however, I tried to work out its possibilities with the help of the late Maganlal Gandhi.
('89', 188, 5, 30, 332462) For instance, the question arose: Why should the spindle be made of
('89', 189, 0, 1, 332530) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 189, 1, 2, 332572) iron, not brass?
('89', 189, 1, 3, 332589) Should it be thin or thick?
('89', 189, 1, 4, 332617) What would be the proper thickness?
('89', 189, 1, 5, 332653) We began with the mill spindles.
('89', 189, 1, 6, 332686) Then, spindle holders used to be bamboo and wood.
('89', 189, 1, 7, 332736) Later we came to leather and gut bearings.
('89', 189, 1, 8, 332779) It was found that spindles got easily bent and were difficult to straighten.
('89', 189, 1, 9, 332856) So we tried to make them out of knitting needles and ultimately of umbrellawires.
('89', 189, 1, 10, 332938) All this called for the exer cise of the inventive faculty and scientific research.
('89', 189, 1, 11, 333022) A khadi worker with a scientific mind will not stop there.
('89', 189, 1, 12, 333081) ‘Why the charkha, why not the spinning mill?’ he will ask himself.
('89', 189, 1, 13, 333148) The reply will be that everybody cannot own a spinning mill.
('89', 189, 1, 14, 333209) If people depend on spinning mills for their clothing, whoever controls the spinning mills will control them and thus there will be an end to individual liberty.
('89', 189, 1, 15, 333371) Today anyone can reduce the whole of London and New York to submission within 24 hours by cutting off their electric and water supply.
('89', 189, 1, 16, 333506) Individual liberty and interdependence are both essential for life in society.
('89', 189, 1, 17, 333585) Only a Robinson Crusoe can afford to be all self sufficient.
('89', 189, 1, 18, 333646) When a man has done all he can for the satisfaction of his essential requirements he will seek the co operation of neighbours for the rest.
('89', 189, 1, 19, 333786) That will be true co operation.
('89', 189, 1, 20, 333818) Thus a scientific study of the spinning wheel will lead on to sociology.
('89', 189, 1, 21, 333891) The spinning wheel will not become a power for the liberation of India in our hands unless we have made a deep study of the various sciences related to it.
('89', 189, 1, 22, 334047) It will then not only make India free but point the way to the whole world.
('89', 189, 1, 23, 334123) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has very aptly remaked that at one time India was not lacking in the inventive spirit but today it has become dormant.
('89', 189, 1, 24, 334266) Once one gets the scientific outlook it will be reflected in every act of his, in his eating, drinking, rest, sleep.
('89', 189, 1, 25, 334383) Everything will be scientifically regulated and with a full appreciation of its why and wherefore.
('89', 189, 1, 26, 334482) Finally, a scientific mind must have detachment or else it willl and itself into the lunatic asylum.
('89', 189, 1, 27, 334583) The Upanishad says that whatever there is in this universe is from Him.
('89', 189, 1, 28, 334655) It belongs to Him and must be surrendered to Him and then enjoyed.
('89', 189, 1, 29, 334722) Enjoyment and sorrow, success and failure will then be the same to you.
('89', 189, 1, 30, 334794) One thing more.
('89', 189, 1, 31, 334810) Supposing the tyrant wants to destroy the spinning wheel itself.
('89', 189, 1, 32, 334875) What then?
('89', 189, 1, 33, 334886) My reply is that in that event we should ourselves perish with the spinning wheel and not live to witness its destruction.
('89', 189, 1, 34, 335009) For every khadi worker who thus sacrifices himself thousands will arise to take his place.
('89', 189, 1, 35, 335100) The act of his will set the final seal of victory on the cause he represents.
('89', 189, 2, 36, 335178) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 13 1 1946, and Harijan, 31 3 1946
('89', 190, 0, 1, 335234) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 191
('89', 190, 1, 2, 335282) 266. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 190, 2, 3, 335312) January 6, 1946
('89', 190, 3, 4, 335328) Gandhiji emphasized what he had said 1 at Mahishadal about the observance of the general rule for attending a meeting.
('89', 190, 3, 5, 335447) He said that it was the common rule that nobody should enter the meeting place after it had begun and nobody should leave the meeting place during the continuance of the meeting.
('89', 190, 3, 6, 335626) Those who would violate this rule, Gandhiji emphasized, would disturb others.
('89', 190, 3, 7, 335704) Even if anybody did not find any interest in the meeting he should think of others who are in the meeting and not leave the meeting before it was concluded.
('89', 190, 3, 8, 335861) This was the common rule for every meeting and in the case of prayer meeting they should be more careful, because at the prayer they had to train their minds and concentrate on God.
('89', 190, 4, 9, 336043) Referring to the song that was sung at the prayer Gandhiji said that they should take the significance of the song to their hearts.
('89', 190, 4, 10, 336175) In the song Poet Rabin dranath said that he would not be frightened to see God coming to him in the form of misery.
('89', 190, 4, 11, 336291) In this connection Gandhiji would remind them of an English poem entitled “The Hound of Heaven” 2 in which God had been described as a huntsman pursuing the disciple continually.
('89', 190, 4, 12, 336470) God, Gandhiji explained, could not leave His devotee alone because He, who had created the world, was concerned about the world going in order.
('89', 190, 4, 13, 336614) So real misery came when they forgot God and happiness came when they kept God in them.
('89', 190, 5, 14, 336702) This 3 is also a kind of misery, but you should not feel like that.
('89', 190, 5, 15, 336770) At the Sabarmati Ashram which was at a short distance from the Station there was a person who took the vow of silence.
('89', 190, 5, 16, 336889) One day he told Gandhiji that he was greatly disturbed by the whistling train at the time of worship.
('89', 190, 5, 17, 336991) Gandhiji suggested to him to shut his ears with cotton or rubber to prevent the whistle disturbing him.
('89', 190, 5, 18, 337095) After a short time the man again came to Gandhiji and told him that he was no more in need of cotton or rubber because he had been trained to such a concentration of mind that no sound or whistle could enter his ears.
('89', 190, 5, 19, 337313) What Gandhiji would tell them was that they should not be perturbed when misery—in whatever shape or form—came to them.
('89', 190, 5, 20, 337433) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 7 1 1946
('89', 190, 6, 21, 337464) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 28 12 1945 2 By Francis Thompson 3 The reference is to the whistling of a train, which interrupted Gandhiji’s speech.

('89', 194, 5, 11, 341757) 275. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 194, 6, 12, 341787) SODEPUR, January 7, 1946
('89', 194, 7, 13, 341812) Gandhiji stressed the need for observance of the rules of cleanliness by every citizen.
('89', 194, 7, 14, 341900) He asked them to remember that cleanliness was next to Godliness and that if they could observe the rules of cleaniness they would be pure in their hearts also.
('89', 194, 8, 15, 342061) Gandhiji said that although he did not travel much during these days he had heard from his friends how the city streets were made dirty with the kernel of fruits, paper pieces and other useless things strewn over them.
('89', 194, 8, 16, 342280) It was also said that Calcutta had been dirty.
('89', 194, 8, 17, 342327) But he could tell them that if every citizen did his part and observed the rules of cleanliness then the face of Calcutta would be changed.
('89', 194, 9, 18, 342467) Gandhiji also exhorted them to apply the rules of cleanliness in other spheres of their lives as well.
('89', 194, 9, 19, 342570) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 8 1 1946

('89', 196, 8, 14, 345109) BHAI VALLABHBHAI Yesterday I sent you a telegram as follows : “God willing reach Bardoli 3rd March.” I very much wanted to come on the 1st but I see that that is not possible, for February has only 28 days and I must look in at Poona, for a few days at least, before going to Bardoli.
('89', 196, 8, 15, 345394) I have, therefore counted two days more so that I may arrange the programme as if the month had 30 days.
('89', 196, 8, 16, 345499) Having started the thing I must see it through.
('89', 196, 8, 17, 345547) I cannot in any circumstances tolerate misuse of money.
('89', 196, 8, 18, 345603) And if I take no interest Dinshaw cannot manage the new venture.
('89', 196, 8, 19, 345668) I will, therefore, quickly finish the work at Wardha, pay a brief visit to Poona, and then come to Bardoli and after that go back to Poona again.
('89', 196, 8, 20, 345814) This is what I have in mind at the moment.
('89', 196, 8, 21, 345857) I have already written something about the Parliamentary Delegation.
('89', 196, 8, 22, 345926) 1 We should not spurn it; on the other hand we should welcome it whole heartedly.
('89', 196, 8, 23, 346008) It is not necessary to get excited over it as people used to when such people arrived in the past.
('89', 196, 8, 24, 346107) We should not insult our guests in any manner whatesoever.
('89', 196, 8, 25, 346166) There is no need for Congressmen to decline the invitation if they are invited to
('89', 196, 9, 26, 346248) 1Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 3 1 1946

('89', 197, 1, 2, 346336) parties that may be held to honour the members of the delegation.

('89', 198, 7, 10, 348752) 281. LETTER TO G. E. B. ABELL
('89', 198, 8, 11, 348782) KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR (NEAR CALCUTTA), January 8, 1946

('89', 201, 1, 2, 353762) sari and lungi worth Rs. 10, Rs. 15, and Rs. 18 respectively are excluded from the operation of the Act.
('89', 201, 1, 3, 353867) My point is that khadi, i.e., hand spun and hand woven, or hand spun yarn should be excluded from all taxes.
('89', 201, 1, 4, 353976) Logically, hand woven cloth also, though woven from mill yarn, should be excluded for the tax hits the handloom weaver.
('89', 201, 1, 5, 354096) Therefore, the exclusion of dhoti, sari and lungi is of no help.
('89', 201, 1, 6, 354161) The revenue derived from khadi is altogether negligible.
('89', 201, 1, 7, 354218) The revenue derived from hand woven cloth is fair because hand woven cloth is large enough in quantity to yield some income to the treasury, but at the poor weaver’s expenese.
('89', 201, 1, 8, 354394) In taxing khadi, however, thousands of poor hand spinners are so hard hit that the tax becomes so deterrent as to be punitive.
('89', 201, 1, 9, 354521) I am quite certain that such was never the intention of the farmers of the Act.
('89', 201, 1, 10, 354601) The oversight has only to be brought to the notice of the Government to be remedied.
('89', 201, 1, 11, 354686) I may also mention that all the khadi depots of the All India Spinners’ Association are benevolent concerns.
('89', 201, 1, 12, 354795) The conductors are servants of the A. I. S. A. which according to the recent judgment of the Privy Council, has been held to be a benevolent institution, not liable to income tax.
('89', 201, 2, 13, 354975) Incidentally, I may mention that whilst fresh milk is excluded from the operation of the Act, all other forms of milk such as boiled milk, pasteurized milk, dahi, etc., are taxable under the Act.
('89', 201, 2, 14, 355171) The clause baffles me.

('89', 201, 2, 18, 355348) Assurance is said to have been given that six months after the cessation of hostilities the villages would be returned to the villagers.

('89', 201, 2, 20, 355556) At the time of evacuation, removal of merchandise was strictly prohibited.

('89', 203, 4, 8, 357780) She has been found to be suffering from severe anaemia.
('89', 203, 4, 9, 357836) It is because of this that her cough does not leave her.

('89', 203, 4, 11, 357977) Dr. Bidhan calls regularly and guides Sushilabehn.

('89', 203, 5, 27, 359032) 286. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('89', 203, 6, 28, 359060) January 9, 1946 Last night (Tuesday) was a terrible night for me.
('89', 203, 6, 29, 359126) The crowds at every station were unmanageable.
('89', 203, 6, 30, 359173) The shouts, although well meant, could not please me in my old age, if they ever pleased me before.
('89', 203, 7, 31, 359273) 1 For the text, vide “Telegram to Munnalal G. Shah”, 8 1 1946
('89', 204, 0, 1, 359335) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 205
('89', 204, 1, 2, 359383) For I know that swaraj is made of truer and sterner stuff.
('89', 204, 1, 3, 359442) They serve no uselful purpose.
('89', 204, 1, 4, 359473) In the beginning stages, when people out of fear were afraid to hear their own voice, shouts and slogans had a place, not today when we seem likely to achieve independence, maybe within a few months.
('89', 204, 1, 5, 359673) I was allowed last night no sleep except for what I could snatch in between stations.
('89', 204, 1, 6, 359759) I cannot repeat this performance for many days and hope to live to the age of one hundred and twenty five years.
('89', 204, 1, 7, 359872) Friends will now appreciate why I have hardened my heart against even a brief tour through East Bengal.
('89', 204, 1, 8, 359976) I would love to travel throughout Bengal but I know that for the sake of the common cause I must restrain myself and invite friends and co workers to do likewise.
('89', 204, 1, 9, 360139) Let them and people at large satisfy themselves with what service I can render without traveling as I used to before.
('89', 204, 1, 10, 360257) Let the leaders in the various places try to conciliate the populace surroun ding them and advise them to restrain from shouts and slogans and from jostling one another.
('89', 204, 1, 11, 360427) One vulgar and uncivilized practice must be given up.
('89', 204, 1, 12, 360481) There is the chain on every train to be used strictly in times of danger or accidents.
('89', 204, 1, 13, 360568) Any other use of it and the consequent stoppage of the train is not merely a punishable offence but it is a vulgar, thoughtless and even dangerous misues of an instrument devised for great emergancies.
('89', 204, 1, 14, 360770) Any such misuse is a social abuse which, if it becomes a custom, must result in a great public nuisance.
('89', 204, 1, 15, 360875) It is up to every lover of his country to issue a stern warning against such wanton abuse of a humanitarian device intended for public safety.
('89', 204, 1, 16, 361018) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 10 1 1946 and 11 1 1946
('89', 205, 0, 1, 361064) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 205, 1, 2, 361106) 287. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('89', 205, 2, 3, 361138) SAULKUCHI, January 9, 1946
('89', 205, 3, 4, 361165) Gandhiji said that he had noticed during the bhajan that some of the people had failed to keep time with the song, but that was pardonable.
('89', 205, 3, 5, 361305) He would like that this form of congregational prayer be adopted all over Hindustan.
('89', 205, 3, 6, 361390) He was told that women in Assam sang sweetly during their work, for example when they were spinning or weaving.
('89', 205, 3, 7, 361502) Gandhiji had noticed that women had not joined in today’s bhajan.
('89', 205, 3, 8, 361568) It might be that they were ashamed to sing in chorus, but Gandhiji told them that swaraj would not come until they gave up this feeling of shyness.
('89', 205, 4, 9, 361716) He was thankful to them for maintaining peace in the prayer meeting.
('89', 205, 4, 10, 361785) In a few months they might have swaraj and they wanted to have swaraj within a few months in a peaceful way.
('89', 205, 4, 11, 361894) But could they achieve swaraj if they went on shouting in season and out of season?
('89', 205, 4, 12, 361978) This would go to show that they did not possess the necessary discipline.
('89', 205, 5, 13, 362052) Mahatma Gandhi referred to the experience of his journey and the indisciplined behaviour of the people at some places.
('89', 205, 5, 14, 362171) He said this showed that the people had not yet fully imbibed the principle of non violence.
('89', 205, 5, 15, 362264) Indiscipline, he added, was only a variety of violence.
('89', 205, 5, 16, 362320) If 40 crores of people or even a major part of them had assimilated the message of truth and non violence which the Congress had been preaching for the last 25 years, India would have been free.
('89', 205, 5, 17, 362515) But that was no reason for despair or despondency.
('89', 205, 5, 18, 362566) To inculcate perfect discipline and non violence among forty crores of people was no joke.
('89', 205, 5, 19, 362657) It needed time.
('89', 205, 5, 20, 362673) Twenty five years were insufficient for such a tremendous task.
('89', 205, 5, 21, 362737) That was why he desired to live 125 years so that he might, with his own eyes, see the consummation of his own ideas.
('89', 205, 5, 22, 362855) But he could not hope to live up to that span of life unless the conditions attaching to it were fulfilled.
('89', 205, 5, 23, 362963) If these conditions were fulfilled not only he, but anybody even in a country like India where the average expectation of life was the lowest in the world could live up to that period.
('89', 205, 5, 24, 363148) It was clear, however, that if he exposed himself to experiences like that of last night his candle would be burnt out within a month.
('89', 205, 6, 25, 363283) Britishers, continued Gandhiji, might realize, as they were bound to one day, that they could not hold down an awakened people for all time with force of bayonets and therefore, decide to transfer power to them.
('89', 205, 6, 26, 363495) They (the people) would find themselves in a quandary in that event, if they had no discipline and organization.
('89', 205, 6, 27, 363608) He hoped that they would not allow themselves to be caught
('89', 205, 7, 28, 363667) 1 Held on the northen bank of the Brahmaputra.
('89', 205, 7, 29, 363714) The first two paragraphs are reproduced here from Amrita Bazar Patrika, 11 1 1946
('89', 206, 0, 1, 363796) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 207
('89', 206, 1, 2, 363844) napping like that.
('89', 206, 2, 3, 363863) There was no greater spell binder of peace than the name of God, said Gandhiji.
('89', 206, 2, 4, 363943) He had, therefore, commenced the practice of holding mass prayers and inviting people to join in singing Ramdhun to the beating of time with the hands, to inculcate in the masses the spirit of non violence and discipline.
('89', 206, 2, 5, 364165) He would love to see that the whole of India was covered with prayer gatherings like that.
('89', 206, 3, 6, 364256) The Hindu, 11 1 1946, and Amrita Bazar Patrika, 11 1 1946
('89', 206, 4, 7, 364314) 288. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('89', 206, 5, 8, 364342) GAUHATI, January 10, 1946 I have seen a report 1 in the Press wholly baseless, to the effect that I propose to give two days to Orissa before reaching Madras.
('89', 206, 5, 9, 364501) I would love, if I at all could, to give some days to Orissa and some days to Andhra.
('89', 206, 5, 10, 364587) But I know the limitations of My body.
('89', 206, 5, 11, 364626) It gives the work that it does from day to day to the utmost limit.
('89', 206, 5, 12, 364694) Therefore, I cannot break my journey either for Orissa or Andhra and I invite all friends and co workers in these two provinces to give their fullest co operation by telling people not to expect from me what seems to me to be impossible.
('89', 206, 5, 13, 364932) I do not know who is responsible for the report in question.

('89', 209, 1, 2, 367800) 293. LETTER TO ARTHUR HENDERSON
('89', 209, 2, 3, 367832) AS AT SEVAGRAM, “VIA” WARDHA, C.P., INDIA, CAMP: SARANIA ASHRAM, GAUHATI, January 10, 1946 Thank you for your letter received some days ago.
('89', 209, 2, 4, 367973) I have been busy with the annual session of the Women’s Conference and hence unable to acknowledge it earlier.
('89', 209, 2, 5, 368084) I am grateful to you for enquiring about the matters mentioned to you by me when we last met.
('89', 209, 2, 6, 368178) I do so wish all political prisoners could be released.
('89', 209, 2, 7, 368234) It would have a good effect.
('89', 209, 2, 8, 368263) What is more, it would be an act of justice though tardy.
('89', 209, 2, 9, 368321) I enclose a list of several prisoners who have done ten to fifteen years in jail.
('89', 209, 2, 10, 368403) This refers to Bengal only and then too the list is probably not exhaustive.
('89', 209, 2, 11, 368480) Some are in bad health.
('89', 209, 2, 12, 368504) Do you not agree that these should be released without delay ?
('89', 209, 2, 13, 368567) ARTHUR HENDERSON, ESQ.
('89', 209, 2, 14, 368590) UNDER SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA WHITE HALL LONDON From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('89', 209, 2, 15, 368673) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('89', 209, 2, 16, 368708) Courtesy: Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar

('89', 210, 6, 11, 369758) 296. LETTER TO PUSHPA K. DESAI
('89', 210, 7, 12, 369789) SARANIA ASHRAM, January 10, 1946
('89', 210, 8, 13, 369822) PUSHPA, I got your letter.
('89', 210, 8, 14, 369849) Keep meeting Vinobaji from time to time.
('89', 210, 8, 15, 369890) You should regard it as your dharma to write regularly cour teous letters to Father.
('89', 210, 8, 16, 369975) If you want to tread the path of truth, you should lovingly and in a spirit of humility do whatever work of service is entrusted to you.
('89', 210, 8, 17, 370112) If you understand only this much, all your pro blems will be sloved.
('89', 210, 8, 18, 370181) To say that God may lead you to this path of truth would be tautologous.
('89', 210, 8, 19, 370254) Truth itself is God.
('89', 210, 8, 20, 370275) Hence dedication to truth is itself discovery of the path of truth.
('89', 210, 8, 21, 370343) Reflect on all the impli cations of the path of bhakti from this point of view.

('89', 211, 6, 14, 371125) 298. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 211, 7, 15, 371155) GAUHATI, January 10, 1946
('89', 211, 8, 16, 371181) Gandhiji congratulated the gathering on the beautiful way in which they had followed Ramdhun.
('89', 211, 8, 17, 371275) Particularly he was pleased that women had whole heartedly joined in it without any feeling of false shame.
('89', 211, 8, 18, 371383) In taking the name of God, hesitation and fear as well as false shame were equally out of place.
('89', 211, 8, 19, 371480) The man who had the realization of God Who dwelt in the hearts of all beings should know no fear.
('89', 211, 9, 20, 371578) “Jai Hind” should not replace “Vandemataram”.
('89', 211, 9, 21, 371624) 1 The words which Subhas Bose uttered were very pleasant to hear.
('89', 211, 9, 22, 371690) But by this poeple should not forget Vandemataram which was being uttered since the inception of the Congress.
('89', 211, 9, 23, 371801) First, they should say “Vandemataram” and then “Jai Hind”.
('89', 211, 9, 24, 371860) He would whole heartedly return that greeting but it should not be to the exclusion of “Vandemataram”.
('89', 211, 9, 25, 371963) If they could discard “Vandemataram” which had such a tradition of sacrifice behind it, he was afraid they would one day discard “Jai Hind” also.
('89', 211, 10, 26, 372109) 1 The source had reported that Gandhiji was greeted by some girl volunteers with ‘Jai Hind’ as he arrived at the prayer ground.
('89', 212, 0, 1, 372237) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 213
('89', 212, 1, 2, 372285) Gandhiji reiterated his belief that Subhas Babu was not dead, but was hiding somewhere 1 and said that if he could communicate with Subhas Babu, he was sure the latter would endorse him in his view about “Vandemataram”.
('89', 212, 1, 3, 372505) The Hindu, 12 1 1946
('89', 212, 2, 4, 372526) 299. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('89', 212, 3, 5, 372558) GAUHATI, January 11, 1946
('89', 212, 4, 6, 372584) MUNNALAL, I got your wire.
('89', 212, 4, 7, 372611) Your decision not to come over is perfectly correct.
('89', 212, 4, 8, 372664) It was my dharma to send you the wire that I did.
('89', 212, 4, 9, 372714) I had explained to you what your dharma was at the time of your father’s death.
('89', 212, 4, 10, 372794) You have adhered to that.
('89', 212, 4, 11, 372820) May you be blessed.
('89', 212, 4, 12, 372840) I daily get news about Kanchan’s progress I am dictating this in the early hours of the morning.
('89', 212, 4, 13, 372937) I had a wire from Sushila yesterday, saying that Kanchan was improving.
('89', 212, 4, 14, 373009) She gives the credit to penicillin.
('89', 212, 4, 15, 373045) I believe that Sushila has nursed her very well indeed.
('89', 212, 4, 16, 373101) She has stayed behind entirely for the sake of Kanchan.
('89', 212, 4, 17, 373157) Let us see now what happens.
('89', 212, 4, 18, 373186) Perhaps this serious illness may bring about a complete transfor mation in Kanchan.
('89', 212, 4, 19, 373270) She is simple hearted but is very much of a child also.
('89', 212, 4, 20, 373326) As she grows in age, she does not correspondingly grow in understanding.
('89', 212, 4, 21, 373399) Can it be that you are the cause of that?
('89', 212, 4, 22, 373441) The people around us believe so, and hold me also jointly responsible with you.
('89', 212, 4, 23, 373521) I do not admit the charge.
('89', 212, 4, 24, 373548) But that is another matter.
('89', 212, 4, 25, 373576) I have men tioned the thing in case you would like to think over it.
('89', 212, 4, 26, 373645) Manibhai must have arrived there by now.
('89', 212, 4, 27, 373686) We had in any case decided to summon him there, and becuase of the development regarding Kanchan I felt it my dharma to send him there and asked him to proceed immediately if he was free.
('89', 212, 4, 28, 373874) I have had very little experience of him.
('89', 212, 4, 29, 373916) But Shantilal,who has lived at Sevagram for some time, and Ishvarlal Desai, husband of Nirmala, Mahadev’s sister, have given me the impression that he is a man of uncommon ability.
('89', 212, 4, 30, 374097) Narahari has had experience of him and seen his worth.
('89', 212, 4, 31, 374152) You will, therefore, find Manibhai of the greatest help.
('89', 212, 4, 32, 374209) He is a capable man at any rate.
('89', 212, 4, 33, 374242) I have been insisting on the account books being kept in English entirely for the sake of Jehangirji 2. If he is not keen on that,
('89', 212, 5, 34, 374373) 1Vide also “Discussion with Midnapore Political Workers”, 2 1 1946 2 Jehangir Patel
('89', 213, 0, 1, 374457) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 213, 1, 2, 374499) you may by all means have them kept in Hindi or Marathi.
('89', 213, 1, 3, 374556) Can it be so arranged that the months and the dates are entered according to the Gregorian calendar, so that Jehangirji can check them ?
('89', 213, 1, 4, 374693) You can show this letter to Dinshaw.
('89', 213, 1, 5, 374730) You may show him any letter of mine.
('89', 213, 1, 6, 374767) Give the accompanying letter to Manibhai.

('89', 213, 4, 10, 374962) 300. LETTER TO SITA CHARAN DIKSHIT
('89', 213, 5, 11, 374997) GAUHATI, January 11, 1946
('89', 213, 6, 12, 375023) BHAI DIKSHITJI, I have your clear letter.
('89', 213, 6, 13, 375065) It is good that you have written frankly.
('89', 213, 6, 14, 375107) I am dictating this also at a Mahila Ashram.
('89', 213, 6, 15, 375152) It is in Gauhati.
('89', 213, 6, 16, 375170) A camp of the Kasturba Fund is being held here.
('89', 213, 6, 17, 375218) On one side there is a village and on the other Gauhati city.
('89', 213, 6, 18, 375280) It is utterly peaceful.
('89', 213, 6, 19, 375304) It gave me satisfaction to know that the cereals which were used for the camp would be cooked as kedgeree.
('89', 213, 6, 20, 375411) It is quite true that I like garba and this I mentioned there.
('89', 213, 6, 21, 375474) In one way I liked the scene, but from another point of view I did not like it and felt sorry.
('89', 213, 6, 22, 375569) 1 I could not then express myself in words as I was deeply moved.
('89', 213, 6, 23, 375635) My heart has already in Bengal.
('89', 213, 6, 24, 375667) I can never say that there was anything wrong in what you did.
('89', 213, 6, 25, 375730) There was nothing wrong.
('89', 213, 6, 26, 375755) The whole scene was one of love and it was performed with my consent.
('89', 213, 6, 27, 375825) Even so I had some talk with Shriman Narayan.
('89', 213, 6, 28, 375871) But its purport was quite different.
('89', 213, 6, 29, 375908) I do not remember whether I was able to convey it or not.
('89', 213, 6, 30, 375966) But if I could not speak out then I am telling you now.
('89', 213, 6, 31, 376022) The Mahila Ashram is an institution of the poor.
('89', 213, 6, 32, 376071) It is born of a noble sentiment.
('89', 213, 6, 33, 376104) It is filled with Jamnalalji’s feelings and Vinobaji’s tapascharya.
('89', 213, 6, 34, 376172) It is regarded as a good means of rendering service to poor women.
('89', 213, 6, 35, 376239) And its manage ment is in the hands of Shantabehn.
('89', 213, 6, 36, 376290) And yet what a difference between what does on in such an institution and the almost naked
('89', 213, 7, 37, 376381) 1Vide “Speech at Mahila Ashram”, 30 11 1945
('89', 214, 0, 1, 376425) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 215
('89', 214, 1, 2, 376473) condition of the millions of poor women of India and Bengal.
('89', 214, 1, 3, 376534) And I being a witness to all this.
('89', 214, 1, 4, 376569) It wrung my heart then.
('89', 214, 1, 5, 376593) Even as I recall the scene, my heart weeps.
('89', 214, 1, 6, 376637) Even if I could not convey my meaning, Shriman understood it and conveyed it.
('89', 214, 1, 7, 376715) I dictate this early in the morning.
('89', 214, 1, 8, 376752) If it calls for further explanation, or if you want to know more, ask me when I come there.
('89', 214, 1, 9, 376844) You may share this letter with all.
('89', 214, 2, 10, 376880) Blessings from BAPU From Hindi: C.W. 10421. Courtesy: Sita Charan Dikshit

('89', 214, 7, 25, 377694) 302. LETTER TO DINSHAW K. MEHTA
('89', 214, 8, 26, 377726) SARANIA ASHRAM, January 11, 1946
('89', 214, 9, 27, 377759) DINSHAW, Chi.
('89', 214, 9, 28, 377773) Munnalal’s wife Kanchanbehn has been very ill, so I sent a wire saying that he should be relieved if he wanted to come away.
('89', 214, 9, 29, 377898) I assumed that someone would have to replace him there and so telegraphed to Sevagram also asking them to send M[anibhai], whom I regard as very competent.
('89', 214, 9, 30, 378054) He has promptly left for Poona.
('89', 214, 9, 31, 378086) I am glad I have been told that Manibhai is a very good worker.
('89', 214, 9, 32, 378150) I believe it.
('89', 214, 9, 33, 378164) I have hardly any personal experience of him.
('89', 214, 9, 34, 378210) You will have some.
('89', 215, 0, 1, 378230) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 215, 1, 2, 378272) I hope you received the Rs. 10,000 I sent you, so the new account will not suffer from paucity of funds.
('89', 215, 1, 3, 378377) The patients who were already there should adapt them selves to the new pattern.
('89', 215, 1, 4, 378458) They should mix with the poor.
('89', 215, 1, 5, 378489) Every one should be punctual to the minute.
('89', 215, 1, 6, 378533) Over and above this, you should accommodate them only if they pay or else let them leave.
('89', 215, 1, 7, 378623) This alone will be true comradeship.
('89', 215, 1, 8, 378660) We cannot any more allot separate rooms to the patients according to their wishes.
('89', 215, 1, 9, 378743) In fact for the present we cannot accommodate patients who need separate rooms.
('89', 215, 1, 10, 378823) I have already written to you to allow as much privacy as the patients may need.
('89', 215, 1, 11, 378904) I hope you remember it.
('89', 215, 1, 12, 378928) If you haven’t had such instructions from me so far, please make a note now.
('89', 215, 1, 13, 379005) Munnalal suggests that the English method of book keeping is more expensive.
('89', 215, 1, 14, 379082) I believe it is true.
('89', 215, 1, 15, 379104) How would it matter if we maintained accounts in the Indian style?
('89', 215, 1, 16, 379171) The Indian method can also ensure accurate account keeping.
('89', 215, 1, 17, 379231) Indian firms maintain accounts in the Indian way and carry on business in millions involving dealings with English banks.
('89', 215, 1, 18, 379353) And since our little affair is going to be and should be worthy of an Indian we ought to infuse into it the swadeshi atmosphere as far as possible right from the beginning.
('89', 215, 1, 19, 379526) Please show this letter to Jehangirji.
('89', 215, 1, 20, 379565) It was at his instance that we had agreed to maintain accounts in the English way.
('89', 215, 1, 21, 379648) But I believe, if opting for the English method is likely to cause an expenditure of Rs. 40 to 50 per month, Jehangirji would be in favour of saving the amount.
('89', 215, 1, 22, 379809) The money that I shall contribute must be regarded as belonging to the poor.
('89', 215, 1, 23, 379886) I may be getting it from the rich, but once it comes into my hands it becomes the poor man’s pie, to be spent solely for the poor.
('89', 215, 1, 24, 380017) All my dealings are carried on in the same old way and it pains me that now because of my old age I cannot fully follow that way, and I also put up with the situation because I cannot get on otherwise.
('89', 215, 1, 25, 380219) But I must not burden others with my foibles.
('89', 215, 1, 26, 380265) I hope you got my earlier letters, and have replied to them.
('89', 215, 1, 27, 380326) For the present save all avoidable expenditure.
('89', 215, 1, 28, 380374) I shall try my best to reach there on the 20th or the 21st of February.
('89', 215, 1, 29, 380446) It is in God’s hands whether I shall succeed.
('89', 215, 2, 30, 380492) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('89', 215, 2, 31, 380538) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('89', 216, 1, 2, 380605) 303. LETTER TO SUSHILA GANDHI
('89', 216, 2, 3, 380635) SARANIA ASHRAM, GAUHATI, [January 11, 1946] 1
('89', 216, 3, 4, 380681) SUSHILA (GANDHI), I saw what you wrote at the bottom of Arun’s 2 letter.
('89', 216, 3, 5, 380754) You will know from my letter to him how my mind is working.
('89', 216, 3, 6, 380814) You should not be soft.
('89', 216, 3, 7, 380838) There is a famous line in Kalidasa and, I think also in the Bhagavata.
('89', 216, 3, 8, 380909) It says that love is more tender than a flower and harder than steel.
('89', 216, 3, 9, 380979) 3 That alone is love which can soften or harden with the occasion, all else is infatuation.
('89', 216, 3, 10, 381071) Those who are worldly wise should also note that such famous sayings are often misconstrued.
('89', 216, 3, 11, 381164) There are many occasions when I remember all of you.
('89', 216, 3, 12, 381217) There are also occasions when there is a feeling of relief that you did not come.
('89', 216, 3, 13, 381299) The experience which you are gaining there and what Arun and Ila are witnessing is of course worth while.
('89', 216, 3, 14, 381405) Maybe, comparatively speaking that is better than anything else.
('89', 216, 3, 15, 381470) Ila for one was not likely to have imbibed anything in this place.
('89', 216, 3, 16, 381537) Hence, for her at least I regard this at mosphere as positively bad.
('89', 216, 3, 17, 381606) You needed peace.
('89', 216, 3, 18, 381624) You cannot expect to find peace in my company, especially while I am touring.
('89', 216, 3, 19, 381702) Arun’s can be considered a different case, yet on the whole he is likely to be safest while he is before your eyes.
('89', 216, 3, 20, 381818) He is a fine boy.
('89', 216, 3, 21, 381836) I am of the view that he will have achieved all if he grows finer and finer.
('89', 216, 3, 22, 381913) As for the other development everything happens in its own course.
('89', 216, 3, 23, 381980) And in the absence of nobility of character even the Kingdom of Heaven is meaningless.
('89', 216, 4, 24, 382067) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('89', 216, 4, 25, 382113) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('89', 218, 4, 8, 384072) 306. LETTER TO ARUN GANDHI
('89', 218, 5, 9, 384099) GAUHATI, January 11, 1946
('89', 218, 6, 10, 384125) ARUN, I have your letter.
('89', 218, 6, 11, 384151) I find it better than your earlier one, although it has scope for improvement, which you must bring about.
('89', 218, 6, 12, 384258) I would always advise you and it is my wish that wherever you be you will always fully observe your vow.
('89', 218, 6, 13, 384363) I can very well understand that there are difficulties while one is travelling.
('89', 218, 6, 14, 384443) It is also quite understandable that sometimes one just cannot spin however much one wants to.
('89', 218, 6, 15, 384538) I shouldn’t mind if you are not lazy but fail to spin owning to some unavoidable circumstances.
('89', 218, 6, 16, 384634) Thorough observance of one vow straightens out all other matters.
('89', 218, 6, 17, 384700) This is invariably found to be the case.
('89', 218, 6, 18, 384741) Why is Ila growing insolent.
('89', 218, 6, 19, 384770) As her elder brother, you are, I think, to blame for it.
('89', 218, 6, 20, 384827) She is a nice girl.
('89', 218, 6, 21, 384847) You can therefore help her make good progress.
('89', 218, 7, 22, 384894) Blessings from BAPU ARUN GANDHI DELHI

('89', 219, 2, 3, 385121) GAUHATI, January 11, 1946
('89', 219, 3, 4, 385147) PRABHU DAYAL, I was glad to have your letter.
('89', 219, 3, 5, 385193) I had seen your letter to Sushilabehn and I think she had sent a reply also.
('89', 219, 3, 6, 385270) It is right for you to remain there as long as they do not relieve you.
('89', 219, 3, 7, 385342) I shall pay your expenses, including your return fare.
('89', 219, 3, 8, 385397) Draw the amount from Devdas and that, too, from my account.
('89', 219, 3, 9, 385457) As long as Devdas is there, there should be no need to send it from the Ashram.
('89', 219, 3, 10, 385537) The Government have of course offered to pay for your journeys.
('89', 219, 3, 11, 385601) All this is only for your information.
('89', 219, 3, 12, 385640) The Delhi weather is considered to be the best during this season.
('89', 219, 3, 13, 385707) Normally, [good] climate and pure food are adequate for maintaining good health.
('89', 219, 3, 14, 385788) I understand about the Jamia.
('89', 219, 3, 15, 385818) It would indeed be good if they let you stay there.
('89', 219, 3, 16, 385870) Maybe they cannot for want of accommodation but if the reason is paucity of funds you can tell them that your expenses will be borne by the Ashram.
('89', 219, 3, 17, 386018) I am writing to Bhai Shriram.
('89', 219, 3, 18, 386048) It is good that you informed me.
('89', 219, 3, 19, 386081) From here, I shall reach Sodepur on the 14th and on the 19th.
('89', 219, 3, 20, 386143) I may leave there for Madras.
('89', 219, 3, 21, 386173) That means that a letter written to reach me by the 19th, should be sent to the Sodepur address.

('89', 220, 1, 2, 386448) 308. LETTER TO SHRIRAM SHARMA
('89', 220, 2, 3, 386478) [January 11, 1946] 1
('89', 220, 3, 4, 386499) BHAI SHRIRAMJI SHARMA, Prabhu Dayal writes that you lost a son while you were in jail and another after your release.
('89', 220, 3, 5, 386617) What can I write to you?
('89', 220, 3, 6, 386642) How can I console you?
('89', 220, 3, 7, 386665) But where is any call for consolation on a death?
('89', 220, 3, 8, 386715) Why fear death?
('89', 220, 3, 9, 386731) Is death painful?
('89', 220, 3, 10, 386749) And is birth joyful?
('89', 220, 3, 11, 386770) Why is it that great epics such as the Ramayana teach the same thing?
('89', 220, 3, 12, 386840) Because, on reflection, we find that birth and death are but two sides of the same thing.
('89', 220, 3, 13, 386930) What is there good or bad about it?
('89', 220, 3, 14, 386966) A world without death would be a frightful thing.
('89', 220, 3, 15, 387016) Maybe the world would then have peri shed.
('89', 220, 3, 16, 387059) All this is not philosophizing but an utterance of the thoughts that come to my mind.
('89', 220, 3, 17, 387145) Prabhu Dayal also writes that after meditation in the jail, your faith in truth and non violence has grown much stronger and that you and your whole family spin beautiful yarn.
('89', 220, 3, 18, 387322) All this makes me very happy.
('89', 220, 3, 19, 387352) My Assam tour will end tomorrow.
('89', 220, 3, 20, 387385) I intend to leave Calcutta for Madras on the 19th and February 8 is the date when I reach Sevagram.
('89', 220, 3, 21, 387485) My address in Madras: Dakshina Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha, Thyagarayanagar.
('89', 220, 3, 22, 387561) At Calcutta, it will of course be Khadi Pratishthan, Sodepur.
('89', 220, 3, 23, 387623) I shall expect your reply at either Place.
('89', 220, 4, 24, 387666) Blessings from BAPU SHRIRAM SHARMA BALKA BASTI NAGPUR
('89', 220, 5, 25, 387720) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.

('89', 222, 0, 1, 388871) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 223
('89', 222, 1, 2, 388919) 311. SPEECH AT KASTURBA MEMORIAL COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('89', 222, 2, 3, 388972) GAUHATI, January 11, 1946
('89', 222, 3, 4, 388998) Addressing the gathering, Gandhiji explained the aims and objects of Kasturba Memorial Trust which had been started 2 during the period when he was in jail.
('89', 222, 3, 5, 389155) Later on he lent a hand in framing the Trust of the Fund.
('89', 222, 3, 6, 389213) 3 The idea behind the whole scheme of Kasturba Trust had been to make women self reliant and self sufficient.
('89', 222, 3, 7, 389323) This did not mean that men would go down, but if womenfolk improved and raised themselves up, men would automatically be raised higher.
('89', 222, 3, 8, 389459) It is good that in India there were no quarrels between the menfolk and the womenfolk as existed in other countries.
('89', 222, 3, 9, 389576) But that did not mean that the condition of Indian women was better than those of European countries.
('89', 222, 3, 10, 389678) If the resources of Assam could be utilized, then the face of Assam could be changed.
('89', 222, 3, 11, 389764) So much time was wasted in useless and idle talk.
('89', 222, 3, 12, 389814) If they kept a diary of their work for the 24 hours, then they would know it.
('89', 222, 3, 13, 389892) If they could utilize only a portion of the time they wasted for constructive work, there would be a wonderful improvement in their condition.
('89', 222, 3, 14, 390035) In Assam muga industry was one through which people could change their conditions considerably and thus could do immense service to the cause of their country.
('89', 222, 4, 15, 390195) He knew that quite a number of ladies had come merely to see him.
('89', 222, 4, 16, 390261) But he could tell them that if they could devote all their strength to the execution of his constructive programme they would be immensely benefited.
('89', 222, 5, 17, 390411) Gandhiji emphasized that beauty lay not in ornaments or fine clothes but in doing something good and in applying oneself to doing some service to others.
('89', 222, 6, 18, 390565) Replying to certain questions, Gandhiji said that the relation between the Congress and the Kasturba Memorial Trust was nothing but at the same time everything.
('89', 222, 6, 19, 390726) If Congressmen took interest, the relation was there.
('89', 222, 6, 20, 390780) If not, there was no relation.
('89', 222, 7, 21, 390811) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 13 1 1946, and The Hindu, 13 1 1946
('89', 222, 8, 22, 390869) 1 This was held at Sarania Ashram to seek Gandhiji’s advice on uplift of women.
('89', 222, 8, 23, 390949) 2 On March 18, 1944 3 In 1944 4 What follows is reproduced from The Hindu, 13 1 1946.
('89', 223, 0, 1, 391035) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 223, 1, 2, 391077) 312. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 223, 2, 3, 391107) GAUHATI, January 11, 1946
('89', 223, 3, 4, 391133) Gandhiji said that prayer was his life.
('89', 223, 3, 5, 391173) He felt that the man who did not pray was a dry person, devoid of everything.
('89', 223, 3, 6, 391251) He did not know whether salvation could come in the other world.
('89', 223, 3, 7, 391316) He wanted salvation in this world, and did not bother about the other world.
('89', 223, 3, 8, 391393) As he was a social being he could not have salvation for himself alone.
('89', 223, 3, 9, 391465) That was why he wanted to share prayer with all of them.
('89', 223, 4, 10, 391522) Gandhiji was sorry that there was some misunderstanding about his going to the women’s ashram (a centre of constructive work in a tribal area about 20 miles from here).
('89', 223, 4, 11, 391691) He did not promise to go there, but a number of persons collected there and they were grieved as he did not go.
('89', 223, 4, 12, 391803) He wanted to tell them through the people here and to the whole of India as well, that he had not the capacity now to go from place to place in view of his old age.
('89', 223, 4, 13, 391968) He therefore wanted to work staying at one place.
('89', 223, 5, 14, 392018) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 12 1 1946
('89', 223, 6, 15, 392050) 313. LETTER TO HOSHIARI

('89', 223, 8, 17, 392101) HOSHIARI, I have your letter.
('89', 223, 8, 18, 392131) Why is your mind perturbed at times?
('89', 223, 8, 19, 392168) If you have grown wise enough there can be no cause for disturbance.

('89', 223, 8, 22, 392393) What more can you ask for?

('89', 225, 1, 2, 393654) 316. LETTER TO SIR STAFFORD CRIPPS
('89', 225, 2, 3, 393689) AS AT SEVAGRAM, VIA WARDHA (INDIA), CAMP: GAUHATI, January 12, 1946
('89', 225, 3, 4, 393757) DEAR SIR STAFFORD, I was delighted to receive your letter 1 of 19th December, 1945. As I am touring in Bengal and Assam, your kind greetings were received only yesterday.
('89', 225, 3, 5, 393928) The Rajkumari had described her talks with you and told me how affectionate you were towards me.
('89', 225, 3, 6, 394025) I am hoping that this time 2 there is determination to do the right thing in terms of Indian thought.
('89', 225, 3, 7, 394127) I well remember what King Edward had said about right dealing.
('89', 225, 3, 8, 394190) I was then in South Africa.
('89', 225, 3, 9, 394218) The question was of inter preting the treaty between the British and the Boers and the King had gently insisted on the Boer interpretation being accepted in preference to the British.
('89', 225, 3, 10, 394402) How I wish that the admirable canon be repeated this time.
('89', 225, 3, 11, 394461) I hope with you that this New Year will bring to the thirsting earth the much needed shower of peace and goodwill for which the “Prince of Peace” lived and died.
('89', 225, 4, 12, 394623) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SIR R. STAFFORD CRIPPS

('89', 227, 3, 10, 398009) 319. LETTER TO G. A. NATESAN
('89', 227, 4, 11, 398038) [AS AT] SODEPUR, January 12, 1946 BHAI NATESAN, Your two letters.
('89', 227, 4, 12, 398104) Jagadisan wrote to me about the state of Sas triar’s 1 health.
('89', 227, 4, 13, 398167) I shall certainly see him.
('89', 227, 4, 14, 398194) As for visiting your house, I am at present unable to decide.
('89', 227, 4, 15, 398256) Apart from the question whether I shall have the time for the purpose, the trouble of the journey to and fro may be too much for me to bear.
('89', 227, 4, 16, 398397) What can I—who have not read many books—say about books 2?
('89', 227, 4, 17, 398456) Again, do I have Sastriar’s power of writing?
('89', 227, 4, 18, 398502) It is said that few are as well read as he and that the books he has not read are not worth reading.
('89', 227, 4, 19, 398603) But I for my part have not read most of the books that ought to be read.
('89', 227, 4, 20, 398676) What then could I write?
('89', 227, 4, 21, 398701) And where is the time ?
('89', 227, 4, 22, 398725) Yours, M. K. GANDHI 3

('89', 228, 1, 2, 399166) 320. LETTER TO MARGARET BARR 1
('89', 228, 2, 3, 399197) January 12, 1946
('89', 228, 3, 4, 399214) DEAR MARGARET, You will pardon me when I tell you that I had forgotten—which I should not have done—that you were in Shillong.
('89', 228, 3, 5, 399341) I am going to Dhubri today and from there tomorrow I say goodbye to Assam.
('89', 228, 3, 6, 399416) Therefore, for the folly of my forgetfulness—and shall I also say your folly in not descending to Gauhati to meet me—I shall have to go away without seeing you even though you are within such a short distance of me.
('89', 228, 3, 7, 399632) However, it is good that you have reminded me of your presence in Shillong and told me how well you are doing there.
('89', 228, 3, 8, 399749) I am sure you have gained by following my instructions about not taking part in the political turmoil.
('89', 228, 3, 9, 399852) I have been hearing fairly regularly from Mary 2. I agree with you that she will return to India when your father does not need her services.
('89', 228, 3, 10, 399994) So far as I gather from her letters, however, she does not expect to come back to India in the near future.
('89', 228, 3, 11, 400102) It does appear as if there ever will be a time when your father will not need her services.
('89', 228, 3, 12, 400194) According to my calculation if the old Mr. Barr’s life is being spent in accordance with the teaching of Ishopanishad, he must complete the full span of life i.e., 125 years.
('89', 228, 3, 13, 400369) Have you read that little Upanishad?
('89', 228, 3, 14, 400406) If not you should get a copy from some library there or at least in Dr. B. C. Roy’s collection.
('89', 228, 3, 15, 400502) I suppose you know he has a bungalow there.
('89', 228, 3, 16, 400546) I shall be in Khadi Pratishthan, Sodepur, near Calcutta, for 4 or 5 days and then proceed to Madras.
('89', 228, 4, 17, 400647) BAPU MISS MARGARET BARR MALKI, SHILLONG

('89', 229, 2, 3, 400879) January 12, 1946
('89', 229, 3, 4, 400896) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 1 after a long lapse of time.
('89', 229, 3, 5, 400958) It appears to be a manifesto and you have invited publication of it.
('89', 229, 3, 6, 401027) I, however, refrain from sending it to the Press at the moment.
('89', 229, 3, 7, 401091) I would like to know from you whether you are allowed to receive visitors.
('89', 229, 3, 8, 401166) Goswami 2 has enquired about you to find out your whereabouts and suddenly within two days of this enquiry I got your letter.
('89', 229, 3, 9, 401292) Are you permitted to tell me whether you are to be tried or how long you are to be detained?
('89', 229, 3, 10, 401385) From your letter I gather that you are keeping well and are being well treated.
('89', 229, 3, 11, 401465) Are you kept in company with others or are you by yourself?
('89', 229, 3, 12, 401525) Your friends and advisers would certainly like to know all about you.
('89', 229, 4, 13, 401595) Yours sincerely,

('89', 232, 1, 2, 405313) 326. TALK TO HARIJANS 1
('89', 232, 2, 3, 405337) GAUHATI, January 12, 1946
('89', 232, 3, 4, 405363) He enquired about their wages, their accommodation and their food supply.
('89', 232, 3, 5, 405437) When his attention was drawn to the next engagement, which was a meeting with sufferers of the August movement, Gandhiji was heard to say that he would also meet 2
('89', 232, 4, 6, 405601) them now.
('89', 232, 4, 7, 405611) They were martyrs and many people would feel for them, but nobody would feel for these Harijans.
('89', 232, 5, 8, 405708) Referring to the condition of the Harijans he said that he knew how they lived and what they ate.
('89', 232, 5, 9, 405806) Their condition was almost similar to what it was in other parts of India.
('89', 232, 5, 10, 405881) Gandhiji asked two headmen of the Harijans to wait and see Mrs. Jayaprakash Narayan and give her a detailed account of their condition.
('89', 232, 5, 11, 406017) He would try to do what he could for them.

('89', 232, 10, 20, 406516) 328. SPEECH AT POLITICAL WORKERS’ CONFERENCE 3
('89', 232, 11, 21, 406563) GAUHATI, January 12, 1946
('89', 232, 12, 22, 406589) Explaining the scope of the constructive programme to them Gandhiji by way of an illustration described how a capital expenditure of about twenty five lakhs of rupees had been able to put into the pockets of the poor a sum amounting to not less
('89', 232, 13, 23, 406834) 1 Gandhiji met about four hundred Harijans at Sarania Ashram.
('89', 232, 13, 24, 406896) 2 Vide the following item.
('89', 232, 13, 25, 406923) 3 About seven hundred workers were present at the meeting.
('89', 233, 0, 1, 406982) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 233, 1, 2, 407024) than five crores of rupees.
('89', 233, 1, 3, 407052) Indian cloth consumption, he said, amounted to about one hundred crores of rupees according to the present price level.
('89', 233, 1, 4, 407172) All that money can be prevented from going out of the pockets of the people by fulfilling one item of the constructive programme, namely, khadi.
('89', 233, 2, 5, 407317) With regard to parliamentary programme Gandhiji reiterated what he had previously said 1 at Sodepur.
('89', 233, 2, 6, 407418) He was fully convinced that if all the people boycotted the legislatures, the country or the nation would not be losers by that.
('89', 233, 2, 7, 407547) On the contrary, Gandhiji stressed that it would mean a great addition to their strength.
('89', 233, 2, 8, 407637) But he realized that was not practical politics at present and as a realist he realized the necessity of preventing self seekers and enemies of the freedom of India from entering the legislatures.
('89', 233, 2, 9, 407834) The main function of the legislatures should be the advancement of constructive work.
('89', 233, 2, 10, 407920) Any programme that hindered constructive work was not worth taking up.
('89', 233, 2, 11, 407991) As an illustration of constructive work Gandhiji mentioned the services to Adivasis.
('89', 233, 2, 12, 408076) Today, he said, they had been divided into water tight compartments by the ruling power and that was why Adivasis had been classified as tribal races.
('89', 233, 2, 13, 408227) It was a shame that they should be isolated from the nation of which they were an inalienable part.
('89', 233, 2, 14, 408327) Here was a vast field of constructive work which Gandhiji exhorted all to take up.
('89', 233, 2, 15, 408410) Nobody could prevent them from undertaking this kind of constructive work.
('89', 233, 2, 16, 408485) And if for undertaking constructive work they were put in jail, they should not be afraid of jail going.
('89', 233, 2, 17, 408590) In this connection Gandhiji referred to his own stand in the Champaran Satyagraha.
('89', 233, 3, 18, 408673) In the course of his long and convincing speech Gandhiji made references to the names of Abbas Tyabji, Badshah Khan and Pandit Jawaharlal in order to illustrate his points by concrete examples.
('89', 233, 4, 19, 408867) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 14 1 1946
