('89', 234, 1, 2, 409246) 330. LETTER TO VICHITRA NARAYAN SHARMA
('89', 234, 2, 3, 409285) ON THE STEAMER, January 13, 1946
('89', 234, 3, 4, 409318) VICHITRA, I have your letter of 26 12 1945. Come and see me by all means.
('89', 234, 3, 5, 409392) Consult Dada if you want.
('89', 234, 3, 6, 409418) I see that you and Jajuji do not get on well.
('89', 234, 3, 7, 409464) I am unable to make up my mind whether I should try to persuade you to keep together or let you work independently in your different ways.
('89', 234, 3, 8, 409603) Either course can be justified.
('89', 234, 3, 9, 409635) What harm could there be if you were to work independently of the Charkha Sangh?
('89', 234, 3, 10, 409716) You are both devoted to khadi.
('89', 234, 3, 11, 409747) It is possible that under Jajuji’s control, the Meerut Gandhi Ashram’s progress is arrested and they cannot work to their full capacity.
('89', 234, 3, 12, 409884) If it is so and if Jawaharlalji and Pantji are also of the same opinion, why not have a separate organization for khadi in the U. P.?
('89', 234, 3, 13, 410018) Assuming that it is done for the love of khadi and if, as a result, khadi is more successful in the U. P., such a step would only do good instead of harm.
('89', 234, 3, 14, 410173) There have been many instances in my life when I gave such encouragement and it always resulted in good.
('89', 234, 3, 15, 410278) The latest instance is that of the Hindi Sahitya sammelan.
('89', 234, 3, 16, 410337) I quit it.
('89', 234, 3, 17, 410348) How could I oppose Tandonji?
('89', 234, 3, 18, 410377) He had the main part in building up the organization.
('89', 234, 3, 19, 410431) I do not approve of his present policies and feel that I would be able to serve Hindi well, perhaps even better, by keeping out of it.
('89', 234, 3, 20, 410566) In case it does not turn out so, I shall admit my mistake and follow Tandonji.
('89', 234, 3, 21, 410645) But if I have not made a mistake, I shall only further the cause of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan from outside.
('89', 234, 3, 22, 410754) The important point is that our actions should not be inspired by selfish motives and our ultimate aim should be one and the same.
('89', 234, 3, 23, 410885) Maybe I should be able to make a definite statement if I could meet all the people.
('89', 234, 3, 24, 410969) Think well over this letter, consult the others and write to me what you think is the proper course of action.
('89', 234, 3, 25, 411080) I shall reach Madras probably on the 21st and shall stay there for 15 days.
('89', 234, 3, 26, 411156) You may come there if you like.
('89', 234, 3, 27, 411188) Jajuji will of course be there.
('89', 234, 3, 28, 411220) You need not go there immediately I arrive.
('89', 234, 3, 29, 411264) We can manage even if you come in the beginning of February.
('89', 234, 3, 30, 411325) My sole intention is that all khadi devotees should make all round progress and khadi should get its rightful place.
('89', 234, 3, 31, 411442) Of course, if you do not sincerely believe in non violence, do
('89', 235, 0, 1, 411505) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 235, 1, 2, 411547) not consider khadi its symbol and have no faith in my present policy with regard to khadi, then it is a different matter.
('89', 235, 1, 3, 411669) When our views differ to such an extent, the question assumes a wholly different form.
('89', 235, 1, 4, 411756) And if, while maintaining different views with regard to the above three points you still want to serve khadi, you must dissociate yourself from the Sangh.
('89', 235, 1, 5, 411912) Then the question is not one of differences with Jajuji but of differences over principle, and if that be the case they ought to be cleared up.
('89', 235, 2, 6, 412056) Blessings from BAPU
('89', 235, 3, 7, 412076) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.
('89', 235, 3, 8, 412119) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('89', 236, 2, 11, 413442) 333. INTERVIEW TO UNITED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('89', 236, 3, 12, 413484) [January 13, 1946]
('89', 236, 4, 13, 413503) Asked whether the cry of Jai Hind could be appropriately adopted in a non violent action since originally it was devised by Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose as a war cry, Mahatma Gandhi said : It does not follow that because Jai Hind was devised by Subhas Babu as a war cry in armed warfare, it must be eschewed in a non violent action.
('89', 236, 4, 14, 413834) On that basis even Vandemataram may have to be given up because there are instances of people committing violence with this cry on their lips.
('89', 236, 4, 15, 413977) If a thing is essentially an evil it becomes a positive duty to abjure it In my opinion Jai Hind and Vandemataram have almost the same meaning.
('89', 236, 4, 16, 414121) In one we make obeisance to Mother India and thereby wish her victory; the other merely wishes her victory.
('89', 236, 4, 17, 414229) There is no question of singing the two together.
('89', 236, 4, 18, 414279) As I have said 2 before Jai Hind cannot replace Vandemataram.
('89', 236, 5, 19, 414341) Asked whether Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose enjoyed the same place in his esteem and affection and whether he heard what Netaji and written about him in his reported book Father of All Nations, as was believed in some sections of the people of Assam, Gandhiji replied : I have not read what Subhas Babu is reported to have said about me.
('89', 236, 5, 20, 414676) But I am not surprised at what you tell me.
('89', 236, 5, 21, 414720) My relations with him were always of the purest and best.
('89', 236, 5, 22, 414778) I always knew his capacity for
('89', 236, 6, 23, 414809) 1 Gandhiji was interviewed by a special correspondent of U. P. I. aboard the steamer Persian which he boarded at Gauhati in the evening of January 12 for going to Dhubri where he arrived on January 13, 1946. 2 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 10 1 1946
('89', 237, 0, 1, 415062) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 237, 1, 2, 415104) sacrifice.
('89', 237, 1, 3, 415115) But a full knowledge of his resourcefulness, soldiership and organizing ability came to me only after his escape from India.
('89', 237, 1, 4, 415240) The difference of outlook between him and me as to the means is too well known for comment.
('89', 237, 1, 5, 415332) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 15 1 1946
('89', 237, 2, 6, 415364) 334. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 237, 3, 7, 415394) GOALPARA, January 13, 1946
('89', 237, 4, 8, 415421) Gandhiji reiterated that there could be no non violent swaraj which was but another name for Ramarajya except through the charkha.
('89', 237, 4, 9, 415552) His definition of Ramarajya was that under it even the weakest must enjoy the same freedom and same rights as the strongest.
('89', 237, 4, 10, 415677) For that it was necessary that even the physically weakest person shold be able to take due share in the struggle for independence.
('89', 237, 4, 11, 415809) In other words, women and children should be able to play an equal part with men.
('89', 237, 4, 12, 415891) It was clear that this was not possible in armed warfare.
('89', 237, 5, 13, 415949) Gandhiji’s reading of India’s history was that every time the people made use of armed forces for their protection it only resulted in tightening their bondage.
('89', 237, 5, 14, 416110) The so called protectors in their turn, Gandhiji added, became oppressors.
('89', 237, 5, 15, 416185) But under non violence as symbolizesd by the spinning wheel, men and women enjoyed absolute parity in the fight for freedom.
('89', 237, 5, 16, 416310) The condition was that every thread of yarn that they spun should be a conscientious sacrifice or yajna for swaraj and it should be backed by the determination to resist with their lives any assault that might be directed against charkha.
('89', 237, 5, 17, 416549) By charkha, he meant not hand spinning alone but all those things which hand spinning symbolized.
('89', 237, 5, 18, 416647) These included the revival of all other village industries, of course, but it included all the various other items of his 18 point constructive programme as well.
('89', 237, 5, 19, 416810) By way of illustration Gandhiji mentioned communal harmony and total abolition of untouchability, both of which were natural corollaries of ahimsa.
('89', 237, 5, 20, 416958) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 15 1 1946

('89', 248, 1, 2, 432889) peacefully, we can hear the inner voice then.
('89', 248, 2, 3, 432935) Government must be alive to their duties regarding these two incidents but at the same time the people should not forget theirs.
('89', 248, 2, 4, 433064) The bhajan sung at the prayer on Monday (Antar mama vikasita karo) indicated the way.
('89', 248, 2, 5, 433150) It was a prayer to open our hearts.
('89', 248, 2, 6, 433186) The world would become a vast fraternity if that was done.
('89', 248, 3, 7, 433245) Gandhiji said that if he were there at Diamond Harbour, he would have advised the men and women not to go there.
('89', 248, 3, 8, 433358) He had witnessed a similar instance at Kumbha Mela at Hardwar in 1915, when in the jostle for a dip in the Ganges, 17 men were drowned.
('89', 248, 3, 9, 433494) At Diamond Harbour the pilgrims had to get on the jetty and the Government should have made proper shipping arrangements.
('89', 248, 3, 10, 433616) However, even if the Government did not do their duty an accusation on that score would not help us.
('89', 248, 3, 11, 433717) The people on their side should follow the right course.
('89', 248, 3, 12, 433774) The Govern ment could not be blamed for the incident at Hardwar.
('89', 248, 3, 13, 433839) Here of course it could be found on enquiry that proper arrangement for shipping facilities had not been made.
('89', 248, 4, 14, 433950) At Chittagong, it was worse.
('89', 248, 4, 15, 433979) People had read the Government account and it was an admission of the story as sent out by Jaminibabu.
('89', 248, 4, 16, 434082) But the people, Gandhiji said, did not play their part as preached in the bhajan.
('89', 248, 4, 17, 434164) The bhajan wanted to make us firm, active and fearless.
('89', 248, 4, 18, 434220) Gandhiji felt sure that if the people could rely on these qualities, the Chittagong incident could not have taken place.
('89', 248, 4, 19, 434341) If people could sing the bhajan as they did in the prayer, why could they not act according to its message, he asked.
('89', 248, 4, 20, 434459) Gurudev’s words were not meant for Bengal only.
('89', 248, 4, 21, 434507) Everywhere saints had preached the same message.
('89', 248, 5, 22, 434556) An Englishman had sardonically asked Gandhiji if the Indians could get independence by harping on the theme of their slavery.
('89', 248, 5, 23, 434682) Gandhiji thought that the remark was true.
('89', 248, 5, 24, 434725) No good could come out of repeating the fact of dependence.
('89', 248, 5, 25, 434785) Slave people lived in eternal misery and only by working for eradicating this misery could they get swaraj.
('89', 248, 5, 26, 434893) Only criticism could not make foreigners quit.
('89', 248, 5, 27, 434940) If people realized the message of satyagraha, if they practised it in life, they could get rid of this misery.
('89', 248, 5, 28, 435051) What was satyagraha?
('89', 248, 5, 29, 435072) It was only the craving for truth inherent in man and there lay its strength.
('89', 248, 6, 30, 435150) Two women were attacked at Chittagong and for that two men were counter attacked.
('89', 248, 6, 31, 435232) As a result a hundred came, attacked the villagers and burnt the hamlet.
('89', 248, 6, 32, 435305) If the people could rest firm on truth such an incident could never happen.
('89', 248, 6, 33, 435381) He had subsequently learnt, Gandhiji said, that the rowdy elements were his countrymen and therefore brothers.
('89', 248, 6, 34, 435492) If that was so he also had some responsibility for their action and it was his duty as well to strive for the eradication of their vile instincts.

('89', 256, 4, 15, 447938) 364. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 256, 5, 16, 447968) SODEPUR, January 17, 1946
('89', 256, 6, 17, 447994) Gandhiji said that Friday 2 would be his last day at Sodepur on this occasion.
('89', 256, 6, 18, 448073) He had always cherished a desire to stay in this place and join them in prayer.
('89', 256, 6, 19, 448153) Indeed he had not been able to stay there continuously owing to his tours.
('89', 256, 6, 20, 448228) His tours had produced good results.
('89', 256, 6, 21, 448265) He hoped that they would stick to the system of congre gational prayer.
('89', 256, 7, 22, 448337) Exhorting them to sing the name of God in chorus and to keep tune with all heart, Gandhiji said that he had told them before and wanted to tell them now that soldiers were compelled to move together and to keep step in marching.
('89', 256, 7, 23, 448566) At first there was an element of compulsion in making them do so but gradually as they became habituated the element of compulsion passed and their movements became easier and smoother.
('89', 256, 7, 24, 448752) In their case the soldiers were made disciplined on pain of dismissal, but in prayer although they were the devotees of God yet there was no question of compelling them to keep or sing in chorus.
('89', 256, 7, 25, 448948) But it was for the sake of their own good that they joined in prayer and if they uttered the name of God in one tune their hearts
('89', 256, 8, 26, 449078) 1 This, however, is not traceable.
('89', 256, 8, 27, 449113) 2 January 18
('89', 257, 0, 1, 449126) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 257, 1, 2, 449168) would be purified and they would get new strength in their hearts.
('89', 257, 1, 3, 449235) This would be their remuneration for becoming the devotees of God.
('89', 257, 2, 4, 449302) Referring to the day’s bhajan, Gandhiji said that in this song the devotee was making the submission that he would offer his salutation to God in all his worldly duties.
('89', 257, 2, 5, 449472) God was their real friend, He was their father and mother and in fact everything.
('89', 257, 2, 6, 449554) Their earthly friends and relations suffered death but God was immortal.
('89', 257, 2, 7, 449627) He never left them at any time.
('89', 257, 2, 8, 449659) The bhajan therefore very aptly taught them to remember God who was their eternal friend in every sphere of their life’s activities.
('89', 257, 2, 9, 449792) The song also told them to keep their inward eye open because it was through this inward eye that they were able to perceive God.
('89', 257, 3, 10, 449922) Concluding, Gandhiji said that in the prayer song of the day they had found such things which would be of great value in their everyday life.
('89', 257, 3, 11, 450064) They should take the teachings of the song to heart.
('89', 257, 3, 12, 450117) After they had attended the prayer if they returned home with their hearts unchanged they would be deprived of a great thing.
('89', 257, 3, 13, 450243) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 18 1 1946

('89', 258, 2, 6, 451482) 367. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('89', 258, 3, 7, 451512) SODEPUR, January 18, 1946
('89', 258, 4, 8, 451538) Gandhiji regretted that he was addressing the congregation for the last time on the present occasion and God only knew when he would be in position to repeat his visit to Bengal.
('89', 258, 4, 9, 451717) He had a mind to go to Chittagong and also to visit Munshigunj but he could not realize his wish.
('89', 258, 4, 10, 451815) Mahatma Gandhi observed : Although during my stay I could not visit the different parts of Bengal as I wished, still I will say that I am satisfied with what little I could do in Bengal.
('89', 258, 4, 11, 452002) My code teaches me to be satisfied even if I succeed in one front out of ten I try.
('89', 258, 5, 12, 452086) Referring to the Chittagong incident, Gandhiji said that there was no point in finding fault with others over this issue.
('89', 258, 5, 13, 452208) They had to analyse themselves.
('89', 258, 5, 14, 452240) They should remember that in always finding fault with others they themselves were likely to be at fault.
('89', 258, 5, 15, 452346) If the habit of fault finding became a permanent feature with them they would never be able to serve anybody.
('89', 258, 5, 16, 452456) Tulsidas in his inimitable way made it quite clear that there were no animate or inanimate objects which were either totally evil or totally good.
('89', 258, 5, 17, 452603) Those two qualities more or less were to be noticed in everything and just like the proverbial swan they had to discard the evil of a thing and adopt the good of it for their own welfare.
('89', 258, 5, 18, 452791) He asked the people to remember this moral sermon of the poet and conduct themselves accor dingly.
('89', 258, 5, 19, 452890) If they concentrated only on black spots they would themselves be spotted.
('89', 258, 5, 20, 452965) Therefore, for one’s own welfare it was desirable that the habit of fault finding be given up.
('89', 258, 5, 21, 453060) In China there was a pillar on which three monkeys were carved in stone: one of them was blindfolded, the second ear logged and the third close mouthed.
('89', 258, 5, 22, 453213) The moral of this illustration was ‘see no evil, hear no evil and speak no evil’.
('89', 258, 5, 23, 453295) He urged upon the congregation to take to heart what this Chinese symbol taught them.
('89', 258, 6, 24, 453381) Dwelling upon the necessity of congregational prayer, Gandhiji hoped that people on return to their homes would conduct such prayer in the company of the members of the family and children.
('89', 258, 6, 25, 453571) Theatres or cinemas they often visited, but those agencies could scarcely benefit the people to the extent the congregational prayer could do.
('89', 258, 6, 26, 453714) He himself had been to a famous theatre in London and could speak from his personal experience that it hardly benefited him.
('89', 258, 6, 27, 453839) Comparing the benefit
('89', 259, 0, 1, 453861) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 259, 1, 2, 453903) of congregational prayer with what little historical knowledge a dramatic perfor mance could offer, Gandhiji said that the former was many thousand times more beneficial.
('89', 259, 1, 3, 454074) What could the stage teach, he asked.
('89', 259, 1, 4, 454112) Was it of any consequence when compared with the realistic drama that the world presented?
('89', 259, 1, 5, 454203) He had seen the role of a hero being played on the stage.
('89', 259, 1, 6, 454261) Could Rama of his conception be played on the stage?
('89', 259, 1, 7, 454314) Could the tragedy on any stage be so realistic and effective as the tragedies they witnessed on the world stage?
('89', 259, 1, 8, 454427) Mothers were ministering angels of homes and they nursed children to life and to them he especially appealed to introduce God and divinity to their children and to introduce bhajan song which was full of eternal bliss.

('89', 260, 1, 2, 455268) 370. LETTER TO SUCHETA KRIPALANI
('89', 260, 2, 3, 455301) SODEPUR, January 19, 1946
('89', 260, 3, 4, 455327) SUCHETA, Your letter written from Allahabad is before me.
('89', 260, 3, 5, 455385) I am dictating this after the morning prayer.
('89', 260, 3, 6, 455431) At 2·30 p.m.
('89', 260, 3, 7, 455444) today, I leave for Madras.
('89', 260, 3, 8, 455471) Your report is good.
('89', 260, 3, 9, 455492) I have written to Bapa regarding the Delhi case as well as the question of representation.
('89', 260, 3, 10, 455583) I am inclined to think that if we just wait till we find a suitable Agent for a place, meanwhile getting the work done through the centre, no problem should arise in the appointment of women Agents.
('89', 260, 3, 11, 455782) Therefore, I am of the opinion that we may take any kind of work from Brijkrishna.
('89', 260, 3, 12, 455865) We should not formally appoint him an Agent.
('89', 260, 3, 13, 455910) If the idea does not appeal to either or both of you I shall be ready to do as you suggest.
('89', 260, 3, 14, 456002) This has been my policy regarding any activity that I am not conducting myself and I am convinced that it is right.
('89', 260, 3, 15, 456118) Therefore, send me your own opinion.
('89', 260, 3, 16, 456155) About the U.P., I am carrying on correspondence with Purnima.
('89', 260, 3, 17, 456217) No decision has yet been reached.
('89', 260, 3, 18, 456251) Concerning the appointments another question had now arisen, viz., whether anyone contesting election to the Assembly can continue to be an Agent.
('89', 260, 3, 19, 456398) We have three or four such cases—those of Durgabai, the sister from Calicut (I forget her name), Rameshwaridevi and probably Purnima too.
('89', 260, 3, 20, 456536) I feel that it would indeed be difficult, if not impossible, for those going into the Assembly, to do full justice to their work as Agents.
('89', 260, 3, 21, 456676) Besides, the mere knowledge that their Agents are members of the Assembly is likely to perturb the village women.
('89', 260, 3, 22, 456790) Do send me your views in the matter.
('89', 260, 3, 23, 456827) Are you coming to Madras?
('89', 260, 3, 24, 456853) Bapa is coming.
('89', 260, 3, 25, 456869) You may also come.
('89', 260, 3, 26, 456888) If you come I shall arrange for your accommodation.
('89', 260, 4, 27, 456940) Blessings from BAPU SHRIMATI SUCHETA KRIPALANI SWARAJ BHAVAN ALLAHABAD

('89', 261, 2, 3, 457147) SODEPUR, January 19, 1946
('89', 261, 3, 4, 457173) MUNNALAL, These days I am kept extremely busy.

('89', 261, 3, 6, 457294) They contained nothing special.

('89', 261, 3, 10, 457467) I cannot do more from here.

('89', 261, 3, 12, 457554) I will see about the khadi after I return.

('89', 261, 3, 18, 457916) Every language has some words which are untranslatable.
('89', 261, 3, 19, 457972) Vevala is such a word.
('89', 261, 3, 20, 457995) I am not reprimanding you at all.
('89', 261, 3, 21, 458029) This is only a joke.
('89', 261, 3, 22, 458050) I actually gave you an opportunity to come, if you wished to.
('89', 261, 3, 23, 458112) Kanchan is better now.

('89', 261, 3, 25, 458206) I am leaving today for Madras.
('89', 261, 3, 26, 458237) It is not certain whether or not I shall take Kanchan with me.
('89', 261, 3, 27, 458300) Dr. Bidhan has had an X ray taken.
('89', 261, 3, 28, 458335) If the report is good, Sushilabehn says I can take her.
('89', 261, 3, 29, 458391) She has not yet been permitted to walk.
('89', 261, 3, 30, 458431) My reason for sending Manibhai was that if such an occasion should arise again, you should be able to leave the place immediately.
('89', 261, 3, 31, 458562) Manibhai, therefore, was to get trained by you even if you had not left.
('89', 261, 3, 32, 458635) But what has happened has happened.
('89', 261, 3, 33, 458671) One thing is certain, namely, that Kanchan was looked after with as much care as would be bestowed on an Emperor.
('89', 261, 3, 34, 458785) And she got a doctor, too, such as only an Emperor could get.

('89', 261, 3, 37, 458908) Kanchan is accompanying me.

('89', 263, 1, 2, 461044) November 3, 1945 He alone who truly serves is a good householder.

('89', 270, 1, 2, 470811) 375. FOREWORD TO “MY MASTER GOKHALE”
('89', 270, 2, 3, 470848) ON THE TRAIN TO MADRAS, 1
('89', 270, 3, 4, 470874) January 20, 1946 Whilst I appreciate Shri Jagadisan’s 2 invitation to contribute a few words by way of Preface or Foreword to his admirable collection of Rt.
('89', 270, 3, 5, 471032) Hon’ble Sastriar’s 3 writings and speeches on Gokhale 4 the Good, as I would call him, it embarrasses me.
('89', 270, 3, 6, 471138) However strange my claim may appear to the reader, I have called Gokhale my political guru.
('89', 270, 3, 7, 471230) Therefore Sastriar is a fellow disciple.
('89', 270, 3, 8, 471271) And what a disciple and yet an amiable usurper!
('89', 270, 3, 9, 471319) I was to have the honour of being Gokhale’s successor but I found in Sastriar a worthy usurper to whom I made a willing surrender.
('89', 270, 3, 10, 471450) I could have given no satisfaction to the few well chosen members of the society.
('89', 270, 3, 11, 471532) 5 I had, and have, no gifts which Gok hale had and Sastriar has in luxurious abundance.
('89', 270, 3, 12, 471620) I confess that however great may be my attempt at impar tiality,I must fail to satisfy the critical reader.
('89', 270, 3, 13, 471728) Fellow admirers need no pass port from me.
('89', 270, 3, 14, 471771) And of whom was I to write?
('89', 270, 3, 15, 471799) As I began to read Jaga disan’s selection, I did not know whether Gok hale absorbed my attention or Sastriar.
('89', 270, 3, 16, 471909) Therefore I would close these hasty and rambling remarks by warning the critical reader against his or her trying the ques tionable task of discovering in these pages an echo of his or her own views.
('89', 270, 3, 17, 472109) It should be enough to find in them the transparent sincerity and patrio tism of the writer or, shall I say, the biographer and the master.
('89', 270, 4, 18, 472249) M. K. GANDHI
('89', 270, 5, 19, 472262) My Master Gokhale

('89', 271, 0, 1, 472771) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 271, 1, 2, 472813) 376. FOREWORD TO “THE GOSPEL OF SELFLESS ACTION OR THE ‘GITA’ ACCORDING TO GANDHI”
('89', 271, 2, 3, 472896) The following pages by Mahadev Desai are an ambitious pro ject.
('89', 271, 2, 4, 472960) It represents his unremitting labours during his prison life in 1933 ’34. Every page is evidence of his scholarship and exhaustive study of all he could lay hands upon regarding the Bhagavad Gita, poetically called The Song Celestial by the late Sir Edwin Arnold.
('89', 271, 2, 5, 473224) The immediate cause of this labour of love was my translation 1 in Gujarati of the divine book as I understood it.
('89', 271, 2, 6, 473339) In trying to give a translation of my meaning of the Gita, he found himself writing an original com mentary on the Gita.
('89', 271, 2, 7, 473460) The book might have been published during his lifetime, 2 if I could have made time to go through the manuscripit.
('89', 271, 2, 8, 473575) I read some portions with him, but exigencies of my work had to interrupt the reading.
('89', 271, 2, 9, 473662) Then followed the imprisonment of August 1942, and his sudden death within six days of our imprisonment.
('89', 271, 2, 10, 473767) All of his imme diate friends decided to give his reverent study of the Gita to the public.
('89', 271, 2, 11, 473859) He had copies typed for his English friends who were im patient to see the commentary in print.
('89', 271, 2, 12, 473955) And Pyarelal, who was colla borator with Mahadev Desai for many years, went through the whole manscript and undertook to perform the difficult task of proof reading.
('89', 271, 2, 13, 474121) Hence this publication.
('89', 271, 2, 14, 474145) Frankly I do not pretend to any scholarship.
('89', 271, 2, 15, 474190) I have, therefore, contented myself with showing the genesis of Mahadev Desai’s effort.
('89', 271, 2, 16, 474278) In so far as the translation part of the volume is concerened, I can vouch for its accuracy.
('89', 271, 2, 17, 474371) He has carried out the meaning of the original translation.
('89', 271, 2, 18, 474431) I may add, too, that Pyarelal has interfered with the origi nal only and in rare cases where it was considered to be essential, an interference which Mahadev Desai would, in my opinion, have gladly accepted, had he been alive.
('89', 271, 3, 19, 474658) M. K. GANDHI ON THE TRAIN TO MADRAS, January 20, 1946
('89', 271, 4, 20, 474712) The Gospel of Selfless Action or The Gita According to Gandhi
('89', 271, 5, 21, 474774) 1 Vide “Anasaktiyoga”, sub title “The Message of the Gita” 2 Mahadev Desai passed away on August 15, 1942.
('89', 272, 0, 1, 474881) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 273
('89', 272, 1, 2, 474929) 377. WHAT EXHIBITION SHOULD BE
('89', 272, 2, 3, 474960) The Congress session is likely to be held within two or three months.
('89', 272, 2, 4, 475030) The question, therefore, arises as to what sort of an exhibition should be put up from the villagers’ point of view.
('89', 272, 2, 5, 475147) It is only the rural view point which can be valid for India, if we desire and believe that the villagers have not only to survive but also to become strong and rich.
('89', 272, 2, 6, 475314) If this is true, there can be no place for city articles and pomp and show.
('89', 272, 2, 7, 475390) There should be no need for the entertainments that are prevalent in cities.
('89', 272, 2, 8, 475467) Under no circumstances, should the exhibition degenerate into cheap entertainment or a means for earning and never into an instrument of advertisment for business men.
('89', 272, 2, 9, 475635) Nothing should be sold there, not even khadi and the products of village industries.
('89', 272, 2, 10, 475720) The exhibition should be educative, and it should be intersting too.
('89', 272, 2, 11, 475789) It should be so organized that a villager after returning home, would begin to feel the necessity of learning some sort of industry or craft.
('89', 272, 2, 12, 475931) There should be somebody who can point out the shortcomings in all the villages of India and someone who can explain the ways and means for getting rid of them.
('89', 272, 2, 13, 476092) There should be someone who can show how far we have progressed since the beginning of the move ment for village uplift.
('89', 272, 2, 14, 476213) There should be somebody who can explain how this exhibition helps in making village life aesthetically satis fying.
('89', 272, 2, 15, 476330) Now let us consider what should be the form of the exhibition which can fulfil these conditions: 1. There should be two models of the village—one showing the village as it is today and the other, the improved one.
('89', 272, 2, 16, 476544) The improved village will be clean.
('89', 272, 2, 17, 476580) The cleanliness will be seen in the houses, the roads, the surroundings and the fields.
('89', 272, 2, 18, 476668) The con dition of the cattle will also be better.
('89', 272, 2, 19, 476718) Maps, pictures and books should show how particular occupations can help in increasing the villagers’ income.
('89', 272, 2, 20, 476828) 2. Complete details should be displayed about how the various village industries should work, where the tools for them are available and how they are manufactured.
('89', 272, 2, 21, 476992) All the crafts should be demons trated.
('89', 272, 2, 22, 477032) At the same time the following items should be shown: (a) Ideal diet for the villagers; (b) the competition between machine industry and handicrafts; (c) a practical demonstration of animal husbandry;
('89', 273, 0, 1, 477233) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 273, 1, 2, 477275) (d) a model for latrines; (e) art section; (f) organic manure v.
('89', 273, 1, 3, 477340) chemical fertilizers; (g) use of hides and bones of animals; (h) village music, musical instruments and village dramas; (i) village games, gymnasium and exercises; (j) Nayee Talim; (k) village medicines; Bearing in mind the policy stated at the outset, whatever addi tional items can be exhibited should be there.
('89', 273, 1, 4, 477654) What I have stated is only illustrative.
('89', 273, 1, 5, 477695) I have deliberately omitted all those village industries which are connected with the spinning wheel.
('89', 273, 1, 6, 477797) Without these industries the exhibition should be considered worthless.
('89', 273, 2, 7, 477869) M. K. GANDHI ON THE TRAIN TO MADRAS, January 20, 1946 [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, February 1946

('89', 277, 4, 9, 486455) 383. FOREWORD TO “HINDUSTANI GUJARATI KOSHA” 2
('89', 277, 5, 10, 486502) ON THE TRAIN TO MADRAS, January 21, 1926 This is the second edition of the Hindustani Gujarati diction ary.
('89', 277, 5, 11, 486610) I have not seen any other dictionary of this type in Gujarati.
('89', 277, 5, 12, 486673) A dictionary giving the words both in Devanagari and Urdu scripts seems to be a new venture.
('89', 277, 5, 13, 486766) If the necessity of knowing both the scripts and speaking both Hindi and Urdu is accepted, a dictionary like this is a great necessity.
('89', 277, 5, 14, 486902) This dictionary is not to be used in the same way as other dictionaries are used.
('89', 277, 5, 15, 486984) If the student of Hindustani consults it fre quently, his knowledge of both the scripts and of words from both the branches of the language is bound to increase.
('89', 277, 5, 16, 487146) Another way of using the dictionary properly is that, if any mistakes are found in it, the reader should note them, as also words which he does not find in it, and send the lists to the Editor from time to time.
('89', 277, 5, 17, 487358) The Editor may make appropriate use of the suggestions when preparing a new edi tion; or the addition’s if supplied as addenda, may enable the owner of the dictionary to use it at nominal cost, as if it was a revised edition.
('89', 277, 5, 18, 487584) The addenda can also be sent as a supplement to everyone having the

('89', 280, 2, 10, 492988) Q. How can a continent like Africa fight down the fetters of slavery when it is so hopelessly divided?
('89', 280, 3, 11, 493091) G. I know your difficulty.
('89', 280, 3, 12, 493118) If you think of the vast size of Africa, the distance and natural obstacles separating its various parts, the scattered condition of its people and the terrible divisions among them, the task might well appear to be hopeless.
('89', 280, 3, 13, 493344) But there is a charm which can overcome all these handicaps.
('89', 280, 3, 14, 493405) The moment the slave resolves that he will no longer be a slave, his fetters fall.
('89', 280, 3, 15, 493488) He frees himself and shows the way to others.
('89', 280, 3, 16, 493534) Freedom and slavery are mental states.

('89', 280, 3, 18, 493669) I shall not obey orders as such but shall dis obey them when they are in conflict with my conscience.’ The so called master may lash you and try to force you to serve him.
('89', 280, 3, 19, 493841) You will say: ‘No, I will not serve you for your money or under a threat.’ This may mean suffering.
('89', 280, 3, 20, 493941) Your readiness to suffer will light the torch of freedom which can never be put out.

('89', 280, 5, 26, 494497) I do not pro pose mechanical joint action between them.
('89', 280, 5, 27, 494553) ‘Each one has to find his own salvation’ is true of this as well as of the other world.

('89', 280, 5, 29, 494717) It will grow as time passes.

('89', 282, 1, 2, 496813) 387. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('89', 282, 2, 3, 496841) [Before January 22, 1946] 2
('89', 282, 3, 4, 496869) QUESTION: In the Bhagavad Gita comes a sloka 3: .
('89', 282, 3, 5, 496919) If everything goes according to fixed law, then if you pray to God, can He intervene and set aside the law for your sake?
('89', 282, 4, 6, 497041) ANSWER: But the meaning at the bottom is: “Thy will be done, not mine.” God’s law is never interrupted, but that very law says that every act has its result.
('89', 282, 4, 7, 497199) In the prayer for the child, father surrenders his will to God.
('89', 282, 4, 8, 497263) The law works as if it were a person, and since every action tells, this prayer has an unforseeable result.
('89', 282, 4, 9, 497371) You should work out what I have written.
('89', 282, 4, 10, 497412) The sum total of every act is a resultant.
('89', 282, 4, 11, 497455) Draw a parallelogram of forces.
('89', 282, 5, 12, 497487) Jnana, karama and bhakti—should not they all go together?
('89', 282, 5, 13, 497545) Unless you know God, how can you have bhakti?
('89', 282, 5, 14, 497591) You cannot even offer him your karma.
('89', 282, 5, 15, 497629) You must not reason like this.
('89', 282, 5, 16, 497660) If you have no work and so called bhakti, the result will be lop sided.
('89', 282, 5, 17, 497732) Do you know God to whom you pray?
('89', 282, 5, 18, 497766) I don’t.
('89', 282, 5, 19, 497775) He is unknown to you and me.
('89', 282, 6, 20, 497804) To whom shall we then pray?
('89', 282, 6, 21, 497832) To God, whom you do not know.
('89', 282, 6, 22, 497862) We always do not know the person to whom we are praying.
('89', 282, 7, 23, 497919) But the Shastras say that He is knowable.
('89', 282, 7, 24, 497961) Since He is knowable we search.
('89', 282, 7, 25, 497993) It may take a billion years.
('89', 282, 7, 26, 498022) Even if you do not believe, you must continue to pray.“Help thou mine 4 unbelief” 5 is a verse from the Bible.
('89', 282, 7, 27, 498133) But it is improper for you to ask such questions.
('89', 282, 7, 28, 498183) For you, there must be infinite patience and inward longing.
('89', 282, 7, 29, 498244) Inward longing obviates all such questions.
('89', 282, 7, 30, 498288) “Have faith and you will be whole” 6 is another chip from the Bible.
('89', 282, 7, 31, 498357) Gita has many such parallel passages.

('89', 294, 0, 1, 520725) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 295
('89', 294, 1, 2, 520773) 402. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS AT CONSTRUCTIVE WORKERS’ CONFERENCE, MADRAS
('89', 294, 2, 3, 520843) January 24, 1946
('89', 294, 3, 4, 520860) The first question related to the place of khadi in the national economy and how far it would help to solve the poverty problem.
('89', 294, 4, 5, 520989) Gandhiji said that khadi was the very foundation of Indian swaraj and economic uplift of the poor.
('89', 294, 4, 6, 521088) He had always linked khadi with swaraj from the beginning.
('89', 294, 4, 7, 521147) The more khadi we produced, the nearer we would be to swaraj.
('89', 294, 4, 8, 521209) Manual labour was an essential factor in his programme, and it was as necessary for the rich also to do manual work.
('89', 294, 4, 9, 521326) Spinning was manual labour par excellence.
('89', 294, 4, 10, 521369) It enabled even poor people to lead independent lives.
('89', 294, 4, 11, 521424) Explaining the symbolism of the charkha, Gandhiji said that it stood for ahimsa.
('89', 294, 4, 12, 521505) Let them not get lost in minor controversies but concentrate on the work of spinning and production of khadi, the most important part of the constructive programme.
('89', 294, 5, 13, 521670) Another question asked was how khadi production could be of help to the poor man when one considered that in the budget more than 80 per cent was spent on food and only 12 per cent on cloth.
('89', 294, 6, 14, 521861) Gandhiji answered that if through khaddar they could add to the income of the people even a few annas, it would be worth while.
('89', 294, 6, 15, 521989) He was looking forward to the day when khadi would become a universal gospel, though today it was confined to India.
('89', 294, 6, 16, 522106) The first step he envisaged was that khadi should touch all the 40 crores of Indian people.
('89', 294, 7, 17, 522198) A question written in English and in pencil on an odd slip of paper was next put aside by Gandhiji with the remark that it was illegible and the questioner was doing violence to an old man to send the question in that way.
('89', 294, 8, 18, 522421) QUESTION: What exactly do you mean by economic equality?
('89', 294, 8, 19, 522478) What is statutory trusteeship as conceived by you?
('89', 294, 9, 20, 522529) Gandhiji’s reply was that economic equality of his conception did not mean that everyone would literally have the same amount.
('89', 294, 9, 21, 522656) It simply meant that everybody should have enough for his or her needs.
('89', 294, 9, 22, 522728) For instance, he required two shawls in winter whereas his grand nephew Kanu Gandhi who stayed with him and was like his own son did not require any warm clothing whatsoever.
('89', 294, 9, 23, 522903) Gandhiji required goat’s milk, oranges and other fruit.
('89', 294, 9, 24, 522959) Kanu could do with ordinary food.
('89', 294, 9, 25, 522993) He envied Kanu but there was no point in it.
('89', 294, 9, 26, 523038) Kanu was a young man whereas he was an old man of 76. The monthly expense of his food was far more than that of Kanu but that did not mean that there was economic inequality between them.
('89', 294, 9, 27, 523226) The elephant needs a thousand times
('89', 294, 10, 28, 523262) 1 What follows is extracted form “Gandhiji’s Communism” by Pyarelal in Harijan.
('89', 295, 0, 1, 523342) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 295, 1, 2, 523384) more food than the ant, but that is not an indication of inequality.
('89', 295, 1, 3, 523453) So the real meaning of economic equality was: “To each according to his need.” That was the definition of Marx.
('89', 295, 1, 4, 523565) If a single man demanded as much as a man with wife and four children that would be a violation of economic equality.
('89', 295, 1, 5, 523683) Gandhiji continued : Let no one try to justify the glaring difference between the classes and the masses, the prince and the pauper, by saying that the former need more.
('89', 295, 1, 6, 523853) That will be idle sophistry and a travesty of my argument.
('89', 295, 1, 7, 523912) The contrast between the rich and the poor today is a painful sight.
('89', 295, 1, 8, 523981) The poor villagers are exploited by the foreign Govern ment and also by their own countrymen—the city dwellers.
('89', 295, 1, 9, 524093) they pro duce the food and go hungry.
('89', 295, 1, 10, 524131) They produce milk and their children have to go without it.
('89', 295, 1, 11, 524191) It is disgraceful.
('89', 295, 1, 12, 524210) Everyone must have a balanced diet, a decent house to live in, facilities for the education of one’s children and adequate medical relief.
('89', 295, 2, 13, 524349) That constituted his picture of economic equality.
('89', 295, 2, 14, 524400) He did not want to taboo everything above and beyond the bare necessaries but they must come after the essential needs of the poor are satisfied.
('89', 295, 2, 15, 524546) First things must come first.
('89', 295, 3, 16, 524576) As for the present owners of wealth, they would have to make their choice between class war and voluntarily converting themselves into trustees of their wealth.
('89', 295, 3, 17, 524737) They would be allowed to retain the stewardship of their possessions and to use their talent to increase the wealth, not for their own sakes, but for the sake of the nation and therefore without exploitation.
('89', 295, 3, 18, 524946) The State would regulate the rate of commission which they would get commensurate with the service rendered and its value to society.
('89', 295, 3, 19, 525080) Their children would inherit the stewardship only if they proved their fitness for it.
('89', 295, 3, 20, 525167) He concluded : Supposing India becomes a free country tomorrow, all the capi talists will have an opportunity of becoming statutory trustees.
('89', 295, 3, 21, 525309) But such a statute will not be imposed from above.
('89', 295, 3, 22, 525360) It will have to come from below.
('89', 295, 3, 23, 525393) When the people understand the implications of trustee ship and the atmosphere is ripe for it, the people themselves, begin ning with gram panchayats, will begin to introduce such statutes.
('89', 295, 3, 24, 525583) Such a thing coming from below is easy to swallow.
('89', 295, 3, 25, 525634) Coming from above, it is liable to prove a dead weight.
('89', 295, 4, 26, 525690) Q. What is the difference between your technique and that of the communists or socialists for realizing the goal of economic equality?
('89', 295, 5, 27, 525825) A. The socialists and communists say, they can do nothing to bring about economic equality today.
('89', 295, 5, 28, 525923) They will just carry on propa ganda in its favour and to that end they believe in generating and accentuating hatred.
('89', 295, 5, 29, 526041) They say, when they get control over and
('89', 296, 0, 1, 526082) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 297
('89', 296, 1, 2, 526130) accentuating hatred.
('89', 296, 1, 3, 526151) They say, when they get control over the State, they will enforce equality.
('89', 296, 1, 4, 526227) Under my plan, the State will be there to carry out the will of the people, not to dictate to them or force them to do its will.
('89', 296, 1, 5, 526356) I shall bring about economic equality through non violence, by converting the people to my point of view by harnessing the forces of love as against hatred.
('89', 296, 1, 6, 526513) I will not wait till I have converted the whole society to my view but will straightaway make a beginning with myself.
('89', 296, 1, 7, 526632) It goes without saying that I cannot hope to bring about economic equality of my conception, if I am the owner of fifty motor cars or even of ten bighas of land.
('89', 296, 1, 8, 526794) For that I have to reduce myself to the level of the poorest of the poor.
('89', 296, 1, 9, 526868) That is what I have been trying to do for the last fifty years or more, and so I claim to be a foremost communist although I make use of cars and other facilities offered to me by the rich.
('89', 296, 1, 10, 527058) They have no hold on me and I can shed them at a moment’s notice, if the interests of the masses demand it.
('89', 296, 2, 11, 527166) Q. What is the place of satyagraha in making the rich realize their duty towards the poor?
('89', 296, 2, 12, 527257) The same as against the foreign power.
('89', 296, 2, 13, 527296) Satyagraha is a law of universal application.
('89', 296, 2, 14, 527342) Beginning with the family, its use can be extended to every other circle.
('89', 296, 2, 15, 527416) Supposing a land owner exploits his tenants and mulcts them of the fruit of their toil by appropriating it to his own use.
('89', 296, 2, 16, 527539) When they expostulate with him, he does not listen and raises objections that he requires so much for his wife, so much for his children and so on.
('89', 296, 2, 17, 527687) The tenants or those who have espoused their cause and have influence, will make an appeal to his wife to expostulate with her husband.
('89', 296, 2, 18, 527823) She would probably say that for herself she does not need his exploited money.
('89', 296, 2, 19, 527902) The children will say likewise that they would earn for themselves what they need.
('89', 296, 2, 20, 527985) Supposing further that he listens to nobody or that his wife and children combine against the tenants, they will not submit.
('89', 296, 2, 21, 528110) They will quit, if asked to do so, but they will make it clear that the land belongs to him who tills it.
('89', 296, 2, 22, 528216) The owner cannot till all the land himself, and he will have to give in to their just demands.
('89', 296, 2, 23, 528311) It may, however, be that the tenants are replaced by others.
('89', 296, 2, 24, 528372) Agitation short of violence will then continue till the replaced tenants see their error and make common cause with the evicted tenants.
('89', 296, 2, 25, 528509) Thus satyagraha is a process of educating public opinion such that it covers all the elements of society and in the end makes itself irresistible.
('89', 296, 2, 26, 528656) Violence interrupts the process and prolongs the real revolution of the whole social structure.
('89', 296, 3, 27, 528752) The Hindu, 26 1 1946; also Harijan, 31 3 1946

('89', 297, 6, 10, 529427) Wherever he had been, whether in Tamil Nadu, Andhra Desha, Karnataka or Kerala, he had heard Tyagaraja’s songs sung with a sweet melody which seemed to spring from the very heart of the singer.

('89', 299, 8, 16, 534814) One of the previous speakers, Mr. T. Krishnaswami, had used a type of English mixed Hindus tani, though he could talk good Hindustani, in order to emphasize how far they had succumbed to the influence of a foreign language.

('89', 299, 8, 18, 535239) This was a kind of slavery.

('89', 303, 5, 14, 544778) 411. SPEECH AT CONVENTION OF HARIJANS, MADRAS 1
('89', 303, 6, 15, 544826) January 26, 1946
('89', 303, 7, 16, 544843) At the outset, Mahatma Gandhi expressed his great pleasure in seeing before him such a large gathering of Harijans.
('89', 303, 7, 17, 544959) He was also glad to notice the great awaken ing among them.
('89', 303, 8, 18, 545019) Englishmen often put the question, what the caste Hindus were going to do for the solution of the problem of untouchability, if the country achieved freedom?
('89', 303, 8, 19, 545177) They further asked what had the people done for Harijans?
('89', 303, 8, 20, 545235) Mahatmaji admitted that the question was pertinent; but at the same time he wished to make it clear that untouchability did not exist in such a horrible form, as their European friends wanted to make out.
('89', 303, 9, 21, 545440) In this connection, Mahatma Gandhi referred to his South African experience and said that there all Indians were regarded by the European people as untouchables.
('89', 303, 9, 22, 545602) An Indian might be a merchant or a barrister.
('89', 303, 9, 23, 545648) Still he was a ‘coolie’, so far as the Europeans there were concerned.
('89', 303, 9, 24, 545719) Separate places were allotted for the residence of Indians.
('89', 303, 9, 25, 545779) There were also other disabilities.
('89', 303, 9, 26, 545815) Therefore it could not be said that Euro peans did not observe untouchability.
('89', 303, 9, 27, 545894) There might not be untouchability amongst themselves; but they treated Indians in South Africa as untouchables.
('89', 303, 9, 28, 546006) He did all he could to remove that kind of untouchability while he was in South Africa.
('89', 303, 10, 29, 546094) 1 Organized as part of Silver Jubilee celebrations of Dakshina Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha
('89', 304, 0, 1, 546184) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 305
('89', 304, 1, 2, 546232) returning to India he had devoted himself to the removal of untouchability in this country.
('89', 304, 2, 3, 546324) “Would the conditions of Harijans be the same, or would it imprive when India attained freedom?” was another question asked.
('89', 304, 2, 4, 546449) He visualized that there would not be any question of untouchability in free India.
('89', 304, 2, 5, 546533) Their Hindu brethren would see to it that untouchability was put to an end and that all Harijans were acknowledged equals.
('89', 304, 2, 6, 546656) Crores of Congressmen would devote themselves towards that end.
('89', 304, 2, 7, 546720) They would work for the removal of untouchability and die for it.
('89', 304, 2, 8, 546786) In his address 1 to the constructive workers, he had stated clearly the nature of work [and asked] the workers to strive sincerely for the removal of untouchability.
('89', 304, 2, 9, 546952) It was not enough, if a few Harijans rose to high positions in life such as barristers or High Court judges.
('89', 304, 2, 10, 547061) For the uplift of the community as a whole, all of them must strive.
('89', 304, 2, 11, 547130) They must educate themselves.
('89', 304, 2, 12, 547160) They must fight and win their own freedom, not by violent means, but through truth and non violence.
('89', 304, 2, 13, 547261) Untouchability should disappear by winning the hearts of the caste Hindus through peaceful means.
('89', 304, 3, 14, 547359) Mahatma Gandhi then went on to explain what was meant by real freedom.
('89', 304, 3, 15, 547430) It did not mean freedom to do as they pleased.
('89', 304, 3, 16, 547477) It meant freedom to do their duty, freedom to abstain from drink, and freedom to work for their own uplift.
('89', 304, 3, 17, 547585) In this connection Gandhiji explained the significance of the term ‘Harijan’ by which he preferred to call them.
('89', 304, 3, 18, 547698) The term signified people of God.
('89', 304, 3, 19, 547732) He who nurtured hatred or ill feeling towards another could not be a man of God.
('89', 304, 3, 20, 547813) The Harijans had borne their sufferings patiently for ages without retaliating.
('89', 304, 3, 21, 547893) Therefore they deserved to be called Harijans.
('89', 304, 3, 22, 547940) True to that expression, they must believe in God and repeat His name.
('89', 304, 3, 23, 548011) They must be true devotees of God, and history furnished them with classic examples of true devotees like Nandanar.
('89', 304, 3, 24, 548127) On this occasion he did not wish to refer to the rights of Harijans, but only to say a few words on their duties or dharma.
('89', 304, 3, 25, 548251) The so called higher castes had their duties; so had Harijans.
('89', 304, 3, 26, 548314) If they considered that inter dining or inter marriage was the purpose of their freedom, they would be mistaken.
('89', 304, 3, 27, 548427) All these things would not bring about real happiness.
('89', 304, 3, 28, 548482) By acquiring clean and healthy habits, by adhering to truth and non violence, and by doing their work in life honestly and sincerely and with love of God, they would be promoting not only individual happiness but also the happiness of the community as a whole.
('89', 304, 3, 29, 548743) Only through truth and non violence could they establish swaraj or Ramarajya in this land.
('89', 304, 3, 30, 548834) The Hindu, 28 1 1946

('89', 305, 2, 3, 548963) January 26, 1946
('89', 305, 3, 4, 548980) Gandhiji said that festivals varied in character with the times.
('89', 305, 3, 5, 549045) The Indepen dence Day was a sacred day to them all, as on that day crores of people would be repeating their pledge for the attainment of the independence of India.
('89', 305, 3, 6, 549210) He hoped that everybody had taken the pledge.
('89', 305, 3, 7, 549256) If not, everybody should take it.
('89', 305, 3, 8, 549290) The special feature of that pledge, he reminded them, was that the means to be adopted for the attainment of independence were unadulterated truth and non violence.
('89', 305, 3, 9, 549455) 2 Crores of people had been repeating that pledge for the last 25 years and offering prayers for the fulfilment of that pledge to the Most High, who, though far, was yet nearer to us than our hands and feet.
('89', 305, 3, 10, 549663) It was the self same Power, though known by various designations, Allah, Rama, Rahman, Rahim, God, and so on.
('89', 305, 3, 11, 549773) There was no limit to His names.
('89', 305, 3, 12, 549806) They were as countless as His attributes.
('89', 305, 3, 13, 549848) It was to this Unseen Power which permeated and sustained the universe that their prayers where made.
('89', 305, 3, 14, 549950) It would be heard only if their means where as pure and spotless as their end.
('89', 305, 4, 15, 550029) Could they expect God to crown their resolve with success, if their means included falsehood, deceit, violence and deception?
('89', 305, 4, 16, 550155) Such a prayer would not ascend to heaven.
('89', 305, 4, 17, 550197) It would only bring ridicule on those who offered it.
('89', 305, 4, 18, 550251) True prayer must transform their conduct.
('89', 305, 4, 19, 550293) How could they indulge in unseemly behaviour like yesterday’s, while they professed to be votaries of truth and ahimsa?
('89', 305, 4, 20, 550413) Prayer meant nothing, if it did not result in self purification and humility.
('89', 305, 4, 21, 550491) Prayer ought to purge the soul of all impurity, pride and egotism.
('89', 305, 4, 22, 550558) Whilst the incident had caused him deep pain, it was not without a redeeming feature.
('89', 305, 4, 23, 550644) The redeeming feature was that although one person had run amok, those around him had refused to be thrown off their legs and had not joined him in the clamour.
('89', 305, 4, 24, 550805) That was as it should be in a well behaved gathering.
('89', 305, 5, 25, 550859) In conformity with yesterday’s announcement, he had discontinued giving any
('89', 305, 6, 26, 550935) translations either in Telugu or Tamil of his remarks at the end of the prayer.
('89', 305, 6, 27, 551015) Even the
('89', 305, 7, 28, 551024) song was in Hindustani because he did not want to make the language of the song a
('89', 305, 8, 29, 551106) bone of ocntention.
('89', 305, 8, 30, 551126) He strongly deprecated the rivarly and recrimination between the
('89', 305, 9, 31, 551191) Tamilians and the the Andhras which he had noticed during his visit to the South.
('89', 305, 10, 32, 551273) Tamilians and the Andhras, the Kanarese and the Malayalees were distinct, but not
('89', 305, 11, 33, 551355) antagonistic to one another.
('89', 305, 11, 34, 551384) They were like branches of the same tree.
('89', 305, 11, 35, 551426) They should
('89', 305, 12, 36, 551438) realize the fundamental unity underlying their diversity.
('89', 305, 12, 37, 551496) Then alone they would be

('89', 306, 1, 2, 551808) worthy of independence.
('89', 306, 2, 3, 551832) Referring to the disturbances that continued through the prayer from the dis tant fringe of the gathering, he said, he realized that it was due to insufficiency of accommodation.
('89', 306, 2, 4, 552011) The clamour came from those who could not find accommodation.
('89', 306, 2, 5, 552073) The right thing for those who failed to get accommodation would have been to quietly sit back or wait in silence outside.
('89', 306, 2, 6, 552195) Similarly, if they had assimilated the spirit of non violence, he would not have been forced to confine himself to the precincts of his residence as he was doing at present.
('89', 306, 2, 7, 552369) It was because he was afraid of the unthinking adoration of the crowds that he did not go out in the open even for his evening walk.
('89', 306, 2, 8, 552502) Genuine love should be more discerning.
('89', 306, 3, 9, 552542) Concluding, Gandhiji asked them all to pray to God to either give them freedom or the strength to die for it.
('89', 306, 3, 10, 552652) He said : Let us hope we shall not have to repeat this pledge next year but shall have attained our freedom before that.
('89', 306, 3, 11, 552773) It is given to man but to try.
('89', 306, 3, 12, 552804) The result is in the hands of God.
('89', 306, 3, 13, 552839) But, if our weapons are un adulterated truth and non violence, our prayer will not go unheard.

('89', 306, 4, 15, 552955) 413. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS AT CONSTRUCTIVE WORKERS’ CONFERENCE, MADRAS
('89', 306, 5, 16, 553025) January 27, 1946
('89', 306, 6, 17, 553042) Mahatma Gandhi said that many women enquired of him about the nature of
('89', 306, 7, 18, 553114) work they might do.
('89', 306, 7, 19, 553134) He had been telling repeatedly, and he would say again that
('89', 306, 8, 20, 553194) women should go to villages and work there.
('89', 306, 8, 21, 553238) They must attend to the health and
('89', 306, 9, 22, 553273) sanitation of the villages and to the education and culture of the womenfolk.
('89', 306, 9, 23, 553351) All these
('89', 306, 10, 24, 553361) should be done in a spirit of love and service and not as a mere formality.
('89', 306, 11, 25, 553437) Replying to a question relating to parliamentary programme, Mahatma Gandhi said that the question of entering legislatures was a small matter.
('89', 306, 11, 26, 553580) Only a limited number of women could engage themselves in this work, whereas the constructive programme provided scope for all of them.
('89', 306, 11, 27, 553716) Mahatma Gandhi added that he had no objection to women standing for election to legislatures; but they must enter the legislatures with the idea of serving the people, always keeping in mind the principle of truth and non violence.
('89', 306, 11, 28, 553948) But how many of them would be able to enter the legislatures in a spirit of service?
('89', 306, 11, 29, 554033) They must also have a clear idea beforehand as to what they would do inside the legislatures.
('89', 306, 11, 30, 554127) The parliamentary programme was like building from the top.
('89', 306, 11, 31, 554187) Their aim must be to build from below so that the foundation would be strong and the structure good.
('89', 306, 11, 32, 554288) If any mistake occurred while building from the bottom, it could be rectified immediately, and the harm done would not be much.
('89', 307, 0, 1, 554416) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 307, 1, 2, 554458) On the other hand, if a mistake was committed in the other programme, the entire structure might collapse and the whole country stood to lose thereby.
('89', 307, 2, 3, 554609) The next question related to receiving assistance from Christian Missionaries in a free India.
('89', 307, 2, 4, 554704) Gandhiji declared that they could certainly accept help not only from Christian Misssionaries but from others also, if such help was offered sincerely and in a spirit of service to the country.
('89', 307, 2, 5, 554898) There was before them the example of the late Deenabandhu Andrews.
('89', 307, 2, 6, 554965) He was a Christian.
('89', 307, 2, 7, 554985) He served India and gave his life for India.
('89', 307, 2, 8, 555030) India required the help of all men of goodwill who were prepared to offer that help in a spirit of love and service.
('89', 307, 3, 9, 555147) In reply to another question, Mahatmaa Gandhi said that the wife or dependent of a Government servant could do national work, provided she was ready to do so without fear of her property being consfiscated or the education of her children suffering.
('89', 307, 3, 10, 555397) If any woman thought that by doing constructive national work her children stood to lose privilege they might otherwise get from the Government, she should not undertake the work.
('89', 307, 4, 11, 555577) He said that this sphere of work was large and all were welcome.
('89', 307, 4, 12, 555642) It was the constructive programme that was responsible for creating an awakening in the country.
('89', 307, 4, 13, 555739) It was only through constructive programme that they would be able to retain their freedom when it was won.
('89', 307, 4, 14, 555847) The important part of the constructive pro gramme was to develop purity of body and mind and to educate their children accor ding to the Nayee Talim or New Education.
('89', 307, 4, 15, 556014) Thereby their girls and boys would grow into self supporting and independent citizens.
('89', 307, 4, 16, 556101) They wanted many workers to go out into the villages and work among the people.
('89', 307, 4, 17, 556181) Educated women should make it a point to get into villages and teach the children to read and write and to lead clean lives.
('89', 307, 4, 18, 556306) If these things were done, the constructive programme would have achieved its purpose.
('89', 307, 5, 19, 556393) If they had a capital of one crore of rupees, they should be able to multiply it and not allow themselves to squander away what they had.
('89', 307, 5, 20, 556531) All of them were aware that he would not allow even a pie being spent unnecessarily.
('89', 307, 5, 21, 556616) The construrctive programme, if correctly followed, would not only pay its way but also add to the capital.
('89', 307, 5, 22, 556724) Therein lay its greatness.
('89', 307, 5, 23, 556751) The Hindu, 29 1 1946

('89', 308, 1, 2, 556820) 414. SPEECH AT DAKSHINA BHARAT HINDI PRACHAR SABHA, MADRAS 1
('89', 308, 2, 3, 556881) January 27, 1946
('89', 308, 3, 4, 556898) The business they had all met to transact was a solemn one, and he was glad to be able to take part in that function.
('89', 308, 3, 5, 557016) If the aspirations of the people of India for freedom were to be fulfilled, they should learn the lessons of true discipline and right conduct, particularly in such large congregations.
('89', 308, 3, 6, 557202) No doubt there was a president on such occasions to regulate proceedings and maintain order.
('89', 308, 3, 7, 557295) But the order he wanted was that which was born of a due sense of discipline in each individual.
('89', 308, 3, 8, 557392) The discipline should be so strong that even where it was a child of five that sought to enforce regulations and law, people should willingly abide by it.
('89', 308, 3, 9, 557547) That he thought was real vinaya 2. They should also concentrate on the main purpose for which they were assembled there and do nothing to mar the solemnity of that purpose and its fulfilment.
('89', 308, 4, 10, 557739) He had again and again said that he preferred the nomenclature ‘Hindustani’ to ‘Hindi’ in this connection.
('89', 308, 4, 11, 557846) The language the Sabha sought to spread was really the language of the common folk of North India, understood by an overwhelming majority.
('89', 308, 4, 12, 557985) He had also stated again and again that students of Hindustani should learn both Urdu and Nagari scripts.
('89', 308, 4, 13, 558091) Some people deliberately mixed more Sanskrit words and some others Arabic and Persian words, with the result that today two distinctive streams were noticeable in the language which was one.
('89', 308, 4, 14, 558282) His own view was that Hindustani was the one common language containing Sanskrit words as well as Arabic and Persian words and understood by the common people.
('89', 308, 4, 15, 558442) He wanted them to do their bit for spreading that languaage.
('89', 308, 4, 16, 558503) The Hindu, 29 1 1946

('89', 308, 7, 21, 558960) The secret of the miracle was her undying faith in God which nothing could shake.
('89', 308, 7, 22, 559042) The legend says that the Lord himself reached out his arm to protect her.
('89', 308, 7, 23, 559116) The poet, of course, is here referring to the

('89', 309, 1, 2, 559302) omnipotence of God, who, however, becomes a living force to those who have faith.
('89', 309, 2, 3, 559384) Gandhiji said that as Draupadi was depicted as being sought to be made naked, India was already naked and was praying for protection from shame—the shame of slavery and serfdom under alien exploitation—and restoration of her independence.
('89', 309, 3, 4, 559623) Yesterday they had pledged themselves that they would either win independence through truth and ahimsa or perish in the attempt, and yet today, in spite of the spacious grounds, they were behaving like an undisciplined mob in one quarter of the prayer ground.
('89', 309, 3, 5, 559883) 1 If they could not behave well even during bhajan, how would they behave when India got freedom?
('89', 309, 3, 6, 559981) Theirs was by no means an extraordinarily big gathering, but for a people who aspired to be free and remain free through no other means than ahimsa, it should be possible to act and obey orders as one man even if they were 400 million.
('89', 309, 3, 7, 560217) If 400 million could but shout with one voice, the effect would be overwhelming.
('89', 309, 3, 8, 560298) But there was a proper time for shouting as for silence.

('89', 309, 4, 11, 560607) He prayed to God to guide them all aright so that they might deport themselves in a manner worthy of the people who aspired to be free.

('89', 313, 8, 20, 566985) So every worker must spin and know all about spinning.

('89', 314, 1, 2, 567937) much time left for other things.

('89', 314, 1, 4, 568111) For instance, he can work for improving the sanitation of the place and render advice about the care of the sick when he cannot take up full responsibility for nursing them.

('89', 314, 1, 7, 568602) The thing is that every worker should decide for himself what will be his main activity besides the spinning wheel, and what will be his subsidiary activities.
('89', 314, 1, 8, 568762) Whatever he does, he should do intelligently and with knowledge.

('89', 314, 1, 11, 569112) A student of astronomy cannot know astronomy without some knowledge of science in general.
('89', 314, 1, 12, 569203) Similarly a worker cannot afford to be utterly ignorant about other items of constructive work.
('89', 314, 2, 13, 569299) Q. Please explain the meaning of samagra gramseva of your conception.
('89', 314, 2, 14, 569369) How can we fit ourselves for that?
('89', 314, 3, 15, 569404) A. The 18 fold constructive programme includes samagra gram seva.
('89', 314, 3, 16, 569470) A samagra gramsevak must know everybody living in the village and render them such service as he can.
('89', 314, 3, 17, 569572) That does not mean that the worker will be able to do everything single handed.
('89', 314, 3, 18, 569652) He will show them the way of helping themselves and procure for them such help and mate rials as they require.
('89', 314, 3, 19, 569763) He will train up his own helpers.
('89', 314, 3, 20, 569797) He will so win over the villagers that they will seek and follow his advice.
('89', 314, 3, 21, 569874) Supposing I go and settle down in a village with a ghani (village oil press), I won’t be an ordinary ghanchi (oil presser) earn ing 15 20 rupees a month.
('89', 314, 3, 22, 570028) I will be a Mahatma ghanchi.
('89', 314, 3, 23, 570057) I have used the word Mahatma in fun but what I mean to say is that as ghanchi I will become a model for the villagers to follow.
('89', 314, 3, 24, 570186) I will be a ghan chi who knows the Gita and the Koran.
('89', 314, 3, 25, 570241) I will be learned enough to teach their children.
('89', 314, 3, 26, 570291) I may not be able to do so for lack of time.
('89', 314, 3, 27, 570336) The villagers will come to me and ask me: ‘Please make arran gements for our children’s education.’ I will tell them: ‘I can find you a teacher but you will have to bear the expenses.’ And they will be prepared to

('89', 320, 3, 24, 585754) India was a glorious country, full of such great examples.
('89', 320, 3, 25, 585813) The glory of Hindustan was in the hands of Indian womanhood.
('89', 320, 3, 26, 585874) Dusshasana was unable to put Draupadi to shame, though the Pandavas were unable to come to her rescue.

('89', 320, 4, 32, 586335) Finally Gandhiji spoke about untouchability and said that some of them could not drink even water given by a Harijan.

('89', 320, 4, 38, 586781) Glancing at his watch, Mahtamaji said that it was time for him to leave.

('89', 321, 1, 2, 587142) 427. SPEECH AT NAYEE TALIM CONVOCATION, MADRAS 1
('89', 321, 2, 3, 587191) January 29, 1926
('89', 321, 3, 4, 587208) Gandhiji addressed an exhortation to the teachers to carry on their work in their respective areas in a spirit of loyalty and earnestness to the cause.
('89', 321, 3, 5, 587360) He wanted them all to remember the several items of work mentioned in their certificates 2 and to strive their utmost to carry out their duties in that connection.
('89', 321, 3, 6, 587524) It was true that there were certain very wide subjects like agriculture included there, but he was sure they would do their best to instil in those coming under their care the proper attitude in this matter.
('89', 321, 3, 7, 587732) The one important matter which he wanted them to bear in mind was that they should all learn Hindustani.
('89', 321, 3, 8, 587837) He added that they should in no circumstance neglect their mother tongue.
('89', 321, 3, 9, 587911) In each linguistic area, the mother tongue should have the first claim.
('89', 321, 3, 10, 587983) But Hindustani would not only serve as a common medium for the different language areas of their own Province but also as a means of communication between the South and the rest of India.
('89', 321, 4, 11, 588171) Another important thing he would urge them to bear in mind was that they should learn all about their immediate surroundings and gradually extend their knowledge in a widening circle to things outside.
('89', 321, 4, 12, 588373) Mere memorizing would not carry them far.
('89', 321, 4, 13, 588415) He remembered how as a young boy he was made to memorize “London is on the Thames’ as part of his geography lesson.
('89', 321, 4, 14, 588531) That kind of knowledge was not much good.
('89', 321, 5, 15, 588573) Knowledge directly derived from anything was much better than knowledge derived through a written lesson or through symbols.
('89', 321, 5, 16, 588698) A child would have a much better idea of a charkha when it saw one and how it worked than by reading or hearing about it.
('89', 321, 5, 17, 588820) That was an essential basis of Nayee Talim.
('89', 321, 6, 18, 588864) These were some of the ideas which he thought he might place before them, and he wanted that they should adopt whatever seemed good to them therein.

('89', 324, 2, 6, 593692) 432. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS AT MEETING OF TEACHERS AND STUDENTS
('89', 324, 3, 7, 593754) January 30, 1946
('89', 324, 4, 8, 593771) Gandhiji first expressed pleasure at the very large gathering that had assembled.
('89', 324, 4, 9, 593853) He said that though of late he had not participated in students’ meeting, yet his affection for them remained the same as before.
('89', 324, 4, 10, 593983) He believed that one could do more service by silent work, and this was borne out by his experience not only in South Africa, where he had moved with Madrasis, but also in this city during his short stay.
('89', 324, 4, 11, 594188) People here, to whom he had not spoken, had clearly understood what he stood for and what shape their service to the country should take.
('89', 324, 5, 12, 594326) The rest of the address was in the nature of replies to questions that were placed in his hands earlier.
('89', 324, 5, 13, 594431) Gandhiji had walked into the meeting bringing the questions with him.
('89', 324, 5, 14, 594501) First he remarked in a humorous vein that while he would answer the questions, he would not like to leave the palce before receiving their promised purse.
('89', 324, 5, 15, 594656) Before he commenced his answers, he put his usual question as to how many of them could understand him in Hindustani.
('89', 324, 5, 16, 594774) The response was not good.
('89', 324, 5, 17, 594801) On this he remarked that it was a matter for regret that, in spite of the fact that the Sabha had been working amongst them for twenty seven years, they had not learnt Hindustani in large numbers.
('89', 324, 5, 18, 594998) He expected that students, at least all of them, would learn Hindustani and said that learning Hindustani was not as costly as college education.
('89', 324, 5, 19, 595144) It was much easier also to learn the language.
('89', 324, 6, 20, 595191) Next the subject of utilization of collections made for the presentation of a purse to Gandhiji was touched upon by him.
('89', 324, 6, 21, 595312) Gandhiji said that since they had made the collections with a view to giving him the amount towards the Hindi Prachar Sabha Fund, law and propriety required that they should not lay any condition on the utilization of the amount.
('89', 324, 6, 22, 595542) He did not wish to say anything more on this point.
('89', 324, 7, 23, 595594) Gandhiji’s opinion was sought on the practice prevalent amongst students of conversing in English.
('89', 324, 7, 24, 595693) Gandhiji condemned such a practice and said that this ought not to be.
('89', 324, 7, 25, 595764) Though the English language could be compared to a gold chain, yet it
('89', 325, 0, 1, 595834) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 325, 1, 2, 595876) bound their hands and feet in slavery.
('89', 325, 1, 3, 595915) The mother tongue could be compared to their mother, and to drop it in favour of English was like letting down their mother.
('89', 325, 1, 4, 596040) Every student should know two languages, his mother tongue and Hindustani.
('89', 325, 2, 5, 596115) Q. Could girl students use cosmetics and boy students ape it?
('89', 325, 3, 6, 596177) Gandhiji’s reply was that only inanimate things like stone images required frequent polishing, and that human beings’ natural beauty required no cosmetics.
('89', 325, 3, 7, 596333) He added that in this country, where poverty and starvation was rampant, it was foolish to waste money on such luxuries.
('89', 325, 4, 8, 596454) Q. Do you approve of smoking which was at present very common amongst students?
('89', 325, 5, 9, 596534) Gandhiji said that he did smoke once or twice when he was young and, reflecting on it, he was really ashamed.
('89', 325, 5, 10, 596644) But, while he did it stealthily, students were doing it at present openly (laughter).
('89', 325, 5, 11, 596730) Smoking was as had as drinking, whether it was indigenous stuff or foreign, and should be avoided.
('89', 325, 6, 12, 596829) Replying to another question solicited Gandhiji’s view on the poor percentage of students using khadi, Mahatmaji observed that khadi had its birth for freedom.
('89', 325, 6, 13, 596989) He reiterated that if they wanted freedom quickly, students must not only wear khadi, but also make it out of their own spun yarn.
('89', 325, 7, 14, 597120) Gandhiji referred the students to his latest book 1 on constructive work, when he was told that many students did not believe in the constructive programme.
('89', 325, 7, 15, 597277) He added : How could work amongst Harijans and aboriginal prove un interesting?
('89', 325, 7, 16, 597357) To say that constructive programme was uninteresting was a vote in favour of slavery.
('89', 325, 8, 17, 597443) When asked for his advice to students who were intolerant, Gandhiji said that tolerance was the first virtue that a student should develop.
('89', 325, 8, 18, 597583) He added : If anyone says that India can gain independence through the sword, I would patiently hear him, even though I have been preaching truth and non violence for the last twenty years for winning swaraj.
('89', 325, 9, 19, 597792) Gandhiji, full of emotion, referred to violence such as causing destruction with the atom bomb and the victory won thereby, and said that he had applied his mind to this point.
('89', 325, 9, 20, 597969) He felt that truth and non violence were really more powerful than the atom bomb.
('89', 325, 10, 21, 598051) “I am not afraid of the atom bomb,” he remarked.
('89', 325, 10, 22, 598100) While they could cause physical injury, they could not kill their soul.
('89', 325, 10, 23, 598172) Once they had the determination that they could not be conquerred by violence, victory was theirs; for a moral protest
('89', 325, 11, 24, 598291) 1 Vide “Constructive Programme: Its Meaning and Place”, 13 12 1941 and “Foreword to “Constructive Programme its Meaning and Place”
('89', 326, 0, 1, 598422) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 327
('89', 326, 1, 2, 598470) against evil was itself a victory.
('89', 326, 2, 3, 598505) Finally Gandhiji exhorted the students to think on the various problems; for students who could not think for themselves could not learn anything.
