('89', 326, 3, 5, 598672) 433. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, MADRAS
('89', 326, 4, 6, 598710) January 30, 1946
('89', 326, 5, 7, 598727) Taking for his theme the text of the bhajan song—“With the grace of the Lord, everything can be achieved”—Gandhiji said, the persistence of the noise from one section of the crowd was such that it seemed that only God’s grace could bring about perfect silence in that gathering.
('89', 326, 5, 8, 599006) For his part, he thought, it would be impossible for him also to speak when so many were “making speeches” at the other end of the gathering.
('89', 326, 5, 9, 599148) Were a similar meeting held under the auspices of the Government, there would surely be silence enforced with a lathi.
('89', 326, 5, 10, 599267) But here there was only the appeal of the volunteers, which they in their sense of freedom did not care to obey.
('89', 326, 5, 11, 599380) He knew they did so because of their love for him, and in their desire to see him closer.
('89', 326, 5, 12, 599470) They would not be denied.
('89', 326, 5, 13, 599496) But they should learn to discipline themselves in such matters and even to deny themselves what they wanted, if it was harmful to discipline and general good.
('89', 326, 5, 14, 599655) How could they do it unless they became filled with Rama for, as the bhajan song went, when they became saturated with Rama all else would be eliminated.
('89', 326, 6, 15, 599809) In Madras, he knew, thousands were addicted to liquor.
('89', 326, 6, 16, 599864) The consequent evil was enough to break one’s heart.
('89', 326, 6, 17, 599917) When the Congress was running the Ministry, drink was abolished in different areas.
('89', 326, 6, 18, 600001) Liquor revenue fell, but the people were happy and their wives and children had a square meal and a happy home.
('89', 326, 6, 19, 600113) Had the reform come from within and not as a result of something from without, then it would have been far more good.
('89', 326, 6, 20, 600231) When could such a phenomenon happen?
('89', 326, 6, 21, 600268) Only when people were saturated with Rama and Gurukripa—God’s grace—as the song went.
('89', 326, 7, 22, 600354) Should a rich man offer them gold or silver from his safe room, people would crowd to his gates.

('89', 329, 1, 5, 606337) In his view, there was no conflict between different religions.
('89', 329, 1, 6, 606401) He did not pray in the manner he did with any ulterior motive of preaching Hinduism or any particular reli gion.
('89', 329, 1, 7, 606514) He merely prayed to God.
('89', 329, 1, 8, 606539) If people misunderstood that, he was not to blame.
('89', 329, 1, 9, 606590) People were welcome to join in the prayer, if it pleased them; otherwise they might keep away and leave him alone.
('89', 329, 2, 10, 606705) Another member asked a question in regard to the elections to the legislatures, Congress committees and Congress executive bodies.
('89', 329, 2, 11, 606836) Gandhiji said : How can I answer this question?

('89', 329, 2, 16, 607135) You should ask these questions of a man like Jawaharlal Nehru, Sardar Patel or other members of the Working Committee.
('89', 329, 2, 17, 607254) And, whatever Congress decides, it is open to you to abide by it.
('89', 329, 3, 18, 607320) It is true, Gandhiji added, that he had been connected with the Congress for many years and had also fought the Government on behalf of the Congress.
('89', 329, 3, 19, 607470) To some extent he had also been responsible for shaping its Constitution.

('89', 329, 3, 21, 607638) So far as they were concerned, such questions should be put to the Working Committee or the Congress President.
('89', 329, 3, 22, 607750) His own particular department was constructive work.
('89', 329, 3, 23, 607803) They were welcome to ask him questions on that subject.
('89', 329, 4, 24, 607859) Gandhiji stated that he met them because, having come all the way to Madras, he did not want to omit meeting Congress workers.
('89', 329, 4, 25, 607986) But he did not want to enter into complicated political matters which were not within his province.
('89', 329, 5, 26, 608086) One member observed that constructive work was also related to politics.
('89', 329, 5, 27, 608159) Gandhiji agreed that it was in a way related to politics, but to him it was pure constructive work.
('89', 329, 6, 28, 608259) One gentleman asked whether the the spread of Hindustani would not prejudicially affect the local languages.
('89', 329, 7, 29, 608368) QUESTION: What place should the Congress assign to people who had carried on black marketing activities during the last War and what punishment should be given to them?

('89', 333, 1, 2, 615131) 437. SPEECH AT VOLUNTEERS’ RALLY, MADRAS 1
('89', 333, 2, 3, 615174) January 31, 1946
('89', 333, 3, 4, 615191) Gandhiji said that he was under the impression that the entire programme was over with the previous evening.
('89', 333, 3, 5, 615300) But he was told in the night that there was this rally and that he must be present.
('89', 333, 3, 6, 615384) He was glad, he was able to attend the function and he was really pleased to meet them all.
('89', 333, 4, 7, 615476) Referring to the service rendered by the several departments in making the celebration a success, Gandhiji profoundly thanked them for their help and co operation.
('89', 333, 4, 8, 615640) Without the aid of volunteers, he could not believe that they could have got through such an important celebration.
('89', 333, 4, 9, 615756) He considered volunteers as those sworn to non violence, as against the police and the military who were pledged to violence and who dominated over the people.
('89', 333, 4, 10, 615916) It was only with this impression that he had appealed as early as 1920 that they should organize volunteer corps all over the country so that service rendered sincerely and non violently could get them freedom quickly.
('89', 333, 5, 11, 616135) They must learn thoroughly how to control large gatherings with tact, poli teness and calmness, without distinction of rich and poor, civilized and uncivilized.
('89', 333, 5, 12, 616296) He knew that people would keep order, if a policeman appeared on the scene because he posed himself as their master and paraded his lathi.
('89', 333, 5, 13, 616435) But this was not what he want ed.
('89', 333, 5, 14, 616469) They must make people understand by persuasion what they should do through tru th and non violence and show that these forces of law and order were only for serving the people.
('89', 333, 5, 15, 616646) He had attended many parades and rallies in foreign countries where the police took an oath that they would serve the public.
('89', 333, 5, 16, 616772) In London, which was considered to be very advanced in policing, policemen took an oath that they would render service to the people through their work.
('89', 333, 5, 17, 616925) Why not the Commissioner of Police here take a similar oath?
('89', 333, 5, 18, 616986) If the servants of Hindustan understood this particular view point, then freedom could easily be obtained.
('89', 333, 6, 19, 617093) Referring to the frequent noisy behaviour of the large concourse at prayer meetings in spite of the efforts of volunteers to keep silence, Maahatmaji said that the volunteers should bear in mind what he had said about their duties and make a practical demonstraton that they were following them by keeping perfect order and silence in that evening’s prayer meeting.

('89', 334, 2, 3, 617600) January 31, 1946
('89', 334, 3, 4, 617617) Addressing the gathering, Gandhiji said that the Mess Committee had fed about 50,000 people, and he heartily thanked them for it.
('89', 334, 3, 5, 617747) Proper feeding had kept people in good spirits to get through the important business at the conferences and meetings.
('89', 334, 3, 6, 617865) They had done this job well and taken away a heavy burden off the shoulders of the Reception Committee.

('89', 334, 3, 10, 618270) By cleanliness he did not mean that their clothes should be nicely ironed.

('89', 334, 5, 18, 619192) Therefore, he said, he was not keeping it with him and wanted to part with it.
('89', 334, 6, 19, 619271) Taking out a silver idol of Muralidhara from the collection, Mahatmaji said that this was presented because he was a Krishna bhakta.
('89', 334, 6, 20, 619404) But his Krishna was He ‘Who sees me but Whom I do not see’.

('89', 336, 3, 4, 622341) Gandhiji said that he had been delayed by another engagement 2 and he was sorry for having come later than the scheduled time to the meeting.
('89', 336, 4, 5, 622483) The truest capital was, in his opinion, one’s capacity for work.
('89', 336, 4, 6, 622548) Money alone could never produce goods; only through labour could goods be created.
('89', 336, 4, 7, 622631) Labourers then were possessed of real wealth, but they were not rich in worthy goods and had no property.
('89', 336, 4, 8, 622737) He wanted that they should all become maliks (men of property), but not through any process of coercion.
('89', 336, 4, 9, 622842) Property got through coercion would not remain with them; a stronger man might snatch it from them.
('89', 336, 4, 10, 622942) If they were to become maliks, therefore, they should first learn to be non violent, truthful and peaceful.

('89', 336, 4, 14, 623219) He wanted them to bear in mind the exapmple of the Ahmedabad Labour Union and take a leaf from its work.

('89', 336, 5, 24, 623975) The workers were all one entity.
('89', 336, 5, 25, 624008) One of them could certainly become President of the Congress.
('89', 336, 5, 26, 624070) The difference between the mazdoor and the kisan was that the kisan stayed to work on the land, while the mazdoor went wherever there was work.
('89', 336, 5, 27, 624214) The workers were taken there by the proprietors.
('89', 336, 5, 28, 624263) Mahatma Gandhi recalled that he had always said that the real pro prietor was not the person who owned the mill, but the person who worked.
('89', 336, 5, 29, 624403) He him self was speaking as a worker.

('89', 337, 1, 2, 624891) workers.
('89', 337, 1, 3, 624900) The Ahmedabad Workers’ Union, which was started by himself, was a model for others.
('89', 337, 1, 4, 624984) He did not suggest that even there the workers had become the owners.
('89', 337, 1, 5, 625054) He felt that the workers would come to own the mills and factories in which they worked, if they became more disciplined and wiser.
('89', 337, 2, 6, 625186) Appealing to them to learn Hindustani, Gandhiji said that all India was one and they should learn the Hindustani language which would enable them to be one with the rest of India.
('89', 337, 2, 7, 625366) Industrial workers and kisans were both badly off; they were suffering alike.

('89', 343, 6, 22, 643318) Why is Harijan revived?
('89', 343, 6, 23, 643342) This question may have occurred to many as it has to me.
('89', 343, 6, 24, 643399) I may tell the reader that no special effort was made for its revival 3. An application for the removal of the ban was made on December 3, 1945, and the ban was removed on January 10, 1946. Many readers, including English and American, had all along felt a void, and they began to feel it more after the defeat of the Fascist Powers.
('89', 343, 6, 25, 643733) The reason for the feeling was obvious.
('89', 343, 6, 26, 643773) They wanted my reaction, in terms of truth and non violence, to the various events happening in India, if not in the world.

('89', 350, 2, 4, 657458) 458. ITS IMPLICATIONS
('89', 350, 3, 5, 657480) The vast meeting at Palni 1 under the shadow of the Temple was perfectly silent; there were no noises.
('89', 350, 3, 6, 657583) I seized the occasion to give the audience the implications of removal of untouchability.
('89', 350, 3, 7, 657673) It began with touch but it would be a wooden thing, if it merely ended there.
('89', 350, 3, 8, 657751) A Brahmin may be a depraved man in spite of his learning.
('89', 350, 3, 9, 657809) It would be preposterous to call him one.
('89', 350, 3, 10, 657851) A Brahmin is he who knows Brahma.
('89', 350, 3, 11, 657885) It is character, not occupation, that determines the man.
('89', 350, 3, 12, 657943) The Bhangi is, or should be, on a par with the Brahmin in all social relations.
('89', 350, 3, 13, 658023) There is no reason why he shoud not, other things being equal, occupy the chair which Maulana Abul Kalam Azad occupies with distinction.
('89', 350, 3, 14, 658160) I would be happy to see the day when a Bhangi, working as such, is in the Presidential chair.
('89', 350, 3, 15, 658254) The ulcer of untouchability has gone so deep down that it seems to pervade our life.
('89', 350, 3, 16, 658339) Hence the unreal differences; Brahmin and non Brahmin, provinces and provinces, religion and religion.
('89', 350, 3, 17, 658442) Why shoud there be all this poison smelling of untouchabiity?
('89', 350, 3, 18, 658504) Why should we not all be children of one Indian family and, further, of one human family?
('89', 350, 3, 19, 658594) Are we not like branches of the same tree?
('89', 350, 3, 20, 658637) When untouchability is rooted out, these distinctions will vanish and no one will consider himself superior to any other Naturally ex ploitation too will cease and co operation will be the order of the day.
('89', 350, 3, 21, 658844) Having dealt with untouchability, I turned to the pilgrimage.
('89', 350, 3, 22, 658906) There was fear of my being unable to negotiate the flight of over six hundred steps on a chair, if crowds of people insisted on accom panying me up the hill which was too small to accommodate them.
('89', 350, 3, 23, 659104) I would be satisfied with doing darshan at the foot of the hill.
('89', 350, 3, 24, 659169) Let not the people, however, think that I was guided by any belief in the potency of images of clay or precious metal.
('89', 350, 3, 25, 659288) Idols became what the devotees made of or imputed to them.

('89', 353, 5, 12, 664323) In reply to Sastriar’s enqiury about the tour, Gandhiji wrote that it had been very nice but very taxing.
('89', 353, 5, 13, 664429) Sastriar was surprised to hear that five to six lakhs had gathered at the prayer meeting at Madura, more than half of which number had come from the surrounding villages.

('89', 355, 5, 6, 668507) Addressing the audience in Hindustani, Mahatma Gandhi first referred to a letter 3, handed over to him by Mr. A. Subrahmanyam, a local Congressman, saying that there was a feeling among the Andhras that he (Gandhiji) had come to Madras to set up Mr. C. Rajagopalachari as the Premier.
('89', 355, 5, 7, 668792) He said that he was very sorry that there was such a misunderstanding even among Congressmen about the purpose of his trip to Madras.
('89', 355, 5, 8, 668926) Even the Telugu papers, he added, were writing that he had come to set up C. R. as Premier, and that he had made his journey specially for Mr. Rajagopa lachari’s sake.
('89', 355, 5, 9, 669094) In fact he had not even dreamt of this.
('89', 355, 5, 10, 669134) Ever since his release from jail he had been thinking of visiting Madras for Hindustani propaganda.
('89', 355, 5, 11, 669234) He made it clear that he had gone there as the President of the Dakshina Bharat Hindi Sabha Rajat Jayant (Siver Jubilee) celebrations and not in any other capacity or for any other purpose.
('89', 355, 5, 12, 669424) He was asked to speak about Mr. C. Rajagopalachari but he refused to do so.
('89', 355, 5, 13, 669500) He did not answer any letter received by him in this connection.
('89', 355, 5, 14, 669565) This was beause he was not even a four anna member of the Congress.
('89', 355, 6, 15, 669633) Mr. Rajagopalachari was his old friend, and he had great respect for his con duct and convictions.
('89', 355, 6, 16, 669732) Mr. C. Rajagopalachri was quite competent to wield the reins of Premier ship, he would do it, but to make him the Premier or to become Premier himself was not in his hands.
('89', 355, 6, 17, 669905) It was the business of the pvovincial Congress Committee and the All India Congress Cmmittee, which were the only bodies compe tent to do the job.
('89', 355, 7, 18, 670052) He was not interested in the elections and the Parliamentary programme.
('89', 355, 7, 19, 670124) Until today he had not done anything secretly nor did he intend to do so in the future.
('89', 355, 7, 20, 670212) He came to know of their misunderstanding only after his arrival in Bezwada.
('89', 355, 7, 21, 670289) He had no occasion to think of it before.
('89', 355, 7, 22, 670331) If it was his intention to interest himself in setting up Mr. C. Rajagopalachari for the post of Premiership, he need not have come all the way to Madras but could have done it from where he was.
('89', 355, 7, 23, 670527) Therefore he wanted to keep silent over this matter and did not want to interfere.
('89', 355, 8, 24, 670610) He wanted them not to forget what he had said about Hindustani propaganda.

('89', 357, 2, 7, 673795) 465. HINDUSTANI
('89', 357, 3, 8, 673811) How can any Indian really be averse to Hindustani?
('89', 357, 3, 9, 673862) Lovers of Sanskritized Hindi are, however, afraid that Hindustani will hurt Hindi and likewise lovers of Persianized Urdu fear hurt to Urdu.
('89', 357, 3, 10, 674003) These fears are futile.
('89', 357, 3, 11, 674027) No language can spread through mere propaganda.
('89', 357, 3, 12, 674075) If it had been so, Esperanto would have found a place amongst the popu lace in the West.
('89', 357, 3, 13, 674164) They failed because in such a matter the enthu siasm of only a few cannot succeed.
('89', 357, 3, 14, 674247) The language of a people who produce hard workers, literary experts, business men and enter prising persons spreads and is enriched.
('89', 357, 3, 15, 674380) It is ours to make the effort in that direction.
('89', 357, 3, 16, 674429) Only that language which the people of a country will them selves adopt can become national.
('89', 357, 3, 17, 674522) However virile the English langu age may be, it can never become the language of the masses of India.
('89', 357, 3, 18, 674624) If the British regime were to be permanent, it would continue to be the official language of their Indian officials and, because education woud be in their hands, provincial languages would suffer.
('89', 357, 3, 19, 674822) The late Lokamanya 1 once said that the British had done a service to the provincial languages.
('89', 357, 3, 20, 674918) This is true to some extent.
('89', 357, 3, 21, 674947) But it was not their business to encourage them nor could they in reality do so.
('89', 357, 3, 22, 675028) That work belongs to the people and their leaders.
('89', 357, 3, 23, 675079) If the Engish educated neg lect, as they have done and even now continue, as some do, to be igno rant of their mother tongue, linguistic starvation will abide.
('89', 357, 3, 24, 675239) We are today certain that the British Raj cannot remain for ever.
('89', 357, 3, 25, 675305) They say, and we believe, that it will go even this year.
('89', 357, 3, 26, 675363) Then there can be no national language for us other than Hindustani.
('89', 357, 3, 27, 675432) Today there are two forms of this language, Hindi and Urdu, the former written in Nagari and the latter in Urdu script.
('89', 357, 3, 28, 675552) One is fed by Sanskrit, the other
('89', 357, 4, 29, 675586) 1 Bal Gangadhar Tilak
('89', 358, 0, 1, 675608) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 359
('89', 358, 1, 2, 675656) by Persian and Arabic.
('89', 358, 1, 3, 675679) Today, therefore, both must remain.
('89', 358, 1, 4, 675715) But Hindustani will be a mixture of these.
('89', 358, 1, 5, 675758) What shape it will take in the future none can say nor need we know.
('89', 358, 1, 6, 675827) Twenty three crores out of thirty speak Hindustani.
('89', 358, 1, 7, 675879) This number must have increased pari passu with the population.
('89', 358, 1, 8, 675943) Obviously in this lies the national language.
('89', 358, 1, 9, 675989) There ought to be no quarrel between the two sisters Hindi and Urdu.
('89', 358, 1, 10, 676058) The rivalry is with English.
('89', 358, 1, 11, 676087) This struggle itself means much labour.
('89', 358, 1, 12, 676127) The rise of Hindustani will also give an impetus to the provincial languages because it is the language of the masses, not of a handful of officials.
('89', 358, 1, 13, 676277) It was for the propaganda of the national language that I went recently to the South.
('89', 358, 1, 14, 676363) The name Hindi used there up till now has been changed to Hindustani.
('89', 358, 1, 15, 676433) During the last few months several persons have been learning both the scripts and have obtained certificates.
('89', 358, 1, 16, 676544) In the South, too, the difficulty is not about the two scripts but in regard to English.
('89', 358, 1, 17, 676633) We may not blame the official world for this.
('89', 358, 1, 18, 676679) The fault lies in us.
('89', 358, 1, 19, 676701) It is we who are infatuated with English.
('89', 358, 1, 20, 676743) I found this disease even in Hindustani Nagar.
('89', 358, 1, 21, 676790) But I hope that the illusion will now disappear.
('89', 358, 1, 22, 676839) A good deal has been done in the South but much still remains, if we have to reach the desired goal.

('89', 358, 2, 24, 676976) 466. THE LESSON OF MADURAI
('89', 358, 3, 25, 677003) The crowd in Madura 1 could not have been less than five lacs and may have been even six.
('89', 358, 3, 26, 677093) Human faces were to be seen as far as the horizon.
('89', 358, 3, 27, 677144) It was a veritabe sea of human faces.
('89', 358, 3, 28, 677182) The long route to the race course was lined by people who were all to swell the crowd in the prayer ground.
('89', 358, 3, 29, 677290) They must push on as much as they could.
('89', 358, 3, 30, 677331) I doubt if the people on the fringe could even see me, much less hear me or anyone else, though loudspeaker arrangements were good and the rostrum high enough.
('89', 358, 3, 31, 677491) The volunteers were not used to manage such vast crowds.
('89', 358, 3, 32, 677548) People had come from distant villages where the Congressmen had not worked habitually, if at all.
('89', 358, 3, 33, 677646) Such being the case, the din and noise and jostle were unavoidable.

('89', 358, 3, 35, 677770) But my satyagraha for the first time failed.

('89', 361, 1, 2, 682634) 468. THE LURE OF LEGISLATURES 1
('89', 361, 2, 3, 682666) I believe that some Congressmen ought to seek election in the legislatures or other elected bodies.
('89', 361, 2, 4, 682766) In the past I did not hold this view.
('89', 361, 2, 5, 682804) 2 I had hoped that the boycott of legislatures would be complete.
('89', 361, 2, 6, 682870) That was not to be.
('89', 361, 2, 7, 682890) Moreover times have changed.
('89', 361, 2, 8, 682919) Swaraj seems to be near.
('89', 361, 2, 9, 682944) Under the circumstances it is necessary that Congress should contest every seat in the legislatures.
('89', 361, 2, 10, 683045) The attraction should never be the honour that a seat in a legislature is said to give.
('89', 361, 2, 11, 683133) The desire and opportunity for service can be the only incentive for a Congressman.
('89', 361, 2, 12, 683217) Congress should have, and has, such prestige that a Congress candi date is irresistible even where a particular seat is contested.
('89', 361, 2, 13, 683348) Moreover those that are not selected by the Board should not feel hurt.
('89', 361, 2, 14, 683420) On the contrary, they shoud feel happy that they are left there to render more useful service.
('89', 361, 2, 15, 683515) But the painful fact is that those who are not selected by the Board do feel hurt.
('89', 361, 2, 16, 683598) The Congress should not have to spend money on the elections.
('89', 361, 2, 17, 683660) Nominees of a popular organization should be elected without any effort in the latter’s part.
('89', 361, 2, 18, 683754) Conveyance arrangements for the poor voters should be made by their well to do neighbours.
('89', 361, 2, 19, 683845) For instance, if the voters from X have to go to Y, the railway fare from X to Y for the poor voters should be paid by the well to do people of X. That is the distinguishing feature of a well organized, non violent, popular organization.
('89', 361, 2, 20, 684083) An organization which looks to money for everything can never serve the masses.
('89', 361, 2, 21, 684163) If money could bring success in a popular contest, the British Government which can, and does, spend most lavishly should be the most popular body in India.
('89', 361, 2, 22, 684320) The facts are that even Government servants drawing fat salaries do not, in their heart of hearts, want the British Government.
('89', 361, 2, 23, 684448) Let us examine the utility value of legislatures.
('89', 361, 2, 24, 684498) The legislatures can expose the Government, but that is the least service.
('89', 361, 2, 25, 684573) He who can tell the people why they become victims of the Government in spite of knowing its faults, and can teach them how to stand up against Government wrongs renders a real service.
('89', 361, 2, 26, 684759) The members cannot do this essential service, for their business is to make people look to them
('89', 361, 3, 27, 684855) 1 This appeared as “translated from the Gujarati” in Harijanbandhu published simultaneously with the source.
('89', 361, 3, 28, 684964) 2 Vide “Resolution on Council Entry”, 19 5 1934
('89', 362, 0, 1, 685012) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 363
('89', 362, 1, 2, 685060) for the redress of wrongs.
('89', 362, 2, 3, 685087) The other use of legislatures is to prevent undesirable legislation and bring in laws which are useful for the public, so that as much help as possible can be given to the constructive programme.
('89', 362, 2, 4, 685283) Legislatures are supposed to carry out the popular will.
('89', 362, 2, 5, 685340) For the moment eloquence may be of some use in these bodies.
('89', 362, 2, 6, 685401) Ultimately that will not be the need.
('89', 362, 2, 7, 685439) Experts with practical knowledge and those who can give to these few their support will be required.
('89', 362, 2, 8, 685540) In an organization which exists for the sake of service and which has boycotted titles and other such paltry things, the sentiment, that to be selected as candidates for the legislatures is a mark of honour, is harmful.
('89', 362, 2, 9, 685760) If such a sentiment takes root, it will bring down the name of the Congress and finally prove its ruin.
('89', 362, 2, 10, 685864) If Congressmen are to be reduced to such degradation, who will put flesh and blood into India’s millions of skeletones?
('89', 362, 2, 11, 685984) On whom will India and the world rely?

('89', 367, 1, 2, 692999) contemplate absorption of ex service men in place of railwaymen, thus putting us against the ex soldiers.
('89', 367, 2, 3, 693105) We have been demanding a minimum living wage of Rs. 30 per mensem.
('89', 367, 2, 4, 693172) At present the lowest wage is Rs. 8 to Rs. 15, and a majority of us receive less than Rs. 18 per mensem.
('89', 367, 3, 5, 693277) Out of 42,000 railway employees, only 8,000 are provided with quarters, of which the majority are infested with insanitary conditions, and are without proper ventilation.
('89', 367, 4, 6, 693448) You may be aware of the decision of the All India Railwaymen’s Federation demanding adjudication or a court of enquiry, if they refuse to redress our grievances and accept the suggestions.
('89', 367, 4, 7, 693637) The suggestions were intended for improvements in the railway system and the condition of the employees.
('89', 367, 4, 8, 693742) For your reference we are giving below the sixteen suggestions forwarded to the Railways Board and the Government by the Federation:
('89', 367, 5, 9, 693875) 1. Reduction of work to 40 hours per week as a first step and further to 40 hours per week for all the staff including running staff without fall in wages.
('89', 367, 6, 10, 694031) 2. Introduction of weekly calendar days off for all the railwaymen.
('89', 367, 7, 11, 694099) 3. Leave reserve to be increased to 25%.
('89', 367, 8, 12, 694140) 4. Reduction of rail length for engineering gangmen.
('89', 367, 9, 13, 694193) 5. Extension of leave facilities to dailyrated and inferior service staff on par with subordinates.
('89', 367, 10, 14, 694293) 6. All the work now done through contract labour should be taken over departmentally.
('89', 367, 11, 15, 694379) 7. Reduction of mileage for overhaul of locomotives, wagons and carriages.
('89', 367, 12, 16, 694454) 8. Expansion of workshop production, namely, construction of boilers, engine parts, etc.
('89', 367, 13, 17, 694543) 9. Manufacture of locomotives, carriages and wagons in the Indian Railways workshop.
('89', 367, 14, 18, 694628) 10. Rebuilding of third class carriages so as to provide better facilities for passengers such as bath rooms, fans and sleeping accommodation for long distance travel, etc.
('89', 367, 15, 19, 694801) 11. Reopening all the lines that were closed and the restoration of all the trains stopped during the period of war and further expansion of services to meet the needs of the public.
('89', 367, 16, 20, 694984) 12. A programme of house building with a view to provide decent houses for all railwaymen.
('89', 367, 17, 21, 695075) 13. Construction of new lines to suit the needs of the country.
('89', 368, 0, 1, 695139) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 369
('89', 368, 1, 2, 695187) 14. Laying down of double tracks wherever necessary.
('89', 368, 2, 3, 695240) 15. Introduction of rail motor transport to the distant towns and villages where railways cannot reach.
('89', 368, 3, 4, 695344) 16. R. A. F. workshops now controlled by railways to be maintained and extended to serve the need of aviation.
('89', 368, 4, 5, 695455) In the demand of ours for full work, living wages, proper housing facilities, etc., we request you to support us and give a lead in the matter to the country and force the Railway Board to accept the same and save thousands of railwaymen and others from unemployment, misery and poverty.
('89', 368, 4, 6, 695743) If the workers are to be retrenched in order to make room, as alleged in the letter, for ex soldiers, it is, in my opinion, doubly wrong.
('89', 368, 4, 7, 695881) Wrong for the ex soldier in that they will be favoured, and a solider who accepts favoured treatment is no solider.
('89', 368, 4, 8, 695997) The second wrong will be to the men to be retrenched who, for no fault of their own, will be thrown out of employment.
('89', 368, 4, 9, 696116) It will not do to say they were temporary hands The State has to find work for all unemployed persons.
('89', 368, 4, 10, 696219) Coming to the railwaymen’s demands, items Nos.
('89', 368, 4, 11, 696266) 1 9 and No.
('89', 368, 4, 12, 696278) 12 fall, in my opinion, within the sphere of labour, but whether they are reasonnable or not cannot be said without hearing the railway authorities’ side.
('89', 368, 4, 13, 696433) They should be referred to arbitration.
('89', 368, 4, 14, 696473) They cannot be made a subject of strike, before the process of arbitration has been gone through.
('89', 368, 4, 15, 696571) Any lightning strike is a form of dictation which is dangerous.
('89', 368, 4, 16, 696635) Items Nos.
('89', 368, 4, 17, 696646) 10, 11 and 13 16, cannot legitimately be demanded by labourers.
('89', 368, 4, 18, 696710) They are passengers’ grievances and passengers, i.e., the public, can take them up.
('89', 368, 4, 19, 696794) Item No.
('89', 368, 4, 20, 696803) 10 I would consider quite extravagant.
('89', 368, 4, 21, 696842) By far the largest number of passengers belong to the third class, and I have no doubt they deserve progressively better treatment, not the first and second class.
('89', 368, 4, 22, 697006) Raiway cars of the not distant future will have no classes.
('89', 368, 4, 23, 697066) Classes society is the idea , not merely to be aimed at but to be worked for and, in such society there is no room for classes or communties.
('89', 368, 4, 24, 697208) Until that time is arrived at, first and second class comforts be standardized and lowered where necessary and all attention bestowed upon third class passengers.
('89', 368, 4, 25, 697371) But I cannot visualize a time when third class carriages, no matter how distant of the journey may be, can carry bathing accommodation for tens of thousands of travellers.
('89', 368, 4, 26, 697543) What is required is proper bathing arrangement for third class passengers at railway stations.
('89', 368, 4, 27, 697638) Third class passengers are the most neglected in
('89', 369, 0, 1, 697687) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 369, 1, 2, 697729) Railway cars and railway stations should be utilized for proper education of the public in sanitation and cleanliness.
('89', 369, 1, 3, 697848) This is not the case today.
('89', 369, 1, 4, 697876) And the quicker Hindu and Mohammedan tea or water distinctions disappear the better 1 .
('89', 369, 1, 5, 697964) Why should the State recognize these unnatural and irreligious distinctions?
('89', 369, 1, 6, 698041) Those who consider themselves defiled by service rendered by person not belonging to their own persuasion may well be left to their own resources.
('89', 369, 1, 7, 698188) The association for railway passengers’ relief should certainly ventilate grievances before the authorities.
('89', 369, 1, 8, 698297) Their main work should be to conduct sustained education among the passengers as to their own duty toward one another and about observing laws of cleanliness and hygiene.

('89', 372, 5, 14, 702985) 483. PRESERVATION OF CATTLE 1
('89', 372, 6, 15, 703015) The Goseva Sangh which has its headquarters in Wardha was the late Shri Jamnalalji’s last creation.
('89', 372, 6, 16, 703115) He served the public cause in a variety of ways.
('89', 372, 6, 17, 703164) For years money making had ceased to be his main occupation.
('89', 372, 6, 18, 703225) If he cared for money, it was only with the object of financing public activities.

('89', 372, 6, 20, 703506) An hour before he died, he was working for this cause.
('89', 372, 6, 21, 703561) Gopuri, where the meeting took place, is his creation.
('89', 372, 6, 22, 703616) His ashes rest there, and the first meeting of the Sangh was also held there.
('89', 372, 6, 23, 703694) The name Goseva was chosen after careful thought.
('89', 372, 6, 24, 703744) The sense of patronage contained in goraksha was eliminated by the substitution of the word seva.
('89', 372, 6, 25, 703842) The Hindu believes in the cow as mother and indeed she is so.
('89', 372, 6, 26, 703904) An American has described her as the “Mother of Prosperity” and the description is correct.
('89', 372, 6, 27, 703996) It is another matter that they eat beef in the West.

('89', 373, 2, 22, 705779) 484. QUESTION BOX 1
('89', 373, 3, 23, 705799) Q. While in conversation or doing brain work or when one is suddenly worried, can one recite Ramanama (the name of God) in one’s heart?
('89', 373, 3, 24, 705935) Do people do so at such times and, if so, how?
('89', 373, 4, 25, 705982) A. Experience shows that man can do so at any time, even in sleep, provided Ramanama is enshrined in his heart.
('89', 373, 4, 26, 706094) If the taking of the name has become a habit, its racitation through the ear becomes as natural as the heartbeat.
('89', 373, 4, 27, 706208) Otherwise Ramanama is a mere mechanical performance or at best has touched the heart only on the surface.
('89', 373, 4, 28, 706314) When Ramanama has established its dominion over the heart, the question of vocal recitation does not arise.
('89', 373, 4, 29, 706422) Because then it transcends
('89', 373, 5, 30, 706449) 1 This appeared as “from the Hindustani” in Harijan Sevak published simulta neously with the source.
('89', 374, 0, 1, 706550) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 375
('89', 374, 1, 2, 706598) speech.
('89', 374, 1, 3, 706606) But it may well be held that person who have attained this state are few and far between.
('89', 374, 1, 4, 706696) There is no doubt whatsoever that Ramanama contains all the power that it attributed to it.
('89', 374, 1, 5, 706788) No one can, by mere wishing, enshrine Ramanama in his heart.
('89', 374, 1, 6, 706849) Untiring effort is required as also patience.
('89', 374, 1, 7, 706895) What an amount of labour and patience have been lavished by men to acquire the non existent philosopher’s stone?
('89', 374, 1, 8, 707008) Surely God’s name is of infinitely richer value and always existent.
('89', 374, 2, 9, 707077) Q. Is it necessary for the mind to go through different stage of progress (including collapse) before it attains absolute calm?
('89', 374, 2, 10, 707205) Why is it that even when one is awake and quite calm, one’s mind is often disturbed as in a dream?
('89', 374, 2, 11, 707304) Why do such things as one has neither felt or seen in real life intrude into one’s conscious or sub conscious mind?
('89', 374, 3, 12, 707420) A. Before attaining perfect calm, it is essential for almost every one to go through stages of progress.
('89', 374, 3, 13, 707525) I use the word ‘almost’ ad visedly.
('89', 374, 3, 14, 707561) It exclude those who have made consistent effort in a pre vious existence, but without complete success, and who will not, there fore, have to pass through purgatory in this life.
('89', 374, 3, 15, 707741) When the apparently calm mind is disturbed as if by dreams, it means that the calm is outward and not inward.
('89', 374, 3, 16, 707851) What does not appear to have any relation to one’s life’s experience and yet disturbs shows, in my opinion, that there are many things which have associations but of which one has no recollection.
('89', 374, 4, 17, 708048) Q. Is it harmful if, owing to stress or exigencies of work, one is unable to carry out daily devotions in the prescribed manner?
('89', 374, 4, 18, 708177) Which of the two should be given preference, service or the rosary?
('89', 374, 5, 19, 708245) A. Whatever the exigencies of service or adverse circumstances may be, Ramanama must not cease.
('89', 374, 5, 20, 708341) The outward form will vary according to the occasion.
('89', 374, 5, 21, 708395) The absence of the rosary does not interrupt Ramanama which has found an abiding place in the heart.
('89', 374, 5, 22, 708496) SEVAGRAM, February 9, 1946 Harijan, 17 2 1946

('89', 375, 1, 2, 708584) 485. CRIMINAL IF TRUE 1
('89', 375, 2, 3, 708608) A letter from Karnataka contains the following information:
('89', 375, 3, 4, 708668) On February 1, 1946, at about 10 a.m.
('89', 375, 3, 5, 708706) when the Karnataka Provincial Congress Parliamentary Board was conducting its business in its office in Hubli, 20 to 25 persons effected an entrance into the meeting hall without first obtaining permission of the President.
('89', 375, 4, 6, 708930) The Board had met to discuss some improtant matters.
('89', 375, 4, 7, 708983) Some of the persons above mentioned asked for time to make certain representa tions.
('89', 375, 4, 8, 709068) The President told them that sufficient time for the purpose had been given to them on the previous day.
('89', 375, 4, 9, 709173) The Board was now engaged in serious deliberations but would see them again during the afternoon.
('89', 375, 5, 10, 709271) reply, they said, they had further important matter to represent and insisted on doing so then and there.
('89', 375, 5, 11, 709377) The president opined that their attitude was quite inconsistent with due decorum and discipline, but they continued to insist, whereupon the President said that he would be obliged to leave the hall.
('89', 375, 5, 12, 709577) As he stood up in order to go away,one member of the party tried forcibly to hold him down.
('89', 375, 5, 13, 709669) Another snatched the office files from his hands and was going to take them away.
('89', 375, 5, 14, 709751) Yet another hit Shri Diwaker on the head with his umbrella.
('89', 375, 5, 15, 709811) Persons in the hall finally came to the rescue and restored order.
('89', 375, 5, 16, 709878) If such be the case, the Congress organization will go to pieces.
('89', 375, 5, 17, 709944) Indeed no organization can successfully work under a system of terror.
('89', 375, 5, 18, 710015) I do not go into the merits.
('89', 375, 5, 19, 710044) That work will be done by the Congress Working Committee.
('89', 375, 5, 20, 710102) What is reported to have taken place is not against decency and all the rules of the game, but is manifestly against non violence.
('89', 375, 5, 21, 710233) Moreover there seems to be an indecent longing for getting into the legislatures.This indecency shows that the deciding reason for contesting elections is being lost sight of.

('89', 376, 1, 2, 710534) 486. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('89', 376, 2, 3, 710564) SEVAGRAM, February 9, 1946
('89', 376, 3, 4, 710591) KRISHNACHANDRA, Today I am dictating this letter in Gujarati.
('89', 376, 3, 5, 710653) 1. Those who feel themselves poor without the knowledge of English may be taught the language.
('89', 376, 3, 6, 710748) The general policy should be understood that nobody should be taught English, and that, when it is found necessary to teach anybody, my permission should be ob tained.
('89', 376, 3, 7, 710916) 2. The reason for stressing the importance of carding is that, if we learn it, we shall be spared the necessity of all other processes.
('89', 376, 3, 8, 711052) If, in addition to carding by hand, they also think it necessary, they may use the carding bow, but I don’ regard that as essential.
('89', 376, 3, 9, 711185) I see no difficulty at all in stopping the practice of procuring the gutstring of the carding bow from outside.
('89', 376, 3, 10, 711297) Good cotton can be carded with a string made of mooj 1 or yarn.
('89', 376, 3, 11, 711361) But I don’t insist on this.
('89', 376, 3, 12, 711389) 3. General supervision work leaves no time for teaching things to others.
('89', 376, 3, 13, 711463) It is another matter if, in order to improve one’s efficiency in supervision work or relax one’s mind, one finds it necessary to take up some other work.
('89', 376, 3, 14, 711617) It is difficult to lay down any rule in this matter.
('89', 376, 3, 15, 711670) The supervisor himself must decide.
('89', 376, 3, 16, 711706) It is a sign of ignorant attach ment to go on working till the breaking point.
('89', 376, 3, 17, 711785) 4. I regard a weekly tour by Vinoba as essential.
('89', 376, 3, 18, 711835) There would be no harm in his taking someone who can be spared from his work and who is eager to learn.
('89', 376, 3, 19, 711939) The rule that one person should always accompany him seems laudable.
('89', 376, 3, 20, 712008) Blessings from BAPU

('89', 376, 6, 23, 712104) During my wanderings in Bengal, Assam and Madras, I heard tales of distress due to shortage of food and cloth.
('89', 376, 6, 24, 712215) Reports come to
('89', 376, 7, 25, 712231) 1 A kind of hay
('89', 377, 0, 1, 712247) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 377, 1, 2, 712289) me from other parts of India.
('89', 377, 1, 3, 712319) They support the same tale.
('89', 377, 1, 4, 712347) Dr. Raj endra Prasad tells me that the Government report expressing fear of shortage of food immediately doubled the market price.
('89', 377, 1, 5, 712478) This is a bad sign.
('89', 377, 1, 6, 712498) Such speculation should be a thing of the past.
('89', 377, 1, 7, 712546) The mer cantile community should be competent to curb such greed.
('89', 377, 1, 8, 712612) Let them not add to the distress caused by the Government mistakes or incom petence.
('89', 377, 1, 9, 712697) There are mercantile association and chambers.
('89', 377, 1, 10, 712744) If they act patriotically, they can help most to prevent panic and speculation.
('89', 377, 1, 11, 712824) It is the fashion to blame nature for famine.
('89', 377, 1, 12, 712870) Scarcity of rain is by no means a monopoly of India.In other countries, though people welcome rains, they have made themselves fairly independent of rainfall during a season or two.
('89', 377, 1, 13, 713052) Here Government have used them selves and the public to the idea that famines come when there is shortage of rainfall 1. Had the mind been framed otherwise, they would have made adequate provision for shortfalls.
('89', 377, 1, 14, 713265) They only tinkered with the porblem and naturally so.
('89', 377, 1, 15, 713319) For the official world was taught to think no better.
('89', 377, 1, 16, 713373) Originality there could be none in a close monopoly organization like the Government of India.
('89', 377, 1, 17, 713468) It is the largest autocracy the world has known.
('89', 377, 1, 18, 713517) Democracy has been reserved only for Great Britain.
('89', 377, 1, 19, 713569) And when it rules and exploits millions belonging to other races, it becomes an unmitigated evil.
('89', 377, 1, 20, 713667) It corrupts the whole island with the idea that such exploitation is the best thing for an enlightened democracy to do.
('89', 377, 1, 21, 713787) It would be well to remember this fundmental fact, if I have correctly estimated it.
('89', 377, 1, 22, 713872) If we recognize this while dealing with the immediate problem, we shall be patient with the present actors.
('89', 377, 1, 23, 713980) There is no call here for patience with the evil.
('89', 377, 1, 24, 714030) The distinction will enable us the better to deal with the evil.
('89', 377, 1, 25, 714095) We must then first put our own house in order as far as may be, and at the same time demand from the foreign Government that since they mean what they say, let them at once replace the irresponsible executive with elected and responsible members from the Central Legislature, however arcahic and based only on a limited franchise it may be.
('89', 377, 1, 26, 714436) There is nothing to prevent the Viceory from doing this today.
('89', 377, 1, 27, 714499) I do not propose to answer the difficulties in anticipation.
('89', 377, 1, 28, 714560) “Where there’s will, there’s a way”.
('89', 377, 1, 29, 714597) This one act will restore confi dence and allay panic.
('89', 377, 1, 30, 714652) “Grow more food” was not a bad cry during the war.
('89', 377, 1, 31, 714703) It is a greater necessity now.
('89', 377, 1, 32, 714734) This can be best done only by a national
('89', 377, 2, 33, 714775) 1 The source has “waterfall”.

('89', 378, 1, 2, 714853) executive.
('89', 378, 1, 3, 714864) Even its mistakes will not loom so large as those of a nominated executive, however able the latter may be.
('89', 378, 1, 4, 714972) As it is, even their ability and integrity are in question—rightly so or wrongly is beside the point in this connection.
('89', 378, 1, 5, 715093) Everything possible should be done to draw water from the bowels of the earth.There is talent enough in this country for the purpose.
('89', 378, 1, 6, 715227) Provincial selfshness should give place to the national want.
('89', 378, 1, 7, 715289) In addition to, not in the place of , these measures, grain should be imported from wherever it can be had.
('89', 378, 1, 8, 715397) Cloth famine can and ought to be averted by telling the millions to spin and weave in their own villages, the State supplying them with cotton where it is not grown or available, and with the simple instruments of production on hire or long term purchase.
('89', 378, 1, 9, 715653) The A. I. S. A. with its seasoned workers should be summoned to render assistance and guidance.

('89', 378, 1, 11, 715814) Indigenous mills will be called upon to assist this national process by a wise distribution of their cloth in citites and villages while the transition process is going on.
('89', 378, 1, 12, 715987) Argumentation on the capacity of mills to supply all the cloth required should cease in face of the calamity which is existent and daily growing in intensity.
('89', 378, 1, 13, 716146) Mills cannot find employment for the millions of unemployed villa gers.
('89', 378, 1, 14, 716218) The educative value of the charkha is not be surpassed.
('89', 378, 1, 15, 716274) But for the spell of hypnotism which rules our minds today, we shall all realize this obvious truth, set ourselves working out the concrete pro position and thereby restore confidence to the millions and, maybe, even to the world which has neither enough food nor cloth 1 .

('89', 379, 1, 2, 717323) editions—the Hindustani, the Gujarati and the English—are my weekly letter to readers.
('89', 379, 1, 3, 717410) But I would not be wrong, if I described the Gujarati edition as specially so.
('89', 379, 1, 4, 717489) Gujarati being my mother tongue, a large number of correspondents write letters to me in that language than in the others, and I reply to them more easily and freely.
('89', 379, 1, 5, 717656) If, therefore, I wrote only in Gujarati and the material for the other editions was supplied as translations, I would have to take less pains, and I would be able to enrich the Gujarati Harijan 1

('89', 379, 3, 19, 718658) For the present, however, I wish to let things continue as they are.
('89', 379, 3, 20, 718727) I cannot say at the moment where the ship will anchor in view of this, I hope, the Gujarati reader will excuse me, if he finds in the Gujarati Harijan more translations of my English articles than original Guja rati articles.

('89', 383, 4, 10, 723931) 496. FLAGS AND SCHOOLS 1
('89', 383, 5, 11, 723956) I have two typical letters about flags in schools and colleges.
('89', 383, 5, 12, 724020) Some boys hoist the Congress flag, therefore others hoist the League flag.
('89', 383, 5, 13, 724095) Both are wrong.
('89', 383, 5, 14, 724111) My correspondents report that the mischief commenced by the hoisting of the Congress flag.
('89', 383, 5, 15, 724202) Probably nothing would have tolerated.
('89', 383, 5, 16, 724241) The right thing was, and is, that boys must not take the initative in such cases.
('89', 383, 5, 17, 724323) The buildings belong to the authorities and they must decide whether or not to fly, which, if any, flag over their buildings.
('89', 383, 5, 18, 724449) If boys take the law into their own hands, the result must be chaos and confusion plus breaking of heads.
('89', 383, 5, 19, 724555) This would be sheer vulgarity and doing no good to anybody.
('89', 383, 5, 20, 724615) Schools and colleges should be institution for healing communal breaches, not for promo ting differences.
('89', 383, 5, 21, 724721) If boys and girls do not learn discipline in their school days, money and time spent on their education is so much national loss.
('89', 383, 5, 22, 724851) The one bright thing that emerges from the Lahore episode is that Maulana Saheb Abul Kalam Azad promptly intervened and ruled that the boys who had hoisted the Congress flag were in the wrong.
('89', 383, 6, 23, 725044) SEVAGRAM, February 11, 1946 Harijan, 17 2 1946
('89', 383, 7, 24, 725091) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('89', 384, 0, 1, 725122) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 385
('89', 384, 1, 2, 725170) 497. LIVING UP TO 125 1
('89', 384, 2, 3, 725194) I have not talked about wishing to live up to the age of 125 years without thought.
('89', 384, 2, 4, 725278) It has a deep significance.
('89', 384, 2, 5, 725306) The basis for my wish is the third mantra from Ishopanishad which, literally rendered, means that a man should desire to live for 100 years while serving with detachment.
('89', 384, 2, 6, 725477) One commentary says that 100 really means 125. Even today in Madras the word ‘hundred’ is used to mean described as Rs. 100, but was, on scrutiny, found to be Rs. 116. 100=99+1 is not an invariable formula in our country.
('89', 384, 2, 7, 725699) Be that as it may, the meaning of ‘hundred’ is not necessary for my argument.
('89', 384, 2, 8, 725777) My sole purpose is to indicate the condition necessary for the realization of the desire.
('89', 384, 2, 9, 725867) It is service in a spirit of detachment, which means complete independenc of the fruit of action.
('89', 384, 2, 10, 725965) Without it one should not desire to live for 125 years.
('89', 384, 2, 11, 726021) That is how I interpret the text.
('89', 384, 2, 12, 726055) I have not the slightest doubt that without attaining that state of detachment, it is impossible to live to be 125 years old.
('89', 384, 2, 13, 726181) Living to that age must never mean a mere life unto death, like that of an animated corpse, a burden on one’s relations and society.
('89', 384, 2, 14, 726314) In such circumstance one’s supreme duty would be to pray to God for early release, not for prolongation of life anyhow.
('89', 384, 2, 15, 726434) The human body is meant solely for service, never for indulgence.
('89', 384, 2, 16, 726500) The secret of happy life lies in renunciation.
('89', 384, 2, 17, 726547) Renunciat ion is life.
('89', 384, 2, 18, 726570) Indulgence spells death.
('89', 384, 2, 19, 726595) Therefore everyone has a right and should desire to live 125 year while performing service without on eye on result.
('89', 384, 2, 20, 726712) Such life must be wholly and solely dedicated to service.
('89', 384, 2, 21, 726770) Renunciation made for the same of such service is an ineffa blye joy of which none can deprive one, because that nectar springs from within and sustains life.
('89', 384, 2, 22, 726929) In this there can be no room for worry or impatience.
('89', 384, 2, 23, 726983) Without this joy long life is impossible and would not be worth while even if possible.
('89', 384, 2, 24, 727071) Examination of the possibility of prolonging life to 125 years by outward means is outside the scope of this argument.
('89', 384, 2, 25, 727190) SEVAGRAM, February 11, 1946 Harijan, 24 2 1946
('89', 384, 3, 26, 727237) 1 Originaly published in Gujarati, this appeared as “from Harijanbandhu”, 17 2 1946.

('89', 386, 4, 9, 728565) 501. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('89', 386, 5, 10, 728593) [On or after February 11, 1946] 1
('89', 386, 6, 11, 728627) The food situation brought the Private Secretary to H. E. the Viceroy to me.
('89', 386, 6, 12, 728704) I had many meetings and appointments up to a fairly long time.
('89', 386, 6, 13, 728767) These I could not disregard, and I do not know how to fly, and hope I may never have to do so.
('89', 386, 6, 14, 728862) Therefore in reply to an imperative invitation from His Excellency, I asked 2 that he should send me someone who could speak for him, and so the P. S. V. came yesterday 3. The food situation alone brought him to me.
('89', 386, 6, 15, 729078) Could I say something in order to lift the question out of the political arena and out of the general distrust of Government intentions and policy?
('89', 386, 6, 16, 729226) As the matter brooks no delay, I give here the purport of what I said.
('89', 386, 6, 17, 729297) So far as the Congress policy is concerned, His Excellency should invite Maulana Saheb and, if he cannot come, ask him to name his deputy.
('89', 386, 6, 18, 729436) I personally feel that the present irresponsible Executive should be immediately replaced by a responsible one chosen from the elected members of the Central Legislature.
('89', 386, 6, 19, 729607) I also personally feel that this responsibility should be shouldered by the elected members of the Central Legislature irrespective of parties, for famine of cloth and food is common to the millions of India.
('89', 386, 6, 20, 729816) Whether the Government can accept the suggestion and whether the different political parties that compose the Central Legislature consider it practicable or not, is more than I can say.
('89', 386, 6, 21, 730002) But this much I can say without fear of contradiction: I have little doubt that if the mercantile community and

('89', 386, 8, 23, 730341) 2 Vide “Letter to Lord Wavell”,10 2 1946
('89', 386, 9, 24, 730382) 3 It being his Silence Day, Gandhiji wrote down his part of the dialogue; for an an extract from Abell’s note, vide “G. E. B. Abell’s Note on Interview With Gandhiji”, 11 2 1946

('89', 387, 1, 2, 730602) the official would become honest, if only in face of the impending calamity, we are such a vast country that we can just tide over the difficulty even if no help comes from the outside world, which is itself groaning.
('89', 387, 1, 3, 730820) Grain and cloth dealers must not hoard, must not speculate.
('89', 387, 1, 4, 730880) Food should be grown on all cultivable areas wherever water is, or is made available.
('89', 387, 1, 5, 730966) Flower gardens should be used for growing food crops.

('89', 387, 1, 10, 731253) Women can play the highest part in the alleviation of the present distress by economizing in their households.
('89', 387, 1, 11, 731364) In nine tenths of our activity we can manage our daily affairs without the aid of the Government, whatever its colour may be, if only it will refrain from interfering with the people.

('89', 387, 1, 14, 731756) Let us not hypnotize into the belief that because we can indulge ourselves, our next door neighbour can do likewise.

('89', 389, 9, 22, 734071) February 12, 1946 The principle of succession to propety should be based on new fundamental, i.
('89', 389, 9, 23, 734167) e., that those who act up to the wishes of the departed soul or carry on his work should be the real heirs and not those born in his family.
('89', 389, 9, 24, 734308) So, if Janaki Devi 2 or Kamalnaya 3 or Ramakrishna3 do not devote themselves to Jamnalal Bajaj’s incomplete work whose anni versary we are observing, they have no right to be Janmnalal’s heirs, but persons like us who carry on his work 4 .

('89', 390, 1, 2, 734719) Mahatma Gandhi then referred to the impending famine and the visit of the Viceroy’s Private Secretary to Sevagram last evening.
('89', 390, 1, 3, 734847) I have visited Bengal and Assam and met workers from Orissa.
('89', 390, 1, 4, 734908) I have seen people who have expressed their views about the famine which is staring them in the face unless proper steps are taken.
('89', 390, 1, 5, 735040) If things or food can be imported from outside, it is well and good.
('89', 390, 1, 6, 735109) But this year there is little prospert for that for transferring food from one province to another.
('89', 390, 1, 7, 735209) So my advice to you would be to minimize food requirements, avoid wastage and serve both men and cattle to your utmost capacity.
('89', 390, 1, 8, 735338) We must produce better milk and increase our wealth and improve our health.
('89', 390, 1, 9, 735414) If you devote to cow keeping, it will be a fiting tribute to Jamnalal’s revered memory.
('89', 390, 1, 10, 735502) 1 If you don’t know how to serve your own people, how can you serve animals and especially cows?

('89', 392, 4, 9, 738380) 511. LETTER TO VERRIER ELWIN
('89', 392, 5, 10, 738409) SEVAGRAM, “VIA” WARDHA (C.P.), February 13, 1946
('89', 392, 6, 11, 738458) MY DEAR VERRIER, Your letter of 1st November was given to me by our mutual friend Jehangir Patel after the 14th January through Thakkar Bapa.
('89', 392, 6, 12, 738600) Your language cannot hurt me.
('89', 392, 6, 13, 738630) I love you so well and so much that language has no effect on me, even as my son Harilal’s has not.
('89', 392, 6, 14, 738730) What has hurt me is that distrust of you has crept into me.
('89', 392, 6, 15, 738790) Bapa, who loves you, if it were possible to do so more than I do, deepens that distrust.
('89', 392, 6, 16, 738879) I do not know whether I have succeeded in conveying to you my full meaning.
('89', 392, 6, 17, 738955) Your learning which I know is very great, is worth nothing to me if you do not or cannot represent truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.
('89', 392, 6, 18, 739104) Of course you know this fine oath that is administered to every witness before a law court.
('89', 392, 6, 19, 739196) That it has become a mere mechanical thing and debasing as that does not matter.
('89', 392, 6, 20, 739277) We utter God’s name in vain.
('89', 392, 6, 21, 739306) He does not suffer.
('89', 392, 6, 22, 739326) Is it possible that untruth has crept into you ?
('89', 392, 6, 23, 739375) Bapa swears, I feel.
('89', 392, 6, 24, 739396) Bapa will see this letter before I send it and so will Jehangir Patel through whom it will go, if it does.
('89', 392, 6, 25, 739503) I have dictated this letter because Harijan takes almost every ounce of my energy.
('89', 392, 8, 26, 739586) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('89', 394, 6, 13, 741420) 515. WHAT OUGHT TO BE DONE
('89', 394, 7, 14, 741447) Food crisis should be regarded as a certainty.
('89', 394, 7, 15, 741494) In the circum stances, the following things should be attended to at once: 1. Every person should confine his daily wants regarding food to the minimum, consistent with his or her health requirements; and where, as in cities, milk, vegetables, oil and fruit are available, grains and pulses should be reduced as they easily can be.
('89', 394, 7, 16, 741826) Starch can be derived from starchy roots such as carrots, parsnips, potatoes, yam, banana; the idea being to exclude from present diet and conserve those grains and pulses which can be kept and stored.
('89', 394, 7, 17, 742028) Vegetables too should not be eaten as an indulgence or for pleasure when millions are denied the use of these things altogether and are now threatned with starvation due to shortage of cereals and pulses.
('89', 394, 7, 18, 742233) 2. Everyone who has access to any water should try himself or herself to grow some edibles for personal or general use.
('89', 394, 7, 19, 742353) The easiest way to do so is to collect clean earth, mix it with organic manure where possible—even a little bit of dried cowdung is good organic manure—and put it in any earthen or tin pot and throw some seeds of vegetable such as mustard and cress, etc., and daily water the pots.
('89', 394, 8, 20, 742635) 1 Dated February 8, 1946; for the text, vide “Letter From M. R. Jayakar”, 8 2 1946
('89', 395, 0, 1, 742718) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 395, 1, 2, 742760) They will be surprised how quickly the seeds sprout and give edible leaves which need not even be cooked but can be eaten in the form of salad.
('89', 395, 1, 3, 742904) 3. All flower gardens should be utiized for growing edibles.
('89', 395, 1, 4, 742965) And in this connection I would suggest to the Viceroy, Governors and high officials to take the lead.
('89', 395, 1, 5, 743067) I would ask the heads of agricultural departments at the Centre and Provinces to flood the country with leaflets in the provincial language tellling laymen how and what to grow easily.
('89', 395, 1, 6, 743252) 4. Reduction should be taken up not merely by the civilian population but equally, if not predominantly, by the military.
('89', 395, 1, 7, 743374) I say “predominantly“ for the military ranks, being under rigid military discipline, can easily carry out measures of economy.
('89', 395, 1, 8, 743501) 5. All exports of seeds, such as oil seeds, oils, oil cakes, nuts, etc., should be stopped, if they have not been already.
('89', 395, 1, 9, 743624) Oil cakes, if the seeds are sifted of earth and foreign matter, are good human food with rich protein content.
('89', 395, 1, 10, 743735) 6. Deep wells should be sunk by the Government wherever possible and required, whether for irrigation or for drinking purposes.
('89', 395, 1, 11, 743863) 7. Given hearty co operation by Government servants and the general public, I have not the slightest doubt that the country can tide over the difficulty.
('89', 395, 1, 12, 744017) Just as panic is the surest way to defeat, so also will be the case when there is widespread distress impending and prompt action is not taken.
('89', 395, 1, 13, 744161) Let us not think of the cause of the distress.
('89', 395, 1, 14, 744208) Whatever the cause, the fact is that if the Government and the public do not approach the crisis patiently and courageously, disaster is a certainty.
('89', 395, 1, 15, 744358) We must fight this foreign Government on all other fronts except this one, and even on this we shall fight them, if they betray callousness or contempt for reasoned public opinion.
('89', 395, 1, 16, 744539) In this connection I invite the public to share my opinion that we should accept Government professions at their face value, and believe that swaraj is within sight inside of a few months.
('89', 395, 1, 17, 744728) 8. Above all, black marketing and dishonesty should disappear altogether, and willing co operation between all parties should be the order of the day in so far as this crisis is concerned.
('89', 395, 2, 18, 744917) SEVGARAM, February 14, 1946 Harijan, 24 2 1946
('89', 395, 3, 19, 744964) 1Vide also “Statement to the Press”, 11 2 1946

('89', 399, 3, 5, 747941) DINSHAW, I shall reach there on the 19th.
('89', 399, 3, 6, 747983) I shall write later by what train.
('89', 399, 3, 7, 748018) We shall be about 11 or 12 people.
('89', 399, 3, 8, 748053) This time I am not coming as your guest, but for the sake of the work that we want to do there.
('89', 399, 3, 9, 748149) This time my party as well as I will meet our food expenses only from the funds reserved for the poor.
('89', 399, 3, 10, 748252) You need not, therefore, incur any expenditur on that account.
('89', 399, 3, 11, 748315) I will reimburse then and there whatever you spend [on our account].
('89', 399, 3, 12, 748384) That too would not be from my own account but from the money that is earmarked for the poor out of the hospital fund.
('89', 399, 3, 13, 748502) The other that lies with me has not been earmarked for any particular purpose.
('89', 399, 3, 14, 748581) And this amount belongs to my rich friends Whatever amont now remians with you is what you have earned yourself and for your personal expenses.
('89', 399, 3, 15, 748725) And I have no right to take a single piece out of it, for after having become a trustee I should not regard it as my right to draw anything from that amount.
('89', 399, 3, 16, 748883) As regards accommodating me, I shall put up wherever you ask me to, i.
('89', 399, 3, 17, 748954) e., in the room you have reserved for me or in any part of the hospital or in a tent.
('89', 399, 3, 18, 749040) I don’t at all regard it as inconvenient for me to put up in a tent in this season.
('89', 399, 3, 19, 749124) And I shall not find it inconvenient to stay throughout the year in a place with a tiled floor.
('89', 399, 3, 20, 749220) You had such a place made for the Working Committee.
('89', 399, 3, 21, 749273) You are not to incur any expenditure on my account.
('89', 399, 3, 22, 749325) If I don’t proceed with a hardened heart as I do, I will not be worthy of the trust, nor will I be able to serve the poor through the trust.
('89', 399, 3, 23, 749466) I hope you, Gulbai 1 and Ardeshir 2 are fine, and I expect Maji 3 is enjoying peace and happiness.
('89', 399, 3, 24, 749565) From there I shall return on the 1st of March.
('89', 399, 3, 25, 749612) I expect to go to Poona again on the 19th or 20th of March.
('89', 399, 3, 26, 749672) The rest when we meet.

('89', 400, 1, 2, 749902) 523. ABOUT RAJAJI
('89', 400, 2, 3, 749920) I have read Shri Kamaraja Nadar’s Press message 1 .
('89', 400, 2, 4, 749972) I am sorry.
('89', 400, 2, 5, 749984) I can easily be silent, but the cause may suffer.
('89', 400, 2, 6, 750034) He says he is my follower.
('89', 400, 2, 7, 750061) In that case he should have referred to me before rushing to the Press and certainly before resigning 2 .
('89', 400, 2, 8, 750167) I have intentionally descri bed myself as a Bhangi.
('89', 400, 2, 9, 750219) In the man made social ladder I want to be at the bottom.
('89', 400, 2, 10, 750277) I would like Shri Kamraj to cease to be a Nadar and to become a Bhangi with me and then in all humility withdraw his resig nation.
('89', 400, 2, 11, 750408) Whatever it is legally or not, the Provincial and Working Com mittees alone can decide.
('89', 400, 2, 12, 750496) Morally it is perfectly possible, if he him self feels he has hurt himself and the cause by resigning.
('89', 400, 2, 13, 750599) Then he will rejoin the difficult post (if it is legally possible) as a strong man.
('89', 400, 2, 14, 750683) He was weak in resigning.
('89', 400, 2, 15, 750709) He says he prevented four others from follow ing him.
('89', 400, 2, 16, 750763) It was well that they did not resign.
('89', 400, 2, 17, 750801) Why worry about the use of the word ‘clique’?
('89', 400, 2, 18, 750847) 3 In spite of all my love for the English lenguage, it is a foreign tongue for me and I am as likely as not to make mistakes in using it.
('89', 400, 2, 19, 750985) Of course, I have used the word ‘clique’ deliberately.
('89', 400, 2, 20, 751040) I must not withdraw it.
('89', 400, 2, 21, 751064) This is its dictionary meaning:“small exclusive party”.
('89', 400, 2, 22, 751120) I know that there is such a clique in Tamil Nadu against Rajaji.
('89', 400, 2, 23, 751185) I am unable definitely to name one single person in it.
('89', 400, 2, 24, 751241) 4 No one need wear the cap unless it fits him.
('89', 400, 2, 25, 751288) There are many cliques in the Congress organization as even in the best managed organizations in the world.
('89', 400, 2, 26, 751396) The fewer their number the better the organization.
('89', 400, 2, 27, 751448) Were I not challenged at the time that I was touring in the South, I would have been silent.
('89', 400, 2, 28, 751541) I must admit that I did not talk to those who were with me in that special train.
('89', 400, 2, 29, 751623) I was buried in my work which was divided between meetings at frequetnt stoppages and writing whilst the train was in motion.
('89', 400, 2, 30, 751749) And let the public know that those who are physically nearest to me have to be so forbearing that they would not come near me and interfere with my work.
('89', 400, 2, 31, 751903) Such has been the usage during my stormy life.
('89', 400, 2, 32, 751950) My own children thus get the least of me.

('89', 401, 1, 3, 752339) SEVAGRAM, February 15, 1946 Harijan, 24 2 1946
('89', 401, 2, 4, 752386) 524. HOW TO CANALIZE HATRED
('89', 401, 3, 5, 752414) Hatred is in the air, and impatient lovers of the country will gladly take advantage of it, if they can, through violence, to fur ther the cause of independence.
('89', 401, 3, 6, 752576) I suggest that it is wrong at any time and everywhere.
('89', 401, 3, 7, 752631) But it is more wrong and unbecoming in a country where fighters for freedom have declared to the world that their policy is truth and non violence.Hatred, they argue, cannot be turned into love.
('89', 401, 3, 8, 752826) Those who believe in violence will naturally use it by saying, ‘Kill your enemy, injure him and his pro perty wherever you can, whether openly or secretly as necessity requires.’ The result will be deeper hatred and counterhatred, and vengeance let lose on both sides.
('89', 401, 3, 9, 753095) The recent war, whose embers have yet hardly died, loudly proclaims the bankruptcy of this use of hatred.
('89', 401, 3, 10, 753201) And it remains to be seen whether they so called victors have really won or whether they have not depressed themselves in seeking and trying to depress their enemies.
('89', 401, 3, 11, 753368) It is a bad game at its best.
('89', 401, 3, 12, 753398) Some philosophers of action in this country improve upon the mode and say, ‘We shall never kill our enemy but we shall destroy his property’, for the remarkable thing is that the so called enemy has brought no property of his own and what little he has brought he makes us pay for.
('89', 401, 3, 13, 753680) Therefore what we destroy is really our own.
('89', 401, 3, 14, 753725) The bulk of it, whether in men or things, he produces here.
('89', 401, 3, 15, 753785) So what he really has is the custody of it.
('89', 401, 3, 16, 753829) For the destruction too we have to pay through the nose and it is the innocent who are made to pay.
('89', 401, 3, 17, 753929) That is the implication of punitive tax and all it carries with it.
('89', 401, 3, 18, 753997) Non violence in the sense of mere non killing does not appear to me, therefore, to be any improvement on the technique of violence.
('89', 401, 3, 19, 754129) It means slow torture and when slowness becomes ineffective we shall immediately revert to killing and to atom bomb, which is the last word in violence today.
('89', 401, 3, 20, 754288) Therefore I suggested in 1920 the use of non violence and its inevitable twin companion truth for canalizing hatred into the proper channel.
('89', 401, 3, 21, 754429) The hater hates not for the sake of hatred but because he
('89', 402, 0, 1, 754487) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 403
('89', 402, 1, 2, 754535) wants to drive away from his country the hated being or beings.
('89', 402, 1, 3, 754599) He will, therefore, as readily achieve his end by non violent means.
('89', 402, 1, 4, 754668) For the past twenty five years, willingly or unwil lingly, the Congress has spoken to the masses in favour of non violence as against violence for regaining our lost liberty.
('89', 402, 1, 5, 754843) We have also dis covered through our progress that in the application of non violence we have been able to reach the mass mind far more quickly and far more extensively than ever before.
('89', 402, 1, 6, 755030) And yet, if truth is told as it must be, our non violent action has been half hearted.
('89', 402, 1, 7, 755117) Many have preached non violence through the lips while harbouring violence in the breast.
('89', 402, 1, 8, 755207) But the unsophisticated mass mind has read the secret meaning hidden in our breasts, and the unconscious reaction has not been altogether as it might have been.
('89', 402, 1, 9, 755368) Hypocrisy has acted as an ode to virtue, but it could never take its place.
('89', 402, 1, 10, 755444) And so I plead for non violence.
('89', 402, 1, 11, 755477) and yet more non violence.
('89', 402, 1, 12, 755504) I do so not without knowledge but with sixty years experience behind me.
('89', 402, 1, 13, 755577) This is the critical moment, for the dumb masses are today starving.
('89', 402, 1, 14, 755646) There are many ways that will suggest themselves to the wise reader as to how to apply the canons of non violence to the present needs of the country.
('89', 402, 1, 15, 755797) The hypnotism of the Indian National Army has cast its spell upon us.
('89', 402, 1, 16, 755867) Netaji’s name is one to conjure with us.
('89', 402, 1, 17, 755908) His patriotism is second to none.
('89', 402, 1, 18, 755942) (I use the present tense intentionally).
('89', 402, 1, 19, 755983) His bravery shines through all his actions.
('89', 402, 1, 20, 756027) He aimed high but failed.
('89', 402, 1, 21, 756053) Who has not failed?
('89', 402, 1, 22, 756073) Ours is to aim high and to aim well.
('89', 402, 1, 23, 756110) It is given to everyone to command success.
('89', 402, 1, 24, 756154) My praise and admiration can go no further.

('89', 403, 3, 4, 757461) 525. PLEASE NOTE
('89', 403, 4, 5, 757478) I have taken up Harijan at such a critical moment in our country’s history that, having undertaken to write, I cannot wait in certain matters for publishing my thoughts till the next number of Harijan is out Then too it is published not at the place where I reside but away from me.
('89', 403, 4, 6, 757761) Thus exacting readers will forgive me, if they find things in the columns of Harijan which have already printed in the daily Press The reason for publication is obvious.
('89', 403, 4, 7, 757931) Harijan goes to many readers who do not read the papers in which my statements may be published and in which accurate publicity can never be guaranteed.
('89', 403, 4, 8, 758084) Harijan is not a commercial concern in any meaning of the experission.
('89', 403, 4, 9, 758155) It is published purely in the interest of the cause of India’s independence.
