('89', 406, 3, 6, 761596) 532. QUESTION BOX 2
('89', 406, 4, 7, 761616) Q. It is necessary to import as many foodstuffs as possible.
('89', 406, 4, 8, 761677) As it is, people do not get enough to eat.
('89', 406, 4, 9, 761720) Any further reduction in rations is fraught with risk.
('89', 406, 4, 10, 761775) It will mean further undernourishment, making the people an easy prey to disease.
('89', 406, 4, 11, 761857) It may even lead to food riots.
('89', 406, 4, 12, 761889) As for increasing production, it is most difficult, if not utterly impossible, at the present juncture.
('89', 406, 5, 13, 761993) A. I am aware that many people hold the views given above.
('89', 406, 5, 14, 762052) But the argument does not impress me.
('89', 406, 5, 15, 762090) People will find it unbearable to have their rations further reduced when they are already not getting enough to eat.
('89', 406, 5, 16, 762208) But, if we accept, as I do, that the Government figures are correct, foresight demands, and it is our duty, to swallow the bitter pill and ask the people to do like wise; that is, we should all eat less so that we can hold out till the next harvest.
('89', 406, 5, 17, 762458) Today, because of the corrupt administration, the masses do not get even their just dues under the rationing system.
('89', 406, 5, 18, 762575) It will be a great thing if this can be rectified so that everyone can get his or her share easily and truly.
('89', 406, 5, 19, 762685) If, however, we believe the Government figure to be wrong and continue the agitation for increased rations, and if the Government concedes that demand, a time will come before the next harvest is in when we shall be let without any food whatsover and the poor will have to die an untimely death.We should take every care to avoid such a calamity.
('89', 406, 5, 20, 763032) It will, therefore, be wisdom on our part to put up with a reduction in the present rations.
('89', 406, 5, 21, 763125) Then I do not think it is impossible to grow more foodstuffs, though I agree that it is difficult.
('89', 406, 5, 22, 763224) The difficulty is due to our lack of knowledge and the requisite skill If we are all optimistic and courageous and employ ourselves forthwith to produce whatever food we can by our individual effort, we shall probably be able before long to give the people a balanced diet and shorten the period of reduced rations.
('89', 406, 6, 23, 763540) 1 Vide also “About Rajaji” 2 Originally published in Gujarati, this appeared as “form Harijanbandhu”, 17 2 1946.
('89', 407, 0, 1, 763653) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 407, 1, 2, 763695) My optimism is irrepressible, but I admit that nothing will be possible without whole hearted co operation on the part of both the Government and the public.
('89', 407, 1, 3, 763853) Without it, even the imported foodstuffs may be squandered and maldistributed.
('89', 407, 1, 4, 763932) Besides we are not yet inde pendent.
('89', 407, 1, 5, 763969) Relying on outside help will make us still more dependent.
('89', 407, 1, 6, 764028) If, however, without relying on them, we do get imports of foodstuffs, we shall gratefully accept and make the best use of them.
('89', 407, 1, 7, 764157) While it is the duty of the Government to try to get food from outside, I do not think it is good for us to look either to them or to other countries.
('89', 407, 1, 8, 764308) What is more, disappointment from that direction will be positively harmful for the morale of our people in these hard times.
('89', 407, 1, 9, 764434) But, if the peo ple become united and determined to look to none save God for help and do not oppose such Governmental measures as they find useful, there will be no cause for disappointment.
('89', 407, 1, 10, 764626) Such action will enable the people to emerge stronger from the ordeal, and foreign countries will think of their duty to send us food of their own accord wherever they can spare it ‘God helps those who help themslves.’ How can others withhold help from the self reliant?
('89', 407, 1, 11, 764897) The British Government, during their hour of need, took away all that India had, and today we have to put up with the consequ ences of their action.
('89', 407, 1, 12, 765046) Need we then tell them and those whom they helped by depleting India’s resources that their duty today is towards India?
('89', 407, 2, 13, 765167) Q. India does not produce enough cotton.
('89', 407, 2, 14, 765208) This has to be imported from Africa and America.
('89', 407, 2, 15, 765257) Peasants are not allowed to grow cotton, the reason given being that they should grow more food.
('89', 407, 3, 16, 765354) A. This cannot apply to those who grow cotton for their own use.
('89', 407, 3, 17, 765419) It can only be applicable in the case of those who grow cotton as a money crop.
('89', 407, 3, 18, 765499) The Government has committed the crime of making cotton a commercial commodity.
('89', 407, 3, 19, 765579) This sin cannot be wiped out by importing cotton.
('89', 407, 3, 20, 765629) That can only aggravate the wrong.
('89', 407, 3, 21, 765664) The export of the cotton was made solely for the benefit of Lancashire.
('89', 407, 3, 22, 765736) It thus became a commerical commodity in an artificial manner.
('89', 407, 3, 23, 765799) I can understand the prohibition against growing large quantities of cotton during war in certain areas in the interests of food production.
('89', 407, 3, 24, 765940) To prohibit the growing of cotton altogether and depend on imports for our needs is no remedy for food scarcity.
('89', 407, 3, 25, 766053) Wherever possible people should grow cotton for their own use.
('89', 407, 3, 26, 766116) I might understand, and even tolerate, the policy of importing cotton for the use of Indian cloth mills.
('89', 407, 3, 27, 766221) But, if this policy prohibits the growing of cotton for the individual’s own use, it becomes wholly untenable and must, there 
('89', 408, 0, 1, 766348) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 409
('89', 408, 1, 2, 766396) fore, be strongly resisted.
('89', 408, 1, 3, 766424) This is a matter for the consideration of both the Government and the public.

('89', 408, 2, 5, 766549) 533. MEANING OF GOD 1
('89', 408, 3, 6, 766571) A correspondent writes :
('89', 408, 4, 7, 766596) I am reading your Gita Bodh these days and, trying to understand it, I am puzzled by what Lord Krishna says in the tenth discourse 2.
('89', 408, 5, 8, 766730) “In dicer’s play I am the conquering double eight.
('89', 408, 5, 9, 766781) Nothing, either good or evil, can take place in this world without my will.” Does God then permit evil?
('89', 408, 5, 10, 766885) If so, how can He punish the evil doer?
('89', 408, 5, 11, 766925) Has God created the world for this purpose?
('89', 408, 5, 12, 766969) Is it impossible then for mankind to live in peace?
('89', 408, 5, 13, 767021) To say that God permits evil in this world may not be pleasing to the ear.
('89', 408, 5, 14, 767096) But if He is held responsible for the good, it follows that He has to be responsible for the evil too.
('89', 408, 5, 15, 767199) Did not God permit Ravana to exhibit unparalleled strength?
('89', 408, 5, 16, 767259) Perhaps the root cause of the perplexity arises from a lack of the real understanding of what God is.
('89', 408, 5, 17, 767361) God is not a person.
('89', 408, 5, 18, 767382) He transcends description.
('89', 408, 5, 19, 767409) He is the Law maker, the Law and the Executor.
('89', 408, 5, 20, 767456) No human being can well arrogate these powers to himself.
('89', 408, 5, 21, 767514) If he did, he would be looked upon as an un adulterated dictator.
('89', 408, 5, 22, 767580) 3 This does not befit a man.
('89', 408, 5, 23, 767609) They become only Him whom we worship as God.
('89', 408, 5, 24, 767654) This is the reality, a clear under standing of which will answer the question raised by the corres pondent.
('89', 408, 5, 25, 767762) The question whether it is impossible for mankind ever to be at peace with one another does not arise from the verse quoted.
('89', 408, 5, 26, 767887) The world will live in peace only when the individuals composing it make up their minds to do so.
('89', 408, 5, 27, 767985) No one can deny the possibility nor say when that will come to pass.
('89', 408, 5, 28, 768054) Such questions are idle waste of time.
('89', 408, 5, 29, 768093) To a good man the whole world is good.
('89', 408, 5, 30, 768132) By following this golden rule the correspondent can live in peace under all circumstances,
('89', 408, 6, 31, 768223) 1 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “from HarijanBandhu” published simultaneouly with the source.
('89', 408, 6, 32, 768336) 2 Verse 36 3 In place of this sentence, Harijanbandhu has: “If he did, we see him as Emperor Nero (devil), as the Viceroy here, the Law maker, the Law and the Executor.”
('89', 409, 0, 1, 768506) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 409, 1, 2, 768548) believing that what is possible for him to be is also possible for others.
('89', 409, 1, 3, 768623) To believe the contrary connotes pride and arrogance.

('89', 414, 6, 15, 778241) February 17, 1946 We should try to draw all the children towards us.
('89', 414, 6, 16, 778310) We should admit that it is our fault if some do not come to us.
('89', 414, 6, 17, 778374) They should all want to come to us.
('89', 414, 6, 18, 778410) We should treat those children who come to us as our own children.
('89', 414, 6, 19, 778477) If their body and mind become sound and they acquire normal discipline, we should be satisfied that our purpose has been served.
('89', 414, 6, 20, 778606) I have taught many boys.
('89', 414, 6, 21, 778631) I never allowed them to indulge in mischief.
('89', 414, 6, 22, 778676) If they were under my care, I would educate them in such a way that they would learn from their very childhood that the desire to destroy was a very bad thing.
('89', 414, 6, 23, 778836) Whatever they do, they should create something, produce something.
('89', 414, 6, 24, 778903) There is an art in making anything and whatever they make should be artistic.
('89', 414, 6, 25, 778981) I do not believe that children are either good or bad from their very birth.
('89', 414, 6, 26, 779058) Some tendency is there, but we have to mould them.
('89', 414, 6, 27, 779109) This means that an infant starts learning right from the time of conception.
('89', 414, 6, 28, 779186) At that time I would teach the mother.
('89', 414, 6, 29, 779225) That would be a part of adult education.
('89', 414, 6, 30, 779266) The training of the infant begins from that stage.

('89', 417, 2, 5, 783531) We should not then be blind persons, one mistak ing the tail for the elephant, another the tusks, a third the trunk, for the noble animal—all wise in their own conceit, yet all wrong in essence.
('89', 417, 2, 6, 783726) Thus I in my conceit said 1 , and still say, that the opposition to Rajaji was, and is, confined to a clique.
('89', 417, 2, 7, 783836) An esteemed friend and others main tain that I have made a serious blunder 2 in calling the opposition by this name.
('89', 417, 2, 8, 783953) My appellation can not be, and was not meant to be applied to the Congress organization, whether provincial, central or any other, which, like the king, can do no wrong.
('89', 417, 2, 9, 784123) A clique generally does the wrong thing.
('89', 417, 2, 10, 784164) But surely both my critics and I are right, each other in our own way, and both are wrong.

('89', 417, 2, 14, 784551) I have no official authority.
('89', 417, 2, 15, 784581) The loss will be purely mine in that, for a wrong estimate, I shall have lost much or some of the moral weight I possess.

('89', 419, 3, 4, 788049) There is a time for laughing and shouting and a time for observing silence and being serious.

('89', 419, 3, 14, 789042) In the police and the army, physical drill and training in the use of arms regarded as an essential part of discipline.

('89', 421, 1, 2, 793018) Proceeding, Gandhiji diagnosed the present helplessness of the country to the double slavery—slavery under the foreign yoke and slavery to our own inertia and sloth.
('89', 421, 1, 3, 793184) As an instance of the latter he mentioned the fitful and inadequate response to the officer under the new khadi plan of the Bombay Kalbadevi Khadi Bhandar to provide instruments of, and instruction in, spinning and carding and the allied processes to all those who care.

('89', 421, 2, 14, 794916) He was afraid, they could not escape that charges today.
('89', 421, 2, 15, 794973) He reminded them of Capt.
('89', 421, 2, 16, 794999) Shah Nawaz’s declaration 2 that Netaji Bose had told them that on their return to India they would be expected to serve their country not by means of the sword but through non violence.
('89', 421, 2, 17, 795185) Granted that India produced sufficient arms and ammunition and men who knew the art of war, what part or lot will those who cannot bear arms have in the attainment of swaraj?
('89', 421, 2, 18, 795360) I want swaraj in the winning of which even women and children would contrubute an eqal share with physically the strongest.
('89', 421, 2, 19, 795484) That can be under ahimsa only.
('89', 421, 2, 20, 795515) I would, therefore, stand for ahimsa as the only means for obtaining India’s freedom even if I were alone.
('89', 421, 2, 21, 795622) Harijan, 3 3 1946
('89', 421, 3, 22, 795640) 1 On February 12, in his statement to the Associated Press of India 2 Vide “Advice to Indian National Army Men”, 22 1 1946
('89', 422, 0, 1, 795763) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 423
('89', 422, 1, 2, 795811) 544. PURSES FOR PUBLIC MEN 1
('89', 422, 2, 3, 795840) An interesting case of the use of purses presented to a public person has recently come under my obeservation.
('89', 422, 2, 4, 795951) I received many purses from the public.
('89', 422, 2, 5, 795991) Thus, during my recent tour, donations covering over two lakhs were given to me between Calcutta and Madura.
('89', 422, 2, 6, 796100) Some of them were anonymous, some earmaked, and some donors said, when asked, that I was to use the money in any manner I liked.
('89', 422, 2, 7, 796229) I have kept no property which I can call my own.
('89', 422, 2, 8, 796278) Am I entitled to use those donations or a part of them for personal needs?
('89', 422, 2, 9, 796353) During the whole of my career I have never made any such use and have always advised friends to do likewise.
('89', 422, 2, 10, 796462) I hold that there is no other course open to persons who enjoy public confidence and to whom the public give donations, fully believing that the money will be used more judiciously and carefully than by themselves for some public purpose.
('89', 422, 2, 11, 796701) It would be a terrible thing, if the trust reposed in one were abused for personal purposes.
('89', 422, 2, 12, 796794) Ruinous consequences of such use can be better imagined than described.
('89', 422, 2, 13, 796866) Public service must be, like Ceasar’s wife, above suspicion.
('89', 422, 2, 14, 796927) BOMBAY, February 19, 1946 Harijan, 24 2 1946
('89', 422, 3, 15, 796972) 545. A LETTER
('89', 422, 4, 16, 796986) BOMBAY, February 19, 1946 Your letter had been forwarded to me by Bhai Sadiq Ali.
('89', 422, 4, 17, 797068) I am sorry I could not send a reply sooner.
('89', 422, 4, 18, 797112) I do not consider what you write a justification for Pakistan.
('89', 422, 4, 19, 797175) The two nation theory does not impress me.
('89', 422, 4, 20, 797218) Economic inequality must go.
('89', 422, 4, 21, 797247) It is not a Hindu Muslim question; it is a question of hunger, affecting millions.
('89', 422, 4, 22, 797330) It is the same both for the Hindus and the Muslims.
('89', 422, 4, 23, 797382) It is the question of the workers and employers.
('89', 422, 4, 24, 797431) I am convinced that when this question is solved, the problem of high and low will also be solved.
('89', 422, 4, 25, 797530) Both parties will have to co operate in solving this problem.
('89', 422, 4, 26, 797592) Let us see what God wills.
('89', 422, 5, 27, 797619) M. K. GANDHI

('89', 425, 6, 9, 800884) 551. NOTE TO DR.
('89', 425, 6, 10, 800901) DINSHAW K. MEHTA
('89', 425, 7, 11, 800918) February 20, 1946 Here is my idea : At present do not admit any patient unless I send him or for whom I cannot arrange the expenses from the fund that is earmarked for the poor.
('89', 425, 7, 12, 801096) This way the poor, but not the destitute, will be accom modated.
('89', 425, 7, 13, 801161) 2. Examine any poor patient, whether male or female.Give him a bath, if necessary; also the syringe, if necessary.
('89', 425, 7, 14, 801276) Prescribe the diet in writing.
('89', 425, 7, 15, 801307) He should himself procure it.
('89', 425, 7, 16, 801337) If he asks for it, we may give it but he should pay for it.
('89', 425, 7, 17, 801397) They need not be made to lie down in a large tub; should be seated to have a hip bath and bathed with a shower.
('89', 425, 7, 18, 801509) There should be provinsion to clean all parts of the body.
('89', 425, 7, 19, 801568) [The patient] should be given nude sun bath.
('89', 425, 7, 20, 801613) He may put on a langoti 1. There should be separate arrangement for women but no separate arrangement for individual patients.
('89', 425, 7, 21, 801740) 3. Let him take as much clean drinking water as he can.
('89', 425, 7, 22, 801796) Those who cannot afford oranges, etc., should be given honey, lime and water.
('89', 425, 7, 23, 801874) 4. Only those for whom such treatment is enough should be attended to This includes indigestion, fever, smallpox, constipa 
('89', 425, 8, 24, 801998) 1 Cod piece or long strip of cloth to cover frontal nudity
('89', 426, 0, 1, 802057) VOL. 89: 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 427
('89', 426, 1, 2, 802105) tion, headache, eczema, eruption, measles, chicken pox, itch, dysentery and such other ailments common among the villagers.
('89', 426, 1, 3, 802229) For carrying on this work we should take on workers, in proportion to the number of patients, and train them.
('89', 426, 1, 4, 802339) We should take only those who are prepared to work at least for two years.
('89', 426, 1, 5, 802414) Generally such workers should stay at their own place.
('89', 426, 1, 6, 802469) Some of them should give a few hours’ free service while some should be paid a regular salary.
('89', 426, 1, 7, 802564) But all these things will settle down gradually.
('89', 426, 1, 8, 802613) As our needs grow, a way will suggest itself and we shall know how to implement it.
('89', 426, 1, 9, 802697) 5. We shall never use foreign medicines nor any organic drugs.
('89', 426, 1, 10, 802760) Medicines made from plant stalks and as simple as can be procured in the village may be used to some extent.
('89', 426, 1, 11, 802869) Castor oil may be used, if found necessary.
('89', 426, 1, 12, 802913) 6. We would need a large number of volunteers for this work.
('89', 426, 1, 13, 802974) None of them, however, should be highly paid.

('89', 426, 1, 15, 803121) 8. It is my firm belief that if the project works, we shall cer tainly get as much land and funds as we need.
('89', 426, 1, 16, 803231) 9. If you cannot appreciate this project but if you can have faith in it, you may go ahead with your work at Bombay until this is put on the rails.
('89', 426, 1, 17, 803379) Examine other places.
('89', 426, 1, 18, 803401) I am not inclined to invest in land or a building right now.
('89', 426, 1, 19, 803462) I wish to carry on with the existing means.
('89', 426, 1, 20, 803506) If you have the faith, you will of course, peep in now and then.
('89', 426, 1, 21, 803571) 10. You must keep your promise to those patients who pay.
('89', 426, 1, 22, 803629) It is for you to see how it can be done.
('89', 426, 1, 23, 803670) Whatever amount you get should belong to you.
('89', 426, 1, 24, 803716) These people may not stay on this site but I think they can stay anywhere in Poona.
('89', 426, 1, 25, 803800) If anything is left unanswered, please ask me.
('89', 426, 1, 26, 803847) I shall reply in writing.
('89', 426, 1, 27, 803873) Show this to Jehangirji.

('89', 426, 1, 29, 803938) You are not to accept defeat and certainly there is no question of despairing.

('89', 430, 4, 5, 808291) 558. LETTER TO G. E. B. ABELL
('89', 430, 5, 6, 808321) NATURE CURE CLINIC, 6, TODIWALA ROAD, POONA, February 21, 1946
('89', 430, 6, 7, 808384) DEAR MR. ABELL, Here are a few more suggestions to meet the food situation which have been sent to me by friends.
('89', 430, 6, 8, 808498) The Indian Army should be given this unique opportunity of doing constructive work.
('89', 430, 6, 9, 808582) They can be moved about easily.
('89', 430, 6, 10, 808614) They could, therefore, be sent to all such places where wells need to be dug most urgently.
('89', 430, 6, 11, 808706) Regarding additional foods, fish has been mentioned.
('89', 430, 6, 12, 808759) Fish abounds in the seas around the coasts of India.
('89', 430, 6, 13, 808812) The war is over; there are innumerable small and medium sized vessels which were used for doing patrol and guard duties along our shores for the last five years.
('89', 430, 6, 14, 808974) The Royal Indian Navy could arrange about staffing these with the Department of Fisheries giving all assistance.
('89', 430, 6, 15, 809087) If everything and any thing can be done during a war, why not a peace time war effort?
('89', 430, 6, 16, 809174) Dry fish does even now form part of the normal diet of a great num ber of people who are very poor—that is when it is available and they can afford to buy it.
('89', 430, 6, 17, 809333) All public gardens should immediately by law made to start growing vegetables.
('89', 430, 6, 18, 809412) Squads of army personnel should be put to work here too People requiring extra labour to transform their ground or garden should also be able to obtain free help through this channel.
('89', 430, 7, 19, 809596) 1 The report said that the message was given to an officer of the British Army in India whose service had been terminated.
('89', 430, 7, 20, 809719) He told Gandhiji that he would go back to England and propagate India’s cause for freedom as he knew how Indians were “exploited under the British rule”.
('89', 431, 0, 1, 809873) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 431, 1, 2, 809915) The distribution of food should be through co operative socie ties or similar organizations.
('89', 431, 1, 3, 810008) All food parcels to friends or relatives in Britain or elsewhere abroad should be stopped as also the export of groundnuts, oils, oil cakes, etc.
('89', 431, 1, 4, 810154) All stocks of foodstuffs in the hands of the military should be released forthwith and no distinction should be made between military and civil ranks.
('89', 431, 1, 5, 810305) In this connection I draw His Excellency’s attantion to the following A. P. I. message published in the Amrita Bazar Patrika of February 11, 1946.
('89', 431, 2, 6, 810452) It is learnt that huge quantities of composed atta are being destroyed for the last few days by throwing them into the river Shitalaksha at Narayanganj.
('89', 431, 2, 7, 810605) The campaign against despondency and for growing more food will avail nothing, unless bribery which is going on as never before is stopped and honesty and straight dealing begin to pervade the Gover nment ranks and the public.

('89', 432, 4, 6, 812234) 560. LETTER TO ANNIE MASCARENE
('89', 432, 5, 7, 812265) POONA February 21, 1946
('89', 432, 6, 8, 812289) ANNIE 1, A report of the speech you made at Bombay has appeared in the newspapers.
('89', 432, 6, 9, 812372) If it is correct, what you said is not right.
('89', 432, 6, 10, 812418) Even otherwise, I know that you have no control over your tongue and when you stand up to speak, you blab anything that comes to your mind.

('89', 434, 6, 13, 815650) 564. COERCIVE FAST
('89', 434, 7, 14, 815669) Telegrams and letters condemning my remarks 1 about Rajaji have been received.
('89', 434, 7, 15, 815748) Some of them say that all the praise bestowed on Rajaji is well deserved.
('89', 434, 7, 16, 815822) They admit his integrity, self sacrifice, great ability and administrative capacity.
('89', 434, 7, 17, 815907) But they hold his so called apos tasy in 1942 to be unforgivable and add that his scheming to be Premier of Madras is insufferable.
('89', 434, 7, 18, 816039) For me there is no offence or apos tasy in resigning from the Congress and maintaining one’s views.
('89', 434, 7, 19, 816139) If he is scheming to get the Premiership, it is undoubtedly worthy of condemnation and would be a sad discovery for me.
('89', 434, 7, 20, 816259) But my purpose in reverting to the subject is not for the sake of defending him.
('89', 434, 7, 21, 816340) My opinion carries no authority save moral which can be rejected at will.
('89', 434, 7, 22, 816414) What I want to reprehend the threat of fasting, or the fast itself, if I do not withdraw the epithet ‘clique’ in respect of those who are opposing him.
('89', 434, 7, 23, 816566) I have given my meaning of the word.
('89', 434, 7, 24, 816603) And I adhered to its use according to that meaning.
('89', 434, 7, 25, 816655) Nobody should be coerced into changing his belief.
('89', 434, 7, 26, 816706) There would be an end to all decency and reason, if such fasting became effective.
('89', 434, 7, 27, 816789) As the author of fasting as a weapon in satyagraha, I must state that I cannot give up an opinion honestly held even if the whole world fasts against me.
('89', 434, 8, 28, 816943) 1 Vide “Curious”, “About Rajaji”, “Interview to “The Hindu”, 16 2 1946 and the following item.
('89', 435, 0, 1, 817038) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 435, 1, 2, 817080) might as well give up my belief in God because a body of atheists fasted against such belief.
('89', 435, 1, 3, 817174) The rule of conduct stated by me is of universal applicability.
('89', 435, 1, 4, 817238) Incidentally I may mention that the fasts reported of prisoners in some U. P. jails and now of persons 1
('89', 435, 2, 5, 817343) aggrieved by the decision of the Parliamentary Board elsewhere fall under the same category though for different and sound reasons.
('89', 435, 2, 6, 817475) POONA, February 22, 1946
('89', 435, 3, 7, 817500) Harijan, 3 3 1946
('89', 435, 4, 8, 817518) 565. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('89', 435, 5, 9, 817546) POONA, February 22, 1946 Among messages and letters condemning my remarks about Rajaji are some from persons threatening to fast, if I do not withdraw the word ‘clique’.
('89', 435, 5, 10, 817716) As the author of fasting as a weapon in the armoury of statyagraha, I must reprehend such use of fasts.
('89', 435, 5, 11, 817820) No one should give up opinion honestly held even if the whole world were against him.
('89', 435, 5, 12, 817906) I, therefore, advise against such fasts.
('89', 435, 6, 13, 817947) Harijan, 3 3 1946

('89', 435, 8, 15, 818034) The first meeting of the trustees of All India Nature Cure Foundation was held on February 21, 1946, at 10.30 p.
('89', 435, 8, 16, 818147) 3 where Gandhiji stayed.
('89', 435, 8, 17, 818172) Gandhiji presided over the meeting.
('89', 435, 8, 18, 818208) Both the other trustees, Shri Jehangir Patel and Shri Dinshaw Mehta, were present.
('89', 435, 8, 19, 818291) I. Regarding the accounts, the following subjects were discussed at length : 1. The weekly expenditure during seven weeks.
('89', 435, 8, 20, 818414) 2. The details of income.
('89', 435, 8, 21, 818440) 3. Daily expenses incurred over the indoor and outdoor
('89', 435, 9, 22, 818495) 1 The reference is to Manchershaw Awari’s fast against the decision of Congress Parliamentary Board; vide footnote 1, “Telegram to Secretary, C. P. Provincial Congress Committee”, 20 2 1946 2 Vide also the preceding item.

('89', 436, 1, 2, 818793) patients.
('89', 436, 1, 3, 818803) 4. Expenses incurred on the boarding and lodging of the resident workers and servants.
('89', 436, 1, 4, 818890) 5. Expenses incurred on construction works and repairs, and also on gardening and the income from garden produce.
('89', 436, 1, 5, 819004) 6. Account of the bills pertaining to expenses of December 1945 or an earlier period paid in January, so that necessary adjustment can be made with the personal account of Dr. Dinshawji.
('89', 436, 1, 6, 819191) 7. The statement showing the outstanding amounts, if any, to be recovered from the patients or from any other source.
('89', 436, 1, 7, 819309) How this institution functioned till today, i.e., January 1, 1946, to February 21, 1946, was discussed in detail.
('89', 436, 1, 8, 819423) Gandhiji desired that the institution should function according to his views.
('89', 436, 1, 9, 819501) Elaborate discussion took place amongst the trustees as to how this institution should function in future.
('89', 436, 1, 10, 819608) Gandhiji expressed his views not only regarding the management but also how treatment should be given so that poor people could derive benefit.
('89', 436, 1, 11, 819752) Dr. Mehta stated that this method of treatment was only experimental and had very limited scope.
('89', 436, 1, 12, 819849) But even in its limied form, if it was made available to the people of India and if a Nature Cure University came into being, he was prepared to run the treatment according to Gandhiji’s views.
('89', 436, 1, 13, 820043) And during that period either its success would have been proved or Gandhiji would give up the idea.
('89', 436, 1, 14, 820144) According to Gandhiji, the creation of a Nature Cure University was the last mission of his life.
('89', 436, 1, 15, 820242) The meeting then adjourned to February 22, to meet at 2.15 p.

('89', 440, 1, 2, 824866) 572. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('89', 440, 2, 3, 824894) POONA, February 23, 1946 I have followed the events now happening in India with pain ful interest.
('89', 440, 2, 4, 824993) This mutiny 1 in the navy and what is following is not, in any sense of the term, non violent action.
('89', 440, 2, 5, 825095) Inasmuch as a single person is compelled to shout “Jai Hind” or any popular slogan, a nail is driven into the coffin of swaraj in terms of the dumb millions of India.
('89', 440, 2, 6, 825262) Destruction of churches and the like is not the way to swaraj as defined by the Congress.
('89', 440, 2, 7, 825352) Burning of tram cars and other property, insulting and injuring Europeans is not non violence of the Congress type, much less mine, if and in so far as it may be different from the Congress.
('89', 440, 2, 8, 825543) Let the known and unknown leaders of this thoughtless orgy of violence know what they are doing and then follow their bend.
('89', 440, 2, 9, 825667) Let it not be said that India of the Congress spoke to the world of winning swaraj through non violent action and belied her word in action and that too at the critical period in her life.
('89', 440, 2, 10, 825856) I have deliberately used the adjective“thoughtless”.
('89', 440, 2, 11, 825909) For, there is such a thing as thought ful violent action.
('89', 440, 2, 12, 825967) What I see happening now is not thoughtful.
('89', 440, 2, 13, 826011) If the Indian members of the Navy know and appreciate non violence, the way of non violent resistance can be dignified, manly and wholly effective, if it is corporate.
('89', 440, 2, 14, 826179) For the individual it always is.
('89', 440, 2, 15, 826212) Why should they continue to serve, if service is humiliating for them or India?
('89', 440, 2, 16, 826292) Action like this I have called non violent non co operation.
('89', 440, 2, 17, 826353) As it is, they are setting a bad and unbecoming example for India.
('89', 440, 2, 18, 826420) A combination between Hindus and Muslims and others for the purpose of violent action is unholy and will lead to and probably is a preparation for mutual violence—bad for India and the world.
('89', 440, 2, 19, 826612) The rulers have declared their intention to “quit” in favour of Indian rule.
('89', 440, 2, 20, 826689) Let the action be not delayed by a moment because of the exhibition of distressul unrest which has been lying hidden in the
('89', 440, 3, 21, 826813) 1 According to The Indian Annual Register, 1946, “The Indian Franchise”, 16 12 1895, the mutiny “against the quality of food supplied.
('89', 440, 3, 22, 826948) and ill treatment” was started “by the men of H. M. I. S. Talwar .
('89', 440, 3, 23, 827015) who secured the sympathy and support of nearly 20,000 men representing the entire Royal Indian Navy personel”.
('89', 440, 3, 24, 827126) On February 19, “strikers .
('89', 440, 3, 25, 827154) in the Bombay Harbour demonstrated widely and sometimes violently for two hours .
('89', 440, 3, 26, 827236) causing utter confusion and complete hold up of traffic .

('89', 443, 6, 12, 830111) 579. NOT LONELY
('89', 443, 7, 13, 830127) A friend 1 wrote to me the other day how lonely he felt in the midst of company.
('89', 443, 7, 14, 830208) This remark was prompted by my telling him that I distrusted the word of the official world.
('89', 443, 7, 15, 830301) He did not and had thought that I might share his trust.
('89', 443, 7, 16, 830358) Behold his disappointment when he found me wanting.
('89', 443, 7, 17, 830410) It may be that was not what he meant by his cryptic letter.
('89', 443, 7, 18, 830470) Anyway that was my interpretation and I replied 2 that as a man of God, he must never feel lonely.
('89', 443, 7, 19, 830569) For God was ever with him.
('89', 443, 8, 20, 830596) 1 The reference is to Sudhir Ghosh, who, in Gandhi’s Emissary, p.

('89', 443, 8, 25, 830988) He told me that I was not to be ‘thrilled’ by the attention that was being paid to me by men in high authority like the Viceroy.
('89', 443, 8, 26, 831117) This hurt, though there was no lack of fatherly love in what he said.

('89', 445, 2, 6, 834576) 580. NATURE CURE TREATMENT 1
('89', 445, 3, 7, 834605) Nature cure treatment means that treatment which befits man.
('89', 445, 3, 8, 834666) By ‘man’ is meant not merely man as animal but as a creature possessing, in addition to his body, both mind and soul.
('89', 445, 3, 9, 834784) For such a being, Ramanama is the truest nature cure treatment.
('89', 445, 3, 10, 834848) It is an unfailing remedy.
('89', 445, 3, 11, 834875) The expression ramban, or infallible cure, is derived from it.
('89', 445, 3, 12, 834938) Nature too indicates that for man it is the worthy remedy.
('89', 445, 3, 13, 834997) No matter what the ailment from which a man may be suffering, recitation of Ramanama from the heart is the sure cure.
('89', 445, 3, 14, 835115) God has many names.
('89', 445, 3, 15, 835135) Each person can choose the name that appeals most to him.
('89', 445, 3, 16, 835193) Iswar, Allah, Khuda, God mean the same.
('89', 445, 3, 17, 835233) But the recitation must not be parrot like, it must be born of faith of which endeavour will be some evidence.
('89', 445, 3, 18, 835344) What should the endeavour consist of?
('89', 445, 3, 19, 835382) Man should seek out and be content to confine the means of cure to the five elements of which the body is composed, i.
('89', 445, 3, 20, 835501) e., earth, water, akash, sun and air.
('89', 445, 3, 21, 835539) Of course Ramanama must be the invariable accompaniment.
('89', 445, 3, 22, 835596) If, in spite of this, death supervenes, we may not mind.
('89', 445, 3, 23, 835653) On the contrary, it should be welcomed.
('89', 445, 3, 24, 835693) Science has not so far discovered any recipe for making the body immortal.
('89', 445, 3, 25, 835768) Immorality is an attribute of the soul.
('89', 445, 3, 26, 835808) That is certainly imperishable but it is man’s duty to try to express its purity.
('89', 445, 3, 27, 835890) If we accept the above reasoning, it will automatically limit the means permissible under nature cure.
('89', 445, 3, 28, 835993) And man is thereby saved from all the paraphernalia of big hospitals and eminent doctors, etc.
('89', 445, 3, 29, 836088) The large majority of persons in the world can never afford these.
('89', 445, 3, 30, 836155) Why then should the few desire what the many cannot have?
('89', 445, 3, 31, 836213) POONA, February 24, 1946 Harijan, 3 3 1946
('89', 445, 4, 32, 836256) 1 Originally written in Hindi, this appeared under “Notes” as “from Harijan Sevak”, published simultaneously with the source.

('89', 449, 0, 1, 840930) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 449, 1, 2, 840972) APPENDICES
('89', 449, 2, 3, 840983) APPENDIX I
('89', 449, 3, 4, 840994) THE SAPRU COMMITTEE PROPOSALS 1
('89', 449, 4, 5, 841026) BOMBAY,
('89', 449, 5, 6, 841034) December 27, 1945
('89', 449, 6, 7, 841052) “The Committee stands for a single Union of India, including the whole of British India and all the Indian States, the claim for secession or non accession, by which individual Provinces or States can keep out of the Union is not accepted,” says the Sapru Committee in its final report on constitutional proposals.
('89', 449, 6, 8, 841367) This report, which was compiled by the Rt.
('89', 449, 6, 9, 841410) Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, the Rt.
('89', 449, 6, 10, 841441) Mr. M. R. Jayakar, the Hon.
('89', 449, 6, 11, 841469) Sir N. Gopalaswami Iyengar and Kunwar Sir Jagadish Prasad, was released to the Press on December 27, 1945.
('89', 449, 7, 12, 841576) Embodying this principle in its proposals, the Committee recommends that the constitution making body to be appointed after the elections should proceed on the basis of framing a constitution for a single State, and urges that the right of secession or non accession given to individual States or Provinces in the Cripps proposals should be withdrawn.
('89', 449, 8, 13, 841928) The Committee maintains that throughout it has endeavoured to make a cons tructive approach to the many knotty problems that confront the country, to investigate them from every angle, to appraise as dispassionately as they could every fact, circumstance or conceivable argument and to reach conclusions which in their estimation were calculated to promote the lasting interests of India and were likely to elicit the approbation of thinking Indians.
('89', 449, 9, 14, 842379) The report says : “It is the Committee’s firm conviction that the future of India lies in adopting a democratic constitution.
('89', 449, 9, 15, 842505) The ultimate sovereign in a demo cracy is the electorate, which chooses those who are to represent it in the Legislature and Executive.
('89', 449, 9, 16, 842641) Adult franchise is therefore recommended.
('89', 449, 9, 17, 842683) Under existing conditions, it is excusable to give religious communities the right to a fair and adequate share of opportunities for service in the Legislature and Executive, but the aspirants for these opportunities should realize that they hold them in trust for the nation as a whole and should for that reason seek the support of all communities.” JOINT GENERAL ELECTORATES
('89', 449, 10, 18, 843061) The Committee has recommended that separate communal electorates should disappear and should be replaced by joint general elctorates with reservations
('89', 449, 11, 19, 843212) 1Vide “Letter to M.R. Jayankar”, 12 1 1946
('89', 450, 0, 1, 843255) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 451
('89', 450, 1, 2, 843304) of seats.
('89', 450, 1, 3, 843314) In the opinion of the Committee, Parliamentary Government is not unsuited to India and can be worked even with communally composed Legislature and Exe cutive.
('89', 450, 1, 4, 843473) One of the cardinal features of the constitutional proposals made by the Committee is the provision of ample and effective safeguards for the minorities.
('89', 450, 2, 5, 843627) Emphasizing the importance of joint electorates, the Committee says : “No Government, which is not merely in power but accepts active responsibility for its decisions, can legitimately flinch from the task of righting a manifestly wrong decision (taken forty years ago, accepting separate electorate for Muslims), which has been so mischievous in its effects.
('89', 450, 2, 6, 843987) We hope the present Labour Government in Britain, with its high democratic ideals and the enormous voting strength behind it, will not lack the courage to get this decision reversed with the support of Parliament.
('89', 450, 2, 7, 844201) We have no doubt that such reversal would be to the lasting benefit of the Muslims themselves.” PARITY AT THE CENTRE
('89', 450, 3, 8, 844318) It is because the Committee attaches great importance to the abolition of separate electorates that it considers parity of representation in the Central Legislative Assembly between Muslims and Hindus, other than Scheduled Castes, not too great a price to pay.
('89', 450, 3, 9, 844579) Hindu objections to this proposal are strong, because it means on a population basis one Muslim will be regarded as equal to two Hindus, other than Scheduled Castes, also the fear that the British Government may accept the parity concession without implementing the important provision that joint electorates must be introduced, is not unfounded in the light of past history.
('89', 450, 3, 10, 844955) Each special concession has, in the past, been made the starting point for fresh demands.
('89', 450, 3, 11, 845045) But in the interests of communal harmony, which abolition of separate electorates will bring about, the Committee has ventured on this proposal, but it insists that in its recommendation on parity, the conditions and limitations it has laid down are equally important.
('89', 450, 3, 12, 845314) Parity, however, is confined to the Lower House of the Union Legislature and Union Executive, which are the final organs for determining all India policy; and it is important that such policy should have the substantial backing of the bulk of Hindus and Muslims.
('89', 450, 3, 13, 845577) The same considerations do not apply to the Provincial Legislatures or Executives, or to the Services, or to other fields of administration.
('89', 450, 4, 14, 845718) Joint electorates, with reservation of seats, are admittedly a far cry from democracy, but they are a necessary halfway house between separate electorates and general electorates without any limitation even as to candidature.
('89', 450, 4, 15, 845944) CONCESSION SHOULD NOT EXTEND TO THE SERVICES
('89', 450, 5, 16, 845989) The Committee considers that it will be unjust and improper to extend the concession of parity to the Services, civil or military.
('89', 450, 5, 17, 846120) Government Services, like any other service, must be based upon individual merit and fitness.
('89', 450, 5, 18, 846214) Neither does the
('89', 451, 0, 1, 846231) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 451, 1, 2, 846273) Committee think that the Muslims are educationally backward, as they were thirty or forty years back.
('89', 451, 1, 3, 846375) As regards other communities, the present proportions are consi dered fair, but they may be revised by future Governments, so as to provide adequate representation for backward communities.
('89', 451, 1, 4, 846565) The Committee also expresses the view that it will be dangerous to extend the principle of parity to the Defence Services.
('89', 451, 2, 5, 846688) Maintaining that the Muslims are not a separate nation, the Committee in the chapter on Pakistan or partition of India says that the separate nationhood of Mus lims cannot be established on grounds of race, language or culture.
('89', 451, 2, 6, 846916) If religion alone will have to be the basis of division, then many other communities can also claim separate nationhood.
('89', 451, 3, 7, 847037) Declaring that self determination is not an absolute right and can only be applied with due regard to circumstances, the Committee examines the practicabilities of Pakistan in the context of Indian conditions and in the light of Indian opinion.
('89', 451, 3, 8, 847282) It says : “The position is that the scheme of Pakistan put forward by Mr. Jinnah is not acceptable either to the Hinuds of the Punjab and Bengal or to the Sikhs or to the Congress or to the Hindu Mahasabha.
('89', 451, 3, 9, 847489) The C. R. Formula has been totally rejected by Mr. Jinnah and has been opposed by the Hindus and Sikhs of the Punjab and Hindus of Bengal.
('89', 451, 3, 10, 847628) PAKISTAN NOT A PRACTICABLE PROPOSITION
('89', 451, 4, 11, 847667) “It is thus clear that Pakistan, whether whole, according to Mr. Jinnah’s ideals, or truncated, according to the C. R. Formula, cannot be established without the consent of parties and will meet with the strongest opposition.
('89', 451, 4, 12, 847893) Arbitration has been ruled out and is out of place when the fate of the entire country is to be decided.
('89', 451, 4, 13, 847998) The only alternatives for enforcing Pakistan are either British enforcement of it or civil war.”
('89', 451, 5, 14, 848095) After considering the problems of Defence of the sub Continent and the position of minorities after division, the report states the Committee’s conclusion that Pakistan “solves no communal problems and only raises fresh ones : that on grounds of Defence, leaving apart other major considerations, the division of the country into two independent States will endanger the safety of both, and that there is no justification for the British Government to support such a revolutionary scheme if they have genuine faith in the unity of India which they themselves have built up and fostered.”
('89', 451, 6, 15, 848683) The report characterizes Prof.
('89', 451, 6, 16, 848714) Coupland’s regional scheme as “fantastic, unreal and academic.”
('89', 451, 7, 17, 848778) Rejecting all schemes of partition and division, the Committee concludes : “We are convinced that the partition of India would be an outrage justified neither by history nor by political expediency.
('89', 451, 7, 18, 848977) It is incompatible with the greatness, safety and economic development of the country and will lead either to constant internecine war
('89', 452, 0, 1, 849112) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 453
('89', 452, 1, 2, 849161) or perpetual foreign domination.
('89', 452, 1, 3, 849194) It multiplies and complicates the problem of minorities without solving it and threatens to plunge India back into the dark and dismal days of the 18th centruy.”
('89', 452, 2, 4, 849356) The Committee feels certain that political unity can be maintained and Hindus and Muslims can live together amicably as they have done for a thousand years.”
('89', 452, 3, 5, 849514) The report proceeds to consider the arrangements to be made by which India will remain united and at the same time, afford the communities sufficient scope for self development.
('89', 452, 3, 6, 849692) One of the Committee’s fundamental recommendations in this regard is the provision by which in the Union Assembly, excluding the seats given to special interests, Muslim representation from British India will be on a par with the representation given to Hindus excluding the Scheduled Castes.
('89', 452, 3, 7, 849985) The offer of parity is subject to the condition that joint electorates with reservation of seats are introduced throughout, i.
('89', 452, 3, 8, 850112) e., for all elective bodies in the country and the Committee adds that, should the Muslims not agree to this condition and insist on separate electorates, not only should the offer stand withdrawn, but the Hindus should be free to ask for a revision of the Communal Award.
('89', 452, 4, 9, 850385) PROVISION FOR ADULT FRANCHISE
('89', 452, 5, 10, 850415) Another important recommendation is the provision for adult franchise.
('89', 452, 5, 11, 850486) If political power is to be transferred to an Indian Democracy, so as to prevent its concentration in the hands of a few, the risk of enfranchising the entire adult population should be taken.
('89', 452, 5, 12, 850679) Political consciousness among the masses has awakened to a great extent and the last elections in 1937 were in themselves a great educative force.
('89', 452, 5, 13, 850826) The average man thinks more and more in terms of politics and, if his judgment is faulty, he is no better or no worse than the average voter in Europe, where franchise has been in existence for some time.
('89', 452, 6, 14, 851031) Before Pakistan came to occupy the field, Muslim opinion generally seemed to demand that the residuary powers should be lodged with the Provinces, in order that the latter might have the fullest freedom to legislate in matters which were not covered expressly by the provisions enumerating the distribution of powers.
('89', 452, 6, 15, 851349) Though the case for a strong Centre is strong, the Committee, as a matter of compromise and for the sake of peace and amity, recommended the vesting of the residuary powers in the Provinces, in accordance with the Muslim view.
('89', 452, 6, 16, 851576) Mr. P. R. Das and some other members disagree with this recommendation.
('89', 452, 7, 17, 851648) While the subjects allotted to the Centre are reduced to a minimum, it is provided that the Centre shall have powers to co ordinate legislation and adminis tration of different units when necessary as well as to ensure the maintenance of the political integrity and economic unity of India as a whole.
('89', 453, 0, 1, 851950) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 453, 1, 2, 851992) REPRESENTATION FOR COMMUNITIES
('89', 453, 2, 3, 852023) The Committee recommends that the constitution should provide for represen tation of different communities in the Central Executive on the basis of their strength in the Legislature.
('89', 453, 2, 4, 852206) The Cabinet will be a composite one only in the sense that communities will be represented on it, but in the interests of harmonious working “the Prime Minister’s choice of his colleagues is not to be fettered”.
('89', 453, 2, 5, 852418) The Committee looks forward to the choice of members to whatever community they may belong on the basis of their political affiliations.
('89', 453, 2, 6, 852555) The substitution of joint for separate electorate should, by compelling candidates to seek support from all communities, help the emergence of political parties each of which will contain members of different communities.
('89', 453, 2, 7, 852777) It is on these considerations that “composite” instead of “coalition” Governments have been envisaged.
('89', 453, 2, 8, 852880) It is also provided that there should be collective responsibility to the Legislature.
('89', 453, 2, 9, 852967) The Committee prefers the British model, namely that the Prime Minister should choose his colleagues though a suggestion had been made that the Swiss model, under which the Central Legislature in joint session by single transferable vote elects the Cabinet and the Ministers hold office for the duration of the life of the Legislature, was made.
('89', 453, 2, 10, 853313) INDIAN STATES AND FEDERATION
('89', 453, 3, 11, 853342) Dealing with the Indian States, the Committee says that provision should be made in the constitution for the accession from time to time of Indian States as units of a Federation on such terms as may be agreed upon but the establishment of the Indian Union should not be contingent on the accession to the Federation of any Indian State or of any minimum unmber of Indian States.
('89', 453, 3, 12, 853722) The Committee, therefore, contemplates that the Union need not be identical with Federation and it may include States which have not formally federated.
('89', 453, 4, 13, 853875) The Committee say: “Our recommendation is that the new constitution should continue at least the unity that now binds the States and British India, though the bond may not be federal.
('89', 453, 4, 14, 854059) Federation, we recognize, is a closer and a more intimate and efficient bond and we earnestly hope that in due course and after the fullest consultation and investigation, all th States—a few individually but the great majority organized in groups and sub federations—will have acceded as federated units of the Union.
('89', 453, 4, 15, 854378) The inherent difficulties of bringing about such a happy con summation and the experience of negotiations which Lord Linlithgow inaugu rated and conducted between 1936 and 1939 do not encourage the hope that these consultations and investigations can be successfully concluded, except with the exercise of infinite patience and after lapse of several years.
('89', 453, 4, 16, 854736) To hang up the Federal Union of such units as are willing to federate until some States, or a minimum number of States, or the last hesitant State has agreed to accede, would be a policy which is calculated to postpone indefinitely the elimination of foreign rule and the achieve ment of full self government.
('89', 453, 4, 17, 855046) The Committee, therefore, insists that the Union of
('89', 454, 0, 1, 855098) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 455
('89', 454, 1, 2, 855147) India should be established without any such waiting and that, while individual States might take their own time to make up their minds as to whether they would accede as federated units, all of them should, from the outset, be treated as in the Union, united with each other and with the rest of India through paramountcy at the Union Centre.”
('89', 454, 2, 3, 855492) As regards paramountcy, the report says, “British suzerainty, which is the mainspring of paramountcy jurisdiction today, will have to cease to exist and the new Union Centre, that is, the Federal Cabinet will come to exercise that jurisdiction over the unfederated States.” The Committee hopes that the Rulers of States will not object to this inevitable development.
('89', 454, 3, 4, 855860) The Committee is also of the view that the Crown Representative as a separate office should disappear and the paramountcy jurisdiction now exercised by him should be transferred to the Union Cabinet.
('89', 454, 3, 5, 856060) It is suggested that the Minister of the Union Cabinet should be in charge of the States affairs, assisted by a reformed Political Department.
('89', 454, 3, 6, 856203) The Minister should also have a body of Indian Advisers to help him in administering paramountcy jurisdiction over the unfederated States.
('89', 454, 3, 7, 856342) “HEAD OF STATE”
('89', 454, 4, 8, 856358) On the question of “Head of the State”, the Committee says : “All parties are agreed that the constitution should be based on Indian independence and, therefore, in law and in fact the indefeasible sovereignty of the people of India from whom alone all powers of legislation and administration should be derive, should be recognized.
('89', 454, 4, 9, 856692) No foreign power should be allowed to exercise any juris diction over the Indian Union and therefore the existing practice by which all residuary powers are exercised by the United Kingdom Parliament on the theory of “the indestructible sovereignty of the King in Parliament over the land through out the King’s dominions” will not be acceptable to any school of Indian political opinion.
('89', 454, 4, 10, 857081) The Head of the State under the new constitution should replace the present chief Executive with his dual role as Viceroy and Crown’s Represen tative.
('89', 454, 4, 11, 857232) He will have such powers as are given to him under the constitution as also such other powers as are now vested in his Majesty the King, including powers connected with the exercise of the functions of the Crown in relation to Indian States.
('89', 454, 4, 12, 857474) The Head of the State cannot act arbitrarily but only on the advice of the Ministry.
('89', 454, 4, 13, 857559) His term of office may be for five years and ordinarily one person may not hold if for more than one term.
('89', 454, 4, 14, 857666) MINORITY RIGHTS
('89', 454, 5, 15, 857682) Dealing with the rights of the Scheduled Castes and other minorities, the Committee has provided that these communities will in future be accorded by statute a place on the Executive and will share in the responsibilities of administration.
('89', 454, 5, 16, 857923) They will have adequate voice in framing the constitution with safeguards against hasty
('89', 455, 0, 1, 858011) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 455, 1, 2, 858053) changes.
('89', 455, 1, 3, 858062) They will have likewise the benefit of the fundamental rights with power to have more important ones enforced by the highest tribunal in the country.
('89', 455, 1, 4, 858212) The Minorities Commission will keep a jealous watch over their welfare and will obtain relief when they are injured.
('89', 455, 1, 5, 858329) The Committee hopes that with their rights ensured and protected, the minorities will not lose sight of their obligations to the sub sections which exist in their midst.
('89', 455, 2, 6, 858499) As regards the Scheduled Castes, the Committee recommends the continuation of the method of election prescribed in the Poona Pact.
('89', 455, 2, 7, 858630) INDIANIZATION OF ARMED FORCES
('89', 455, 3, 8, 858660) Dealing with the question of Indianization of armed forces the Committee says : “Under any system of real self government, these must be in the charge of a member of a responsible ministry.
('89', 455, 3, 9, 858850) The disciplinary head of the armed forces, the Commander in Chief, has to work under the orders of the Ministry and, on the Dominion analogy, the supreme command of the armed forces has to be vested in the Head of the State; Indian statute law will make provision for the government of the armed forces, the application of the British Army Act and any other enactment of a similar nature to the Indian Army being done away with.”
('89', 455, 4, 10, 859280) The Committee lays great stress on the creation and rapid development of a National Army.
('89', 455, 4, 11, 859370) SECESSION
('89', 455, 5, 12, 859380) Dealing with the question of secession, the Committee takes strong exception to the provision contained in the Cripps offer in regard to secession.
('89', 455, 5, 13, 859528) In the opinion of the Committee such a provision amounts to the recognition of revolt from and repudiates the constitution.
('89', 455, 5, 14, 859652) It is, in essence, an extraconstitutional act and common sense is against the constitution recognizing it as a legal right to be unilaterally exercised at the option of the unit.
('89', 455, 6, 15, 859831) In the opinion of the Committee, the constitution making body should proceed on the basis of framing the constitution for a single State as a safe guard for minorities, it is provided that no decision of the constitution making body will be valid unless it is supported by three fourths of the members present and voting.
('89', 455, 6, 16, 860153) Valid decisions of the Constituent Assembly must be binding on the British Government.
('89', 455, 6, 17, 860240) The Committee says that a stage has been reached when the British Government can no longer evade responsibility.
('89', 455, 6, 18, 860353) Therefore they should not allow things to drift and the situation to deteriorate.
('89', 455, 6, 19, 860435) INTERIM GOVERNMENT
('89', 455, 7, 20, 860454) In conclusion the Committee makes an earnest appeal to all communities and parties in the country to accept the principles underlying its recommendation.
('89', 455, 7, 21, 860608) In the event of there being no agreement, the Committee calls upon His Majesty’s
('89', 456, 0, 1, 860689) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 457
('89', 456, 1, 2, 860738) Government to set up an interim Government at the Centre and proceed to establish a suitable machinery for framing a new constitution, substantially on the principles enuciated by it and to have it put into operation at the earliest possible date by handing over all the power now vested in them to the authorities establised there under.
('89', 456, 2, 3, 861077) The Indian Annual Register, 1945, Vol. II, pp.
('89', 456, 3, 4, 861124) APPENDIX II
('89', 456, 4, 5, 861136) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON INDONESIA 1
('89', 456, 5, 6, 861189) The Working Committee have watched with admiration and sympathy the valiant struggle in defence of their newly won republic and independence which the people of Indonesia have been carrying on with steadfast courage and determination against British and Dutch forces.
('89', 456, 5, 7, 861457) This Commitee emphatically condemn the wanton invasion of Java and other parts of Indonesia in order to impose Dutch imperialist domination on their inhabitants against their unanimous demand for a free State.
('89', 456, 5, 8, 861667) Any support from any quarter to imperialist designs in Indonesia, Indo China and elsewhere is resented throughout Asia as culpable violation of the professed aims of the United Nations and the undeniable right of Asian nationals.
('89', 456, 5, 9, 861897) This will destroy the chance of international understanding and the very basis of any future world organization.
('89', 456, 5, 10, 862010) The Committee regret that the United States of America have by their passive attitude encouraged these imperialist aggressions.
('89', 456, 5, 11, 862138) While expressing their heartfelt sympathy with the Indonesia and Indo Chinese nationalists for the enormous loss and suffering inflicted upon them by the imperialist powers, this Committee are particularly distressed to find the units of the Indian army arrayed against the Indonesians and Indo Chinese and view with deep indignation this mischievous misuse of the Indian forces by the British Government.
('89', 456, 5, 12, 862544) This Committee note with resentment that the Government of India has not granted necessary facilities to enable Jawaharlal Nehru to proceed to Java in response to Dr. Soekarno’s invitation to which the present intolerable state of humiliating helplessness is due.

('89', 457, 0, 1, 862909) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 457, 1, 2, 862951) APPENDIX III
('89', 457, 2, 3, 862964) G. E. B. ABELL’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW WITH GANDHIJI 1
('89', 457, 3, 4, 863015) SEVAGRAM,
('89', 457, 4, 5, 863025) February 11, 1946
('89', 457, 5, 6, 863043) At 1 p.
('89', 457, 5, 7, 863051) exactly I was taken along to Mr. Gandhi and was given a chair beside him.
('89', 457, 5, 8, 863125) He sat on a mattress on the floor.
('89', 457, 5, 9, 863160) Mr. Pyarelal, Mr. Ghosh, Rajkumari Amrit Kaur and an anonymous young girl also sat on the floor.
('89', 457, 6, 10, 863257) It was Mr. Gandhi’s day of silence.
('89', 457, 6, 11, 863293) When I asked if I might speak first and deliver His Excellency’s message, he nodded assent.
('89', 457, 7, 12, 863385) I said, His Excellency hoped he had recovered from the fatigue of his Madras tour.
('89', 457, 7, 13, 863468) He wanted me to explain the grave food situation and ask for Mr. Gandhi’s help and co operation.
('89', 457, 7, 14, 863565) I had come without any high hopes as Mr. Ghosh had told me over the telephone that Mr. Gandhi’s attitude was thoroughly hostile—I said this in a joking way and Mr. Gandhi laughed heartily.
('89', 457, 7, 15, 863754) His Excellency had toured in the scarcity areas of Bombay, Mysore and Madras.
('89', 457, 7, 16, 863832) In these areas there were practically no crops.
('89', 457, 7, 17, 863880) Food had to be found for the people of these areas for 8 to 10 months; otherwise there would be a disaster.
('89', 457, 7, 18, 863988) There was a very heavy all India dificiency and the world food situation was such that in spite of our best efforts we might get very little in the way of extra imports.
('89', 457, 7, 19, 864158) Two different policies had been suggested.
('89', 457, 7, 20, 864201) The first was to maintain the present basic ration of 1 lb.
('89', 457, 7, 21, 864261) and rely on getting imports.
('89', 457, 7, 22, 864290) The other was to cut down the rations every where, impose equal sacrifices on all, and thus ensure that even if no extra imports were obtainable, the people in the villages of South India would not starve.
('89', 457, 7, 23, 864496) The Government of India were quite clear that the second was the right alternative.
('89', 457, 7, 24, 864580) Mr. Gandhi signified that he agreed.
('89', 457, 8, 25, 864617) I said that we had very slender reserves, and that hoarding was a grave danger.
('89', 457, 8, 26, 864697) If political parties used the opportunity of the ration cut to agitate against the Government and undermine confidence in the food administration, the result might be to make a large scale disaster inevitable.
('89', 457, 8, 27, 864907) We had no desire to shirk responsibility, but there was a clear humanitarian issue to which everyone must face up.
('89', 457, 9, 28, 865022) On the political side, the scarcity involved a grave risk to the success of the efforts that would be made shortly to form a National Government and to get ahead with deliberations on a new Constitution.
('89', 457, 9, 29, 865226) It would also be a very serious obstacle in the way of the new Ministries in the Provinces.
('89', 457, 9, 30, 865318) The present Government was pre pared to incur the odium of cutting the ration now in order that every available ounce of foodgrains should be saved for the scarcity areas, and a fair field given to the new Executive Council and the new Provincial Ministries.
('89', 457, 10, 31, 865577) 1Vide “Letter toLord Wavell”, 10 2 1946 & “Statement to the Press”, on or after 11 2 1946
('89', 458, 0, 1, 865667) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 459
('89', 458, 1, 2, 865716) Though the Government of India would have welcomed the nomination of a Congress representative on the delegation now going to London, His Excellency realized that Mr. Gandhi might find it difficult to help in this particular matter.
('89', 458, 1, 3, 865949) Mr. Gandhi nodded emphatically, and I did not pursue the point.
('89', 458, 2, 4, 866013) It had also been suggested that Mr. Gandhi’s support to an appeal for imports would be valuable.
('89', 458, 2, 5, 866110) I did not think His Excellency would press this either.
('89', 458, 2, 6, 866166) Again an emphatic nod from Mr. Gandhi.
('89', 458, 3, 7, 866205) His Excellency did, however, urge very strongly indeed that Mr. Gandhi should assist by not embarrassing the administration on the food issue—Party capital should not be made of it as the result of agitation would be panic, hoarding and the loss of many lives.
('89', 458, 3, 8, 866466) Mr. Gandhi’s influence would be invaluable and His Excellency hoped he would use it.
('89', 458, 4, 9, 866551) Mr. Gandhi was in a more friendly mood than I had expected.
('89', 458, 4, 10, 866611) He wrote down that he had written at 5 a.
('89', 458, 4, 11, 866653) that morning an article for the Harijan which met His Excellency’s requirements.
('89', 458, 4, 12, 866734) This he produced.
('89', 458, 4, 13, 866752) I read the article and said that though it contained some very useful advice to the public, the emphasis, which was on the futility of the administration, was wrong, I thought he could do better than that.
('89', 458, 5, 14, 866958) Mr. Gandhi wrote that the emphasis was a matter of opinion.
('89', 458, 5, 15, 867018) His article showed a way out, which was to put in a National Government at once.
('89', 458, 5, 16, 867099) I said His Excellency wanted such a Government as soon as possible but the President of the Congress himself had deprecated the formation of a new Executive Council until after the elections were over in the Provinces.
('89', 458, 5, 17, 867318) Mr. Gandhi said that he personally dis agreed with this.
('89', 458, 5, 18, 867375) An Executive Council could be formed in two days.
('89', 458, 5, 19, 867425) I said, I did not agree.
('89', 458, 5, 20, 867450) A serious attempt would have to be made to get the Muslim League into such a Government.
('89', 458, 5, 21, 867539) This would be very difficult and at the best take time.
('89', 458, 5, 22, 867595) If it were urged that the League should be by passed, at once I would say that this could not possibly be done during the elections.
('89', 458, 5, 23, 867728) Nor, at such a critical time, could we have two changes of Government in the space of two or three months.
('89', 458, 5, 24, 867835) (Mr. Gandhi made it clear he thought only of a short term Interim Government to give way to another Government in April or May.) Finally there was the obvious difficulty about the budget.
('89', 458, 5, 25, 868023) Mr. Gandhi seemed to be impressed with the practical difficulties and did not pursue the idea further.
('89', 458, 5, 26, 868126) Mr. Gandhi then said, it would be helpful, if I would give him in writing suggestions as to what he should do.
('89', 458, 5, 27, 868237) I said, if he wanted anything authorita tive, I would ask His Excellency to send him a letter on my return, but I emphasized that we were short of time and wanted a lead from him in the next few days.
('89', 458, 5, 28, 868438) He said it would help, if I wrote down my ideas “as a man”.
('89', 458, 5, 29, 868498) I wrote down a few suggestions in the following words and got Rajkumari Amrit Kaur to give me a copy before I left :
('89', 459, 0, 1, 868615) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 459, 1, 2, 868657) 1. Put about the idea that sacrifices are necessary by all, rich and poor, in order that the poor may live.
('89', 459, 2, 3, 868765) 2. Encourage thrift, especially by housewives.
('89', 459, 3, 4, 868812) 3. Discourage hoarding as a criminally wicked act.
('89', 459, 4, 5, 868863) 4. So far as possible give the lead to electioneering speakers either to speak helpfully on food or at least not to say anything that will tend to destroy confidence.
('89', 459, 5, 6, 869030) Other moves in the same direction will occur to you.
('89', 459, 5, 7, 869083) May not the shor tage be a blessing in disguise, if all parties and people work together both now and under a new government to mitigate the suffering of the poor?
('89', 459, 6, 8, 869247) Mr. Gandhi read this and indicated that he was fully prepared to help on these lines.
('89', 459, 6, 9, 869333) I asked him whether he would give a lead at once to Congress and electio neering politicians all over India.
('89', 459, 6, 10, 869442) He refused to commit himself firmly on this point, but sent a message after I had left him that he would consider making a Press statement.
('89', 459, 7, 11, 869582) Mr. Gandhi advised that His Excellency should send for Maulana Azad and say to him what I had said to Mr. Gandhi.
('89', 459, 8, 12, 869696) Before leaving I asked what I should say to the Press.
('89', 459, 8, 13, 869751) I told him that I had suggested that the Press should only be told today that I had gone to see Mr. Gandhi on His Excellency’s behalf to apprise him of the food situation in India as a whole.
('89', 459, 8, 14, 869943) He said, he would like us to say no more than that, unless we added that His Ex cellency had asked Mr. Gandhi to see him in Delhi but I had gone to Sevagram instead, because Mr. Gandhi, owing to his engagements, could not make the journey at once.
('89', 459, 8, 15, 870191) He wanted no mention made of fatigue of ill health and indeed he seemed very fit and spry.
('89', 459, 9, 16, 870282) The Transfer of Power.
('89', 459, 9, 17, 870305) 1942 47, Vol. VI, pp, 932 5
('89', 459, 10, 18, 870333) APPENDIX IV
('89', 459, 11, 19, 870345) LETTER FROM M. R. JAYAKAR 1
('89', 459, 12, 20, 870373) BOMBAY, February 8, 1946
('89', 459, 13, 21, 870398) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('89', 459, 14, 22, 870414) You will kindly excuse this letter, which is consequent on the eventful news in today’s Press that H.H. the Aga Khan is meeting you on the 20th at Poona.
('89', 459, 14, 23, 870568) This is an astute move, which he foreshadowed during his interview on reaching India a few days ago.
('89', 459, 14, 24, 870669) Why should he be bothering you with his attention instead of meeting Mr. Jinnah’s, it is not difficult to understand.
('89', 459, 14, 25, 870787) You have done your best to meet Mr.
('89', 459, 15, 26, 870823) 1 Vide “Letter to M.R. Jayankar”, 13 2 1946
('89', 460, 0, 1, 870867) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 461
('89', 460, 1, 2, 870916) Jinnah’s point of view by offering a division of India, though on the basis of a friendly transaction between two brothers.
('89', 460, 1, 3, 871040) Mr. Jinnah contemptuously spurned it wanting the division as between two separate nations.
('89', 460, 1, 4, 871131) With this background, the Aga Khan should be busy in meeting Mr. Jinnah and not you.
('89', 460, 1, 5, 871216) But he won’t do this because he knows that Mr. Jinnah will show him the door, if he tried to interfere.
('89', 460, 1, 6, 871320) So he turns in your direction.
('89', 460, 2, 7, 871351) As for the Aga Khan’s credentials to be an intermediary in such a vital cause, you will no doubt remember that he was the sponsor of the deputation to Lord Minto in 1906, asking for separate electorates—a deputation which the late Maulana Mohammed Ali described as a command performance.
('89', 460, 2, 8, 871639) Further if you were aware of the proceedings of that deputation and knew, as I do, the activities of the Aga Khan during the four years of the Round Table Conferences in London, you would have no difficulty in realizing that, under the cloak of an international diplomat, he is as vicious a communalist as any in India.
('89', 460, 2, 9, 871959) You will also recall what is now well known, though at one time a part of the secret history of that time, that, on the occurrence of a European crisis, the Aga Khan went to Turkey to carry on negotiations, but the Ata Turk Kamal Pasha, on becoming aware of his visit, summarily ordered him out of the country.
('89', 460, 3, 10, 872270) These are some of the Aga Khan’s antecedents which I have been able to recall.
('89', 460, 3, 11, 872349) So I am writing this letter, as I did during your talks with Mr. Jinnah, with the view of conveying a caution—perhaps unnecessary—about the subtle nature of this attempt.
('89', 460, 4, 12, 872520) As reported in this morning’s papers, the Aga Khan talks of a Pakis tan State as part of an ‘Indian and South Asiatic Confederation’.
('89', 460, 4, 13, 872654) The South Asiatic Confederation is not in his power to establish.
('89', 460, 4, 14, 872720) It may or may not come.
('89', 460, 4, 15, 872744) But, if you accede to his delusive scheme, the Pakistan in India will be established and the other ingredients of the scheme may evaporate into thin air.
('89', 460, 4, 16, 872898) His clever device is to sink Pakistan in an attractive scheme of an Asiatic Confederation, but a little search into the matter will reveal that it is an astute method for obtaining for the Muslim League its cherished object of a divided India.
('89', 460, 4, 17, 873142) I need not say anything more.
('89', 460, 4, 18, 873172) I am aware, as you said in one of your replies to me that you will not be wanting in caution, remembering that, anything which you think of conceding, it will be difficult for the country later to avoid.
('89', 460, 4, 19, 873376) Such is your great influence in the country.
('89', 460, 5, 20, 873421) Begging you to excuse once more, I am,
('89', 460, 6, 21, 873460) Yours sincerely, M. R. J. MAHATMA GANDHI SEVAGRAM WARDHA Gandhi Jayakar Papers.
