('89', 461, 1, 2, 873637) APPENDIX V
('89', 461, 2, 3, 873648) STATEMENT OF K. KAMARAJA AND T. PRAKASAM 1
('89', 461, 3, 4, 873691) KAMARAJA’S STATEMENT
('89', 461, 4, 5, 873712) After Gandhiji’s recent article, I feel that I can do nothing else than resign from the Parliamentary Board because all this conflict has come about only on account of the parliamentary programme.
('89', 461, 4, 6, 873909) Yesterday the Parliamentary Board met, as already arranged.
('89', 461, 4, 7, 873969) But meanwhile Gandhiji’s article appeared.
('89', 461, 4, 8, 874012) That needed serious attention.
('89', 461, 4, 9, 874043) So I adjourned the Board meeting, so that I may consider Gandhiji’s statement.
('89', 461, 4, 10, 874122) It came as a shock to me.
('89', 461, 5, 11, 874148) I am the official head of the Tamil Nadu Congress.
('89', 461, 5, 12, 874199) According to the Cons titution, I nominated the Working Committee.
('89', 461, 5, 13, 874266) Therefore Gandhiji’s reference can only be applicable to me.
('89', 461, 5, 14, 874327) I have paid my respects to Gandhiji in person, and have been in his calling distance in Madras and during his Tamil Nadu tour.
('89', 461, 5, 15, 874454) So have been many of the other members of our Working Committee.
('89', 461, 5, 16, 874519) It pains me much that Gandhiji did not talk to us anything about the Tamil Nadu Congress affairs while here.
('89', 461, 5, 17, 874628) His use of the word “clique” affects me deeply.
('89', 461, 6, 18, 874676) Neither I nor my colleagues believe in the parliamentary programme except as a means to further the country’s struggle for freedom.
('89', 461, 6, 19, 874808) I had made my position clear on dozens of platforms since my release.
('89', 461, 6, 20, 874878) At any rate I am no aspirer to any kind of office under the parliamentary activities.
('89', 461, 7, 21, 874964) As for the public agitation against Rajaji, it is only the reaction among Congressmen and the public to Rajaji’s action and his speeches since his Pakistan resolution and resignation from the Congress.
('89', 461, 7, 22, 875166) But, after Gandhiji’s recent article, I feel that I can do nothing else than resign from the Parliamentary Board, because all this conflict has come about only on account of the parliamentary programme.
('89', 461, 8, 23, 875369) My four colleagues, Messrs T. S. Avinashilingam, C. N. Muthuranga Mudaliar, O. P. Ramaswamy Reddiar and Mrs. Rukmani Lakshmipathy felt compelled to quit also.
('89', 461, 8, 24, 875528) I have persuaded them to remain for the very simple reason that the short time available for the election work ahead could not admit of such wholesale resignations.
('89', 461, 8, 25, 875693) I thank them for the spirit in which they have agreed to continue on the Board.
('89', 461, 8, 26, 875773) They would certainly have been within their rights, if they had followed my example.
('89', 461, 8, 27, 875858) But they and I do not want to disturb the election work.
('89', 461, 9, 28, 875915) For my part, I cannot but quit.
('89', 461, 9, 29, 875947) For 20 years Gandhiji has been the leader whom I have unswervingly followed and my faith in him continues unabated.
('89', 461, 9, 30, 876063) That I should occasion him pain drives me to take the action I have decided to take.
('89', 461, 9, 31, 876148) I assure
('89', 461, 10, 32, 876157) 1 Vide “About Rajaji”, 15 2 1946 & “Interview to The Hindu”, on or before 16 2 1946
('89', 462, 0, 1, 876241) VOL. 89 : 7 DECEMBER, 1945 24 FEBRUARY, 1946 463
('89', 462, 1, 2, 876290) everybody concerned that every decision taken by the Board here or at the centre will command my whole hearted acceptances.
('89', 462, 1, 3, 876414) PRAKASAM’S STATEMENT
('89', 462, 2, 4, 876435) February 13, 1946
('89', 462, 3, 5, 876453) Mahatma Gandhi, who had declared more than once that he had nothing to do with Parliamentary politics and that he was not interested in anyone particularly, was led into a serious error when he characterized the official Tamil Nadu Congress as a “clique”.
('89', 462, 4, 6, 876709) I feel strongly that Gandhiji should make amends in this matter, and I have every hope he will.
('89', 462, 5, 7, 876805) Shri Kamaraja Nadar did well in resigning the presidentship of the Tamil Nadu Provincial Parliamentary Board.
('89', 462, 5, 8, 876915) He fought well over a big constitutional issue until it became impossible for him to continue any further.
('89', 462, 6, 9, 877022) The Hindustan Times, 13 2 1946 and 14 2 1946
('89', 462, 7, 10, 877067) APPENDIX VI
('89', 462, 8, 11, 877079) LETTER FROM G. E. B. ABELL 1
('89', 462, 9, 12, 877108) THE VICEROY’S HOUSE, NEW DELHI,
('89', 462, 10, 13, 877140) February 26, 1946
('89', 462, 11, 14, 877158) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('89', 462, 12, 15, 877175) Thank you for your letter of the 21st February making suggestions to meet the food situation.
('89', 462, 12, 16, 877269) His Excellency, to whom I have shown your letter, is grateful to you for writing, and will have the various proposals examined where this has not been done already.
('89', 462, 13, 17, 877434) 2. Only a day or two ago His Excellency suggested to the Commander in Chief that it might be possible for the R. I. N. to assist with fishing.
('89', 462, 13, 18, 877577) Recent events may make this difficult, but meanwhile His Excellency has initiated enquiries about the possibility of importing dried fish from Canada and Newfoundland, and also about the securing of suitable vessels and equipment so as to make a start with developing on modern lines the fisheries industry.
('89', 462, 13, 19, 877885) Already the Army is doing a good deal in the Grow More Food campaign and is releasing machinery for digging wells, levelling ground, etc.
('89', 462, 14, 20, 878023) 3. In Delhi, a considerable part of the Central Vista is to be ploughed up and the gardens of bungalows are to be used for growing vegetables on a larger scale.
('89', 462, 14, 21, 878184) The sending of food parcels to friends or relatives outside India has been ordered to be stopped and an urgent examination is being undertaken of the question of exporting groundnuts, oil cakes, etc.
('89', 462, 15, 22, 878384) 1 Vide “Letter to G.E.B. Abell”, 21 2 1946 & 3 3 1946
('89', 463, 0, 1, 878438) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('89', 463, 1, 2, 878480) 4. Bribery and corruption is admitted to be one of the worst enemies of efficient food administration.
('89', 463, 1, 3, 878583) This is also one of the most difficult to defeat.
('89', 463, 1, 4, 878633) The detailed implementing of the controls is mainly in the hands of Provincial Governments, and perhaps the new Ministries may be able to achieve results in this direction.
('89', 463, 2, 5, 878806) Yours sincerely, G. E. B. ABELL M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.
('89', 463, 3, 6, 878857) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, p.
('89', 463, 4, 7, 878916) APPENDIX VII
('89', 463, 5, 8, 878929) LETTER FROM SUDHIR GHOSH1
('89', 463, 6, 9, 878955) During the conversation I had with you at Sevagram you talked about ‘distrus ting’ one’s friend.
('89', 463, 6, 10, 879052) I pondered over it after I left Sevagram.
('89', 463, 6, 11, 879094) It made me feel that I ought to say something about what I am trying to do and why.
('89', 463, 6, 12, 879178) It is difficult to talk about it.
('89', 463, 6, 13, 879212) But I enclose a letter which a young Englishwoman wrote to me when I left Cambridge.
('89', 463, 6, 14, 879297) I hope you will have a look at it in a spare moment.
('89', 463, 6, 15, 879350) She was a Quaker and a deeply religious person.
('89', 463, 6, 16, 879398) We worshipped together in the Friends’ Meet ing House during our three years at the University.
('89', 463, 6, 17, 879494) You know how young people get drawn towards each other and become fond of each other.
('89', 463, 6, 18, 879580) We were very fond of each other; but we succeeded in keeping this friendship free from any sentimental bonds.
('89', 463, 6, 19, 879690) She says in this letter : “You have not chosen to do anything easy and I fear that, humanly, you will often be lonely.
('89', 463, 6, 20, 879809) But you have a source of strength which will not fail you in the worst trials and desolation.
('89', 463, 6, 21, 879903) If my friendship can help, I shall be more than glad and shall send you my love as I do now.” She helped me to understand the good that is England, and Cambridge gave me the inspiration to work for peace betwen the British and the Indian peoples.
('89', 463, 6, 22, 880150) When I left Cambridge in the summer of 1940, she sent me a copy of the Oxford Book of Mystical Verses along with this letter.
('89', 463, 6, 23, 880276) I experienced when I left Sevagram this time something of the ‘loneliness’ which she talks about in the letter.
('89', 463, 6, 24, 880388) I know you will understand what I am trying to say.
('89', 463, 7, 25, 880440) Gandhi’s Emissary, p.
('89', 463, 8, 26, 880462) 1 Vide “Not Lonely”, 24 2 1946
